div2.p: At Athens there is a reawakened desire to conquer Sicily, but a lack of exact knowledge of the size and population of the island. Remarks on the magnitude of Sicily.

e)bou/lonto au)=qis...katastre/yasqai : the earlier unsuccessful expeditions from 427 B.C. (3. 86. 1), under Laches and Charoeades, until 424 B.C., under Pythodorus, Sophocles, and Eurymedon (3. 86, 88, 90, 99, 103, 115; 4. 1, 2, 24, 25, 46, 48, 65), are here comprised in th=s meta\ *la/xhtos kai\ *eu)rume/dontos(paraskeuh=s). That even before this the conquest of Sicily had been contemplated is clear not only from 3. 86. 18 pro/peiran poiou/menoi ei) sfi/si dunata\ ei)/h ta\ e)n th=| *sikeli/a| pra/gmata u(poxei/ria gene/sqai, but also from the charge against the last-named generals 4. 65. 13 w(s e)co\n au)toi=s ta\ e)n *sikeli/a| katastre/yasqai dw/rois peisqe/ntes a)poxwrh/seian.
mei/zoni th=s : = h)\ th=|, cf. 1. 85. 5; 3. 83. 7; see on 16. 1.— 3. a)/peiroi oi( polloi/: as appos. to *)aqhnai=oi restricting the whole to the designated part.

tou= plh/qous: alien element inserted in the closely connected words tw=n e)noikou/ntwn . . . barba/rwn, as freq. in Thuc.—kai\ o(/ti...a)nh|rou=nto : note change of const. from a)/peiroi with gen. to o(/ti clause.— ou) pollw=| tini: as in 7 below; not elsewhere in Thuc.; in Hdt. 1. 181. 2; 2. 48. 8, 67. 8. Elsewhere in Thuc. ou) pollw=| or ou) polu/ serves to limit the comp. (5. 59. 5; 7. 19. 8; freq. in the formula ou) polu\ u(/steron, u(/steron ou) pollw=|, see on 1. 45. 3). The modifying tis with ou) polu/s also 7. 1. 20.
a)nh|rou=nto: were about to take up. For the thought, cf. 7. 28. 23.

*sikeli/as ga\r peri/plous me\n kte(.: amplification of the two first points designated above as unknown to most
Athenians of that time, the rest of this chapter discussing the size of Sicily, 2-5 the barbarian and Hellenic inhabitants of the island. To peri/plous me/n corresponds w)|ki/sqh de/ 2. 1.

ou)k e)/lasson : in statements of time or space freq. adv. Cf. 25. 7, 67. 16, 95. 5.— o)ktw\ h(merw=n: acc. to Strabo, p. 266 c, the circumnavigation required five days and nights. To-day a steamer would require at most 60 hours to sail round. See Holm, Gesch. Siziliens I, 330 f., where all the statements of ancient writers are found.—kai\ tosau/th ou)=sa...ei)=nai : the narrowness of the strait geographically contrasted with the extent of the island. Thuc. can hardly have meant to intimate, as Stein thinks, that Sicily as almost belonging to the mainland was esp. difficult to conquer.—e)n ei)/kosi stadi/wn ma/lista me/trw|...diei/rgetai : in Greek the stretch of sea is conceived as the point wherein a hindrance consists. Cf. e)n with kwlu/esqai 2. 8. 17, 64. 10; 4. 14. 13. With diei/rgein, an emphasized ei)/rgein, cf. diakwlu/ein.

to\ mh\ h)/peiros ei)=nai : so nearly all recent editors for ou)=sa of the Mss. The impossible ptc. seems to be due to dittography from ou)=sa in 8. For the const., cf. 3. 1. 7; GMT. 811; Kühner-Gerth 479, 1, and 514, N. 9, 1. The inf. without to/, 1. 62. 17; 3. 6. 7. See App.

div2.head: On the settlements of barbarians and Hellenes in Sicily (2-5)
div2.p: Non-Hellenic settlements.

w)|ki/sqh de\ kte(.: see on 1. 7. oi)ki/zein used here, contrary to Thuc.'s usual habit, universally and not simply of Hellenes. See on 7. For the sources used by Thuc. for the matter of 2-5, see App. —w(=de: for the reading, see App.— 2. e)/sxe: acquired. Cl. thought that, acc. to the usage of Thuc. (see on e)/sxon 1. 12. 11), not *sikeli/a but tosa/de e)/qnh must be subj. of e)/sxe, and au)th/n the obj. understood. But, apart from the harshness of this const., there would be an analogy with 1. 12. 11 and similar passages only if the different e)/qnh mentioned in what follows had all occupied the whole of Sicily, which was not the case. On the other hand *sikeli/a e)/sxe tosa/de e)/qnh differs really only in tense from 2. 68. 10 h( po/lis au(/th . . . tou\s dunatwta/tous ei)=xen oi)kh/toras, and St. very aptly compares Soph. Phil. 1147 e)/qnh qhrw=n ou(\s o(/d) e)/xei xw=ros.

ta\ cu/mpanta : all together. Cf. 1. 4 tw=n e)noikou/ntwn kai\ *(ellh/nwn kai\ barba/rwn, 6. 1. tosau=ta e)/qnh *(ellh/nwn kai\ barba/rwn *sikeli/an w)/|kei. For the expression, cf. 2. 78. 14; 3. 92. 3; 7. 87. 17.

palaio/tatoi: in 1. 4. 1, 13. 13, we have the shorter form palai/tatos; see St., Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 56.—le/gontai: of mythical or poetical tradition, as 2. 102. 27, 34; 3. 96. 2; 4. 24. 18.—
4. oi)kh=sai: settled. Cf. w)|kh/samen 2. 64. 20.

a)rkei/tw kte(.: as authentic information is not to be had, one must be content either with the account of the poets (here esp. Homer, as also 1. 10. 4, 11. 19, 21. 3), or with one's own judgment about these peoples (w(s e(/kastos gignw/skei, cf. 2. 48. 10).

poihtai=s: dat. of agent with pass. See on 1. 125. 6; 3. 64. 15; and Steup, Thuk. Stud. II, 55 f.; C. F. Smith, Trans. Amer. Phil. Assoc. XXV, 71.—peri\ au)tw=n: Cl. renders “about these matters,” referring to 1. 1. 10; but the following met' au)tou/s points to a personal sense.

*sikanoi/: see Holm I, 58 ff., 350 ff., and Busolt, Gr. Gesch.^{2} I, 378 f.—fai/nontai: presumably of written testimony rather than, as le/gontai, of mythical or poetical tradition. Cf. 1. 9. 22, 13. 9. Still more definitely the following w(s h( a)lh/qeia eu(ri/sketai (this word of historical inquiry; see on 1. 1. 11) points to a credible source.—e)noikisa/menoi: which Dion. H. 1. 22 seems also to have used of the same occurrence; to be preferred to e)noikhsa/menoi of most Mss., whose authority in such cases is questionable. Only from oi)ki/zein, not from oi)kei=n, are found mid. aor. forms in compounds: a)noiki/sasqai 1. 58. 13, katoiki/sasqai 2. 102. 31. See App.
kai\ pro/teroi: even before, sc. tw=n *kuklw/pwn kai\ *laistrugo/nwn.

*)/ibhres o)/ntes : before these words Kr. missed, and Stein has inserted, u(/steroi, which is clearly what Thuc. meant; but u(/steroi would only repeat what is already contained in met' au)tou\s prw=toi. As to the credibility of Thuc.'s view of the origin of the Sicanians, see esp. Holm I, 58 f., 356 f., and Freeman, Hist. of Sicily I, 474 ff. —tou= *sikanou= potamou= tou= e)n *)ibhri/a|: the river generally called later Sucro (now Xucar) seems to be meant, not the tributary of the Iberus, Sicoris (now Segre), nor the Seine (*shkoa/nas, Sequana). See K. Müllenhoff, Deutsche Altertumskunde I, 164 f.— 11. *trinakri/a: Hom. *qrinaki/h, of uncertain derivation. See Holm I, 329.— 12. ta\ pro\s e(spe/ran: adv. Cf. to\ pro\s bore/an, 99. 1. For the matter, cf. l. 27 pro\s ta\ meshmbrina\ kai\ e(spe/ria and see Holm I, 59 ff. and 357 ff.
th\n *sikeli/an: see Weidner, Parerga Dinarch. et Thuc. p. 20 (in Gießener Gymn. Progr. 1875), who considers this, as well as pro\s th\n *sikeli/an (14), interpolated.

a(liskome/nou: with force of pf., as
in 1. 23. 8. GMT. 27.
pro\s th\n *sikeli/an: cf. similar consts. 5. 2. 11, 65. 12; 7. 80. 19.

o(/moroi toi=s *sikanoi=s oi)kh/santes: on account of the statement below (16) proscunw/|khsan kte(., Steup thinks some words have fallen out here, perhaps kai\ au)tw=n tisi cunoikh/santes. He holds that with the traditional text cu/mpantes can mean only the whole of the Trojans who came to Sicily. Better St., who says that more probably the Trojans and Sicani united are meant.—*)/elumoi: for their origin, see Holm I, 86 ff. and 374 f.; Freeman I, 195 ff. and 542 ff.; Busolt^{2} I, 375 ff.

e)klh/qhsan: (aor.) received the name. Cf. 4. 29; 1. 3. 20.—*)/egesta: the form used everywhere by Thuc.; also the people *)egestai=oi, as in Hdt. 5. 46. 5, 47. 8; 7. 158. 8. In later writers the form *ai)/gesta also occurs. Inscriptions of the oldest coins of the city have *seg- (or *sag-), the form later adopted by the Romans. See Holm I, 90, 375; III, 598f.—proscunw/|khsan: the compound only here.

*fwke/wn tine/s: Pausanias (5. 25. 6) also mentions Hellenes tou= *fwkikou= ge/nous in Sicily. Holm (I, 87) and others have suggested that the Hellenic immigrants here mentioned were really Phocaeans, and that the mention of Phocians is due to the Phocaeans calling themselves descendants of the Phocians (Paus. 7. 3. 10; cf. Hdt. 1. 146). Scholars have even tried to find in the inscriptions of the coins of Egesta the dialect of Phocaea (but cf. Holm III, 599 f.). The immigration of Phocians seems to have been introduced here in a chapter treating otherwise exclusively of barbarian immigrations (cf. the concluding words, l. 39) and not where Hellenic settlements are mentioned, because the Phocians were not able to Hellenize the barbarians with whom they coalesced as second or third component. The fact that the mention of the Phocians occurs after the name of the whole people and the two chief places indicates that this is a side remark. To the otherwise improbable conjecture of W. Ridgeway (Class. Rev. H, 180 (1888)), *frugw=n for *fwke/wn, is opposed the fact that from the whole context it is clear that only Hellenes returning from Troy are in mind.— to/te: of a time assumed as known, as 1. 101. 8. For the matter, cf. 4. 120. § 1.

*sikeloi/: see Holm I, 62 ff. and 360 ff.; Busolt^{2} I, 380 ff.; Freeman I, 124 ff. and 472 ff.—e)c *)itali/as: the term is used by Thuc. only of the peninsula south of the river Laus and Metapontum. Cf. 1. 12. 14; 7. 33. 21.

feu/gontes *)/opikas: cf. Dion. H. 1. 22 biasqe/ntes u(po\ oi)nw/trwn kai\ *)opikw=n. The reading of Vat. and other good Mss. *)/opikas is hardly due to a slip of copyists, even though acc. to all later writers the form should be *)opikou/s.

w(s ei)ko\s kai\ le/getai : referring to d<*>/bhsan e)pi\ sxediw=n. This for mula w(s le/getai always stands within or after the words it qualifies. Cf. 1. 24. 10, 118. 21; 3. 79. 10; 7. 86. 17; 8. 50. 16.

thrh/santes: after waiting for.—to\n porqmo/n: i.e. the favorable time for the passage. Cf. Soph. Trach. 571.—katio/ntos tou= a)ne/mou: i.e. when the wind blew seaward (different from 2. 25. 19). Cf. Dion. H. 1. 22 kataskeuasa/menoi sxedi/as e)pi\ tw=| porqmw=| kai\ fula/cantes katio/nta to\n r(ou=n.

ta/xa a)\n de/ : sc. die/bhsan. Order as in 10. 13. For pot. indic. with a)/n expressing past possibility, see GMT. 244; KühnerGerth 392, 4.—ei)si\ de\...e)pwnoma/sqh : two circumstances supplementarily mentioned in confirmation of the Italic origin of the Sicels.
a)po\ *)italou=, basile/ws tino\s *sikelw=n: cf. Dion. H. 1. 35 *)itali/a w)noma/sqh e)p' a)ndro\s duna/stou o)/noma *)italou=, who acc. to Antiochus had made himself master of Southern Italy.
ou(/tws: emphasizes summarily the reason just given in a)po\ *)italou= . . . e)/xontos. See on 1. 22. 7.
strato\s polu/s: appos. in explanation of the general subject. Cf. 2. 47. 5; 4. 58. 4.
a)ne/steilan: forced back, Bk.'s emendation (for a)pe/steilan of the Mss.), now generally adopted (cf. 70. 14; 3. 98. 3), except by Steup, who compares a)poste/llein 3. 89. 20.
pro\s ta\ meshmbrina\ kai\ e(spe/ria au)th=s : only the west of Sicily is mentioned above (12) as still occupied by the Sicanians.— 28. e)poi/hsan: caused, with acc. and inf., as 2. 5. 6.
e)pei/: after, like e)peidh/. Cf. 2. 73. 10 a)f) ou)= cu/mmaxoi e)geno/meqa.
e)/th e)ggu\s triako/sia : belongs to the complexive aor. w)/|khsan. For e)ggu/s and e)ggu/tata (cf. 4. 19; 5. 8. 10), see App. on 2-5.

pri\n *(/ellhnas e)s *sikeli/an e)lqei=n: i.e., acc. to 3. 2, before the founding of Naxos, which
occurred a year before that of Syracuse.
bore/an: for the Mss. reading borra=n, see App. on 2-5.

*foi/nikes: their settlements in Sicily, as on all coasts of the Mediterranean (see Curtius, Peloponnesos II, 10), are well characterized here peri\ pa=san . . . nhsi/dia. Of these a)/krai Pachynos (from pachun, lookout) and Lilybaeum (opposite Libya) kept their Phoenician names throughout all antiquity. For detailed investigations concerning individual settlements, see Movers, Die Phönizier II, 309-362. Cf. Holm I, 79 ff. and 370 ff.; III, 747 f. The correctness of the statement that the Phoenicians came to Sicily before the Hellenes is doubted by Beloch, Rh. Mus. XLIX, 117 ff.—peri\ pa=san me\n th\n *sikeli/an: in consideration of the antithesis below (34) e)peidh\ de\ . . . e)pese/pleon, Steup suggests the loss of some temporal modifier, like pri/n, pa/lai, pote/, or e)pi\ polu/, after pa=san me/n.
a)polabo/ntes : i.e. from the rest of Sicily. Cf. 1. 7. 4; 4. 45. 7; 7. 60. 9.
e)/neka: for the Mss. e(/neken, see App. on 2-5.

e)pese/pleon: sailed in afterwards, i.e. after the Phoenicians. Cf. e)pikata/getai 3. 49. 18. As kata\ qa/lassan adds nothing to the force of the verb, Steup suspects that a ptc. like metanista/menoi has dropped out after polloi/. St., who explains e)pi- as insuper, ad veteres incolas, thinks the addition of kata\ qa/lassan was due to contrast with the crossing of the strait by the Sicels, described in § 4.—*motu/hn kai\ *solo/enta kai\ *pa/normon: Motye (prob. spinnery) on the little island S. Pantaleo near the promontory of Lilybaeum. Soloeis (Phoen. name Kafara, village) east of Palermo, now Solanto; for us a “little Pompeii” on account of the important remains from the time of the Roman Empire unearthed there. See Holm III, 250 ff. *solo/enta uncontracted, like *malo/eis 3. 3. 13, 25. Panormus, now Palermo (Phoen. name unknown). The city names include also the territory belonging thereto.

cunoikh/santes: i.e. after they had restricted themselves to narrower bounds (no longer peri\ pa=san th\n *sikeli/an). The compound, used in 63. 14; 2. 68. 15 of the joining of new settlers with older, designates here the union of scattered communities. cunoiki/santes, the reading of some good Mss., is inadmissible, since here it is not a matter of the new settlement of the three places (see on 5. 3).

e)ne/monto: for the idiom ne/mesqai po/lin, cf. 1. 84. 4; 2. 30. 4; 4. 52. 11, 56. 13.—pi/sunoi: poetical word, found in Attic prose
only in Thuc. (2. 89. 21; 5. 14. 19), though freq. in Hdt. It is common in the poets. See C. F. Smith, Traces of Epic Usage in Thuc. (Trans. Amer. Phil. Assoc. XXXI, 80).

e)la/xiston plou=n a)pe/xei: cf. 49. 20, 97. 4.— 39. ba/rbaroi tosoi/de: partial resumption of tosa/de e)/qnh ta\ cu/mpanta above (1). Cf. 6. 2; 7. 57. 63, 58. 25, where also toso/s de looks backward. For like use of ta/de, cf. 1. 41. 1, 43. 9, and toia/de 7. 78. 1.
kai\ ou(/tws w)/|khsan : and thus they fixed their settlements in Sicily.

-5. Hellenic settlements in Sicily. —The summary here given from 3-5 of the Hellenic colonies in Sicily, in the order of the date of settlement, follows Holm (I, 118 ff., 381 ff., 390 f., 393); see per contra Busolt, Rh. Mus. XL, 466 ff.
Syracuse (3. § 2) Ol. 11, 3; 734 B.C.
Zancle-Messene (4. §§ 5, 6) Ol. 12, 3; 730 B.C.
Leontini and Catana (3. § 3) Ol. 12, 4; 729 B.C.
Casmenae (5. § 2) Ol. 34, 1; 644 B.C.
Camarina (5. § 3) Ol. 45, 2; 599 B.C.

prw=toi: after the part. gen. to be preferred to the adv. prw=ton of most good Mss. See App. on 3. 101. 6. —*xalkidh=s: on the relation of Euboean Chalcis to Hellenic colonization, see Curtius, Gr. Gesch.^{6} I, 417 ff., 425 ff.

*qoukle/ous: from Athens, acc. to Ephorus (apud Strab. 6. 2. 2).—*na/con: at the best point for first landing from Greece, near Tauromenium (Taormina).—*)arxhge/tou: epithet of Apollo (esp. the Delphian Apollo), as protector of new settlements, occurring also in Pindar (P. 5. 66). His statue in Sicilian Naxos is mentioned by Appian (Bell. Civ. 5. 109).

o(/stis: referring to a concrete noun only here in Thuc. See App. on 2-5.—nu=n e)/cw th=s po/lews: which had, then, earlier a wider compass. The destruction of the city in 403 B.C. (see Holm II, 105) was evidently not yet known to Thuc.
qewroi/: delegates to festivals or to oracles. Cf. 5. 16. 24.

*sura/kousai: form adopted by most editors. The Mss. vary, Vat. having generally *surakou=sai, and *surakou/ssioi for the people. See Buttmann, Ausf. Sprachl. § 21, N. 9.—e)xome/nou: = e)pigignome/nou, in Thuc. only here; elsewhere local (2. 96. 22; 5. 67. 15; 8. 90. 31), or in the sense of keeping (1. 22. 7).—*)arxi/as tw=n *(hrakleidw=n e)k *kori/nqou: cf. 1. 24. 4 *fali/os, *kori/nqios
ge/nos, tw=n a)f' *(hrakle/ous. Both, designated by Thuc. merely as Heraclidae, prob. belonged to the ruling clan of Bacchiads. Plutarch, Narrat. Amat. 2, relating the occasion for the founding of Syracuse, says it was ordered by the oracle in atonement for crime. The mythical character of the story is evident in that acc. to it Ortygia and Syracusa were daughters of Archias.
e)k th=s nh/sou: named Ortygia, and later connected with the mainland, first by a mole (ou)ke/ti perikluzome/nh|, with Bk. for perikluzome/nh), later by a bridge. See Strabo 1. 3. 18.

kai\ h( e)/cw...e)ge/neto : also the outer city, being joined on by a wall, became populous. There is no need, with Kr. and Bm., to make the whole city subj. of e)ge/neto, and kai\ h( e)/cw prosteixisqei=sa a sort of part. appos.—h( e)/cw: the special name for the mainland part of Syracuse was Achradina or “place of the wild pear-tree” (from a)xra/s). See Holm I, 126. Modern Syracuse is again limited to the island.—prosteixisqei=sa: elsewhere only in late writers; cf. Dion. H. 3. 1 prosetei/xise th=| po/lei to\n kalou/menon *kai/lion lo/fon.

meta\ *surakou/sas oi)kisqei/sas: = meta\ *surakousw=n oi)/kisin 4. 16, or meta\ *surakousw=n kti/sin 5. 10. For const. of the ptc., see GMT. 829 b. The year of settlement of the chief city of Sicily Thuc. could assume to be known. See App. on 2-5.—*leonti/nous: Leontines, though like *(alih=s, *delfoi/, *oi)nia/dai, the name designates the place as well as the people. But in Thuc. only once (4. 4) do we have certainly the name of place (cf. h( po/lis h( *leonti/nwn 5. 4. 12), whereas in numerous other passages *leonti=noi is unquestionably an ethnic term (6. 12, 15; 50. 8; 63. 15; 77. 6; 79. 7; 3. 86. 4, 9, 11, 12; 4. 25. 34, 42, 49; 5. 4. 3, 21). Hence it is better to regard it as ethnic here, esp. in view of met' au)tou/s. Cf. *megare/as w)/|kisan 4. 7; *)/iwnas *)aqhnai=oi w)/|kisan 1. 12. 13. The city lay in a fruitful region south of Aetna, some three or four miles from the sea. See Polyb. 7. 6 and Holm I, 130.

*kata/nhn: on its favored site, which, in spite of the constant danger from the neighboring Mt. Aetna, makes it to the present day the only great city on that coast, see Holm I, 130 f. On the various explanations of the name, see Holm I, 389. —oi)kisth\n de\ au)toi\...*eu)/arxon : i.e. from themselves they chose the oecist (with a name of good omen, *eu)/arxos), thus avoiding subordination to Naxos.

1. kata\ de\ to\n au)to\n xro/non: i.e. at about the time when Leontini and
Catana were founded.
u(pe\r *pantaku/ou potamou=: cf. 1. 46. 10 e)/sti de\ limh/n, kai\ po/lis u(pe\r au)tou= kei=tai a)po\ qala/sshs. For omission of the art., see Gild., Syn. II, 559.
*trw/tilo/n ti o)/noma xwri/on: the site is uncertain; see Holm I, 131, 390. The unnatural order is as in 1. 106. 3. For o)/noma, by name, cf. 4. 133. 11; 8. 85. 7.

e)s *leonti/nous: see on 3. 10. For particulars of the treachery by which Thucles expelled from Leontini first the Sicels by means of the Megarians, then the latter also, see Polyaen. 5. 5.—o)li/gon xro/non: six months, acc. to Polyaen. 5. 5. 2.—cumpoliteu/sas: i.e. metoikh/sas e)s *leonti/nous kai\ e)kei= cumpoliteu/sas toi=s *xalkideu=si.

*qa/yon : peninsula just north of Syracuse (now called Isola di Magnisi). Cf. 97. 6.— 6. a)nasta/ntes: with pass. force, as in l. 11 and freq. Possibly they were ousted by hostile Sicels.—basile/ws *sikelou=: for adj. use of *sikelo/s, see on *(/ellhn 3. 103. 2.

parado/ntos...kai\ kaqhghsame/nou : i.e. he gave them the land and himself led them in. Cl.'s parado/ntos, for prodo/ntos of the Mss., seems necessary, since from the context there could be no idea of treachery. —*megare/as w)/|kisan tou\s *(ublai/ous: the personal acc. with oi)ki/zein, as in 1. 12. 14; rare in prose. Megara Hyblaea (sometimes simply Megara, 49. 19, 75. 5, 97. 26; 7. 25. 15) was the name of the new Hellenic city, beside which the Sicel Hybla (*u(/bla h( *gelea=tis 62. 21) still existed. The name Hyblaean is still given to the neighboring heights. See Holm I, 132.
klhqe/ntas: aor., because when Thuc. wrote the Hyblaean Megarians had long ceased to exist. See App. on 2-5.
e)/th oi)kh/santes kte(.: Ol. 74. 2; 483 B.C.
u(po\ *ge/lwnos: ruler in Syracuse from 485 B.C.
a)ne/sthsan: sc. *megarh=s oi( *(ublai=oi klhqe/ntes.

u(/steron h)\ au)tou\s oi)kh=sai : the inf. as with pro/teron h)/ 1. 69. 21 and freq. The antithesis to au)tou/s is *selinou=nta: “a hundred years after they themselves had settled, they founded Selinus.” For oi)kh=sai, see App.— *pa/mmilon: for the form (not *pa/millon with most of the Mss.), see Herodian 1. 162; 2. 446; and Lobeck,
Pathol. s. Gr. Proleg. 117.

*selinou=nta: in the Mss. e)s precedes, which Duker rejected as originally due to an unconscious repetition of the final letters of pe/myantes. On the uncertain derivation of this name,—acc. to Steph. Byz. s.v. *)akra/gantes from a river, acc. to others from se/linon, parsley,—see Holm I, 394.—kai\ e)k *mega/rwn...cugkatw/|kise : co-ord. for rel. connection, and he had come from Megara, the mother-state, to take part in the colony. For the custom, see 1. 24. § 2 tau/thn a)pw/|kisan me
 *kerkurai=oi, oi)kisth\s d' e)ge/neto *fali/os . . . *kori/nqios . . . kata\ dh\ to
 palaio
 no/mon e)k th=s mhtropo/lews kataklhqei/s.
*)anti/fhmos...kai\ *)/entimos : for the oracle which they obeyed, see Diod. 8. 23. 1. On the uncertain site of Gela, near the present Terranova, see Holm I, 392.

meta\ *surakousw=n oi)/kisin: as 5. 10 meta\ *surakousw=n kti/sin. The preceding gen. takes the place of the article. See on 1. 1. 11. —a)po\ tou= *ge/la potamou=: cf. l. 21. Duris apud Steph. Byz. s.v. *)akra/gantes: ai( plei=stai tw=n *sikelw=n po/lewn e)k tw=n potamw=n o)noma/zontai. The Doric gen. as in 1. 103. 6; 5. 25. 3; 8. 58. 2.— 17. h(po/lis: = h( a)kro/polis. Cf. 2. 15. § 6. But Steup remarks that Thuc. has nowhere himself used this general designation for the Acropolis (5. 18. 55, 23. 23, 47. 65 being documentary), and that he could not in such a passage contrast h( po/lis (in the sense of the whole city) and to\ xwri/on ou)= nu=n h( po/lis e)sti/ without any explanation. He suggests therefore h( po/lis h( e)nto/s (cf. 3. 8). Van Herw., Mnem. N.S. VIII (1880), 146, would write h( a)kro/polis.

kai\ o(/ : the rel. pron. expressed here in the second clause because of its importance; besides, to supply it from the adv. would be a harsh const. Cf. 89. 23, 101. 3.—*li/ndioi: evidently from Lindus in Rhodes. Cf. Hdt. 7. 153 ktizome/nhs *ge/lhs u(po\ *lindi/wn te tw=n e)k *(ro/dou kai\ *)antifh/mou.
kalei=tai : van Herw. and St. write kalou=ntai with Cod. B, though that has -eitai in rasura.
e)ggu/tata: see on 2. 29.
*)akra/ganta: Agrigentum (Girgenti); on the situation and history of this important city, see Schubring, Hist. Topographie von Akragas, Leipz. 1870.

o)noma/santes, poih/santes, do/ntes:
aor. ptcs, synchronous with w)/|kisan. Cf. geno/menos 5. 15; also 1. 86. 2; 2. 68. 10; 3. 20. 21.
ta\ *gelw/|wn: where ta\ e(autw=n would be expected. Cf. 5. 36. 11 meta\ *boiwtw=n for meq' e(autw=n, and 5. 18. 29 au)tou\s *)aqhnai/ois for e(autoi=s.

*za/gklh: on old coins *da/gklh. For divergent, but little credible, traditions about the origin and fortunes of this city, see Strabo 6, p. 268 c and Paus. 4. 23. 6 ff.—a)po\ *ku/mhs: “acc. to uniform tradition the oldest Greek city on Italian soil.” See Curtius, Gr. Gesch.^{6} I, 426. Acc. to more recent researches, however, Cumae is hardly much older than the earliest Greek cities of Sicily. See Busolt, Gr. Gesch.^{2} I, 391 f., and Freeman, Hist. of Sicily I, 311 f.— 24. e)n *)opiki/a|: the later Latium and Campania are meant. See Niebuhr, Röm. Gesch.^{3} I, 71 ff.
cugkatenei/manto th\n gh=n: shared the land with them. The pl. with collective noun as in 1. 125. 4. The word seems to occur clsewhere only in late writers. Cf. katane/mesqai 2. 17. 18.

o)/noma : explan. acc. with pass. verb of naming, as 1. 122. 25. Kr. Spr. 50, 7, 5.—*za/gklh h)=n...klhqei=sa : was called Zancle by the Sicels. See App. on 2-5. For the periphrasis h)=n klhqei=sa = e)klh/qh, cf. h)=san geno/menoi 4. 54. 12.

drepanoeide\s th\n i)de/an : somewhat pleonastic, like o)/noma klhqei=sa. In the sense of form, i)de/a is used only here by Thuc., who is fond of the word. See on 1. 109. 2. “The harbor of Zancle is one of the finest and safest in the world; the sickle-shaped tongue of land which forms it extends northward.” See Holm I, 133. 30. oi( *sikeloi/: B. Heisterbergk, Fragen d. ältest. Gesch. Siziliens, p. 98 ff. (Berl. Stud. IX, H. 3), attempts to prove that not the Sicels, but the Siceliotes, called the sickle za/gklon. Acc. to Diod. 4. 85 *za/gklh was named after a King Zanklos.— 31. au)toi/: i.e. the former Chalcidian inhabitants.—u(po\ *sami/wn...e)kpi/ptousin kte(.: for particulars, see Hdt. 6. 22 ff.—kai\ a)/llwn *)iw/nwn: besides the Samians Hdt. 6. 22 mentions *milhsi/wn oi( e)kpefeugo/tes.
*mh/dous feu/gontes : after the sea fight at Lade.
*)anaci/las *(rhgi/nwn tu/rannos: acc. to Hdt. 6. 23 it was this very Anaxilas who had first caused the Samians to take Zancle.

au)to/s: correctly restored by Dobree for au)toi=s. Cf. 5. 15.—cummei/ktwn a)nqrw/pwn oi)ki/sas: having colonized it with men of mixed nationality. Gen. of material as with plhrw/sas. G. 1113; H. 743.— 35. a)po\ th=s e(autou= to\ a)rxai=on patri/dos: cf. Paus. 4. 23. 6 te/tartos a)po/gonos h)=n *)alkidami/dou: metw/|khse de\ *)alkidami/das e)k *messh/nhs e)s *(rh/gion meta\ th
 *)aristodh/mou teleuth/n. The adv. to\ a)rxai=on is unusual for a)rxai/as. See on 4. 3. 18.— a)ntwno/masen: with Bk. for au)to\ w)no/masen of most of the better Mss.; for au)to/ would be superfluous, and so near th
 po/lin would seem strange in spite of to\ xwri/on in l. 30. St. thinks this would require met wno/masen. But cf. Dio C. 55. 6 to
 mh=na to
 *secti/lion e)pikalou/menon *au)/gouston a)nt wno/masen. The statement of Hdt. 7. 164 para\ *sami/wn e)/sxe te kai\ katoi/khse po/lin *za/gklhn th
 e)s *messh/nhn metabalou=san to\ o)/noma does not make it necessary to refer the change of name to the Samians. See Unger, Rh. Mus. XXXVII, 184 n.—The complete destruction by earthquake and tidal wave of Messina and Reggio on December 28, 1908, has recently drawn the attention of the whole world to this region.
1. *(ime/ra: see Holm I, 136, 393.— 2. oi( plei=stoi: i.e. the most that came were Chalcidians.

cunw/|khsan de\ au)toi=s: and there settled with them, i.e. with the Chalcidians. So Steup reads with Bk. and Kr. and the majority of the Mss. against cunw/|kisan of most editors. Cf. proscunw/|khsan 2. 16, and see on cunoikh/santes 2. 36. He would restore cunw/|khsan also in 1. 24. 6.— 4. sta/sei nikhqe/ntes: overcome by an opposing faction. Cf. Hdt. I. 150. 2 sta/si e(sswqe/ntas. For const. of the dat., see on 2. 6 and 1^{4}. 125. 6.—oi( *mulhti/dai kalou/menoi: the definite statement that these were fuga/des e)k *surakousw=n shows that Strabo's notice (6. p. 272 c) th\n *(ime/ran oi( e)n *mulai=s e)/ktisan *zagklai=oi rests on a misunderstanding. The name *mulhti/dai has not been explained.
metacu\...e)kra/qh : peculiar const. for e)k . . . e)kra/qh.
th=s *xalkide/wn : i.e. th=s *)ia/dos.
kai\ *dwri/dos : cf. *dwri\s glw=ssa 3. 112. 14.

*)/akrai: not far from the sources of the Anapus. See Holm I, 141 f., 396.
The situation of Casmenae is less certain. See Holm I, 143, 396.
meta\ *surakou/sas: possibly ktisqei/sas has fallen out.
*kama/rina: between the outlets of the rivers Oanis (Frascolaro) and Hipparis (Camarana). See Holm I, 143.
meta\ *surakousw=n kti/sin: see on 4. 16. 13. *(ippokra/ths: tyrant of Gela 498-491, followed by Gelon, who in 485 brought Syracuse also under his rule.
lu/tra...*kamarinai/wn : the cession of Camarina to Hippocrates is mentioned also by Hdt. 7. 154.— 15. geno/menos: for force of aor. ptc., see on 4. 21.
u(po\ *gelw/|wn: for *ge/lwnos of the Mss., correctly restored by Dodwell, acc. to Diod. 11. 76. This last settlement was made about 461.

From the foregoing general statement we gather the following facts, which are of importance for the history of the great war to follow, namely, that of the Hellenie settlements in Sicily Naxos, Leontini, and Catana belonged to the Ionian race; to the Dorian belonged Syracuse, Gela, Acrae, Casmenae, Selinus, Camarina, and Aeragas; of mixed race were ZancleMessene and Himera. Since 483 Megara Hyblaea had been deserted, and its territory was in the hands of the Syracusans.
A plea for help from the Egestaeans causes the Athenians to make investigations as to the state of affairs in Sicily.

tosau=ta e)/qnh: refers to tosa/de e)/qnh 2. 1 (with division into ba/rbaroi c. 2 and *(/ellhnes cc. 3-5).— 2. e)pi\ tosh/nde ou)=san au)th/n: referring, per chiasmum, to 1. § 2. See on 2. 39. —w(/rmhnto: were eager. See on 3. 92. 18.

e)fie/menoi...a)/rcein : eagerly desiring in simple truth to attain to the empire of the whole island. The dat. is causal, the sense being that desire for
the sway of the whole island was the truest ground of their eagerness. For pro/fasis meaning real ground or cause, see on 1. 23. 23. St. writes a)/rcai for a)/rcein of the Mss., considering (see Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 18 ff.) the fut. inf. inadmissible after e)fi/esqai, as after dei=sqai 1. 27. 9, bou/lesqai 6. 57. 11, pei/qein 2. 29. 26, dunato\n ei)=nai 3. 28. 1. But Cl. considers the fut. appropriate, even after verbs that do not usually take it, where the result is postponed to a more distant (as here) or a conditional future time, and refers to St.'s defense, on like grounds, against Cobet, of the fut. inf. after dianoei=sqai in five passages of Thuc. and one of Hdt. The force of the fut. here is attain to rule, for a)/rcein is fut. of a)/rcai as well as of a)/rxein. In 1. § 1 e)/boulonto . . . katastre/yasqai comprehends the conquest in a single act. See also on 4. 27. 20 and 8. 2. 10.
eu)prepw=s: in fair-seeming wise, as in 4. 60. 8. Cf. 8. 19 profa/sei eu)prepei=.
toi=s e(autw=n cuggene/si : i.e. the Hellenes of Ionic stock.
progegenhme/nois: with Mss. E and M and Valla for prosgegenhme/nois, as St., Cl., and others have recognized to be necessary; for not new, but only old, allies can be meant.

*)egestai/wn te: Cl. assumes with Bm. an anacoluthon, the regular const., interrupted by a long parenthetical statement which ends with i(kana/ in 23, being resumed with w(=n a)kou/ontes kte(., where we have tw=n te *)egestai/wn . . . kai\ tw=n cunagoreuo/ntwn. Perhaps the simplest remedy would be to omit te, with three inferior Mss.—proqumo/teron: not essentially different from the positive proqu/mws (eagerly, earnestly) here and in 77. 7; 80. 2. See on 54. 2.
peri\ gamikw=n tinwn: particulars not known. Proximity easily gave occasions for such difficulties.
e)pagago/menoi: to be preferred to e)pago/menoi here and in 3. 34. 8. See App. on the latter passage.
th\n genome/nhn...*leonti/nwn...cummaxi/an : i.e. the alliance concluded by the Egestaeans with the Leontines at the time of Laches and the former war of the Athenians in Sicily. See App.
oi( *)egestai=oi: subj. incorporated in the obj. clause.

a)namimnh/|skontes: with double
acc., whereas in 2. 54. 4; 3. 59. 15 we have the gen. of the thing. Both consts. are in use elsewhere.
a)/lla te polla\ kai\ kefa/laion kte(.: cf. 4. 50. 8 pollw=n a)/llwn gegramme/nwn kefa/laion h)=n.
*leonti/nous a)nasth/santes : as related in 5. 4. § 3.
au)tw=n: sc. tw=n *leonti/nwn.

diafqei/rontes : pres. ptc. indicating the means by which the Syracusans can, acc. to the speaker, gain th\n a(/pasan du/namin th=s *sikeli/as,— for sxh/sousi is ingressive (Kr.),—and hence there is no need to change to diafqei/rantes, as some editors do.— 18. kata\ to\ cuggene/s: = kata\ th\n cugge/neian. See on 1. 6. 12.
toi=s e)kpe/myasi *peloponnhsi/ois: referring esp. to Corinth, the mother-city of Syracuse.
th\n e)kei/nwn: i.e. tw=n *)aqhnai/wn.
sw=fron ei)=nai : was prudent. Cf. 1. 42. 10.
sfw=n: sc. tw=n *)egestai/wn.

w(=n a)kou/ontes: i.e. tou/twn tw=n lo/gwn; for const., cf. tou= khru/gmatos a)kou/santes 4. 37. 5, th=s a)ggeli/as 5. 44. 1, th=s e)pistolh=s 7. 16. 2. The pres. ptc. here with reference to the repeated e)kklhsi/ai and the polla/kis le/gein.
pe/myai : for the unintelligible pe/myantes of the Mss.—prw=ton: i.e. before making a definite decision.— 27. w(/sper fasi/n: sc. oi( *)egestai=oi.
ta\ tou= pole/mou : proleptic obj. acc. of ei)some/nous. For nonrepetition of tou= before pro\s tou\s *selinounti/ous, cf. 76. 17; 1. 55. 11; 7. 43. 12; 8. 6. 9.

Invasion of the territory of the Argives by the Lacedaemonians. The
Argive refugees are settled in Orneae, but must soon again leave this place in consequence of an attack of the Argives and Athenians. The Athenians, with their base at Methone, devastate the land of Perdiccas, whom the Lacedaemonians vainly seek to help through the Thracian Chalcidians.

plh
 *korinqi/wn: these had, since the alliance of Argos, Mantinea, and Elis (420 B.C.), held rather with Sparta (5. 48. § 2 f.); though their relations with Sparta were by no means so close as before the fifty years' peace of 421 B.C. In the summer of 418 B.C. 2000 Corinthians had taken part in the first expedition of King Agis against the Argives (5. 57. § 2), and later the Corinthians had bestirred themselves to aid the Spartans after Mantinea (5. 64. § 4, 75. § 2). But in the account of the winter of 417-416 (5. 83. § 1) we read *lakedaimo/nioi e)stra/teusan e)s to\ *)/argos au)toi/ te kai\ oi( cu/mmaxoi plh
 *korinqi/wn, and in 5. 115. § 3 separate dealings of the Corinthians with the Athenians are reported.—strateu/santes e)s th
 *)argei/an: continuing the hostilities (5. 83, 116) caused by the democratic revolution in Argos in the summer of 417 B.C.

th=s gh=s ou) pollh/n: for assimilation of gender of articular adj. to that of part. gen., see on 1. 2. 13.— si=ton...komi/santes : carried off some corn, having brought along wagons. As a)na- can signify off, away (cf. a)nairei=n, a)nalamba/nein, a)naskeua/zein), Hude's conjecture a)pekomi/santo is unnecessary. Cl. would take tina/ with zeu/gh, but thus it would be meaningless, whereas si=ton requires some modifier to offset ou) pollh/n in the first clause. It is not likely that tina/ is dittography for tina/ with xro/non in 7, as Cl. doubtingly suggested.

*)ornea/s: whose inhabitants were on the Argive side at Mantinea (5. 67. § 2, 72. § 4, 74. § 3), prob. first came through the expedition here reported into the power of the Spartans.—tou\s *)argei/wn fuga/das: of the oligarchic party, who had first found refuge in Phlius and hitherto had remained there. Cf. 5. 83. § 3, 115. § 1.— 6. parakatalipo/ntes: elsewhere only in late authors, as also proskatalei/pein 2. 36. 8; 4. 62. 16.

speisa/menoi/ tina xro/non : sc. toi=s *)argei/ois. The acc. of the duration of the time for which the truce was to last, as 4. 63. 7; 5. 41. 12, 60. 6. Cf. 3. 114. 13.—w(/ste: on condition that. See on 1. 28. 18. GMT. 587, 2.

e)lqo/ntwn: i.e. to Argos and its
harbor Nauplia.

e)celqo/ntes: restored by Haacke, following Valla, for e)celqo/ntwn of all the Mss.—tou\s e)n *)orneai=s: Cod. Laur. has tou\s me\n e)n *)orneai=s, but as here neither persons nor actions are contrasted, me/n is inadmissible.
u(po\ nu/kta: by night. See on 64. 3.
oi( e)k tw=n *)ornew=n: the prep. phrase attached proleptically to the subj., as 1. 8. 9.
w(s h)/|sqonto: without expressed obj.; see on 1. 95. 21.

e)s *meqw/nhn th\n o(/moron *makedoni/a|: to distinguish from *meqw/nh th=s *lakwnikh=s 2. 25. 4 and *meqw/nh h( metacu\ *)epidau/rou kai\ *troizh=nos 4. 45. 6. The place belonged to the Athenian alliance. See on 4. 129. 18.
sfw=n au)tw=n: dependent on i(ppe/as, as *makedo/nwn is on tou\s . . . fuga/das, the two part. gens., as corresponding chief factors, being correlated by te . . . kai\.
tou\s...fuga/das : the followers of the princes hostile to Perdiccas. Cf. 1. 57. 6, 59. 8, 61. 17; 2. 95. 8, 18, 100. 10.
a)/gontas...dexhme/rous sponda/s : i.e. a truce to be renewed every ten days. Cf. 5. 26. 14.

div2.head: Seventeenth Year of the War (8-93)
Seventeenth Year of the War (8-93)
div2.p: In view of the favorable report of the ambassadors sent to Sicily the Athenians vote to send thither sixty triremes under Alcibiades, Nicias, and Lamachus. In an ecclesia called five days later to discuss the equipment Nicias tries to effect the abrogation of the vote.
h(=kon: as freq. with the force of came back. Cf. 5. 34. 1; 7. 21. 2; 8. 92. 6.

a)/gontes: of transport by ship, as 7. 16. 12, 31. 12.—w(s: with misqo/n, as pay. The estimate is for
a drachma per day for each man— reckoning 200 men for each trireme (see Boeckh-Fränkel, Staatshaush.^{3} I, 344 ff.), i.e. twice as much as usual (60 x 200 x 30 = 360,000 drachmas, or 60 talents). See on 31. 19.
e)pagwga/: enticements, as 4. 88. 3; 5. 111. 14.

e)n tw=| koinw=|: for the traditional e)n toi=s koinoi=s, correctly restored by van Herw. (Stud. Thuc. p. 46), following early editions, and Haacke, as seems to be required by e)n tw=| koinw=| 6. 27. Cf. also 1. 80. 19, 141. 11; 8. 1. 15. It is the sort of miscopying that has been corrected in 3. 65. 2; 5. 27. 2, 48. 1. W. E. Heitland (Journal of Phil. XXIV, 3) calls attention to the fact that, acc. to 46. § 3, the Athenian ambassadors were led also into the sanctuary of Aphrodite in Eryx, but that proves nothing for toi=s koinoi=s, since our passage has direct reference to 6. § 3.

au)tokra/toras: within the limits of the instructions implied in bohqou\s me\n . . . *)aqhnai/ois the generals were to have free hand in Sicilian matters. Later (26. § 1) they were given unlimited authority also to determine the strength and equipment of the forces to be sent to Sicily.
*la/maxon: cf. 4. 75. 5.

cugkatoiki/sai, (14) pra=cai: infs. of purpose after pe/mpein, as in 4. 132. 15. Cf. 50. 14. For the correlation of these infs. with bohqou\s me/n, cf. 1. 72. 6, 128. 14.—cugkatoiki/sai de\ kai\...pole/mou : but also to join in restoring Leontini in case they should have any success in the war. So Bm. and Pp.-St. explain. St. renders si quid ex bello commodi nacti essent. tou= pole/mou depends on ti or rather on the subst. idea derived from its connection with perige/nhtai. On the fortunes of the Leontines, cf. 5. 4. § 4 ff.; 6. 6. § 2. For Steup's view, see App.

kai\ ta)=lla...pra=cai : cf. 1. 95. 7 ta)=lla katasthso/menoi h(=| fai/noito a)/rista au)toi=s. Here we have the more general pra/ssein, since there could be no question of a complete establishment (kaqi/stasqai). Cf. also 26. 2 peri\ stratia=s plh/qous kai\ peri\ tou= panto\s plou= tou\s strathgou\s pra/ssein h(=| a)\n au)toi=s dokh=| a)/rista ei)=nai *)aqhnai/ois, 1. 126. 26 to\ pa=n diaqei=nai h(=| a)\n a)/rista diagignw/skwsi. Cf. also 9. 12, 10. 5.—ta)=lla ta\ e)n th=| *sikeli/a|: art. repeated, as in 8. 64. 6, 84. 18; but only one art. in 1. 44. 15,
56. 11, 91. 3; 3. 101. 7.
gignw/skwsin: judge. Cf. 9. 12; 8. 67. 18, and diagignw/skein 1. 126. 26.
kaq) o(/ ti xrh\ kte(.: to be taken directly with e)kklhsi/a, something like w(/ste bouleu/esqai being understood. For kaq' o(/ti, in what way, cf. 9. 2; 8. 67. 5, and see on 1. 35. 16; 4. 34. 25.

ei)/ tou prosde/ointo: in case they should need anything further (besides the equipment voted), containing the subj. of yhfisqh=nai, inf. of purpose after e)kklhsi/a e)gi/gneto (cf. 38. 25, 80. 10; 4. 114. 9). Hude unnecessarily inserts tou= before toi=s strathgoi=s, but is right in denying that yhfisqh=nai depends on kaq' o(/ ti xrh/, as Cl. and others explain.

profa/sei braxei/a| kai\ eu)prepei=: on a slight and (only) fair-seeming pretext. The first adj. has reference to the insignificance of Egesta, the second to 6. 4 bohqei=n de\ a(/ma eu)prepw=s boulo/menoi toi=s e(autw=n cuggene/si kte(. Cf. 79. 9 eu)lo/gw| profa/sei.
mega/lou e)/rgou : a great thing, matter, as in 3. 3. 3. mega/lou is esp. antithetic to braxei/a|.

My advice is to reconsider the whole question of the expedition to Sicily, and I do this although a position of honor is accorded me in the enterprise and fear of personal danger influences me less than others. Following solely my convietion of the public interest, I will show that the undertaking is untimely and the object in view not easy to attain.
h( me\n e)kklhsi/a...e)kplei=n: e)moi\ me/ntoi dokei= : cf. the similar introduction to the e)pita/fios lo/gos 2. 35.
kaq) o(/ ti...e)kplei=n : explanatory of peri\ paraskeuh=s th=s h(mete/ras. On the matter, cf. 8. § 3.
ei) a)/meino/n e)stin: formula used esp. in questions put to the oracle. See on 1. 118. 21.
kai\ mh\...a)/rasqai : dependent on xrh=nai.

a)ndra/sin a)llofu/lois : cf. 11. 27 tw=n *)egestai/wn,
a)ndrw=n barba/rwn.
ou) prosh/konta : that does not concern us.

kai/toi: anticipating the objection (see on 4. 18. 5) that he speaks from personal motives: these would rather lead to the opposite advice; the orator will nevertheless (o(/mws de/ 11), as heretofore, speak solely acc. to conviction. —timw=mai e)k tou= toiou/tou: cf. 5. 16. 4 tima=sqai e)k tou= polemei=n. The reference is to Nicias's election as one of the three generals (8. 10). e)k tou= toiou/tou, as 8. 51. 10, referring to something definite or already mentioned.— 7. h(=sson e(te/rwn: = h(/kista. See on 1. 84. 7.—peri\ tw=| e)mautou= sw/mati o)rrwdw=: the dat. with verbs meaning to fear, be concerned about (timere de); otherwise rare and only in local sense. sw=ma of personal security, as 1. 17. 2.

nomi/zwn: although convinced. In this and the following clause we have merely a side remark, in self-defense against the possible reproach of timidity (cf. 13. § 1). o(/mws de/ (11), opp. to e)/gwge kai\ timw=mai kte(., resumes the main thought.—o(moi/ws a)gaqo\n poli/thn: just as good a citizen.
ma/lista ga\r...o)rqou=sqai : for similar thought, cf. 2. 60. § 3. For o)rqou=sqai (subj. ta\ th=s po/lews) = eu)tuxei=n, see on 3. 37. 26.
ou)/te e)n tw=| pro/teron xro/nw|...ou)/te nu=n : parataxis, though the first clause is really subord. to the second. For similar cases of parataxis, cf. 10. 17, 16. 10, 40. 10.

ei)=pon para\ gnw/mhn: cf. 3. 42. 29.—ou)/te nu=n: sc. le/gw, as contrarily in 1. 86. 7 and 3. 40. 5 with kai\ to/te a pret. is supplied from the following kai\ nu=n and pres.—a)lla\ h(=| a)\n gignw/skw be/ltista: as 8. 14 o(/ph| a)\n gignw/skwsin a)/rista. See App.

pro\s: against. See on 3. 43. 15. —tou\s tro/pous: ways. Cf. 2. 36. 16, 41. 7. On the matter, cf. 1. 70. § 2 ff., where the Athenians are denominated para\ du/namin tolmhtai\ kai\ para\ gnw/mhn kinduneutai/, while the characteristics of the Spartans are given as oi)/esqai tw=| e)pelqei=n kai\ ta\ e(toi=ma a)\n bla/yai.

mh\ toi=s e(toi/mois kinduneu/ein : not to hazard present possessions. The dat. as 10. 17, 47. 12; 2. 65. 24; 4. 117. 14; 8. 45. 27. ta\ e(toi=ma, a strengthened u(pa/rxonta, as 1. 70. 16; 4. 61. 2, to which are opposed ta\ a)fanh= kai\ me/llonta of the distant objects of passionate desire.
Cf. 5. 113. 4, 5.
r(a/|dia katasxei=n: cf. r(a/|ous a)/rxein 42. 8; r(a=|stoi a)mu/nesqai 4. 10. 15. katasxei=n = kth/sasqai (Schol.). See on 11. 1, 39. 12.
e)f' a(\ w)/rmhsqe: what you are striving for. Somewhat different is e)pi\ tau=ta w(/rmhsqe 78. 26.

For if you meet with any considerable reverse in Sicily, your enemies here will surely renew the war; indeed it is likely that they will unite with the Siceliotes if they find your forces divided. It is bad policy to seek new dominion in Sicily before we have firmly established our sway at home.
fhmi/: emphatically put first in an explanation, as 39. 1, 87. 4; Dem. 2. 11.—ga/r: see on 33. 7.— u(ma=s, deu=ro: universally accepted corrections of the Mss. readings (h(ma=s, deu/teron).
e)pagage/sqai: bring upon you, as 5. 98. 10.
ta\s...sponda/s : cf. 5. 18, 19.— 4. ai(/: rel. with adversative force. See on 1. 35. 15; 4. 17. 18.—o)no/mati: merely in name, me/xris o)no/matos (Schol.).

a)/ndres: for tines, with intentional omission of name. Cf. 38. 3, 50. 11; 1. 107. 19; 4. 132. 16. Under e)nqe/nde are meant esp. Alcibiades, under e)k tw=n e)nanti/wn e.g. Cleobulus and Xenares (5. 36. § 1).—e)/pracan au)ta/: negotiated them, i.e. the relations between Athens and the Peloponnesians (au)ta/ with all good Mss., not au)ta/s). See on ta)=lla pra=cai 8. 13. For au)ta/ of matters under discussion, see on 1. 1. 10.

sfale/ntwn de/ pou a)cio/xrew| duna/mei: but should you fail perchance with a considerable force. For same const. of dat. with sfalh=nai, cf. 2. 65. 51. Note gen. abs., for greater emphasis, notwithstanding h(mi=n in leading clause. See on 1, 114. 2. GMT. 850; Kr. Spr. 47, 4, 2.— e)pixei/rhsin poih/sontai: periphrasis for simple verb.
dia\ cumforw=n: in consequence of misfortunes.

cu/mbasis...e)ge/neto : = pass. of cu/mbasin poiei=sqai (see on 6).—e)k tou= ai)sxi/onos h)\ h(mi=n: with less credit than to us. Cf. 11. 23 dia\ to\ ai)sxro/n. Steup follows Naber (Mnem. N. S. XIV, 324) in bracketing h)\ h(mi=n, on the ground that Nicias could not have said in the Ecclesia that the Athenians at the conclusion of the fifty years' peace were in a discreditable condition, and sees in these words a mistaken explanation of e)k tou= ai)sxi/onos.

kat) a)na/gkhn : under
compulsion, defined by dia\ cumforw=n and e)k tou= ai)sxi/onos. Weidner (Parerga Dinarch. et Thuc. p. 20) would reject the words.
e)/peita e)n au)th=| kte(.: independent sent. tacked on to rel. Cf. 2. 41. 15. Kr. Spr. 59, 2, 6.—ta\ a)mfisbhtou/mena: disputed points, for which see 5. 35, 42.

oi( me\n a)/ntikrus polemou=sin: the Corinthians (cf. 5. 30. § 2), who, after having an a)nokwxh\ a)/spondos with the Athenians (5. 32. 30), had again, at least in the summer of 416, been openly at war with them (5. 115. § 3; see on 7. 3).—oi( de\ kai\...kate/xontai : esp. the Boeotians (5. 26. 14) and the Thracian Chalcidians (7. § 4).
kai\ au)toi\ kate/xontai: as the Lacedaemonians h(suxa/zousin, so these too refrain from hostilities within the conditions of the dexh/meroi spondai/ (5. 26. 14).

ta/xa a)\n d): so, not ta/xa d' a)/n, all Mss. except Laur. Cf. 2. 22. ta/xa with i)/sws to express what is quite possible, as 34. 9, 78. 15. See on 1. 77. 21.— di/xa: dih|rhme/nhn ei)s du/o me/rh Schol. Cf. 100. 4; 1. 64. 6.

la/boien: in the sense of deprehendere, as 33. 13.—o(/per nu=n speu/domen: just what we are now striving for. speu/dein with acc., as 79. 13; 1. 141. 27; 5. 16. 7.—kai\ pa/nu a)\n...*sikeliwtw=n : they would even eagerly join with the Siceliotes in attacking us. For kai/, see Kr. Spr. 69, 32, 18. For a)/n repeated, see GMT. 223; H. 862. In view of the fact that we have here a stronger assertion than above (6), sfale/ntwn de/ pou . . . poih/sontai, Steup, feeling the need of a word of intensification, suggests that paraxrh=ma has fallen out before pa/nu.
ou(\s...xro/nw| : an alliance with whom on former occasions they would have prized beyond many other things. Cf. 1. 33. 8; 3. 40. 33.
xrh\ skopei=n tina au)ta/: one must consider these matters. For tina/ thus used in admonitions, cf. 4. 62. 10. For au)ta/, cf. 5 above; here referring to the Sicilian expedition.

kai\ mh\ metew/rw| th=| po/lei...o)re/gesqai : and not demand that we run hazards for the ship of state in mid-ocean and reach out after another empire. Kr.'s conjecture th=|, for te of the Mss., approved by Cl., has been almost universally adopted, partly because the Schol. (see below) seems to support the art., partly because the second member does not add something new or different, as would
be expected with te . . . kai/. But Steup retains te, urging that a general statement (po/lei, a state) is quite allowable here (see on 1^{4}. 10. 11), though the reference is plainly to Athens, and for te . . . kai/, where the second member merely amplifies the first, citing such passages as 103. 20; 1. 132. 8.—metew/rw|: figure of a ship on the high seas, as 2. 8. 6. Schol. th=s po/lews h(mw=n ou)k e)n tw=| a)sfalei= o(rmou/shs. metenh/nektai de\ to\ o)/noma a)po\ tw=n ploi/wn tw=n mh/pw w(rmisme/nwn. See Smyth, Melic Poets, p. 215. —kinduneu/ein: with dat., as in 9. 15.

bebaiwsw/meqa: subjv. (with C; Mss. mostly bebaiwso/meqa) after pri/n, as 29. 7, 38. 8; 8. 9. 3, 14. Cf. pro/teron h)/ 7. 63. 3. See St., Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 26.—ei) *xalkidh=s ge kte(.: Cl. suggests that after the preceding admonition, “not to run hazards for the state” etc., we must supply in thought before ei), “as we shall be doing.” He makes all that follows one sent. dependent on ei), as the warning against ambitious foreign expeditions before the sway of Athens has been fully reëstablished at home is based upon the ei) clauses, which are apparently hypothetical (see on 1. 33. 8), but really set forth the situation not only of the unruly allies (*xalkidh=s . . . a)krow=ntai) but also of the Athenians themselves (h(mei=s de\ . . . a)mu/nesqai). Most editors make an independent sent. of h(mei=s de\ . . . a)mu/nesqai, contrasting what is being done with what ought to be done.—ei)...ge : si quidem.
e)/th tosau=ta: the Chalcidians had revolted from Athens along with Potidaea in the winter of 433-432 (1. 58).

kata\ ta\s h)pei/rous: on the coasts of Thrace, Asia, and western Greece, whither acc. to 2. 9. § 4 the Athenian a)rxh/ extended. What places Nicias had in mind is hard to determine (cf., however, 2. 69; 3. 19).—e)ndoiastw=s: dubia fide. Cf. 8. 87. 26; Hdt. 7. 174. 5. For the verb e)ndoia/zein, see on 91. 19.

*)egestai/ois dh\ ou)=si cumma/xois: ironical dh/ (cf. 54. 17, 80. 13, and see on 3. 10. 17) placed before the words emphasized, as dh=qen 1. 127. 2. Strietly speaking, the Egestaeans were only allies of the Leontines. See App. on 6. 12.

u(f' w(=n pa/lai a)festw/twn: for the pred. ptc. with force of a verbal subst., cf. u(po\ tw=n *qhbai/wn e)fepome/nwn 4. 96. 25; u(po\ th=s *dekelei/as polla\ blaptou/shs 7. 28. 25; dia\ th\n *deke/leian teixizome/nhn 7. 42. 10. See App. on 4. 63. 2.—au)toi/: correctly restored by Reiske for au)tw=n of the Mss. The important thing is the antithesis in au)toi\ a)dikou/meqa to w(s a)dikoume/nois. Such contrasted phrases (cf. ou)=si cumma/xois and pa/lai a)festw/twn, bohqou=men and a)mu/nesqai) are good examples of antithesis in the enthymeme, which is common in the speeches.

Even after a victory we could not hold what we had won. There would be no danger for us, however, if the Syracusans should obtain dominion over the rest of the Siceliotes. It would be best if we merely showed our power for a little while to the Siceliotes or did not go thither at all. But we must be on the watch against the Lacedaemonians, who unquestionably are minded to wipe out their humiliation by defeating us.
tou\s me/n: i.e. tou\s pa/lai a)festw=tas tw=n cumma/xwn.
katergasa/menoi : cf. 33. 20, 86. 8.— kata/sxoimen: sometimes even in aor.= hold fast. Cf. 39. 12, 86. 10; 1. 6. 13, 91. 9.—tw=n de/: i.e. tw=n *sikeliwtw=n. For the thought, cf. 86. § 3.
dia\ pollou=: at a distance. Cf. 1. 15; 2. 97. 10; 4. 115. 16.
e)pi\ toiou/tous i)e/nai: of hostile advance, as 63. 3, 82. 17, 92. 12, and freq.
mh\ e)n tw=| o(moi/w| kai/: not in the same condition as, but far worse off. For tw=| o(moi/w| kai/, see on 3. 14. 2. H. 1042 a; Kühn. 423, N. 18.

*sikeliw=tai d)...*surako/sioi : the sense intended here seems to be that of Valla's translation: Sicilienses, ut nune saltem se habent, mihi videntur parum formidabiles, multoque minus formidabiles fore, si Syracusani ipsis imperitent. See App.
w(/s ge nu=n e)/xousi: except Leontini all Hellenic cities of Sicily were at that time autonomous.
o(/per...h(ma=s e)kfobou=si : neut. cogn. acc. besides pers. obj., the very thing with which they are trying to frighten us.

nu=n: i.e. w(/s ge nu=n e)/xousi, while e)kei/nws (9) stands for ei) a)/rceian au)tw=n *surako/sioi. Cf. 3. 46. 5, 8.—ka)\n e)/lqoien: sc. deu=ro e)f' h(ma=s. Cf. 40. 9. St.'s e)pe/lqoien is unnecessary.

e(/kastoi: only separate action of individual cities not united by a common bond was, acc. to the orator, to be anticipated. —xa/riti: out of regard for, with gen., as 3. 95. 1.—ou)k ei)ko\s a)rxh
 e)pi\ a)rxh
 strateu=sai: it is not likely that an imperial city would proceed against an imperial city. Schol. ou)k ei)ko\s e)pi\ th
 tw=n *)aqhnai/wn a)rxh
 strateu=sai tou\s *surakosi/ous *sikeliwtw=n a)/rcantas. For ei)ko/s with inf. without a)/n, see GMT. 415, 416, and see on 1. 81. 13.

w(=| a)\n tro/pw|...a)fe/lwntai : supply as subj. oi( *surako/sioi *sikeliwtw=n a)/rcantes.
Aor. subjv. here = Lat. fut. pf. For a)fele/sqai, take away, despoil, cf. a)felome/nhs nukto\s to\ e)/rgon 4. 134. 8; to\ *)aqhnai/wn kra/tos th=s qala/sshs a)fele/sqai 8. 76. 16.
u(po\ tw=n au)tw=n : i.e. tw=n *peloponnhsi/wn.
th\n sfete/ran : referring to subj. of preceding clause. Cf. sfi/si 32. 9.

dia\ tou= au)tou= : through the same means. Cf. di) au)tou= 15. 7. It seems most natural to supply, with the Schol., tro/pou from tro/pw| just above, though dia\ tro/pou seems not to occur.—kaqaireqh=nai: cf. 5. 14. 14 kaqairh/sein th\n tw=n *)aqhnai/wn du/namin, and see on 1. 77. 20.

h(ma=s de/: put first to sharpen the contrast: “The Egestaeans want to frighten us with the Syracusans; these will rather have respect for us.”— 14. e)/peita de\ kai/: sc. a)\n e)kpeplhgme/noi ei)=en. Nicias real wish is expressed in the first alternative, but the second would at least insure the respect of the Siceliotes.—dei/cantes th\n du/namin: cf. 47. 8.—di) o)li/gou: after a little. Cf. 5. 14. 5; 7. 39. 13. See on 47. 10.

ta\ ga\r dia\ plei/stou...do/nta : Steup, St., Hude, and the Oxford text follow Rauchenstein (Philol. XXXVI. 242) in transposing this clause, which stands in the Mss. after ei) de\ sfalei=men . . . e)piqoi=nto, on the ground that it serves in no way to explain this latter clause and must be regarded as parenthetical if left as in the Mss., since o(/per must refer to u(perido/ntes e)piqoi=nto. For the sentiment, cf. Tac. Ann. 1. 47 maior e longinquo reverentia; Agr. 30 omneignotum pro magnifico est; Agr. 25 maiore fama, uti mosest de ignotis; Liv. 28. 44. 3 maior ignotarum rerum est terror.— dia\ plei/stou: see on 2 above.— pei=ran do/nta: giving a test or proof, as 1. 138. 9.

ei) de\ sfalei=me/n ti: (on form of opt., see on 1. 38. 4, and St., Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 62) presupposes ei) d' e)s fanero\n po/lemon katastai=men, and therefore is opp. to ei) di) o)li/gou a)pe/lqoimen, as to ei) mh\ a)fikoi/meqa. The possibility of the victory of the Athenians Nicias does not consider, and thus leaves a break in his argument.
u(perido/ntes: katafronh/santes h(mw=n Schol. Cf. 5. 6. 15, 43. 10.
pepo/nqate...e)fi/esqe : (restored for e)fi/esqai of Mss.) for the asyndeton, cf. 2. 60. 13 dra=te . . . a)fi/esqe.
pro\s a(\ e)fobei=sqe to\ prw=ton : in comparison with what you feared at first.

xrh\ de\ mh\ pro\s ta\s tu/xas...qarsei=n : cf. the similar admonition of King Archidamus 1. 84. § 3, where tu/xh is characterized as the always uncertain element and chief stress is laid upon dia/noiai. And as there dia/noiai of opponents are represented as like one's own, that one may not count upon enemies' mistakes, so here confidence (qarsei=n) is based only upon ta\s dianoi/as krath=sai, i.e. on being superior to the enemy in well-considered plans. With this view ta\s dianoi/as is not object (see on 1. 108. 19) but limiting acc. The sense of the passage is: “You must not be elated at the mishaps of your opponents, but only when you have got the better of them (sc. au)tw=n) in your calculations and plans, should you be confident.” dia/noiai in Nicias' sense are then set forth in mhde\ *lakedaimoni/ous . . . meletw=sin.

a)/llo ti h)/ : for this elliptical const., see on 2. 16. 10; 3. 39. 10. H. 612; Kr. Spr. 62, 3, 7; Kühn. 587, 18.—dia\ to\ ai)sxro/n: on account of their humiliation. Cf. 10. 8 e)k tou= ai)sxi/onos. On Thuc.'s fondness for the neut. adj. or ptc. = abstract noun, see Trans. Amer. Phil. Assoc. XXV, 75.

to\ sfe/teron a)prepe\s eu)= qh/sontai: retrieve their own discredit. Cf. 5. 46. 7 e)n tw=| e)kei/nwn a)prepei=. For eu)= qh/sontai, cf. 1. 75. 16.— 25. o(/sw|: by as much as. Cf. 78. 5, and see on 1. 68. 11.—peri\ plei/stou kai\ dia\ plei/stou: in the highest degree and for the longest time. Cf. 1. 124. 12 dia\ plei/onos, in a longer period.

w(/ste ou)...ei) swfronou=men : for a perfect parallel, cf. 3. 44. 2. On such brachylogy, see Steup, Thuk. Stud. II, 18.—e)n *sikeli/a|, a)ndrw=n barba/rwn: in disdainful rejection of an occasion at once far off and unworthy. Cf. a)ndra/sin a)llofu/lois 9. 5.

po/lin di) o)ligarxi/as e)pibouleu/ousan : a state (i.e. Sparta) under an oligarchy intriguing against us. The emphasis is on the antithesis in the political constitution. dia/ with gen. to indicate the conditions under which a thing happens, as 4. 8. 39; 7. 40. 10, and freq. —o)ce/ws fulacw/meqa: keep a sharp watch upon. The aor. subjv. with the majority of the Mss., for fulaco/meqa. Where the form of the verb does not remove all doubt (as a)posth/sontai 1. 57. 21; a)nti/sxh| 1. 65. 6; eu(/rwsi 3. 49. 6; o)fqw=si 3. 81. 4), in most cases only Mss. authority can decide between
fut. indic. and aor. subjv. See St., Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 25 f.

It would be foolish if we risked our strength, just recovered, for strangers whom we cannot trust, and from whom even under the most favorable conditions we should receive no proper thanks; or sacrificed it to the selfish plans of an ambitious young man not yet old enough to command an army.
newsti\...lelwfh/kamen : cf. 26. 6. lwfa=n, recover, rather rare, and used by Thuc. with reference to sicknesses and grave misfortunes. Cf. 2. 49. 16; 7. 77. 13.

braxu/ ti: a little, somewhat. Cf. 1. 63. 11.—kai\ xrh/masi kai\ toi=s sw/masin: in such combinations of xrh/mata and sw/mata Thuc. usually puts the art. with both (1. 121. 12; 2. 53. 7; 8. 45. 27, 65. 16), whereas in 1. 141. 18 the art. is omitted with both. Cl. suggests that the art. emphasizes sw/masi here as the more important word. For art. similarly placed with sw/mata, cf. 1. 143. 29 th/n te o)lo/fursin mh\ oi)kiw=n kai\ gh=s poiei=sqai, a)lla\ tw=n swma/twn, and Dem. 22. 55.

kai\ tau=ta...a)nalou=n : and these things we must consider it right to expend for ourselves here. tau=ta, i.e. these recovered resources in money and men, put first for emphasis. di/kaion ei)=nai still dependent on memnh=sqai, or rather on a word like nomi/zein that was before the mind instead of memnh=sqai, with transition from o(/ti const. to inf. e)nqa/de put for esp. emphasis between di/kaion and ei)=nai. Cl. and Steup construe the clause as independent (di/kaion sc. e)sti) and take e)nqa/de ei)=nai as an adv. phrase, “within our own sphere of action.” See App.

fuga/dwn: in his aversion to the Egestaeans (cf. 10. 21, 11. 27, 21. 6) Nicias transfers the situation of the Leontines to the former (cf. 8. § 2; 19, § 1). On the word, see App.—fuga/dwn tw=nde: without art. before rel. sent., as 2. 74. 11, and freq.
to\ yeu/sasqai kalw=s: kalw=s, dexterously, as in kalw=s tou=to dra=n 1. 5. 11.

tw=| tou= pe/las kindu/nw| : at their neighbor's risk. Cf. 1. 12. The sing. tou= pe/las as 1. 32. 16; 2. 37. 12. For dat. expressing attendant circumstances, cf. 85. 8.—au(tw=n: put forward with pregnant emphasis, for themselves, on their own part. au(tw=n, Bk.'s emendation for au)tw=n of nearly all the Mss., has been generally adopted. For the matter, cf. 22. 13 f.
cunapole/sai: correctly restored by Reiske for cunapole/sqai of the Mss.

ei)/ te/ tis kte(.: new point emphatically introduced by te. In what follows Alcibiades is designated clearly
enough without his name.
a)/rxein a)/smenos ai(reqei/s: in contrast with Nicias 8. 18. Aor. ptc. here on acc. of the reference to the conduct of Alcibiades immediately described.
new/teros: too young. He was born about 450 B.C. See on 5. 43. 4.

o(/pws qaumasqh=| me\n kte(.: explains to\ e(autou= mo/non skopw=n, the first o(/pws clause expressing the ultimate object of his striving (to be admired for the raising of fine race horses; cf. 15. 11) without immediate reference to the Sicilian expedition; the second indicating, and that too even by its well-considered order of words (dia\ polute/leian put forward), the connection with that expedition (but because that is very expensive, [hoping] that he may get some advantage too from his command). “Generalships were usually the road to wealth.” Boeckh, Staatshaushaltung^{3} I, 569.— 12. mhde\ tou/tw| e)mpara/sxhte...e)llampru/nesqai : and do not even to this man afford opportunity, at the risk of the state, to make a personal display. mhde/ adds the warning against Alcibiades to that against the Egestaeans. e)n- in both verbs refers to the matter in hand and not to tw=| kindu/nw|. The question is not of display through military glory, but of the satisfaction of the lust for i(ppotrofi/a which Nicias aseribes to him. For similar compounds, cf. e)n diatri/bein 2. 18. 8; e)nstratopedeu=sai 2. 20. 10; e)neudaimonh=sai kai\ e)nteleuth=sai 2. 44. 5; e)nagwni/sasqai 2. 74. 13. e)mparasxei=n occurs also 7. 56. 21, elsewhere only in late writers; lampru/nomai in 16. 12.
tou\s toiou/tous: people of this sort, after tis, as 2. 63. 10.
to\ pra=gma me/ga ei)=nai: cf. peri\ mega/lwn pragma/twn 9. 5.

kai\ mh\ oi(=on newte/rous...metaxeiri/sai : and not such as younger people may determine and hastily (rashly) execute. Cl., St., Bm., and Hude read, with Pluygers (Mnem. XI, 92), newte/rous for newte/rw| of the Mss. The sing. between the plurals tou\s toiou/tous and ou(/s would be strange, and the const. of the dat. newte/rw| with oi(=on has no satisfactory explanation (7. 14. 4 oi(=o/n te . . . e)moi/ is quite a different const.). The pl. newte/rous is supported by the reply of Alcibiades 18. 27 h( *niki/ou . . . dia/stasis toi=s ne/ois e)s tou\s presbute/rous. Steup writes, with H. Stein, newte/rwn, as nearer the Mss. reading. For bouleu/esqai with acc. of neut. pron. or adj., cf. 23. 8; 1. 43. 10, 85. 11. metaxeiri/sai used only in act. by Thuc. See on 1. 13. 7.

In opposition to this man and his youthful following, I beg you earnestly for the good of the fatherland to vote against this dangerous enterprise, and let the Siceliotes settle their affairs for themselves; especially to declare to the Egestaeans that as they began the feud with the Selinuntians without us, so they may fight it out without us; and in future to avoid all alliances in which only sacrifice and no advantage can be foreseen.

ou(/s: referring to newte/rous above. It would be hard to justify the plural here with newte/rw| there.—tw=| au)tw=| a)ndri\ parakeleustou/s: urged on by the same man (i.e. Alcibiades) to the support of his plans. parakeleustou/s = parakeklhme/nous (Schol.), as shown by the antithesis toi=s presbute/rois a)ntiparakeleu/omai mh\ kte(.
mh\ kataisxunqh=nai : not to be shamed into fear.

o(/pws mh\ do/ch| malako\s ei)=nai: lest he may seem to be weak. Sing. on account of tis in ei) clause. For obj. clause after verb of fear or caution, see GMT. 370. Of the better Mss. only Laur, reads do/cei.
a)/n : = e)a/n, as 18. 34; 4. 46. 13, and in some Mss. 8. 75. 19. St. writes everywhere e)a/n.

au)toi/ : i.e. the new/teroi just designated by tw=nde (3).—duse/rwtas ei)=nai tw=n a)po/ntwn: to be sick in love with; as second member depending on a)ntiparakeleu/omai, and with resumption of the plural. du/serws (so accented acc. to Herodian 1. p. 244) in Attic prose elsewhere prob. only in Xen. Oec. 12. 13 and Lys. 4. 8. Cf. Eur. Hipp. 193; Theocr. 1. 85. For the thought, cf. Pind. P. 3. 20 ff.— 6. katorqou=tai: so for katorqou=ntai of the Mss. (1) because neither in Thuc. nor elsewhere have we a certain example of the middle of this compound, and (2) because in a proverbial sent. of this kind the omission of oi( a)/nqrwpoi with the plural verb is strange. For the pass., cf. 1. 120. 25; 2. 65. 28; 4. 76. 21.

me/giston dh\ tw=n pri/n: the gen. prob. felt as part., though the limited word does not belong to the sphere of the gen. See on a)ciologw/taton tw=n progegenhme/nwn 1. 1. 4. Kr. Spr. 47, 28, 10; Kühn. 349 b, 4.
ki/ndunon a)narriptou/shs: running the risk; as 4. 85. 13, 95. 5. Cf. 5. 103. 3. The figure is from the game of dice.
oi(=sper nu=n o(/rois xrwme/nous: = xrwme/nous toi=s o(/rois oi(=sper nu=n xrw=ntai.

ou) memptoi=s : not to be found fault with (ironical).—
10. para\ gh=n: for emphasis before the verb. With this order the nonrepetition of h)/n tis ple/h| with dia\ pela/gous is more natural.

tw=| *sikelikw=|: sc. ko/lpw| from l. 10, though this sea is called pe/lagos in 4. 24. 20, 53. 15. So we have *turshniko\n pe/lagos 4. 24. 19; *turshniko\s po/ntos 7. 58. 6, as well as *turshniko\s ko/lpos 62. 7.

dia\ pela/gous : i.e. through the open sea without touching at intervening islands. See on 3. 4. 20.—ta\ au(tw=n nemome/nous: possessing their own territory, as 1. 2. 6; 2. 15. 13, 72. 10.—kaq' au(tou\s kai\ cumfe/resqai: to settle also their differences among themselves. Cf. 4. 65. 2 au)toi\ kata\ sfa=s au)tou\s cunhne/xqhsan gnw/mh|.

toi=s d' *)egestai/ois i)di/a| ei)pei=n: still dependent, as is also mh\ poiei=sqai (15), on a)ntiparakeleu/omai. So editors generally construe, but Steup governs ei)pei=n by yhfi/zesqai, though he agrees that mh\ poiei=sqai must depend on a)ntiparakeleu/omai.
kai\ cunh=yan...kai\ katalu/esqai : correlation of the dependent and leading clauses. Cf. 1. 83. 7.
meta\ sfw=n au)tw=n: sarcastic repetition of a)/neu *)aqhnai/wn.
katalu/esqai : to settle differences. See on 1. 81. 9.— 15. oi(=s: supply as antecedent tou/tous or toiou/tous.
kakw=s pra/casin : faring ill. Cf. 75. 17; 2. 64. 8; 5. 9. 36.
w)feli/as d)...teuco/meqa : supply par' w(=n with teuco/meqa, or possibly w)=n, dependent along with w)feli/as on dehqe/ntes (cf. 1. 32. 23).
Therefore I call upon the prytanis, as his civic duty demands, even though the law forbids, again to put the matter to a vote.

pru/tani: who as e)pista/ths presided on this day. The full title was e)pista/ths tw=n pruta/newn. See Hermann, Gr. Staatsalt.^{6} p. 491, N. 4.—tau=ta: with e)piyh/fize, bring these matters to a vote. Cf. 1. 87. 1; 2. 24. 6; 8. 15. 7.—h(gei=: this form of the second sing. mid. is rightly preferred by St. (Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 62) to h(gh=|. Cf. 1. 129. 16 u(pisxnei=, the only other instance in Thuc. of this person.—soi/: emphatic, hence orthotone.

kh/desqai: always of especially thoughtful sympathy. Cf. 76. 9, 84. 1.—bou/lei: added in second clause, although the preceding te looked to a dependence of both inf. clauses on h(gei= soi\ prosh/kein.

poli/ths a)gaqo/s : pregnant, a good citizen, i.e. a true patriot. Cf. 9. 8; 3. 42. 22.—
3. gnw/mas proti/qei au)=qis *)aqhnai/ois: lay the question once more before the Athenians. Cf. 3. 36. 21. For the dat., cf. 1. 139. 18.

a)nayhfi/sai: to put again to vote. Our passage indicates that this was illegal, although the same course in the Mytilenaean affair (3. 36. 21, 49. 1) seems to meet with no objection. Perhaps it had been made illegal in the meanwhile.—to\ me\n lu/ein tou\s no/mous: considered by Cl. and Steup a sort of abs. acc. (cf. 1. 141. 8, 142. 6; 4. 62. 1, 63. 3), as to breaking the laws, and not the subj. of ai)ti/an sxei=n, since Thuc. uses this only of persons (46. 26; 1. 39. 11, 83. 8; 3. 13. 34; 4. 114. 26). With this const. su/ must be understood from nomi/sas as subj. of ai)ti/an sxei=n. But it seems most natural, with St., F. Müller, and Widmann, to construe to\ lu/ein tou\s no/mous as subj. of ai)ti/an sxei=n (cf. Plato Phileb. 23 A h(donh\ a)/n tina kai\ a)timi/an sxoi/h), notwithstanding the force of Kr.'s objection that with a change of subj. we should expect in the second clause au)to\s de\ th=s po/lews.
mh/ : for mh/ with inf. instead of ou) after a verb of thinking, see GMT. 685; Gildersleeve, A. J. of Phil. I, 49.

th=s de\ po/lews bouleusame/nhs i)atro\s a)\n gene/sqai: and of the state that has made a decision you could become a physician, i.e. the decree of the Athenians with reference to Sicily is, acc. to Nicias, a disease which requires healing from the e)pista/ths as physician (cf. 5. 65. 7 kako\n kakw=| i)a=sqai). Steup considers th=s po/lews bouleusame/nhs dependent on i)atro/s, a further example of the const. of noun with pred. ptc. discussed in App. to 4. 63. 2. That the decree was bad need not be emphatically reasserted, hence kakw=s, found in some inferior Mss. after po/lews, may be regarded as a gloss, though the Schol. (kai\ th=s po/lews i)atro\s genh/sh| kakw=s boulensame/nhs) seems to support that reading.
tou=t) ei)=nai, o(\s a)\n...w)felh/sh| : free connection of pers. rel. pron. with neut. dem. as 2. 44. 4; 7. 68. 3. Kr. Spr. 51, 13, 11; Kühn. 563, 3 d. Cf. 16. 15; 2. 62. 30.
e(kw\n ei)=nai: willingly. For the abs., seemingly pleonastic, inf., see GMT. 780; Kr. Spr. 55, 1, 1. Cf. 2. 89. 29; 4. 98. 14; 7. 81. 14.
Nicias is opposed especially by Alcibiades. Reflections follow on the latter's motives in urging the Sicilian expedition and on his lawless life, which later became so dangerous to the state.

e)nh=ge: with obj. of the thing, as
1. 67. 8; 2. 21. 20. See on 4. 21. 8.— 4. boulo/menos tw=| te *niki/a| kte(.: correl. to te is kai\ ma/lista (6). From the arrangement in the first member e)piqumw=n kai\ e)lpi/zwn was not to be expected after boulo/menos. See on 14. 2.

w)\n kai\ e)s ta\ a)/lla dia/foros ta\ politika/: being also in general his political opponent, which is emphasized by the addition of kai\ o(/ti . . . e)mnh/sqh. ta\ politika/ belongs to dia/foros (cf. 8. 96. 24 dia/foroi to\n tro/pon), hence is not to be bracketed with Weidner (Parerga Dinarch. et Thuc. p. 21) as unnecessary with e)s ta\ a)/lla.
diabo/lws : invidiously; with reference to 12. § 2.—strathgh=sai: ingressive.
e)lpi/zwn...lh/yesqai : cf. 90. § 2.—*sikeli/an te...kai\ ta\ i)/dia a(/ma : for the correlation freq. in Thuc., see on 3. 102. 24.—di) au)tou=: i.e. tou= strathgei=n. See on 11. 12.
ta\ i)/dia...w)felh/sein : will help his private fortunes. —eu)tuxh/sas: cond., in case of success.
w)\n ga\r...u(po\ tw=n a)stw=n : being held in high consideration by the citizens. For the const., see on 1. 130. 3. For the matter, cf. 5. 43. § 2.

h)\ kata\...ou)si/an : than was appropriate to his means. Cf. 1. 76. 17; 2. 50. 2; 5. 102. 2. His property was considerable, but not more than 100 talents, acc. to Lys. 19. 52. See Boeckh, Stsh.^{3} I, 568 f.— e)s ta\s i(ppotrofi/as: i.e. for chariotracing. Cf. 12. 11.
o(/per: and that very thing, i.e. his uncontrolled disposition and extravagant ways.

th=s...paranomi/as e)s th
 di/aitan : his personal lawlessness (selfindulgence) in his manner of living. Cf. 28. 12 th
 au)tou= e)s ta\ e)pithdeu/mata . . . paranomi/an. Note the omission of the art. with the second modifier (e)s th
 di/aitan) of th=s paranomi/as, as 55. 5.

kai\ th=s dianoi/as...e)/prassen : and the greatness of purpose in all that he set before himself in every matter wherein he was active. th=s dianoi/as is still dependent upon to\ me/geqos, and w)=n = tou/twn a(/. gi/gnoito is iterative opt.

w(s turanni/dos...a)xqesqe/ntes : on the ground that he was aiming at a tyranny, and because, though publicly
he had managed military matters excellently, privately they had as individuals been offended at his practices, they had become hostile. pole/mioi kaqe/stasan is inserted between the two causal clauses, correlated by kai/(w(s . . . e)piqumou=nti and dhmosi/a| . . . a)xqesqe/ntes), which depend on it. Cf. 17. 9, 68. 18; 1. 121. 1; 4. 15. 6. St. takes kai/ (before dhmosi/a|)—kai/per and separates the clause i)di/a| . . . a)xqesqe/ntes by commas. But there is no reason why kai/ may not be and, the ptc. diaqe/nti being still construed as concessive.— 16. diaqe/nti: the correct reading from a single inferior Ms. (H.), for diaqe/nta of the rest. See App.

e(/kastoi: the plural arouses suspicion here where neither states nor groups can be thought of; van H. writes e(/kastos. See on 46. 20. —toi=s e)pithdeu/masin au)tou=: on account of his manner of life (cf. 28. 12). For causal dat. in addition to obj. dat., see on 4. 87. 13.

a)/llois e)pitre/yantes: th\n po/lin is common obj. of the ptc. and of e)/sfhlan. a)/llois refers above all to the successors of Alcibiades in the position of foremost citizen (tou= dh/mou prostasi/a 2. 65. 49).—ou) dia\ makrou=: as 91. 12,—d<*>) o)li/gou (see on 11. 14), speedily. The position of ou) is due to reluctance to separate the prep. from its case. Cf. w(s ou) peri\ bra<*>/wn 1. 78. 1.
d' ou)=n: common in resumption after a digression. See on 1. 3. 19.— parelqw\n toi=s *)aqhnai/ois: for dat. with parelqw/n, cf. 19. 7, 32. 19, 35. 7, 72. 3.

div2.head: Speech of Alcibiades (16-18)
Speech of Alcibiades (16-18)
div2.p: It is my right above that of others to be at the head of an army; for the magnificence of my public appearance has often been a benefit to the state. Nor is it unjust if I have not esteemed every one my equal. People of my stamp may be burdensome while they live, but to posterity they become a boast. Furthermore, I manage public affairs as well as any other man. By the alliances in Peloponnesus and even by the lost battle of Mantinea I won respect for you from the Lacedaemonians.

kai\ prosh/kei e)moi/: (the emphatic form of the pron. seems necessary as opp. to e(te/rwn) referring to family prestige, kai\ a)/cios a(/ma nomi/zw to personal merit. As only the second claim is dwelt upon in what follows, kai\ . . . kai\ . . . a(/ma is like our “as . . . so also.” See on 72. 22, 79. 1, and 4. 64. 18.—e(te/rwn: = h)\ e(te/rois, as 1. 85. 6; 2. 15. 1, 60. 21. H. 643 b; Kühn. 543, 2c.<*>2. e)nteu=qen: from that point, i.e. with a personal matter.—e)peidh\...kaqh/yato : 12. § 2. kaqa/yasqai, attack, also 82. 2.<*>3. e)pibo/hto/s ei)mi: I
am railed at. Cf. e)pibow/menos below (28).
tau=ta: at the end for emphasis.
kai\ u(pe\r du/namin...e)no/misan : they formed an idea of our state even greater than its actual power. The aor. is ingressive. Note the pleonasm in u(pe\r du/namin mei/zw.
tw=| e)mw=| diaprepei= th=s...qewri/as : neut. adj. for abstr. subst. = th=| diaprepei= qewri/a| mou. Cf. 2. 61. 8 tw=| u(mete/rw| a)sqenei= th=s gnw/mhs.

th=s *)olumpi/aze qewri/as : *)olumpi/aze due to the usual const. of qewrei=n. Cf. qewrei=n e)s ta\ *)efe/sia 3. 104. 17; qewrei=n e)s ta\ *)/isqmia 8. 10. 2. The date of the festival here mentioned must be assumed to be Ol. 91 = 416 B.C. (see G. H. Förster, Die Ol. Sieger bis z. Ende des 4. Jhdts., Progr. v. Zwickau, 1891, p. 20 f.). pro/teron . . . katapepolemh=sqai is decidedly against Ol. 89 = 424, since the Athenians at that time had the upper hand of their enemies (cf. 4. 65. § 4, 79. § 2). In Ol. 90 = 420, the date suggested by Cl. and Grote, Lichas, the Lacedaemonian, was victor (5. 50. § 4). As Alcibiades speaks first of his private life, the battle of Mantinea (fought in 418) could not well be mentioned before the Olympic victory.— 7. e)lpi/zontes au)th\n katapepolemh=sqai: hoping that it had been exhausted by war (cf. 90. 16). This hope was, even if thought of as lasting till 416, quite intelligible in the light of 12. § 1 and 26. § 2.
kaqh=ka: misi in certamen. Cf. Isocr. 16. 34.—i)diw/ths: as opp. to a basileu/s or po/lis.

deu/teros kai\ te/tartos e)geno/mhn : in the Euripidean e)pini/kion (apud Plut. Alcib. 11) we read a(/rmati prw=ta dramei=n kai\ deu/tera kai\ tri/ta, and in Isocr. l.c. w(/ste kai\ prw=tos kai\ deu/teros gene/sqai kai\ tri/tos. Possibly the deviation in our passage from these statements may be due to corruption in the text,—though, if so, the corruption antedated Plutarch's time,—to be remedied by changing te/tartos to tri/tos or by inserting kai\ tri/tos before kai\ te/tartos.
ta)=lla...pareskeuasa/mhn : for particulars, see Isocr. l.c., Plut. Alcib. 12, and Athen. 1. 3 E.—no/mw|: according to custom.

timh/: sc. e)sti. In the thought the clause no/mw| . . . toiau=ta is subord. to the second member, which alone contains proof for oi( *(/ellhnes kai\ u(pe\r du/namin kte(. (5 f.). See on 9. 11.—e)k de\ tou= drwme/nou...u(ponoei=tai : and from that which is done an impression of power also is gained.

o(/sa...lampru/nomai : in whatever
respects I distinguish myself (cf. e)llampru/nesqai used by Nicias 12. 13). This furnishes the subj. of fqonei=tai.
toi=s a)stoi=s : for dat. of agent with pass., see on 3. 64. 15, and Steup, Thuk. Stud. II, 55 f., C. F. Smith, Trans. Amer. Phil. Assoc. XXV, 71 f.

kai\ au(/th: this too, i.e. as well as the Olympic qewri/a. The pron. is assimilated in gen. and number to the pred.—h(/d' h( a)/noia: so with M alone of the better Mss. for h( dia/noia. That a)/noia is correct is shown not only by the context but also by the Schol. ei)rwneu/etai le/gwn o(/ti, ei) kai\ a)no/htos fai/nomai/ tisin, a)ll' ou)=n th=| po/lei ou)k a)/xrhsto/s e)sti/ mou h( a)/noia, and by the repetition in 17. 1 h( e)mh\ neo/ths kai\ a)/noia. Even though Nicias did not use the word in 12. § 2, it was clearly implied there.— h( a)/noia, o(\s a)/n: for the loose connection of the rel., see on 14. 6 and cf. 7. 68. 3.
te/lesi: = dapa/nais (Schol.). Cf. 4. 60. 12.
ou)de/ ge a)/dikon kte(.: blunt expression of aristocratic self-assertion, and it is not unfair that one who has a great opinion of himself is not on an equality, etc.

mh\ i)/son ei)=nai: as i)somoirei= (18) rather of view or feeling than of actual condition: the one does not consider himself on an equality, the other does not claim to share his misfortune with others.

w(/sper dustuxou=ntes ou) prosagoreuo/meqa: as when pursued by fate we are not spoken to, i.e. our society is avoided. dustuxou=ntes is stronger than kakw=s pra/ssontes, the latter of a transitory stage, the former of persistent pursuit by tu/xh. The sense here assumed for prosagoreuo/meqa is so natural that neither Kr.'s proshgoreu/meqa nor Madvig's prosarkou/meqa would be an improvement.

u(perfronou/menos: for the suppl. pte. with a)nexe/sqw, cf. 1. 77. 18; 2. 74. 3; 5. 69. 8. GMT. 879; H. 983.— h)\...a)ntaciou/tw : the stress is on ta\ i)/sa ne/mwn: otherwise (h)/ = ei) de\ mh/) let him give equality and then claim the like in turn. a)ntaciou=n elsewhere only in post-classical writers. See App. on 4. 80. 4.

tou\s toiou/tous: i.e. men of my spirit; perhaps not without parodying reference to 12. 14, since it is the same persons that are represented, there in the worst, here in the best light.—kai\ o(/soi: and all others that. Cf. 71. 16, 76. 14; 1. 95. 3.—tinos: sc. pra/gmatos
(Schol.).

e)n tw=| kat' au)tou\s bi/w|: in their own lifetime.—luphrou/s: give offense, excite envy. Cf. 1. 76. 5, 99. 4. For the thought, cf. 2. 45. § 1.— 23. cuno/ntas: so long as they are with them, cum versentur cum eis (Pp.). The word seems unnecessary and is suspected by Steup to be a gloss.— tw=n...a)nqrw/pwn : part. gen. dependent on tisi.
prospoi/hsin cuggenei/as : claim of kinship.—kai\ mh\ ou)=san: even when not existing, the ptc. agreeing formally with prospoi/hsin, but in sense with cuggenei/as. St. and Steup write ou)/shs.
au)/xhsin : exulting pride, i.e. occasion for boasting. The word only here in Thuc.; elsewhere only in postclassical writers. Cf. au)/xhma 2. 62. 28; 7. 66. 15, 75. 37; au)xei=n 2. 39. 18.
w(s ou) peri\ a)llotri/wn : for w(s peri\ ou) from reluctance to separate the prep. from its case. Cf. 1. 78. 1.

w(=n: neut. (as dia\ tau=ta shows), summing up what precedes, i.e. a position like this, which in life excites envy, but after death admiration.— 28. ta\ i)/dia e)pibow/menos: assailed in my private life. Cf. 3 above.
metaxeiri/zw: doubtless intentional repetition of Nicias' word in 12. 16.—*peloponnh/sou ta\ dunatw/tata: i.e. Argos, Mantinea, and Elis.
