u(mi=n: note the emphatic position, as 1. 47. 5; 3. 61. 7; 7. 78. 26.—e)s mi/an h(me/ran...a)gwni/sasqai : and upon a single day I forced the Lacedaemonians to stake all at Mantinea. e)s mi/an h(me/ran, under the influence of kate/sthsa for e)n mia=| h(me/ra|, which v. H. would write. Cf. 4. 89. 6; 8. 67. 5. For kate/sthsa with inf., cf. 2. 84. 24.
e)n *mantinei/a|: 5. 66 ff.
kai\ perigeno/menoi th=| ma/xh|: though victorious on the field (418 B.C.).—ou)de/pw kai\ nu=n: i.e. after three years.

Use both my fresh young vigor and the tried luck of Nicias, and do not abandon the Sicilian expedition out of baseless fear. We shall not have there to contend with a great power; besides, against the Syracusans we
shall find allies in the Sicels. And for the enemies whom we leave behind here, we shall be more than a match by reason of our fleet.

kai\ tau=ta...e)/peise : thus did my youthful folly, which is thought to be abnormal, deal with (consort with) the power of the Peloponnesians in fitting words and with an impetuosity that inspired faith win assent. This is substantially St.'s rendering; for Cl.'s and Steup's views, see App.—tau=ta: cognate acc. with w(mi/lhse (= tau/thn th\n o(mili/an w(mi/lhse, cf. 2. 37. 14 ta\ i)/dia prosomilou=ntes), as with e)/peise.
para\ fu/sin dokou=sa ei)=nai : i.e. transcending the bounds of even youthful folly.

e)s th\n *peloponnhsi/wn du/namin: either (1) the power of the Peloponnesians in general, i.e. the Lacedaemonian power as well as the confederacy, or (2) the states referred to in 16. 29 *peloponnh/sou ta\ dunatw/tata. For du/namis, cf. 2. 7. 7 o(/soi h)=san e)kto\s th=s e(autw=n duna/mews.
lo/gois pre/pousin : i.e. suitable to the occasion.
o)rgh=| pi/stin parasxome/nh|: Kr.'s correction, with three good Mss., adopted by most editors for the Vulg. parasxome/nh.
pefo/bhsqe : necessary correction of Reiske for pefobh=sqai of the Mss.—au)th/n: i.e. th\n e)mh\n neo/thta kai\ a)/noian.
o( *niki/as eu)tuxh/s : cf. 5. 16. 4; 7. 77. 7.—a)poxrh/sasqe: make the most of. Cf. 1. 68. 20; 7. 42. 27.
mh\ metagignw/skete: as 3. 40. 5.— 7. o)/xlois...cummei/ktois : with motley crowds, i.e. of various race and so without community of feeling or interests.

poluandrou=sin: swarm with inhabitants. The word found elsewhere only in late writers.—tw=n politw=n ta\s metabola\s kai\ e)pidoxa/s: politw=n of E with Stahl, Steup, Hude, and the Oxford text, for politeiw=n of the rest of the Mss., which fits neither with e)pidoxa/s (which can only mean the reception of something additional) nor with the foll. sent., which clearly looks only to inhabitants here. Cf. 1. 2. 12 ma/lista th=s gh=s h( a)ri/sth ai)ei\ ta\s metabola\s tw=n oi)khto/rwn ei)=xen. e)pidoxa/s only here in Thuc.

di) au)to/: on this account, i.e. (the idea of the preceding sent.) because of mixed population and easy changes of condition.—w(s peri\ oi)kei/as patri/dos: as for his own fatherland, such conditions not tending to rouse a true fatherland-feeling. The order—for one would expect these words after ou)/te—is prob. due to the fact that the correlating of ta\ peri\ to\ sw_ma and ta\ e)n th=| xw/ra| was an afterthought. Some editors take ou)dei/s zeugmatically with the second ou)/te clause = no state.
But ou)dei/s must unquestionably mean the same for both clauses, and that individual persons are meant is proved not only by the expression ta\ peri\ to\ sw=ma, but also by e(/kastos (of the foll. sent.), which is the positive antithesis to the negative here.

ta\ peri\ to\ sw=ma: in matters pertaining to personal protection.—e)ch/rtutai: placed between its two dependent clauses. Cf. 15. 16. For the sense of the passage, cf. 1. 80. 10 kai\ toi=s a)/llois a)/pasi a)/rista e)ch/rtuntai, plou/tw| te i)di/w| kai\ dhmosi/w| kte(.

nomi/mois kataskeuai=s : with regular (or proper) equipments, i.e. in buildings ete. The Schol. explains nomi/mois by ou) tai=s nomizome/nais, a)lla\ tai=s i(kanai=s: ou(/tw kai\ no/mimon r(h/tora to
 i(kano
 kai\ no/mimon a)qlhth/n famen. St. and Cl. adopt the emendation of Dukas—moni/mois, permanent. —o(/ ti de\...tau=ta e(toima/zetai : but whatever each man thinks that he can obtain from the common stock by persuasive speech or by sedition, and settle with it elsewhere, in case of failure, that he provides for himself. “The obscurity of the latter part of the sentence arises from the principal idea being expressed by the participle and the subordinate idea by the verb” (Jowett). e)k tou= le/gwn pei/qein (lit. ‘from persuading byspeech’) is parallel to stasia/zwn. The reference is to colonization in consequence of popular decree or of sedition. For the epanaleptic tau=ta in plural after the collective o(/ ti, cf. Xen. Cyrop. 1. 6. 11 o(/ ti d' a)
 pro\s toi=s ei)rhme/nois lamba/nh| tis, tau=ta timh
 nomiou=si. Kr. Spr. 58, 4, 5. See App.
to\n toiou=ton o(/milon: a rabble of this kind. For Thuc.'s use—16 times in all—of the Ionic and poetic o(/milos, see C. F. Smith, Trans. Amer. Phil. Assoc. XXXI, 80.
w(s e(/kastoi: severally. See on 1. 3. 19.
ei)/ ti kaq' h(donh\n le/goito: i.e. by Athenian ambassadors.—prosxwroi=en: sc. h(mi=n.

kai\ mh\n...w(pli/sqh : the whole section, suspected by Cl. on the ground that it has nothing to do with the matter in hand, is bracketed by Steup and Müller. See App. It is generally agreed that it is at least an observation of Thuc. rather than of Alcibiades, who could hardly use e)n tw=|de tw=| pole/mw| when there had been at least a nominal peace for six years.

ou)/t) e)kei/nois o(/soiper kompou=ntai, ou)/te oi( a)/lloi *(/ellhnes kte(.: parataxis, though the second is really subord. to the first.—kompou=ntai: only here in Thuc., and rare
in prose. Cf. ko/mpos 2. 40. 3, 41. 5; kompw/dhs 2. 62. 7; 5. 68. 6.
me/giston: cogn. acc. with e)yeusme/nh.

e)/ti eu)porw/tera: explained by the parenthetical sent. (barba/rous . . . au)toi=s).—barba/rous [te] ga\r pollou/s : i.e. many Sicels. Cf. 88. § 3 ff.; 3. 103. § 1. Haacke was the first to bracket the inexplicable te.
e)pikwlu/sei : rare word, Cf. Xen. Occ. 8. 4; Soph. Phil. 1242.

oi( ga pate/res...th
 a)rxh
 e)kth/santo : the stress is on kai\ prose/ti to
 *mh=don e)xqro
 e)/xontes, the argument being that the Athenians had at the time when they acquired their supremacy a foreign as well as a domestic foe.

fasi: i.e. Nicias and his followers.—u(polipo/ntas: the Mss. ABE give u(polei/pontas, which Bk. and Cl. adopt, but most of the rest rightly adopt the aor. Cf. 36. 13; 8. 82. 8; and esp. 10. 1, to which our passage refers.

kai\ nu=n: paratactically correlated with oi( pate/res h(mw=n. Cf. kai\ nu=n above (3). The argument is: ‘as our fathers established their sway even against a double enemy, so our enemies havenothingserious to hope (wenothing material to fear); irruptionsinto Attica they may still make without great harm to us.’—ou)/te a)ne/lpistoi...e)ge/nonto : never were the Peloponnesians more hopeless against us. a)ne/lpistoi act. as 3. 30. 6; 8. 1. 15. Cf. to\ a)ne/lpisto<*> 2. 51. 13. Elsewhere in Thuc. pass. 33. 22; 4. 55. 8. Kr. suggests that the passive force would suit the sense better,—“and so even now the Peloponnesians were never less to be expected against us,” —but that contradicts the foll. remark that nothing stands in the way of their irruptions by land.

ei)/ te: correl. to ou)/te. The argument is: ‘on the one hand, they never had less hope against us; on the other, even if they are ever so confident, they can do no considerable harm.’ In the paratactic arrangement (to\ me
 . . . e)sba/llein . . . i(kanoi/ ei)si, tw=| de\ nautikw=| . . . bla/ptein) the stress is on the second clause.—e)/rrwntai: in moral sense. See on 2. 8. 1.—to\ me

. . . e)sba/llein: to be taken as accus. of specification with i(kanoi/, as to\ me
 prostalaipwrei=n with pro/qumos 2. 53. 9.

There is, therefore, no reason for not fulfilling our treaty obligations to our Sicilian allies. Nor can we, if we would remain an imperial state, refrain from the expedition. Let us go, then, not only that we may abase the arrogance of the Peloponnesians, but also that we may either by the subjugation of Sicily win empire over all Hellenes or at least injure the Syracusans. Do not let yourselves be deterred by Nicias' advice, but in the spirit of your fathers allow scope to every period of life, and by stirring activity exercise and strengthen your powers. For an energetic state inactivity is ruin, and holding firmly to customs and laws is under all circumstances the greatest safety.

w(/ste ti/ a)\n le/gontes...mh\ bohqoi=men : what reasonable thing then can we say why we ourselves should shirk (the enterprise), or to our allies there by way of excuse why we should refuse to aid them. There is something incongruous in the arrangement of the sent. As it stands, ti/ le/gontes ei)ko/s belongs to both members. We should have expected in the second member skhptoi/meqa mh\ bohqei=n, but as the main idea of the second clause is expressed in a finite verb (bohqoi=men) to balance the main idea of the first (a)poknoi=men), so skhpto/menoi is felt as the antithesis to le/gontes, as if the first h)/ stood before that ptc.—au)toi/: antithetic to pro\s tou\s e)kei= cumma/ xous skhpto/menoi.

mh( bohqoi=men : mh/ because a neg. answer is implied. Kr. compares Dem. 23. 75 pw=s a)\n di/kaia tau)ta\ kai\ mh\ ge/noito; Xen. Mem. 3. 1. 10 ti/ ou) skopou=men pw=s a)\n au)tw=n mh\ diamarta/noimen;
xrew/n : without e)sti as in 9; 1. 77. 13; 2. 61. 17; 7. 73. 5.

e)peidh/ ge kai\ cunwmo/samen: especially as we have actually sworn to do so. For this intensive force of kai/, see Kr. Spr. 69, 32, 17. At least with the Leontines the Athenians had a sworn treaty. Cf. 19. § 1, and see App. on 6. 12.—a)ntitiqe/nai: to hold against, retort, in 2. 85. 8 and 3. 56. 16, with gen., to set against, contrast.— 4. o(/ti ou)de\ e)kei=noi: sc. e)ph/munan.
proseqe/meqa au)tou/s : attached them, nobis eos adiunximus, with accus. only here in Thuc., with dat. (se alicui adiungere) freq. Cf. 80. 12; 3. 11. 20; 8. 48. 29, 87. 25.
toi=s e)kei= e)xqroi=s h(mw=n: i.e. toi=s *surakosi/ois, who were e)xqroi/, even if not in open war pole/mioi.
ou(/tws: looks forward here, being explained by the ptc. clause paragigno/menoi kte(.
h)=rcan : ingressive=a)rxh\n e)kth/santo.

toi=s...e)pikaloume/nois : the attrib. ptc. placed after noun attended by other modifiers. See on 1. 11. 19. G. 969; Kühn. 464, 8.—h)\ barba/rois: referring to Nicias' reproach 11. 27 *)egestai/wn, a)ndrw=n barba/rwn.

e)pei/ : whereas. Cf. 2. 51. 21; 7. 30. 8.—fulokrinoi=en oi(=s xrew\n bohqei=n: distinguish by race whom we should aid. Cf. Bk.'s Aneed. 1, p. 71 (referring prob. to our passage) kuri/ws to\ ta\s fula\s (perhaps ta\ fu=la)ta\s e)n tai=s po/lesi diakri/nein.

braxu\ a)/n ti prosktw/menoi...kinduneu/oimen : some editors consider that a)/n is here not merely repeated (see on 4. 18. 17), but that the first a)/n belongs to the ptc., the second only to the verb. But for the thought one a)/n would have sufficed, since only the verb requires it. See on 5. 9. 16. —peri\ au)th=s tau/ths: i.e. th=s u(parxou/shs a)rxh=s.

kinduneu/oimen : from third to first person in transition from general remark to special condition. Steup adopts Hude's attractive conjecture in 1. 9 h(suxa/zoimen pa/ntws and fulokrinoi=men, thus avoiding transition here.

mh\ [o(/pws] e)/peisi prokatalamba/nei : takes precaution lest he shall come on. GMT. 370. For prokatalamba/nein, see on 1. 57. 15; 3. 2. 15. Pp. was first to bracket o(/pws. Cl. thought mh\ o(/pws might be understood as = o(/pws mh/, but free as Thuc. is in placing strougly emphatie words before the conjunction (see on <*> 10. 5) there is no parallel in Thuc. or elsewhere for such an inversion as mh\ o(/pws. Besides mh\ o(/pws elsewhere (Xen. Cyrop. 1. 3. 10), like ou)x o(/pws, means not only not. Some editors (e.g. Kr., Hude) transpose (o(/pws mh/), others (e.g. St., Bm.) adopt Haacke's conjecture mh/ pws. But o(/pws was prob. a marginal explanation added to mh/ which crept into the text.

tamieu/esqai e)s o(/son boulo/meqa a)/rxein: to calculate, reckon accurately, to what extent we will rule. tamieu/esqai, a term from the counter, only here in Thuc., but cf. tami/an gene/sqai 78. 14. Cf. Xen. Cyrop. 3. 3. 47 parado/ntes e(autou\s h(mi=n tamieu/esqai, w(/sq' o(po/sois a)\n boulw/meqa ma/xesqai. Strabo, 4. 196 c, prettily applies the action to the cautious warfare of the Iberians, e)tami/euon kai\ katekerma/tizon tou\s a)gw=nas.

e)n tw=|de : Cl. remarks not merely = e)n tw|
a)/rxein (Schol.), but more pregnant e)n tw=|de th=s a)rxh=s, “at the point of sway that we have reached,” as expressed also by the pf. kaqe/stamen. But that is implied in the Schol. e)n tw=| a)/rxein.

a)nie/nai : let go, turn loose. Though Thuc. does not use the verb elsewhere with accus. of pers., the const. is common enough in other Attic writers.— dia\ to\ a)rxqh=nai a)\n u(f' e(te/rwn: because we might come under the domination of others. Cf. 7. 62. 8 dia\ to\ bla/ptein a)\n to\ th=s e)pisth/mhs th=| baru/thti tw=n new=n. For the bracketed words [au)toi=s ki/ndunon ei)=nai], see App.

kai\ ou)k...to\ h(/suxon : and you must not regard inaction in the same light as others.— 17. e)k tou= au)tou=: cf. e)k tou= o(moi/ou 78. 24, 87. 23; e)k tou= i)/sou 2. 3. 19.—e)piskepte/on : cf. Schol. to\ e)piskepte/on a)nti\ tou= e)pithdeute/on te/qeiken. The verb only here in Thuc.—toi=s a)/llois: dat. with e)k tou= au)tou=. G. 1175; H. 773 a; S. 1500.—to\ h(/suxon: neut. adj. stronger than the abstract th\n h(suxi/an. See C. F. Smith, Trans. Amer. Phil. Assoc. XXV, 75.—ei) mh\...metalh/yesqe : unless you will change your conduct also to the like. Cf. e)s to\ i)/son kaqista/nai 1. 121. 15. See on metala/bete 87. 23, and cf. metalamba/nein, take in exchange, 1. 120. 16. ta\ e)pithdeu/mata, lit. practices, the sum or consistent carrying out of which individual acts is e)pith/deusis. See on 1. 32. 10; 2. 37. 11.
ta/de: ta\ e)ntau=qa pra/gmata Schol. —e)p' e)kei=na: for emphasis before conj. See on 1^{4}. 10. 5.

store/swmen to\ fro/nhma: the Schol. remarks tw=n para\ *qoukudi/dh| tropikw=n o)noma/twn to\ sklhro/taton tou=to/ e)sti, a)lla\ kata\ *)alkibia/dhn fhsi/n. The figure is taken from the stilling of stormy waves. e)sto/resen de\ qeo\s megakh/tea po/nton Hom. g 158 (cf. Hdt. 7. 193. 2). Cf. store/sai th\n o)rgh/n Aesch. Prom. 190; *)aqhnai=oi *maraqw=ni xrusofo/rwn *mh/dwn e)sto/resan du/namin (inscription apud) Lycurg. c. Leocr. 109; sternet Poenos Gallumque rebellem Verg. Aen. 6. 858; stratis iam militum odiis Tac. Hist. 1. 58. Imitations in Plut. Lucull. 5; Caes. 25. See C. F. Smith, Trans. Amer. Phil. Assoc. XXXI, 75.

ei) do/comen: if we shall seem, i.e. if it shall be said of us.—u(perido/ntes: see on 11. 17.— th\n e)n tw=| paro/nti h(suxi/an: our present quiet; directed esp. against the reproach of Nicias 11. 20 katafronh/santes h)/dh kai\ *sikeli/as e)fi/esqe. What Nicias condemns, Alcibiades commends. Note kai\ (even) e)pi\ *sikeli/an here as kai\ *sikeli/as there.

kai\ a(/ma h)/ th=s *(ella/dos...a)/rcwmen, h)\ kakw/swme/n ge kte(.:
still dependent on i(/na (20). For the correlation te . . . kai\ a(/ma, see App. on 4. 27. 4. Cl.'s restoration of the subjv. for the fut. (a)/rcomen and kakw/somen) is approved by Steup and Hude. Most editors accept the future and explain it as anacoluthic transition to independent const. But it seems more natural to continue the sentence as it began and express the chief goal of Aleibiades' ambition as something aimed at.— 23. tw=| ei)ko/ti: in all probability. Found only here; elsewhere Thuc. uses ei)ko/tws, e)k tou= ei)ko/tos, kata\ to\ ei)ko/s.
e)n w(=| : i.e. tw=| kakw=sai *surakosi/ous (Schol.).— oi( cu/mmaxoi: i.e. the allies in Sicily. —w)felhso/meqa: fut. mid. as pass., as 7. 67. 16.

to\ de\ a)sfale/s: obj. of pare/cousi and explained by kai\ me/nein, kai\ a)pelqei=n. Kr. renders (on the analogy of to\ de\ me/giston) what however is (or assures) security. Steup, satisfied with neither explanation, commends Gertz's conjecture to\ de\ a)sfalw=s.

h)/n ti proxwrh=| : Reiske's correction, with three inferior Mss., for prosxwrh=|. The question can only be of success in general here, not of the adhesion of new allies. For the expression, cf. 74. 11; 2. 5. 2; and Sall. Jug. 35. 4 sin id parum procedat.

pare/cousi: naukra/tores: Valekenaer's correction for pare/cousin: au)tokra/tores of all the Mss. Cf. 5. 97. 5, 109. 7. For gen. dependent on naukra/tores St. compares Hdt. 5. 36. 11 naukrate/es th=s qala/sshs.
h( *niki/ou kte(.: the art. covers both a)pragmosu/nh and dia/stasis.
*niki/ou tw=n lo/gwn : i.e. implied in Nicias' speech.

dia/stasis...presbute/rous : putting the young at variance with the older men. The unusual dat. (for tw=n ne/wn) Kr. explains as due to the desire to avoid another gen., along with *niki/ou tw=n lo/gwn, dependent on dia/stasis.

a)potre/yh| : so nearly all recent editors for a)postre/yh|, which, “in fig. sense is prob. nowhere permissible” (Kr.). Cf. 8. 21, 19. 6, and see on 4. 80. 2.—oi( pate/res h(mw=n...e)s ta/de h)=ran au)ta/ : it is doubtless intentional on the part of Thuc. to put into the mouth of Alcibiades, who would play the role of successor in Pericles' policy, almost the very words with which the latter just before the Peloponnesian War encourages the Athenians (1. 144. § 4): oi( gou=n pate/res h(mw=n u(posta/ntes *mh/dous . . . e)s ta/de proh/gagon au)ta/: w(=n ou) xrh\ lei/pesqai. Alcibiades, however, puts the merit of the fathers (i.e. of Pericles and his contemporaries) esp. in the fact that they, as the then young men, took counsel along with the older men (a(/ma ne/oi geraite/rois
bouleu/ontes), and uses this against the assertion of Nicias, 12. 15 to\ pra=gma me/ga ei)=nai kai\ mh\ oi(=on newte/rous bouleu/sasqai/ te kai\ o)ce/ws metaxeiri/sai. Cf. also the thoughts of Pericles 2. 36 with those of Alcibiades here.

a(/ma ne/oi geraite/rois bouleu/ontes: as young men counseling with older men, the ne/oi as part of the pate/res taking same case. See on 31. 16. Note the separation, as often, of the gram. connected words. —e)s ta/de h)=ran au)ta/: raised our power to this point. Cf. 1. 144. 25 e)s ta/de proh/gagon au)ta/.

to/ te fau=lon...kai\ to\ pa/nu a)kribe/s : Alcibiades ironically takes the standpoint of Nicias, as if youth in its thoughtlessness were of little use, while age has the advantage of most careful reflection.—a)
 cugkraqe
 ma/list' a)
 i)sxu/ein: a)/n repeated as in 1. 10 above.

a)
 me
 h(suxa/zh|: for a)/n = e)a/n, see on 13. 4.—tri/yesqai au)th
 peri\ au(th/n: will wear out of itself, i.e. without influence from outside. The verb as in 7. 42. 35. Cf. 8. 46. 13 au)tou\s peri\ e(autou\s tou\s *(/ellhnas katatri=yai. For the thought of the sent., cf. Liv. 30. 44 nulla magna civitas quiescere potest. si foris hostem non habet, domi invenit.

w(/sper kai\ a)/llo ti: just as also anything clse. Cf. 1. 142. 24.—pa/ntwn th
 e)pisth/mhn e)gghra/sesqai: sc. th
 po/lin, will grow old in knowledge of everything. So with St. and others. Cf. Liv. 1. 22. 2 senescere civitatem otio ratus undique materiam excitandi belli quaerebat. e)gghra/sesqai, i.e. will grow old e)n tw=| tri/besqai. See on e)llampru/nesqai 12. 13. Steup takes e)pisth/mhn as subj., explaining e)gghra/sesqai i.e. e)n au)th=|(th=| po/lei), and a)gwnizome/nhn he then makes agree with th
 po/lin as if no new subj. had intervened.

to\ a)mu/nesqai...ma=llon cu/nhqes e(/cein : will have self-defense more as a habit, opp. to the caution only theoretically recommended by Nicias (10. § 5, 11. § 7, 13. § 2). Cf. Sall. Jug. 85. 7 ita ad hoc aetatis a pueritia fui, ut omnes labores et pericula consueta habeam.
para/pan te gignw/skw: cf. the similar conclusion 37. 17 to/ te cu/mpan . . . h(gou=mai.

gignw/skw...moi dokei=n : I declare that in my opinion. gignw/skw being thus understood (= censeo), the pleonasm is relieved.—mh\ a)pra/gmona: not inactive in foreign politics.—
39. a)pragmosu/nhsmetabolh=|: by a change to political inactivity, recommended, acc. to Aleibiades (cf. 27 above) by Necias for Athens. Cf. h( e)nanti/a metabolh/, a change to the opposite, 2. 43. 26. In 76. 21 metabolh/ is exchange. Alcibiades is consciously using Pericles' terms with regard to the danger of an imperial state in keeping clear of foreign complications, though the situation is quite different. Cf. 2. 62. § 2, 3.

oi(\ a)\n toi=s parou=sin h)/qesi...h(/kista diafo/rws politeu/wsin : who in their politics are as little as possible at variance with established customs and laws, even when these are inferior. This view agrees in form and content with that of Cleon 3. 37. § 3. The dat. with the adv. diafo/rws as with the adj. Cf. diafe/resqai/ tini.
As the Athenians after Aleibiades' speech are more than ever in favor of the expedition, Nicias tries to frighten them by a strong picture of the efforts and the sacrifices that will be required.

toiau=ta me/n: Bk. expects toiau=ta de/, doubtless after the analogy of 88. 1; 1. 44. 1, 79. 1; 3. 49. 1, 68. 1. But here and in 41. 1 exceptions are made to the rule that after a speech in reply narration is resumed with de/, because in both these cases a further speech follows.

tw=n *)egestai/wn: it is quite natural that the ambassadors of the Egestaeans (8. § 1, 2) were present also in the ecclesia which was to determine about the equipment (8. § 3) of the fleet to be sent to Sicily.—*leonti/nwn: dependent on fuga/dwn, and only to *leonti/nwn fuga/dwn belongs oi(/. For the relations of the Leontines to Athens, cf. 3. 86. 12, and see App. on 6. 12; on the fortunes of the Leontines, cf. 5. 4. § 4 ff.; 6. 6. § 2. See App.
pollw=| ma=llon...strateu/ein : cf. 15. § 1.

a)po\ tw=n au)tw=n lo/gwn: for a)po/, by means of, cf. 1. 91. 28; 3. 48. 3; 7. 29. 6. Cf. e)k tw=n lo/gwn 1. 72. 11.— 7. e)pita/ceie: cf. 8. § 3.—parelqw\n au)toi=s au)=qis e)/lege toia/de: au)toi=s, as well as au)=qis, belongs to parelqw/n, see App.

div2.head: Second Speech of Nicias (20-23)
Second Speech of Nicias (20-23)
div2.p: May your undertaking be successful; but make up your minds to this, that you will find in Sicily itself only weak support, your enemies on the contrary numerous and wellequipped, especially in cavalry superior to you, and not dependent on imports of supplies from abroad.— 1. pa/ntws: under all circumstances. Cf. 5. 41. 19.

cunene/gkoi: act., as freq. in Hdt., in the sense of cumfe/resqai (1. 23. 4; 7. 44. 3; 8. 83. 4, 84. 1). —e)pi\ tw=| paro/nti: in view of present circumstances, as 2. 36. 18. See on pro\s to\ paro/n 2. 22. 1, and e)pi\ tou= paro/ntos 2. 54. 8.
shmanw=: as 2. 45. 8 and freq. in Thuc.; not common elsewhere in Attic prose.

e)pi\ ga\r po/leis kte(.: for introductory ga/r, see on 33. 7. The exposition from here to the end of the chap, is directed against the argument of Alcibiades (17. § 2 ff.) that in Sicily they will not have to deal with a mega/lh du/namis. Cf. 21. 1.—w(s e)gw\ a)koh=| ai)sqa/nomai: cf. Alcibiades' words 17. 22.
mega/las: cf. 7. 58. 20 oi( *sikeliw=tai au)toi\ . . . a(/te mega/las po/leis oi)kou=ntes.

ou)/q) u(phko/ous a)llh/lwn ou)de\ deome/nas : the first member of the neg. sent., as ou)/t' a)\n . . . prosdecame/nas (6) is the second, the former of the internal conditions of the Sicilian cities, the latter of their foreign relations. This becomes clearer with Bk.'s correction—ou)de/ for ou)/te in 5 and ou)/t) for ou)d) in 6. See L. Herbst, Philol. XVI, 329 ff.

e)s r(a/|w meta/stasin: into an easier change of lot, i.e. into another condition more tolerable. Cf. 4. 74. 18. —ou)/t) a)\n...prosdecame/nas : i.e. ou)/q ai(\ a)\n prosde/cainto. Cf. 5. 15. 10; 7. 67. 26. In all three passages the Mss. vary between aor. and fut. ptc. The latter is preferred by L. Herbst (on a)/n with fut. ptc. in Thuc. p. 35 ff.); but cf. Stahl, Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 22 ff.

w(s e)n mia=| nh/sw|: for a single island. For w(s cf. 1. 10. 34; 2. 65. 44; 3. 113. 25; 4. 34. 10; 7. 30. 20.—ta\s *(ellhni/das: opp. to the o)/xlois cummei/ktois of Alcibiades in 17. 7, and emphatically put at the end to lead over to what follows. See App.
kata\ to\ *leonti/nwn cuggene/s: cf. 3. § 3.

prose/sesqai: will be with us, answering to prosgi/gnesqai, attach oneself to.—a)/llai e(pta/: *sura/kousai, *selinou=s, *ge/la, *)akra/gas, *messh/nh, *(ime/ra,
*kama/rina (Schol.). Acrae and Casmenae, which might be thought of (acc. to 5. § 2), did not attain to independent importance.—kai\ pareskeuasme/nai kte(.: and indeed equipped with everything.
o(moiotro/pws: only here in Thuc., the adj. 1. 6. 24; 3. 10. 5; 7. 55. 6; 8. 96. 27; both very rare elsewhere in Attic writers. Cf. o(mo/tropa Hdt. 8. 144. 16.
ma=llon: sc. h)\ e)pi\ ta\s a)/llas, i.e. especially.

polloi\ me\n...au)ta/s: xrh/mata/ t) e)/xousi kte(.: after the words above (10) kai\ pareskeuasme/nai . . . duna/mei, reference is here doubtless made again to all seven Sicilian cities thought of by Nicias as opponents of the Athenians, not alone to Selinus and Syracuse. Cf. also 7. 58. 21, where it is said of the contingents of the Siceliotes against Athens, o(pli=tai polloi\ kai\ nh=es kai\ i(/ppoi kai\ o( a)/llos o(/milos a)/fqonos cunele/gh.
o( plhrw/swn au)ta/s : to man them = Lat. qui with subjv., as 2. 51. 18; 4. 78. 29, 93. 13; 7. 85. 12.

e)n toi=s i(eroi=s: surprising as opp. to ta\ me\n i)/dia, the usual antithesis in money matters being koino/s (1. 80. 19, 141. 11) or dhmo/sios (1. 80. 11). It is strange, too, that there is no express mention here, along with temple treasures, of the public moneys freq. kept in temples, as Kr. noted suggesting the loss of ta\ de\ koina/ before ta\ de\ kai/.

[*selinounti/ois] : bracketed as an interpolation, with Weidner (Parerg. Dinarch. et Thuc. p. 12f.). It rests on the erroneous assumption that from polloi\ me\n ga\r o(pli=tai (13) on only Selinus and Syracuse were under consideration and that the fact was to be emphasized that the Selinuntians, as opp. to the Syracusans, possessed only the resources treated under xrh/mata . . . e)/sti. That actually only the temples of Selinus served for the deposit of moneys is incredible.

*surakosi/ois de\...fe/retai : and to the Syracusans from some barbarians also moncy has been paid from the beginning (or from of old). For a)po\ barba/rwn . . . fe/retai, cf. 4. 87. 14 toi=s a)po\ u(mw=n xrh/masi ferome/nois. By barba/rwn tinw=n Sicels are meant. Cf. 45. 4, 88. 18. On this much discussed passage, see App.

w(=| de\...proe/xousin : and wherein they have the advantage over us. For sing. rel. referring to members correlated by te . . . kai/, cf. me/giston 1. 35. 19; deino/taton 2. 51. 11; a)porw/taton 7. 14. 4. Cobet (Mnem. N.S. XIV, 13) proposed du/o de\ kte(.

si/tw|...e)paktw=| : = e)pei/saktos si=tos Dem. 18. 87; 20. 31. To require no imported food is emphasized
for Athenians, who acc. to Demosthenes depend of all men most upon foreign grain.
Therefore we must from the start take the field with unusual equipment, especially as the theater of war is so far away.
fau/lou: elsewhere in Thuc. (31. 14; 4. 9. 6) of three terminations; in its real sense, ordinary, common, from which comes the prevailing meaning, unsatisfactory, worthless. Cf. English mean.
cumplei=n: note the change to inf. dependent on dei=, as also e)pie/nai (9), the words ai)sxro\n (sc. h)=n) . . . bouleusame/nous (6-8) being an independent parenthesis.
a)/cion: without ti. See on safe/s 4. 50. 11.— dianoi/as: here, as freq., the plan conceived; see Introd.^{4} p. xlvii.

ei)/rgesqai th=s gh=s: as 3. 86. 15; 5. 82. 22; more freq. ei)/rgein th=s qala/sshs (1. 141. 16; 2. 85. 4; 3. 115. 10).—ei) custw=sin: the only undoubted case in Thuc. of ei) with subjv., after the older poetic usage See St., Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 26 f.
a)ntipara/sxwsin: for this verb, see on 4. 80. 4 App.

a)/lloi <*>)\ *)egestai=oi: injected contemptuously. From the Egestaeans Nicias expected (12. § 1; 22. 14) no actual support. We read, however, of Egestaean cavalry with the Athenians 62. 13, 98. 2.—w(=| a)munou/meqa: answering to o( plhrw/swn 20. 14. The rel. with fut. indic. to express purpose, as 3. 16. 15; 4. 22. 8; 7. 49. 11; 8. 1. 28. GMT. 565; Kr. Spr. 53, 7, 8; Kühn. 387, 4.
biasqe/ntas: i.e. forced by superior power. See on 4. 15. 6.

au)to/qen: from right here. A large levy of troops having been already designated as necessary, here it is emphasized that the requisite force must be got together beforehand, not after reaching the theater of conflict.

gno/ntas o(/ti...prose/dei : recognizing that we are about to sail far from our own land and shall not wage war in like manner as when, in the capacity of allies to subject states here, you went against an enemy whence it was easy to get whatever you further needed out of friendly territory. See App. Stahl's view, that we have in kai\ ou)k . . . strateuso/menoi an anacoluthon, i.e. suppl. ptc. dependent, like o(/ti . . . me/llomen plei=n, on gno/ntas, seems most natural, though the position of te favors the St.-Cl. view that polu/ and strateuso/menoi are co-ord. and both dependent on me/llomen plei=n.

e)n tw=| o(moi/w|...kai/ : see App.— strateuso/menoi: the reading of Laur. (for strateusa/menoi) adopted by most recent editors.—toi=s th=|de u(phko/ois cu/mmaxoi: for the dat. with cu/mmaxoi, cf. 1. 102. 20; 2. 99. 5; 3. 86. 5; and esp. 8. 65. 3.

o(/qen: referring to a person, as 59. 19. Cf. e)/nqa 45. 4. Kr. Spr. 66, 3, 2.—komidai/: importation of supplies. Cf. 4. 27. 5. For the omission of h)=san, see on 1^{4}. 14. 12 and 1. 16. 4.— 12. a)lla\ e)s a)llotri/an pa=san a)parth/santes: but removed into an utterly alien land. a)parth/santes (for which the Mss. CEM read a)parth/sontes) is not paralled to strateuso/menoi, but opp. to ou)k e)n tw=| o(moi/w| kai\ o(/te h)/lqete. The meaning assumed above for a)parta=n (intr.) does not occur, it seems, elsewhere in earlier Greek, but cf. Dio C. 40. 15. 6 e)s a)llotriwta/thn sfi/si kai\ th=s gh=s kai\ tou= ou)ranou= kata/stasin a)partw=ntes and 51. 4.2 qorubhsa/ntwn au)tw=n e)n tou/tw| fanerw=s a(/te kai\ polu\ a)po\ sfw=n a)partw=ntos au)tou=. The Schol., too, recognizes the act. as intr.: a)parth/santes: a)nti\ tou= a)parthqe/ntes, a)pelqo/ntes kai\ polu\ th=s oi)kei/as xwrisqe/ntes. Pp.'s conjecture a)pa/rantes would emphasize esp. the time of departure, and against Meineke's a)panth/santes is the fact that a)panta=n everywhere (also in Lys. 2. 52) implies “going to meet.” e)s a)llotri/an pa=san is manifestly an overstatement (cf. 37. 14 e)n pa/sh| polemi/a| *sikeli/a|).

e)c h(=s...e)lqei=n : from which not even in four winter months could a messenger easily come, i.e. to ask for help or supplies; much less then could these be sent thither in that time.—tw=n xeimerinw=n: cf. Hdt. 2. 68. 1 tou\s xeimeriwta/tous mh=nas te/sseras. These months are *maimakthriw/n, *ho/seidew/n, *gamhliw/n, *)anqesthriw/n. For the position of tw=n xeimerinw=n. cf. ta\s *(ellhni/das 20. 8. Nearly all editors take ou)de/ as belonging to a)/ggelon, from which it is separated for emphasis; but it belongs naturally, where it stands, with mhnw=n tessa/rwn, as Steup takes it, with Kr. and Marchant. For Steup's view that tw=n xeimerinw=n is part. gen., see App.

Provide, then, a large army well equipped with hoplites, as well as with bowmen and slingers, also a superior fleet, abundant provisions, and especially plenty of money; for as to that promised by the Egestaeans, you may consider that to be ready mainly in talk.

o(pli/tas te: which is continued by kai\ toco/tas (4), is defined by kai\ h(mw=n au)tw=n and kai\ tw=n cumma/xwn, the latter again explained by tw=n te u(phko/wn (see on 69. 23) and kai\ h)/n tina e)k *heloponnh/sou dunw/meqa, with the twofold mode of gaining these—h)\ pei=sai
(by persuasion) h)\ misqw=| prosagage/sqai (by pay). The results of these counsels are found in c. 43 and 7. 57. § 9, and we must therefore refer pei=sai esp. to the Argives, misqw=| prosagage/sqai to Arcadian mercenaries.

h)/n tina: for sing., when pl. is in mind, cf. 21. 11.— 5. nausi/ te: third member as so freq. in Thuc. The nh=es are warships (trih/reis), which besides their other duties were to keep the sea open for bringing in supplies.

to
 de\ kai\ au)to/qen si=ton...a)/gein : Jowett's explanation of this much discussed passage seems reasonable, as well as simple. “The supplies taken out from Athens are contrasted by de/ with the supplies which would have to be procured by plunder or otherwise in Sicily itself. au)to/qen is to be explained as a confusion of two notions, au)to/qen a)/gein and a)/gein to
 au)to/qi si=ton.” Kr., followed by Bm. and Mueller, explains to
 de/ as preparatory to the foll. epexegetical si=ton, somewhat like Eur. apud Lycurg. c. Leocr. 100. 42 a)/rcousin a)/llwn, th
 d' e)gw\ sw/sw po/lin. Cf. Stahl's rendering: aliud autem etiam hinc frumentum in navibus onerariis advehere. Steup objects to taking au)to/qen with to
 si=ton, because Nicias is not speaking of all the grain in Athens; also to kai\ au)to/qen with a)/gein (1) because such an interposition between to
 and si=ton is not Thucydidean, (2) because thus to
 si=ton would be in contradiction with kai\ au)to/qen, which would clearly imply importa-tions from other regions besides Attica. For Stahl's to
 de\ si=ton, aliud autem frumentum, Steup knows no Thucydidean parallel. He thinks, therefore, the passage corrupt, and that perhaps polu
 de\ kai\ kte(. was to be expected.— 7. pefrugme/nas kriqa/s: parched barley, which kept better. The verb fru/gw or fru/ssw is rare.

sitopoiou\s...e)mmi/sqous : to be closely connected, slaves to make bread for pay.—e)k tw=n mulw/nwn pro\s me/ros h)nagkasme/nous: designates how these slaves were procured, drafted from the mills in proportion to their size, i.e. acc. to the number of slaves employed in each.— 9. h)/n pou...a)polambanw/meqa : if perchance we be kept from sailing by unfavorable weather. Cf. u(po\ a)ne/mwn a)polamfqe/ntes Hdt. 2. 115. 14; 9. 114. 3. For a)ploi/a, impossibility of sailing, which in case of triremes (with oars) would be only in case of storms or contrary winds, see 2. 85. 24; 4. 4. 23; 8. 99. 20.

pollh\ ga\r...u(pode/casqai : a peculiar form of pers.
const. for neut. = ou)k e)/stai pa/shs po/lews au)th\n pollh\n ou)=san u(pode/casqai. For similar cases, cf. 1. 40. 13, 93. 2; 3. 11. 1; 4, 17. 17; 8. 91. 4. For act. inf., cf. 9. 16 r(a/|dia/ e)sti katasxei=n.
ta/ te a)/lla kte(.: conclusion of whole foregoing admonition. Cf. 71. 15.
mh\ e)pi\ e(te/rois gi/gnesqai: not to be at the mercy of others. Cf. 2. 84. 11; 3. 12. 14; 4. 29. 18. gi/gnesqai as in 1. 37. 13; 3. 53. 4.

le/getai: cf. 6. § 2, 3; 8. § 2.— 14. lo/gw|: ironical repetition of le/getai. The sense of the passage is: and as to the money from the Egestaeans which is said to be ready there, you may assume that it is mostly ready only in talk. For the thought, cf. 12. 5 ff. That Nicias was right is seen in 46. § 1.

In view of the great difficulty of the expedition, which must be regarded as an attempt to found a new city in hostile territory, I am willing to assume leadership only if furnished with quite sufficient means, and will gladly give place to another who thinks differently.

h)\n ga\r au)toi\ e)/lqwmen e)nqe/nde kte(.: the substantiation with ga/r follows upon the urgent admonition of the whole preceding chapter, that by Athens herself most is to be provided, in provisions and money: “for even if we set out with means in every way superior, victory will still be not easy.” Everything is calculated to excite doubt.—h)\n au)toi/: if we ourselves, i.e. not depending on allies like the Egestaeans.—a)nti/palon...paraskeuasa/menoi : (cogn. acc., like naumaxh/santes a)nti/pala 7. 34. 23) limited immediately by the parenthetical selfevident admission, plh/n ge pro\s to\ ma/ximon au)tw=n, to\ o(plitiko/n, except indeed as regards their auailable force of hoplites, i.e. there can be no thought of our opposing them with an equally numerous hoplite force. See App.— 2. to\ ma/ximon: as collective only here in Thuc., but freq. in Hdt. (2. 165. 6; 7. 186. 1). Cf. Xen. Cyrop. 5. 4. 46.— to\ o(plitiko/n: epexegetical to to\ ma/ximon, i.e. “in so far as it consists in hoplites.”

tw=n me\n kratei=n: neut., i.e. supremacy in Sicily. Cf. 30. 12.— ta\ de\ kai\ diasw=sai: the reference is not to their rule at home (Schol. ta\ oi)kei=a), for their activity in Sicily was not to preserve this; nor yet, as most editorsassume, to their Siceliote allies, for Nicias had the fate of these little at heart; but to the Athenian army in Sicily. Cf. 24. § 3. kai/ not at least, as 90. 7; 1. 1. 7. but also, emphasizing
diasw=sai by the side of krath=sai. Cf. oi( de\ kai/ 10. 12; ta\ de\ kai/ 38. 20.

po/lin te nomi/sai xrh\...oi)kiou=ntas i)e/nai : with i)e/nai goes the general subj. implied in oi)kiou=ntas, as St. explains: and you must consider that men will set out to found a city amid alien and hostile peoples.

kratei=n th=s gh=s: to dominate the open country. See on 3. 85. 13.—h)\n sfa/llwntai: Steup would bracket these words as an interpolated explanation of h)/, on the ground (1) that as placed the cond. belongsonly to e(/cousin, against the thought of the passage, and (2) that transposition would not help, since h)\ ei)de/nai o(/ti kte(. alone is much stronger. But these reasons are far from convincing.— pole/mia e(/cousin: for this favorite idiom of Thuc. (= pa/nta e)/stai pole/mia), see on 1. 120. 9.
eu)= bouleu/sasqai: eu)=, though omitted by good Mss., indispensable as antithesis to eu)tuxh=sai.

plei/w : cogn. acc. with eu)tuxh=sai as polla/ with bouleu/sasqai (see on 12. 15).—xalepo\n...o)/ntas : sc. polla\ eu)tuxh=sai h(ma=s. Better taken, with Pp., as independent sent., than construed with ei)dw/s, as Cl. does.
o(/ti e)la/xista...e)mauto/n : guiding motive of Nicias also in 5. 16. 16.
a)po\ tw=n ei)ko/twn: in accordance with human calculations, as Plato, Legg. 941 E; 950 D.

[e)kpleu=sai]: bracketed as a gloss with Kr., as after the preceding e)kplei=n neither the repetition nor the change of tense is explicable. Cl., retaining e)kpleu=sai, emended a)sfalh/s to a)sfalei=, and rendered: “but only with an equipment which in all human probability is assured of success to sail out.”
tau=ta: i.e. the precautions recommended in all the foregoing.— 14. pari/hmi au)tw=| th\n a)rxh/n: cf. the similar offer of Nicias to Cleon with reference to Sphacteria 4. 28.
The effect of the speech was only to increase in the majority the eagerness for the enterprise; the few who felt otherwise suppressed their views.

o( me\n *niki/as: without regard to what has gone before (see on 19. 1), opp. only to oi( de/ (3).— tosau=ta: only so much (see on 2. 12.
1; 3. 31. 1), for he had spoken much more briefly than in his first speech. —tw=| plh/qei tw=n pragma/twn: by the multitude of difficulties (lit. things to be done) which he brought forward. Cf. 8. 48. 29, 39.

h)\ a)potre/yein: the h)/ is misplaced, for clearly the words tou\s *)aqhnai/ous . . . pragma/twn do not belong also to the second clause; but it is hardly to be bracketed with Cobet and St., since misplacements of this kind are freq. in Thuc. See on 18. 1. Because part of the Mss. omit (as so often in similar cases) ei) after h)/, Weidner (Parerg. p. 10) would bracket ei) a)nagka/zoito strateu/esqai as an interpolation. a)nagka/zesqai is clearly used, not of physical force, but of moral compulsion (after his wishes should have been complied with). Certainly ma/lista ou(/tws a)sfalw=s (i.e. with the equipment which he demanded, ‘at least securely’; cf. paraskeuh=| a)po\ tw=n ei)ko/twn a)sfalh/s 23. 11) e)kpleu=sai can refer only to Nicias. Weidner finds no difficulty, after bracketing the words indicated, in taking *)aqhnai/ous with both clauses; but the const. as obj. with a)potre/yein and subj. with e)kpleu=sai would be too harsh.

e)kpleu=sai: aor. inf., dependent on nomi/zwn, of the fut., because of the definite limitation by the intervening clause ei) a)nagka/zoito strateu/esqai, whereas without such a limitation the fut. a)potre/yein is correct; just as in 12 after the general a)rgu/rion oi)/sein the aor. proskth/sasqai follows, because it is limited by du/namin o(/qen . . . u(pa/rcein to a definite object. St. writes ma/list' a)\n . . . e)kpleu=sai and proskth/sesqai.
to\ e)piqumou=n: for neut. ptc. as abstract noun, see on 1. 36. 3; 3. 30. 4.

ou)k e)ch|re/qhsan: were not freed from, const, as a)fairei=sqai 1. 120. 21; 2. 41. 19; 5. 69. 6.—u(po\ tou= o)xlw/dous th=s paraskeuh=s: by reason of the burdensomeness of the equipment (on account of its magnitude, cf. 19. § 2). With to\ o)xlw=des, cf. di) o)/xlou ei)=nai 1. 73. 13.

w(/rmhnto : sc. plei=n or e)s to\n plou=n. For the thought, cf. 19. § 1.—tou)nanti/on perie/sth au)tw=|: turned out the opposite for him. See on 1. 76. 21.— 6. nu=n dh/: now certainly, i.e. with such an outfit.
toi=s pa=sin o(moi/ws: to all alike. See on 1. 93. 8.

toi=s me
 ga presbute/rois kte(.: before this epexegetical explanation, with which e)/rws e)ne/pese is to be supplied, as in 68. 14 with oi( me
 ga/r and e)gw\ de/ the corresponding verbs, only a comma is to be placed. See Vahlen on Arist. Poet.^{3} p. 100 and K. Hude, Hermes XXXVI, 313 ff.—w(s: followed first by the regular dat. (katastreyome/nois), then by the acc. abs. (a)

sfalei=san . . . du/namin). The same const. in reverse order 4. 5. 3.
e)f' a(\ e)/pleon: i.e. the states against which they were sailing. Cf. 20. 12.—ou)de\n a)\n sfalei=san: could suffer no failure.
th=s a)pou/shs...qewri/as : through desire for a far-off sight and spectacle, i.e. to see and gaze upon something far away.

eu)e/lpides o)/ntes: anacoluthon; const. as if e)pequ/mhsan . . . e)kpleu=sai had gone before. For similar anacolutha, see on 2. 53. 13.—o( de\ polu\s o(/milos kai\ stratiw/ths kte(.: sc. eu)/elpis w)/n, and the great multitude being in good hope also as soldiers (i.e. besides the inducements esp. in the minds of old and young, namely, trade) at the present time to earn money. stratiw/ths is thus taken as pred. to a)rgu/rion oi)/sein. For the force = strateuo/menos, cf. 1. 60. 9, 95. 15. Kr. says: “The Schol. correctly explains with h)/goun to\ stratiwtiko\n plh=qos, accordingly o( stratiw/ths o(/milos is the military mass.” But this leaves kai/ unexplained.

proskth/sasqai du/namin kte(.: to acquire power besides (i.e. to increase the supremacy of Athens), with the result that there would always be wage-carning (in military service). proskth/sasqai opp. to e)n tw=| paro/nti. For aor. inf., see on 3.
o(/qen...u(pa/rcein : for inf. in rel. sent. in indir. disc., see on 1. 91. 24.
kako/nous th=| po/lei: i.e. unpatriotic. Cf. th=| po/lei ou)k ei)/nous 36. 3; th=| po/lei du/snous 2. 60. 21.
Nicias, in response to a demand for it, states more specifically the land and naval armaments which he deems necessary.
parelqw/n tis: Demostratus by name, acc. to Plut. Nic. 12.
parakale/sas: calling on, appealing to. Cf. Lys. 22. 8 parakale/santes tou\s a)/rxontas h)rwtw=men.
diame/llein : freq. in Thuc., but elsewhere only in late writers.—h)/dh: right now, as 29. 6, 9.
yhfi/swntai: delib. subjv., as 1. 107. 25. Kr. Spr. 54, 7, 1.
a)/kwn me\n ei)=pen: brachylogy for a)/kwn me\n ei)=pen, ei)=pe de/.

o(/sa...dokei=n :
so far, however, as it now seemed to him. For inf., cf. 1. 2. 8; 3. 49. 16. GMT. 759; Kr. Spr. 55, 3, 5.

ou)k e)/lasson: see on 1. 8.—pleuste/a: for Thuc.'s use of neut. pl., see on 1. 7. 2, and C. F. Smith, Trans. Amer. Phil. Assoc. XXV, 73f.—au)tw=n d) *)aqhnai/wn kte(.: the sense is clearly that of 100 Athenian triremesas many as may seem necessary shall be used for transports —40 acc. to 31. § 3; 43. § 1—and that other triremes besides the 100 shall be called for from the allies. Kr. suggests au)tw=n [d)] *)aqhnai/wn, <w(=n> e)/sesqai kte(., which Hude adopts. Stcup thinks there is a lacuna after e)/sesqai to be filled in with taxei/as e(ch/konta kai/.
au)tw=n d) *)aqhnai/wn : for proper name without art. when joined with au)to/s, see on 1. 27. 15.
h)/n ti du/nwntai: if in any way they can, as 7. 29. 5.— 12. w(s kata\ lo/gon: in proportion (i.e. with the hoplites). w(s as with kaq) e(/kasta.
tw=n au)to/qen kai\ e)k *krh/ths : cf. c. 43, and see on 2. 13. 54.
sfendonhtw=n: 700 Rhodian slingers were taken, acc. to 43. 15.—pre(pon ei)=nai: see App. on 14. 1. 5.
e(toimasa/menoi a)/cein: grammatically belonging to ei)=pen, but really with the three strategi in mind.
Nicias and his colleagues are voted full power to do as may seem best. The equipping of the expedition is pushed vigorously.
e)yhfi/santo: again on motion of Demostratus, acc. to Plut. Nic. 12; Alcib. 18.
au)tokra/toras ei)=nai: acc. to Plutarch, Alcib. 18, with the addition kai\ th=s paraskeuh=s kai\ tou= pole/mou panto/s.
a)/rista : adj. with implied general subj., as in 8. 14.
katalo/gous e)poiou=nto: made levies. Cf. 31. 26.

tou= cunexou=s pole/mou: i.e. the ten years' war. See App. on 2. 1. 2.—e)s...e)pigegenhme/nhs : as to the youth that had grown up. For e)s, cf.
1. 41. 8; 3. 14. 1.
a(/qroisin: only here in Attic prose.—dia\ th\n e)kexeiri/an: gives reason for a)neilh/fei e(auth/n.
Suddenly there was great commotion in the city over the mutilation of the Hermae, done in one night, and feararose of secret designs for the overthrow of the democracy.

e)n paraskeuh=| h)=san: periphrasis as in 2. 80. 17, 101. 10.—e)n tou/tw|: it is clear from 29. 3 h)/dh ta\ th=s paraskeuh=s e)pepo/risto that preparations were far advanced. For the abundant literature on the mutilation of the Hermae and the consequent legal processes, see K. F. Hermann, Gr. Antiq.^{6} I, 716 f.—o(/soi *)ermai= h)=san li/qinoi: “the marble Hermae which enclosed a part of the agora and were placed before residences and sanctuaries.” Curtius, Gr. Gesch.^{6} II, 633. On the shape, see O. Mueller, Arch. § 67, and Chr. Scherer in Roscher's Lex. d. Mythologie I, 2392 ff.
kata\ to\ e)pixw/rion: dhlono/ti e)/qos, Schol.
h( tetra/gwnos e)rgasi/a: appositive, the art. indicating the figure familiar to the Athenians. Note the unusual abstract for concrete.

oi( plei=stoi: cf. pa/ntwn a)krwthriasqe/ntwn plh\n e(no/s Plut. Nic. 13; tw=n plei/stwn a)krwthriasqe/ntwn ta\ pro/swpa Plut. Alcib. 3; accidit ut una nocte omnes Hermae deicerentur praeter unum Nep. Alcib. 3.
mega/lois mhnu/trois: cf. Andoc. 1. 27 h)=san kata\ to\ *klewnu/mon yh/misma xi/liai draxmai/, kata\ de\ to\ *heisa/ndrou mu/riai. Cf. also Andoc. 1. 40.
ei)/ tis...oi)=den : in the words of the yh/fisma.

meizo/nws e)la/mbanon: took very seriously. meizo/nws as 1. 130. 10; 4. 19. 16. Cf. u(po/ptws lamba/nein 53. 18; xalepw=s lamba/nein 61. 2; lamba/nein mh\ polemi/ws 4. 17. 9. See on 3. 59. 6. Cf. Tac. Hist. 2. 7 res . . . in maius accipitur.—oi)wno/s: a bad sign (ominous).
e)pi\ cunwmosi/a|: based on, in consequence of, a conspiracy, the prep. as in 60. 4. The foll. gens. depend on cunwmosi/a|, just as in 3. 82. 45 cunallagh=s on o(/rkoi (conspiracy for).

On receipt of further denunciations of profanation of the mysteries in private houses, in which Alcibiades is named as participator, his adversaries proceed against him, and, accusing him likewise of the mutilation of the Hermae, charge that the object of both crimes is the overthrow of the democracy.
a)po/: on the part of. See on 3. 36. 24.
a)kolou/qwn: prob. servants enjoying closer relations to their masters and cognizant of their secret doings.
meta\ paidia=s kai\ oi)/nou: in drunken sport, the effect stated first in Greek.—ta\ musth/ria w(s: so placed for emphasis, as 29. 9 and freq.
e)f' u(/brei: in mockery. Cf. Eur. Or. 1581.
au)ta/: i.e. the charges against Alcibiades of profanation of the mysteries. It is obj. both of u(polamba/nontes (Schol. prosdexo/menoi w(/ste pisteu/ein) and e)mega/lunon.
e)mpodw\n o)/nti sfi/si mh\...proesta/nai : for const. with verb of hindrance, see GMT. 807 c; 815, 1.

met' e)kei/nou: in collusion with him. See on 3. 30. 10.—e)pile/gontes tekmh/ria: citing as further proofs (i.e. besides the testimony of the me/toikoi/ te/ tines kai\ a)ko/louqoi (1). Cf. e)pei=pon 1. 67. 18.
th\n a)/llhn au)tou=...paranomi/an : cf. 15. 13. The pl. tekmh/ria prob. points to various manifestations of paranomi/a.
ou) dhmotikh/n : Schol. th\n e)/cw tou= e)/qous th=s dhmokrati/as.

Alcibiades' urgent demand for an immediate investigation is rejected and his speedy departure voted.— 2. kri/nesqai: to be tried.—ei)/ ti...h)=n : as to whether he had done any of these things. This, as well as ei) me\n . . . ei)/rgasto (4), said from standpoint of the historian, as the plpf. shows, i.e. not in indir. dise., but ei) d' a)poluqei/h (4) from that of Alcibiades. There is no good reason for changing to opt.,
with Cobet, or bracketing the clause, with v. H., St., and others.
h)/dh ga\r...e)pepo/risto : explanation referring to pri\n e)kplei=n.
ta\ th=s paraskeuh=s : as 65. 8.
a)/rxein: as 12. 9; 8. 64. 8. Sc. h)ci/ou from e(toi=mos h)=n.

e)pemartu/reto: with the infs. in the sense appealed to, with the o(/ti clause (cf. 80. 17) admonished.—a)po/ntos peri\ au)tou=: the prep. belongs to au)tou= and hence does not suffer anastrophe. Cf. Schol. A on Hom. B 839 *)ari/starxos toi=s kuriwte/rois sune/tatte ta\s proqe/seis. For position of a)po/ntos, cf. 1. 3. 18 a)nti/palon e)s e(\n o)/noma.

h)/dh: as 25. 3.— 7. pri\n diagnw=si: Cobet would bracket because implied in meta\ toiau/ths ai)ti/as. But ai)ti/a is perhaps not so much the legal charge, as blame which might not cease with legal acquittal. The const. too, unusual in prose, is against the assumption of an interpolation.
e)pi\ tosou/tw| strateu/mati: at the head of so great an army. Cf. Dinarch. 1. 74 e)pi\ toi=s ce/nois e)ge/neto. See Kühner-Gerth II, 1, 500 f.

to/ te stra/teuma...o(/ te dh=mos : the two nouns brought by emphatic position (cf. 28. 4) and by te . . . te (see on 1. 8. 14) into closest relation.— 10. malaki/zhtai: cf. 3. 37. 8, 40. 34. —qerapeu/wn o(/ti: favoring him because. Severity toward him might result in the Argives and Mantineans abandoning the campaign. Cf. 61. § 5, where fear is expressed of the effect of his arrest upon these allies.—di) e)kei=non: because of him. Cf. 61. 24 di) e)kei/nou peisqh=nai.
oi( *)argei=oi : cf. 43. 11, 61. 24; for the relations of Alcibiades with the Argives, 61. § 3.

tw=n *mantine/wn tine/s: these were merecenaries; cf. 7. 57. 48, and see on 43. 12. Mantinea belonged from the winter of 418-417 (5. 81. § 1) again to the Spartan symmachy, but Alcibiades must from an earlier time (cf. 16. § 6) have had great influence there.—a)pe/trepon kai\ a)pe/speudon: Schol. a)perri/ptoun meta\ spoudh=s. For the conative impf., see GMT. 36.

e)nie/ntes: subornantes, not elsewhere in Attic in this sense.—e)/legon: = e)ke/leuon, as 1. 78. 10; 2. 5. 21.— 13. th\n a)nagwgh/n: for a)gwgh/n of most of the better Mss. Cf. 30. 1, and see App. on 4. 29. 3.—e)lqo/nta: = e)panelqo/nta.
See on 1. 117. 6.

e)n h(me/rais r(htai=s: cf. 30. 7, 64. 20; 4. 76. 19.—e)k mei/zonos diabolh=s: with meta/pempton, summoned as the result of more serious defamation. Schol. e)/mellon au)ch/sein th\n diabolh\n a)po/ntos au)tou=. The relation of meta/pempton to komisqe/nta as to a)ph/|ei in 74. 3. Van H. and St. bracket komisqe/nta unnecessarily. The narrative here interrupted is resumed in 53 ff.

-32, § 2. Departure for the campaign in Sicily. The whole population of Athens goes down to the Peiraeus, partly to take leave of friends, partly to view the magnificent spectacle; for never had a military expedition been sent off in such splendor from a single state. Fleet and land force were alike well equipped. The length of the journey, too, and the greatness of the object aimed at excited wonder. Before sailing the usual prayers and sacrifices were offered. 1. qe/rous mesou=ntos h)/dh: when it was already midsummer. The art. omitted as with a(/ma h)=ri and pro\s e)/ar h)/dh. Steup prefers to take h)/dh with e)gi/gneto, comparing 7. 75. 1 meta\ de\ tou=to . . . kai\ h( a)na/stasis h)/dh tou= strateu/matos . . . e)gi/gneto.
h( a)nagwgh\ e)gi/gneto : introductory impf. of the whole, the details following; so 3. 92. 2 kaqi/stanto.
toi=s ploi/ois : Schol. toi=s mikroi=s, a(\ dh\ kai\ lepta\ a)/lloqi ei)=pen.
o(/sh...cunei/peto : i.e. a(pa/sh| th=| a)/llh| paraskeuh=| h(\ cunei/peto.

pro/teron ei)/rhto : the o(lka/des and ploi=a needed more time to get to Corcyra, and for most of the allies it was easier to sail directly thither. Cf. also 32. 13.—ei)/rhto: = e)nete/talto, as in 42. 10, 61. 20, 67. 7, 102. 16, and freq.
e)pi\ a)/kran *)iapugi/an: promontory in Calabria.—to\n *)io/nion: sc. ko/lpon. See on 3. 107. 4.
tw=n cumma/xwn: for not all of the allies were ordered to Corcyra; cf. tw=n cumma/xwn toi=s plei/stois above (2).
cugkate/bh: anaphora, emphatically put first.

w(s ei)pei=n: with
a(/pas, to modify a seemingly extravagant statement, as often. See on 1. 1. 9.

oi( me\n e)pixw/rioi: the antithesis is oi( de\ ce/noi in 31. 5. The subj. here still has reference to cugkate/bh with the explanatory ptcs. prope/mpontes, i)o/ntes, e)nqumou/menoi, but in the further description of dominant feelings (e)sh/|ei ta\ deina/, o(/mws de\ a)neqa/rsoun) not only the attendant e)pixw/rioi but the whole body of the Athenians are in mind, and so oi( de\ ce/noi takes independently a new finite verb.—prope/mpontes: deducentes, prosequentes.

ui(ei=s: on this form offered here in all Mss., see Kühner-Blass I, 1, 507 f.; Meisterhans^{3} 144; and on 1. 13. 26.—kai\: correlating i)o/ntes with prope/mpontes, the two nouns being united closely by te a(/ma and the following kai/.
ta\ me\n w(s kth/sointo : explanatory of e)lpi/dos (cf. 3. 40. 1; 8. 94. 11). ta\ me/n = ta\ e)n *sikeli/a|.

tou\s d) ei)/ pote o)/yointo : explanatory of o)lofurmw=n, and tou\s de/ refers to their friends. Cf. 23. 3 mo/lis ou(/tws oi(=oi/ te e)so/meqa tw=n me\n kratei=n, ta\ de\ kai\ diasw=sai. For position of the conjunctions (w(s, ei)), see on 28. 4. For o(ra=n, see again, cf. Soph. O.R. 824; Phil. 1392; Xen. Anab. 3. 2. 39. Cf. e)fora=n 7. 61. 5, 77. 37.
o(/son plou=n : acc. of measure.

1. kai\ e)n tw=| paro/nti kairw=| . . . (4) th=| o)/yei a)neqa/rsoun: conclusion of the statement beginning with (30. 10) oi( me\n e)pixw/rioi. From this point the subject is not oi( prope/mpontes, but the whole body of Athenians.

meta\ kindu/nwn: under (impending) dangers. —ma=llon au)tou\s e)sh/|ei ta\ deina/: the dangers came closer home to them, i.e. made them more anxious. Cf. 4. 30. 2 ou)x h(/kista au)to\n tau=ta e)sh/|ei.

o(/mws de\...a)neqa/rsoun : but still by reason of their present strength on account of the multitude of all whom they saw before them they were encouraged by the sight. The words dia\ to\ plh=qos e(ka/stwn w(=n e(w/rwn, explanatory of th=| parou/sh| r(w/mh|, are omitted by St. as unnecessary. For th=| o)/yei a)neqa/rsoun, cf. 4. 34. 5 th=| o)/yei tou= qarsei=n to\ plei=ston ei)lhfo/tes. For the views of Cl. and Steup, see App.— 5. kata\ qe/an: to look on. See on 5. 7. 11.—w(s e)pi\...dia/noian : in the feeling that the undertaking was stupendous and scarcely credible.

paraskeuh\ ga\r au(/th...e)ge/neto : for this armament sailing out as the first from a single
city with a Hellenic force was the costliest and finest of those up to that time. For the const., see on 1. 1. 8. Here the pred. noun placed first has besides the sup. a further modifier (e)kpleu/sasa . . . *(ellhnikh=|) with the effect of a gen. pl. prw/th e)kpleu/sasa kte(. means “such as had sailed out from no single city before.” h( prw/th was to be expected, as Dobree says. See App.
h( e)s *)epi/dauron...meta\ *(/agnwnos : cf. 2. 56. § 1 ff., 58.
kai\ cu/mmaxoi e)/ti polloi/: these additional allies, which seem to have been with the Attic forces on the 100 Athenian triremes, are not mentioned in 2. 56. § 2.
e)pi/: for, with dat. of object. See on 4. 86. 2.—fau/lh|: see on 21. 1.

ou(=tos de\ o( sto/los: sc. w(rmh/qh. Cl. unneccessarily follows Kr. in thinking the sent. anacoluthic. He objects to supplying w(rmh/qh as “not answering to the moment of the narrative.” But between e)ge/neto in 9 and 42 the aor. w(rmh/qh is quite in place.

ou(= a)
 de/h|: of whichever there might be need, i.e. whether they had to proceed by water or by land.—to\ me
 nautiko
...e)kponhqe/n...to\ de\ pezo
...e)kkriqe/n : part. appos. as freq. in Thuc.
e)kponhqe/n: built up with effort. Cf. 3. 38. 13.

tou= me\n dhmosi/ou kte(.: on the contributions of the state on the one side and of the trierarchs on the other, see Boeckh, Staatshaushaltung^{3} I, 639 ff. The pay of the sailors, usually three obols per day, was this time doubled. See on 8. 3.

kena/s: acc. to Ar. Eq. 912 ff., the state furnished at other times in the Peloponnesian War besides the body or hull of the ship also at least a part of the equipment. See Boeckh, ibid., with note 858 of M. Fränkel. That a)ndrw=n is not to be supplied here with nh=es kenai/, as in 1. 27. 15 and freq. (cf. 7. 77. 40), is clear from the context, and esp. from kai\ u(phresi/as tau/tais ta\s krati/stas. Naber (Mnem. N.S. XIV, 326 f.) would write kaina/s. But if the Athenians had built at that
time such an unusual number of new triremes (cf. Diod. 11. 43), Thuc. must surely have mentioned the fact in his reference to the Athenian preparations 26. § 2.

u(phresi/as: here, 1. 23, and 8. 1. 15, and the sing. u(phresi/a 1. 143. 7, the technically trained seamen, who were on the triremes along with the marines (e)piba/tai) and oarsmen (nau=tai in a narrowersense), and were regarded as assistants of the trierarchs. Acc. to 1. 143. 6, the kubernh/ths belonged to the u(phresi/a, and in (Xen.) De Rep. Athen. 1. 2 oi( kubernh=tai kai\ oi( keleustai\ kai\ oi( penthko/ntarxoi kai\ oi( prw|ra=tai kai\ oi( nauphgoi/ the whole or nearly the whole of the u(phresi/a seem to be included. See A. Kirchhoff, Abhdl. d. Berl. Akad. 1865, 81 f.; U. Köhler, Mitt. d. dtsch. arch. Instituts in Athen VIII, 177 f.; G. Gilbert, Handb. d. gr. Staatsalt.^{2} I, 365 f.
tw=n <de\> trihra/rxwn : the de/, due to the Schol. of Patmos, was first adopted by Heilmann.—e)pifora/s: bounties in addition to the pay of the state.

kai\ tai=s u(phresi/ais: these words, bracketed by Bl., Cl., St., and most other recent editors, offer no difficulty if the u(phresi/ai (see on 20) are not included in the nau=tai, as 1. 143. § 1 requires they should not be. The correct understanding of the term u(phresi/ai makes unnecessary the assumption that the Schol. (oi( qrani=tai . . . plei/ona ko/pon e)/xousi tw=n a)/llwn: dia\ tou=to tou/tois mo/nois e)pido/seis e)poiou=nto oi( trih/rarxoi, ou)xi\ de\ pa=si toi=s e)re/tais) did not have before him the words kai\ tai=s u(phresi/ais.

ta)=lla : adv. as 3. 3. 26; 4. 55. 6; 8. 86. 32.—shmei/ois: figures or other outer ornaments by which the ships were distinguished and named. Schol. shmei=a le/gei ta\s e)/cwqen katagrafa\s tw=n trih/rwn. Cf. Ar. Ranae 933 (of the i(ppale/ktwr)shmei=on e)n tai=s nausi\n e)nege/grapto.
kataskeuai=s : inner equipments of the ships, as elsewhere of houses (2. 14. 3, 38. 3, 65. 9).
e)s ta\ makro/tata: Schol. e)pi\ to\ plei=ston. Unusual for e)s ta\ me/gista, which also occurs only once in Thuc. (4. 86. 24), but freq. in Hdt.
e(no\s e(ka/stou: sc. tw=n trihra/rxwn.
au)tw=| tini : for each one himself. Cf. 77. 17; 1. 37. 12, 40. 21, 43. 2.
katalo/gois xrhstoi=s: i.e. katalo/gois tw=n xrhstw=n, levies of the best.

tw=n...skeuw=n : accouterments for the body. skeu/h of equipment outside of the regular arms, as in 7.
84. 14.
a(millhqe/n: active in force as everywhere else in Attic, Plato, Legg. 968 B; Eur. Suppl. 195; Hel. 165, 387; Cycl. 628. Cf. e)camillh/sasqai Eur. Hel. 1471. (Kr.)

cune/bh de/: and it came to pass. See on 5. 10. 33.—pro/s te sfa=s au)tou\s a(/ma...proseta/xqh : that both among themselves there was rivalry in that whereto each was assigned. Here e)/ris = a)gaqh\e)/ris. Stein rightly understands tou/tou before w)=|. Cf. Hom. s 366 ei) ga\r nw=in e)/ris e)/rgoio ge/noito.
tis e(/kastos : order as 7. 75. 29; but e(/kasto/s tis 3. 45. 18; 4. 4. 7, 63. 4.

proseta/xqh : of military assignment; see on 2. 87. 32.—kai\ e)s tou\s a)/llous *(/ellhnas kte(.: and it seemed rather a display of power and wealth before the rest of the Greeks than an undertaking against enemies. The subj. implied with ei)kasqh=nai is tou=to or the preparations just described. For the meaning of e)cousi/a, cf. 3. 45. 17 and Schol. periousi/an e)cousi/an fhsi/. Cl. understood duna/mews of Athens' strength at home, e)cousi/as of her outward supremacy. But the distinction seems arbitrary, and acc. to 30. § 1 the allies were only slightly represented in the paraskeuh/ in question here, most having sailed direct to Corcyra. On the other hand, in § 5 is without doubt described the enormous cost of that paraskeuh/ to the state of Athens and the individual Athenians.

dhmosi/an: Cl. and most recent editors follow Kr. in bracketing the word, because it is omitted by Valla, is unnecessary after th=s po/lews, and requires the art. But Steup, referring to 1. 51. 11 and 4. 43. 15 for like omissions of the art., argues that if dhmosi/an is superfluous, then in the second clause kai\ th\n tw=n strateuome/nwn, or merely kai\ tw=n strateuome/nwn, would have sufficed without i)di/an.
proetetele/kei : correctly restored by Reiske for prosetetele/kei of the Mss. o(/sa h)/dhproetetele/kei is opp. to a)\ e)/xontas tou\s strathgou\s a)pe/stelle.
tis : every one, collective opp. to trih/rarxos.
xwri\s de/ : and besides, as 1. 61. 15; 2. 97. 16. See on 3. 17. 6.

pa/nta tina/: every one. See on 2. 41. 21; 3. 13. 33.— paraskeua/sasqai: aor. inf. after ei)ko\s h)=n referring to the past. For const. see on 3. 10. 20.—e)fo/dion: pred., as money for the journey. Cf. 2. 70. 16.—
39. e)pi\ metabolh=|: for barter and sale. See on 14.—h)\ stratiw/ths h)\ e)/mporos: cf. 7. 13. 16.
to/lmhs qa/mbei: on account of astonishment at the daring. qa/mbos only here in Thuc., rare in Plato. Cf. Plut. Caes. 32 qa/mbei to/lmhs.

pro\s ou(\s...u(perbolh=| : sc. tou/twn dependent on u(perbolh=|, by superiority of force over those whom they went against. Cf. Lys. 14. 38 u(perbolh
 poihsa/menos th=s prote/ras ponhri/as. In agreement with what is here said is 86. 6 duna/mei mei/zoni pro\s th
 tw=nde i)sxu
 pa/resmen, and 2. 65. 11 ff. —me/gistos h)/dh...oi)kei/as : a very long journey then from home. On h)/dh Bk. remarks “usitatius dh/,” but the particle does not belong to the superlative. The relatively unimportant first Sicilian expedition (see Steup, Rh. Mus. LVI, 453 ff.) is disregarded here; the Egyptian expeditions of 1. 104. § 2, 110. § 4, 112. § 3, were undertakings of the Delian Alliance, not of the Athenians alone.

e)pi\ megi/sth| e)lpi/di...e)pexeirh/qh : and was undertaken in (i.e. on the basis of) very great hope for the future as compared with the present, i.e. what they now possessed. On the expectationsentertained at the time, cf. 90. § 2f.
1. plh/reis h)=san: were manned. Cf. e)plh/roun 30. 8.
e)se/keito : plpf. pass. of e)sti/qhmi. Cobet (Mnem. N.S. XIV, 14) would restore e)ne/keito.
u(peshma/nqh : by a conventional signal easy to be understood. Cf. 1. 82. 15.— ta\s nomizome/nas pro\ th=s a)nagwgh=s: those customary before departure.

u(po\ kh/rukos: i.e. following the loud tones of the herald. Cf. Hdt. 9. 98.—kera/santes: goes with the general subj., whereas with spe/ndontes we have oi( e)piba/tai kai\ oi( a)/rxontes as limiting appositives; the e)re/tai were already in place.

cunephu/xonto: after eu)xa\s e)poiou=nto, as cugkate/bh 30. 8 after kataba/ntes.
For pl. verb with collective noun, cf. 1. 89. 15; 3. 80. 2, 110. 6.
ei)/ tis a)/llos = o(/soi tw=n a)/llwn.
sfi/si : i.e. toi=s *)aqhnai/ois, referring to the subj. of the preceding sent. See on 11. 12.— paiani/santes: for paiwni/santes of the Mss., see on 1. 50. 20.
e)pi\ ke/rws: in column. Cf. 2. 90. 16 kata\ mi/an e)pi\ ke/rws.
a(/millan e)poiou=nto : periphrasis for h(millw=nto, sc. e)re/ssontes.
e)s th\n *ke/rkuran: cf. 30. 4.—to\ a)/llo stra/teuma tw=n cumma/xwn: as opp. to the few allies who acc. to 30. 6 sailed from Peiraeus.
h)pei/gonto a)fike/sqai: impf. in view of the goal to be reached 42. § 1.
§ 3. In Syracuse the reports that came in of the approach of the Athenians are for a long time discredited. Hermocrates seeks in an assembly to win over the people to his contrary views.

toioi/delo/goi: i.e. as those of Hermocrates and Anaxagoras. St. brackets toioi/de as an interpolation.— a)po\ a)/llwn: for the prep., cf. 28. 1.— 17. tw=n me\n...lego/ntwn : bracketed by Steup; see App.

*(ermokra/ths: cf. 4. 58 ff. 19. parelqw\n au)toi=s: see on 15. 19.—w(s oi)o/menos: in the belicf, as 4. 114. 19; 7. 40. 7. Cf. 33. 6.— safw=s: belongs to ei)de/nai. Cf. 3. 12. 11; 7. 14. 17.—ta\ peri\ au)tw=n: i.e. ta\ peri\ tou= e)pi/plou (14). See on 1. 1. 10.

div2.head: Speech of Hermocrates (33, 34)
Speech of Hermocrates (33, 34)
div2.p: Incredible as it sounds, I know from a sure source that the Athenians are advancing against us with a large fleet and land force. Prepare therefore to ward them off. Their audacity and power need not frighten you; rather have you every prospect of winning victory and fame.
As to the decision and energy displayed in the speeches of Hermocrates, see App. on 4. 58 ff.

w(/sper kai\ a)/lloi tine/s: as also some others, referring to those who besides Hermocrates believed the reports of the coming of the Athenians. Cf. 32. 17. Cl.
rendered, as much as any others, citing 18. 35 and 1. 142. 24; but in that case the singular a)/llos tis was to be expected. See R. Oehler, Animadv. in Hermocr. Or. (Homburg Progr., 1885, p. 5).
tou= e)pi/plou th=s a)lhqei/as: obj. gen. placed first as often. See on 1. 32. 8; 7. 42. 30.
le/gontes h)\ a)pagge/llontes: the first of statements made on their own judgment, the latter of reports based on what others say.

ou): negatives both ptc. and verb. Cf. 4. 126. 24.—e)pisxh/sw: abs., hold back, as 1. 90. 20, 131. 8; 4. 78. 29.— 6. pei/qwn e)mauto/n: = pepeisme/nos, in Thuc. only here, freq. in Plato and the orators.—safe/stero/n ti e(te/rou: e(te/rwn might have been used, as 9. 7, 16. 1. Hermocrates compares himself with all who thought they knew something of the expedition of the Athenians, whether accepting it as actual or not.

ga/r: introducing the promised exposition. Cf. 10. 1, 20. 3, 34. 18, 54. 5, 76. 4, 87. 4.—e)f' h(ma=s: so with almost all recent editors for e)f' u(ma=s of the better Mss. It would be strange if Hermocrates did not include himself among those threatened by the danger; besides, the Mss. all read h(mete/ras in 10 and h(ma=s in 16.

w(/rmhntai: have set out. Cf. 1. 32. 20 and see on 2. 9. 1.—pezh=|: all good Mss. have here pezikh=|, and all except Vat. pezikh/n in 7. 7. 7, 16. 7. But as in Thuc. only pezo/s, pezo/n, pezoi/, peza/, occur as substantives, and even pezo/s as adj. is the reading of all or nearly all Mss. in a larger number of passages (1. 141. 14; 2. 84. 6; 4. 8. 10; 5. 2. 10; 6. 103. 5; 7. 12. 4, 15. 8, 22. 2, 43. 3, 79. 3), it seems certain that Bk. and others correctly restore everywhere the shorter form. Cl. accepted pezikh=| here because it is so cited for this passage by Thomas Mag. p. 309 R., but this testimony of the late grammarian is not conclusive.—pro/fasin: on the pretext, as 3. 111. 2; 5. 80. 17. Cf. dat. 76. 5; 5. 53. 2. On the matter, cf. 8. § 2.

cummaxi/a|, katoiki/sei: dats. of purpose. See on kakw/sei 3. 82. 8. For cummaxi/a meaning “help of allies,” cf. 73. 5; 1. 32. 2, 42. 12; 3. 82. 7. If we took cummaxi/a| as dat. of cause, as many do, we should have next a transition to dat. of purpose in katoiki/sei, then back to dat. of cause in e)piqumi/a|. Van H. unnecessarily inserts e)pi/ before *)egestai/wn. On the relations of the Athenians to Egesta, see App. on 6. 11.—to\ de\ a)lhqe/s: but in truth, antithesis to pro/fasin.

w(s...paresome/nwn : on the assurance that they will soon be here.—e)n ta/xei: soon, with all specd, freq. in Thuc., e.g. 91. 13, 92. 1; 1. 79. 7, 86. 13, 90. 31; 2. 86. 22, 101. 21; 3. 29. 2; 4. 106. 8, 123. 19; 5. 57. 5, 64. 2; 8. 95. 7.

a)po\ tw=n u(parxo/ntwn: placed first for emphasis.—o(/tw| tro/pw|.: for more usual o(/pws with fut. indic., as 11. 23, 44. 21. See on 1. 107. 18.— 13. katafronh/santes: because you have despised them. Cf. 11. 20, 34. 54.— a)/fraktoi lhfqh/sesqe: be caught unguarded, i.e. without sufficient means of defense. Cf. 3. 39. 8. lamba/nein as 10. 14.
tou=cu/mpantos: as comprehensive as possible, everything threatening the state's existence.

ei) de/ tw| kai\ pista/: sc. do/cw le/gein from 1. 1. So Cl., but most editors, on account of the distance from the beginning, supply with the Schol. ta\ th=s e)fo/dou tw=n *)aqhnai/wn, or something similar (tau=ta, au)ta/). Steup refers pista/ to the following th\n to/lman au)tw=n kai\ du/namin, “if, however, to any one they are even credible, still he need not be in terror at their audacity and power.”

plei/w: cogn. acc. with bla/ptein, as 64. 9. So with w)felei=n 2. 60. 5. See on 1. 81. 8.—h)\ pa/sxein: sc. ei)ko/s e)sti (from oi(=oi/ te e)/sontai).— 17. a)nwfele/s: correction of Faber and Dobree for a)nwfelei=s of the Mss., which some editors retain and explain as due to Thuc.'s partiality for the pers. const. (cf. di/kaioi/ e)ste 1. 40. 13; bebaio/teroi a)\n h)=san 3. 11. 1). But a)/meinon in the adversative clause makes the neut. here highly probable.
katergasw/meqa: see on 11. 1.—a)pra/ktous: act., as always in Thuc.

ou) ga\r dh/: confidently rejecting, as 1. 122. 23; 5. 111. 11.—ka/lliston dh\ e)/rgwn: dh/ emphasizing the sup., as 31. 8. The pl. is rarer but more emphatic than e)/rgon. Cf. kindu/nwn 2. 42. 17; 7. 68. 17.— 22. kai\ ou)k a)ne/lpiston e)/moige: sc. au)to/, i.e. ka/lliston e)/rgwn, our success; and to me at least it is not improbable.
polu\ a)po\ th=s e(autw=n: sc. gh=s, cf. 21. 9; 1. 15. 9.—katw/rqwsan: empiric (gnomic) aor. GMT. 154; Gild., Syn. 255; Kühn. 386, 7.

pa/nta ga\r...cuni/statai : in support of ou) plei/ous. For cuni/statai, cf. 21. 4, 37. 15, 79. 13; 7. 15. 4.—h)/n te: correl. to ou)/te above (24): on the one hand, there is every prospect that we shall win by superior force; but on the other, if they fail through lack of supplies, we shall get the glory of it.
toi=s e)pibouleuqei=sin: sc. h(mi(=n, the objects of the attack.

o)/noma: = do/ca. Cf. 2. 64. 12; 4. 87. 25; 5. 16. 14; 7. 64. 14.—peri\ sfi/sin au)toi=s: by their own fault. Cf. peri\ au(tw=| ta\ plei/w sfale/nta 1. 69. 27; mh\ peri\ *mardoni/w| ptai/sh| h( *(ella/s Hdt. 9. 101. 13.—ta\ plei/w: cf. 16, and see on 1. 81. 8.—ptai/swsin: the Mss. ABFM all read ptai/wsin, but after sfalw=si above the aor. (C's reading) is clearly preferable here.
o(/per: as if e)/paqon were to follow, but construed with hu)ch/qhsan = h(/nper au)/chsin hu)ch/qhsan. But it is practically adv. here (= w(/sper).
e)pi\ tw=| o)no/mati w(s: on the repute that. Cf. 5. 16. 14 katalipei=n o)/noma w(s.
kai\ h(mi=n...cumbh=nai : and that to us something of the sort will happen is not beyond hope.

Above all seek outside alliances, in Italy, in Carthage, in Greece. But the threatened attack you will most surely ward off if you go to meet the enemy's fleet at the gulf of Tarentum. Possibly they would then turn back at Corcyra; at any rate you will have the favor of circumstances and the advantage of timely resistance.
tou\s me/n: i.e. the u(ph/kooi of 88. 19, and described 3. 103. 3 o)/soi *sikelw=n kata\ kra/tos a)rxo/menoi u(po\ *surakosi/wn kai\ cu/mmaxoi o)/ntes.

toi=s de/ : i.e. toi=s au)tono/mois (88. 20).—e)s th\n a)/llhn *sikeli/an: sc. pro\s tou\s *sikeliw/tas. Schol. ou)xi\
pa=san, a)lla\ th\n u(po\ *(ellh/nwn oi)koume/nhn. proei=pe ga\r peri\ tw=n barba/rwn.
o(/pws h)\ cummaxi/an poiw/meqa [h(mi=n] h)\ mh\ de/xwntai *)aqhnai/ous : note change of subject. See App.
de/xwntai: sc. oi( *)italiw=tai. Cf. au)toi=s below (7) after *karxhdo/na, and see on 1. 24. 9.
a)ne/lpiston: sc. to\ *)aqhnai/ous e)pelqei=n to be supplied from the context (mh/ pote *)aqhnai=oi . . . e)/lqwsin).

dia\ fo/bou ei)si/: they are in constant fear, as 59. 5. Cf. di) a)sfalei/as 1. 17. 4; di) o)/xlou ei(=nai 1. 73. 13; di) h(suxi/as 2. 22. 6; di) o)rgh=s 2. 37. 12, 64. 2; 5. 29. 13; di) ai)ti/as 2. 60. 16.
ta/x) a)\n i)/sws : see on 10. 13. a)/n belongsto e)qelh/seian.

ta/de : Schol. ta\ kaq' h(ma=s, i.e. Sicily.— 10. kai\ sfei=s: with inf., taking the place of kai\ au)toi/ in dir. disc.—h)/toi kru/fa ge h)\ fanerw=s: either secretly at least or openly, i.e. secretly at least, if not openly. The more probable supposition is put first. Cf. 38. 4, 40. 3; 2. 40. 8.

[h)\] e)c e(no/s ge/ tou tro/pou : in some way certainly, as e(ni/ ge/ tw| tro/pw| Plat. Phaedr. 242 B; Meno 96 D. Cf. e)k panto\s tro/pou 92. 15. [h)/] is rightly bracketed, after Baehr, as already the Schol. had recognized that the disjunctive expression h)/toi kru/fa ge h)\ fanerw=s admits no third. The reference is merely to the manner of rendering assistance (troops, ships, money).— 12. boulhqe/ntes: the emphasis is enhanced by the position at the end (“as soon as they will to do so,” aor.).— 13. o(/qen...eu)porei= : po/lemos is personified, as in 1. 122. 1. For the thought cf. 1. 83. 3 kai\ e)/stin o( po/lemos ou)x o(/plwn to\ ple/on, a)lla\ dapa/nhs, di) h)\n ta\ o(/pla w)felei=, and 2. 13. 21 ta\ de\ polla\ tou= pole/mou gnw/mh| kai\ xrhma/twn periousi/a| kratei=sqai.
to\n e)kei= po/lemon kinei=n: set in motion the war there; for it had not completely quieted down (36. 14). Cf. 1. 82. 3 o(/pla mh/pw kinei=n.

dia\ to\ cu/nhqes h(/suxon: on account of your characteristic love of ease. Cf. to\ pro/teron cu/nhqes . . . fobero/n 55. 14; to\ eu)prepe\s a)/spondon 1. 37. 16; to\ a)nqrw/peion kompw=des 5. 68. 6. The substantivized
adj. is a favorite usage with Thuc., expressing as it were the abstract idea in concrete form and so more effectively. See C. F. Smith, Trans. Amer. Phil. Assoc. XXV, 76-79.
h(/kista: opp. to ma/lista, not without irony, and the effect is enhanced by the paratactically opposed e)gw/ te . . . u(mei=s te and the contrasting pred. modifiers e)pi/kairon and o)ce/ws.

*sikeliw=tai : put first with emphasis, “we Greeks in Sicily.” See on 1^{4}. 10. 5.—ga/r: as 33. 7.— qe/loimen: the form qe/lein for e)qe/lein seems to occur in Thuc. only after long vowels, esp. h, unless 7. 18. 15 be an exception. See on 2. 51. 17.— 19. meta\ duoi=n mhnoi=n trofh=s: dependent gen. before the governing gen., as in 33. 2. Cf. Caes. B. G. 7. 74 dierum triginta pabulum frumentumque habere.
a)/kran *)iapugi/an: see on 30. 5.—dh=lon poih=sai: cf. dei=cai 77. 7.

peri\ th=s *sikeli/as : so Cl., with Dobree and Stahl, for peri\ th=| *sikeli/a| of the Mss., as required by the articular inf. (peri\)tou= e)kei/nous peraiwqh=nai. Thuc. might have written peri\ *sikeli/a| following Homeric and other precedent, but not the single preposition with different cases in the same sent. See App.— 23. to\n *)io/nion: see on 30. 5.—e)kplh/caimen: cf. kataplh/cantes 38. 5, and e)s e)/kplhcin kaqista/nai 36. 6.
e)s logismo\n katasth/saimen : forcethemto a consideration. Cf. e)s e)/kplhcin kaqista/nai 36. 6; e)s u(poyi/an kaqi/sthn 5. 29. 18; e)s e)lpi/das kaqi/sth 8. 81. 11.

o(/ti o(rmw/meqa me
 kte(.: explanation of logismo/s which extends to a)qumoi=en (35). The thing to be considered is twofold: (1) o(/ti o(rmw/meqa me
 e)k fili/as xw/ras fu/lakes ‘awaiting the Athenians at the Iapygian promontory, we have behind us a friendly land, which we must protect, and so need not venture far out into the open sea’; (2) to\ de\ pe/lagos au)toi=s polu\ peraiou=sqai meta\ pa/shs th=s paraskeuh=s ‘for them on the contrary the sea is a large place to cross with their whole fleet.’ Each of these clauses is then explained by a parenthetical addition: fili/as xw/ras by u(pode/xetai ga h(ma=s *ta/ras, and to\ pe/lagos polu\ peraiou=sqai by xalepo
 de\ . . . mei=nai. From these conditions results an alternative: either the Athenians must advance with undivided fleet or come on with only the part ready for battle leaving behind their transports. The consequence of the first possibility is expressed in kai\ h(mi=n a)
 eu)epi/qetos ei)/h bradei=a/ te kai\ kat' o)li/gon prospi/ptousa, and it (i.e. the fleet undivided so as not to break its order) coming up slowly and few at
atime would be at our mercy. The second part of the alternative (ei) d' au)=) admits again of two possibilities: either we could attack them tired out with rowing (and so with prospect of victory) or we could draw back before their superior force into the harbor of Tarentum; and they would then, in lack of supplies on a coast which offered no support, either while awaiting (me/nontes) their transports be surrounded and shut in by us (poliorkoi=nto—possibly Thuc. wrote talaipwroi=nto reduced to straits) or, attempting to sail along the coast, in constant uncertainty whether the coast cities would receive them (ei) u(pode/cointo), would be disheartened.
u(pode/xetai: vivid pres. for fut. Cf. 80. 18; 1. 121. 13; 4. 61. 27.

peraiou=sqai: limiting inf. after polu/. GMT. 763. See on 42. 8.—xalepo\n de\...mei=nai : rightly taken parenthetically by Cl., partly for the sake of parallel sentencestructure, partly that h( paraskeuh/ may more readily be supplied as subj. of eu)epi/qetos ei)/h.
kat) o)li/gon : necessary for kata\ lo/gon of all the better Mss.; and so was evidently read by the Schol. brade/ws te ple/ousa dia\ to\n e)n tw=| pela/gei ka/maton kai\ ou)k a)qro/a.
tw=| taxunautou=nti: sc. me/rei.
a(qrowte/rw| : i.e. a(qrowte/rw| o)/nti or genome/nw|.
koufi/santes : i.e. after loading all heavy baggage upon the transport vessels, thus lightening the others. Cf. Dio C. 33. 4 o(/pws koufi/santes diafu/gwsi.
ei) de\ mh\ dokoi/h : sc. h(mi=n e)piqe/sqai.
e)/sti : supposed case stated as a present possibility. Weidner suggested e)/stai.
met) o)li/gwn e)fodi/wn : in consequence of the koufi/santes.
poliorkoi=nto a)/n : would be blockaded by us, and so cut off from supplies.

th/n te a)/llhn paraskeuh\n a)poli/poien a)/n: would abandon the part of the fleet left behind.—kai\ ta\ tw=n po/lewn...ei) u(pode/cointo : Schol. kai\ ou)k ei)do/tes bebai/ws ei) ai( po/leis u(pode/contai au)tou\s a)qumoi=en a)/n.
a)qumoi=en : the a)/n of the ptc. clause belongs to the verb, as Arn. and Pp. explain.

a)poklh|ome/nous: exclusos, held
back, as 2. 76. 4; 4. 34. 22.
diabouleusame/nous: (aor.) after long consideration this way and that.
xrwme/nous: pres. of frequency.

e)cwsqh=nai...e)s xeimw=na : would through the lateness of the season be overtaken by winter. Cf. Hdt. 1. 31. 11 e)kklh|o/menoi th=| w(/rh|; Caes. B. G. 7. 11 diei tempore exclusus in posterum oppugnationem differt.—tw=| a)dokh/tw|: as below 50, 47. 11; 4. 36. 11; 5. 10. 33; 7. 29. 30, 43. 39. Cf. a)dokh/tws 3. 45. 25; 4. 17. 16. Not found elsewhere in Attic prose, but freq. in tragedy and late writers. Cf. a)prosdo/khton 2. 61. 13; a)prosdokh/tws 4. 29. 17; 7. 21. 19.
pro/fasin : sc. tou= to\n plou=n katalu=sai.
ei)/ ti a)cio/xrewn...o)fqei/h : if any considerable demonstration on our part were seen. For a)f' h(mw=n, cf. 4. 126. 32.

a)ggelloi/meqa d) a)\n...e)pi\ to\ plei=on : pers. const., as 37. 1.—eu)= oi)=d' o(/ti; adv., like dh=lon o(/ti, as below 58, 38. 2, 68. 14.—e)pi\ to\ plei=on: with exaggeration, as e)pi\ to\ mei=zon 1. 10. 20. Cf. Dio C. 41. 21. 4 e)pi\ to\ mei=zon a)gge/llesqai and 47. 24. 1 e)pi\ to\ foberw/teron a)gge/llesqai.

tw=n d) a)nqrw/pwn...i(/stantai : opinions of men veer according to what they are told. The figure is nautical, taken from the wind and sails. Cf. pro\s th\n e)kei/nwn gnw/mhn ai)ei\ e(/stasan 4. 56. 17; pro\s ta\s cumfora\s kai\ ta\s gnw/mas trepome/nous 1. 140. 4.
