tou\s proepixeirou=ntas...pefo/bhntai : fear more those who commence an attack, or who at any rate show betimes to aggressors that they will defend themselves. For the thought, cf. 4. 92. § 5. proepixeirei=n elsewhere only in late writers. ge, put forward for emphasis, affects the whole clause.
i)sokindu/nous: equal to the risk, i.e. able to defend themselves. Elsewhere only in late Greek. Cf. Dio C. 41. 55 i)so/rropoi a)llh/lois kai\ i)soki/ndunoi e)gi/gnonto.
o(/per a)\n nu=n...pa/qoien : i.e. ei) peisqe/ntes e)moi\ a)panth/saite au)toi=s. The idea is more fully expressed below (49) ei) d' i)/doien kte(.
dikai/ws kategnwko/tes: justly judging meanly (kata-) of us.
e)fqei/romen: conative.—para\ gnw/mhn: with reference to kate gnwko/tes. Schol. para\ th\n do/can au)tw=n.
tw=| a)dokh/tw|...duna/mei : for the thought, cf. 2. 89. 24 tw=| ou)k ei)ko/ti ple/on pefo/bhntai h(ma=s h)\ th=| kata\ lo/gon paraskeuh=|.
th=| a)po\ tou= a)lhqou=s duna/mei : = th=| a)lhqei= duna/mei.

ma/lista me\n...ei) de\ mh/ : as 1. 32. 4, 35. 23, 40. 13; 2. 72. 8; 3. 38. 24; 4. 104. 20; 5. 21. 15; 8. 91. 15.— ma/lista me\n tau=ta tolmh/santes: (with pei/qesqe) if possible by the execution of this bold plan, i.e. to go to meet the Athenians at the Iapygian promontory and fight them from there. The following infs. are grammatically dependent on pei/qesqe, though this gives way perhaps in thought to some more general word like dei=. Hence it is unnecessary to explain even parasth=nai = imv. (see 5. 9. 26), as some do.

parasth=nai...dei/knusqai : it must be brought home to every one that contempt of invaders is shown in active defense. For parasth=nai in this sense, cf. 68. 11, 78. 1; 4. 61. 8, 95. 3. It has dependent on it the infs. dei/knusqai and a)\n cumbh=nai, and of these infs. in turn the subjs. are the articular infs. to\ katafronei=n and to\ pra/ssein.

to\ katafronei=n : (cf. 33. 13) with pers. acc., as 8. 82. 6. —tw=n e)/rgwn th=| a)lkh=|: i.e. defense manifested by deeds. For position of gen., cf. 1. 9. 25; 5. 47. 65; 7. 24. 5. a)lkh/ in this old poetical sense, see on 3. 30. 7, and C. F. Smith, Proc. Amer. Phil. Assoc. XXII, xviii.
h)/dh: at once (cf. 25. 6, 29. 6), belongs with pra/ssein.
ta\s meta\ fo/bou paraskeua/s : i.e. preparations made in full sense of the danger. Cf. dedio/tas pareskeua/sqai 2. 11. 21.
w(s e)pi\ kindu/nou : as in the face of danger, with pra/ssein.
xrhsimw/taton a)\n cumbh=nai : cf. 5. 92. 1.
o(/son ou)/pw pa/reisin: are all but present, as 4. 125. 9; 8. 92. 45. Cf. o(/son ou) parei=nai 1. 36. 8 and freq.

The speech of Hermocrates has little effect. Athenagoras replies.— 1. tosau=ta: esp. after short speeches,
“so much and no more.” Cf. 24. 1 and see on 2. 12. 1; 3. 31. 1.

o( dh=mos e)n pollh=|...e)/ridi h)=san, oi( me
...oi( de/ : cf. kata\ custa/seis gigno/menoi e)n pollh=| e)/ridi h)=san, oi( me
 keleu/ontes e)cie/nai, oi( de/ tines ou)k e)w=ntes 2. 21. 15; also e)ge/neto ou)=n e)/ris toi=s a)nqrw/pois mh\ loimo
 w)noma/sqai 2. 54. 6. For collective noun with pl. verb, see on 32. 7.—oi( me/n: sc. le/gontes.

a(\ le/gei : sc. o( *(ermokra/ths, referring to the assertions made by him in 33. § 2 with reference to the undertaking of the Athenians, to which passage refers also to\ pisteu=on tw=| *(ermokra/tei (6). Cl., St., and Hude adopt the conjecture of Madvig (Advv. I, 326) le/getai, as reported.

oi( de/: adopted by nearly all recent editors, following Portus, for toi=s de/ of the Mss.; for the latter, with which must be supplied h)=n e)/ris (= lo/gos e)ristiko/s, e)rw/thsis e)ristikh/), is too hard an anacoluthon between oi( me/n and a)/lloi de/. Such transitions do occur, in longer periods, from an oblique case to nom., as 24. 11, but not from nom. to oblique case. Steup retains toi=s de/, “however harsh the anacoluthon, until a satisfactory emendation is found.”—ei) kai\ e)/lqoien: kai/ expressing skeptical doubt, as in 33. 15. See on 1. 15. 7.—ti/...o(/ ti ou)k : = ou)de\n o(/ ti ou)k. Cf. 3. 81. 24; 7. 87. 14, 25. See on 3. 39. 38. Kr. Spr. 51, 10, 11; Kühn. 555, 5.

kai\ pa/nu katafronou=ntes: just what Hermocrates had urged them not to do, 33. 13.—e)s ge/lwta e)/trepon: cf. Hdt. 7. 105. 1; Ar. Vesp. 1260.— 6. to\ pisteu=on: Thuc. freq. uses the neut. ptc. or adj. in personal collective sense. Cf. to\ a)nti/palon 2. 45. 5; to\ qerapeu=on, to\ mh\ u(pei=kon 3. 39. 29; to\ ei)=kon, to\ e)pio/n 4. 61. 20; to\ maxo/menon 4. 96. 17; to/ te fau=lon kai\ to\ me/son kai\ to\ pa/nu a)kribe/s 6. 18. 35; to\ u(ph/koon 6. 69. 25. See C. F. Smith, Trans. Amer. Phil. Assoc. XXV, 76-79.
parelqw\n au)toi=s: see on 15. 19.

dh/mou prosta/ths: as 3. 75. 9, 82. 4; 4. 46. 15, 66. 10; 8. 89. 31. Cf. prostasi/a tou= dh/mou 2. 65. 49; prostasi/a tou= plh/qous 6. 89. 17; proesta/nai tou= dh/mou 3. 70. 12; 6. 28. 8; 8. 65. 6; prosth=nai th=s po/lews 2. 65. 17. See on 4. 21. 9. It was not a state office, but a position of influence and confidence. See Arist. Ath. Pol. 28 and Holm, Gesch. Siziliens II, 420.

piqanw/tatos toi=s polloi=s: cf. the remark about the demagogue Cleon w)\n kai\ e)s ta\ a)/lla biaio/tatos tw=n politw=n tw=| te dh/mw| para\ polu\ e)n tw=| to/te piqanw/tatos 3. 36. 26; also 4. 21. 9.

div2.head: Speech of Athenagoras (36-40)
Speech of Athenagoras (36-40)
div2.p: However much we might wish the Athenians to attack us, the reports of their approach are only senseless fabrications of people who are always exciting disquiet. The insight and experience of the Athenians make such folly on their part incredible.

tou\s me\n *)aqhnai/ous...ou(/tw : accidental hexameter, as 2. 49. 18. For accidental trimeters, cf. 1. 80. 6; 3. 40. 39; 4. 17. 6. The ancients disliked such occurrences in prose; cf. Cic. De Orat. 3. 47. 182; Quint. 9. 4. 72. tou\s me\n *)aqhnai/ous, as antithesis to tou\s d' a)gge/llontas, placed before the rel. Cf. 1. 5. 11; 3. 39. 5.—ou(/tw kakw=s fronh=sai: i.e. as is alleged, with the result expressed in kai\ u(poxeiri/ous h(mi=n gene/sqai e)nqa/de e)lqo/ntas, where chief stress is on e)lqo/ntas. The sent. is colloquial, as indeed the tone of the whole speech.
ou)k eu)/nous: = kako/nous 24. 15.

th=s me\n to/lmhs ou) qauma/zw, th=s de\ a)cunesi/as : I am astonished not at their audacity but at their simplicity (cf. tolmh/santes 34. 52). th=s me\n to/lmhs said mockingly, as Cl. explains; for Athenagoras ascribes the whole alarm to the seare of his opponents. But Steup thinks it clear from 38. § 2 that Athenagoras considers that those who are spreading these reports are not acting sincerely and hence does not ascribe fear to them. For the gens. of cause with qauma/zein, cf. a)lgei=n 2. 65. 14; o)neidi/zein 3. 62. 15; xalepw=s fe/rein 2. 62. 18. See on 4. 11. 17.

ei) mh\ oi)/ontai e)/ndhloi ei)=nai: if they fancy their object is not transparent. Steup thinks the orator means that those who spread the reports would use the general panic to get control of the state (th=s po/lews a)/rxein 38. 6).

oi( ga dedio/tes i)di/a| ti: for those who have any private grounds of alarm.—e)s e)/kplhcin kaqista/nai: see on 34. 23.— 7. o(/pws...e)phluga/zwntai : that with the general fear they may hide their own. So Cl. and most recent editors, reading, for to\ sfe/teron of the Mss., to
 sfe/teron. Cf. Schol. o(/pws koinh=| fobh/santes a(/pantas to
 i)/dion fo/bon a)pokru/ywntai, and Valla, ut publico metu suum occultent. Cf. also Dexippus (Hist. Gr. Min., Dind. I, p. 196) imitating this passage, o(/pws a)
 to\ sfe/teron de/os e)phluga/zhsqe. See App.—e)phluga/zwntai: rare word, derived from h)lu/gh (= ski/a, sko/tos). See Hesych. s.v. h)lugisme/nos.

kai\ nu=n...tou=to du/nantai : so now these rumors (mean this) have this object. For du/nasqai = valere, cf. 1. 141. 5; 3. 46. 10.—<ai(/>: which, first added by Cl., is now generally
adopted, was prob. lost owing to the final letters of du/nantai. The rel. seems necessary to show that the following clause is explanatory of a)ggeli/ai and not epexegetical of tou=to. If <ai(/> be not inserted, we must put a semicolon (;) after du/nantai and regard the following sent. as an asyndetical explanation of a)ggeli/ai.
a)po\ tau)toma/tou : of themselves, sua sponte, as 2. 77. 17. With this, cu/gkeintai, which as pf. pass. of sunti/qhmi means have been invented, has the special force of a)rxh\n ei)lh/fasi.

e)k de\ a)ndrw=n : stronger than u(po\ a)ndrw=n. See on 2. 49. 1; 3. 69. 3; and C. F. Smith, Trans. Amer. Phil. Assoc. XXV, 66 f. —oi(/per ai)ei\ ta/de kinou=si: who are always stirring up things here, i.e. disturbing the public mind, as explained by the orator himself 38. § 2. Cf. the pass. kinei=sqai 3. 82. 3; 4. 76. 21; and ki/nhsis 1. 1. 8.
ou)k e)c w(=n...skopou=ntes : not forming your judgment from what these men report. Cf. 5. 68. 7 e)k toiou=de logismou= e)/cesti/ tw| skopei=n.
deinoi/ : Schol. sunetoi/, fro/nimoi. Cf. Isocr. 12. 229 a)/ndra deino\n kai\ pollw=n e)/mpeiron.

w(/sper e)gw\ *)aqhnai/ous a)ciw= : just as I hold the Athenians, sc. deinou\s kai\ pollw=n e)mpei/rous ei)=nai. Kr., who so explains with Cl., suggests oi(/ousper e)gw\ *)aqhnai/ous a)ciw=, comparing 3. 14. 7 gi/gnesqe de\ a)/ndres oi(/ousper u(ma=s oi(/ te *(/ellhnes a)ciou=si kai\ to\ u(me/teron de/os bou/letai. St. supplies a)\n dra=sai.
dra/seian : potential, as a)/n in e)c w(=n a)/n belongs to the verb. Cf. 7. 48. 22.

*peloponnhsi/ous u(polipo/ntas: comparison with 10. 1 (polemi/ous pollou\s e)nqa/de u(polipo/ntas) and 17. 26 (ou(/sper nu=n fasi polemi/ous u(polipo/ntas) suggests the loss here of polemi/ous. But the modifier here needed is sufficiently implied in the following closely correlated ptc. clause, kai\ to\n e)kei= po/lemon mh/pw bebai/ws katalelume/nous, before they have completely ended the war there.— 14. to\n e)kei= po/lemon: see on 34. 15.— mh/pw: not ou)/pw since katalelume/nous is part of the inf. clause dependent on ei)ko/s.
katalelume/nous : of settling hostilities, as 1. 24. 19 and freq. Cf. Hdt. 7. 146. 2 katalusa/menoi ta\s e)/xqras. See on 1. 81. 9.
au)tou\s...e)kei/nous : both referring to the Athenians. Cf. 61. 18, 20, and see on 1. 132. 31.

If however they should risk an attack, with their relatively inferior
forces, they would surely be destroyed.
o(/sw|: after, as well as before, a comp., in so far as (because). Cf. 1. 82. 19, and see on 1. 68. 11.

au)th/n: antithesis to *sikeli/an, Syracuse alone. Cf. 1. 139. 16; 3. 27. 9.—th=s nu=n stratia=s: governed by krei/ssw. The attrib. ptc. may stand after the noun, since there is another modifier (nu=n). See on 1. 11. 19.

ou)/q' i(/ppous: has its correlative in ou)/q) (correctly restored by Haacke for ou)d))o(pli/tas i)soplh/qeis, both to be construed with a)kolouqh/sontas. The clause ou)d' au)to/qen porisqhsome/nous modifies i(/ppous alone. As to i(/ppoi, cf. 43. 16, 98. 2.
i)soplh/qeis: rare word. For similar formations, cf. i)soki/ndunos 34. 46; i)sopalh/s 2. 39. 9; i)so/rropos 2. 42. 7; 7. 71. 2.
e)pi\ new=n ge e)lqo/ntas : in sense of fut. pf. belonging to o(pli/tas and explaining why the Athenian leaders would not have a hoplite force equal in numbers to the Syracusan.

me/ga ga\r...komisqh=nai : for it is a great thing to be brought so long a sail with actually their ships only, unladen as they are, i.e. with crew only, without hoplites or provisions. tosou=ton plou=n, const. as o(/son plou=n 30. 13. Abresch's suggestion that the whole sent. is parenthetical has been generally approved.

th/n te a)/llhn paraskeuh/n...ou)=san : third member dependent on oi(=s g' e)pi/stamai, and that all the rest of the equipment which must be provided against so large a city is not small, and therefore not easy to be procured by them. th\n a)/llhn paraskeuh/n refers prob. to provisions, arms, and implements. To take th/n te a)/llhn paraskeuh/n with porisqh=nai construed also with me/ga, as has usually been done, would weaken the force of kai\ au)tai=s tai=s nausi\ kou/fais and make the connection th/n te a)/llhn unintelligible. See App.

para\ tosou=ton gignw/skw: by so much do I decide otherwise, i.e. so much do I differ from those who spread these reports. Schol. para\ tosou=ton diafe/romai toi=s ta\ e(/tera diagge/llousi. See on 3. 49. 18. This expression is parenthetical here, just as eu)= oi)=d' o(/ti in 34. 43, 57. —mo/lis a)/n: a)/n, which belongs to diafqarh=nai, is there repeated. See on 4. 18. 17. GMT. 223; Gild., Syn. 467.— 12. ei) po/lin e(te/ran tosau/thn...to\n
po/lemon poioi=nto: the condition assumed by the speaker as most favorable for the Athenians is made clear from its opposite, the real state of the case: that in a land entirely hostile they would have their base only in an ill-provided camp and would be without freedom of movement owing to the enemy's cavalry. The opp. condition is expressed by po/lin e)te/ran tosau/thn o(/sai *sura/kousai/ ei)sin e)/xontes kai\ o(/moron oi)kh/santes, i.e. if they had in possession another city (in Sicily) as large as Syracuse and had settled therein contiguous (to Syracuse). ei) e)/lqoien means here merely if they should come (against us), and we have here a case of the opp. character to e)pi\ new=n e)lqei=n (cf. l. 7 e)pi\ new=n ge e)lqo/ntas, and l. 15 stratope/dw| te e)k new=n i(druqe/nti). Hence it is unnecessary to bracket, with Cl., e)/lqoien, or with v. H., St., etc., e)/lqoien e)/xontes. L. Herbst (on 2. 101 f.) explained po/lin e(te/ran e)/xontes, “with another city on board.” But the real meaning of Athenagoras is exactly that the Athenians e)k new=n would not be in any way dangerous in their advance upon the Syracusans. Cf. also 86. § 3.— 14. h)= pou/ ge dh/: much less then would they not be entirely destroyed. Cf. 1. 142. 7.—e)n pa/sh| polemi/a| *sikeli/a|: cf. e)s a)llotri/an pa=san 21. 12.

custh/setai : cf. 21. 4, 33. 26, 79. 13; 7. 15. 4.—stratope/dw| te e)k new=n i(druqe/nti: and in a camp pitched right from the ships (and therefore lacking in much). —kai\ e)k skhnidi/wn...e)cio/ntes : third member. skhni/dion found only here.— 16. a)nagkai/as paraskeuh=s: i.e. from meagre equipment and war materials; what was absolutely necessary rather than sufficient. For a)nagkai/as in this sense, cf. 2. 70. 5; 5. 8. 10; 7. 69. 21.— u(po\ tw=n h(mete/rwn i(ppe/wn: by reason of our cavalry, as 7. 78. 30.

to/ te cu/mpan: for to\ de\ cu/mpan of the Mss., as Haase emended, acc. to Thuc.'s usage for such comprehensive formulas. See on 3. 82. 34. It is only when a general remark is expressly opposed to what went before, as in 3. 116. 6, that Thuc. uses de/.
ou)d) a)\n krath=sai th=s gh=s : would not even effect a landing. Cf. 23. 7, and see on 3. 85. 13.

The Athenians, too, are aware of this. But ambitious men from here wish, by exciting fear of dangers from without, to help themselves into power; these I oppose with word and deed.— 1. tau=ta: with gignw/skontes.

ta\ sfe/tera au)tw=n...sw/|zousi : cf. 36.
15 a)gapa=n oi)/omai au)tou\s o(/ti ou)x h(mei=s e)p' e)kei/nous e)rxo/meqa. The pres. is conative.—eu)= oi)=d' o(/ti: as 34. 43.—e)nqe/nde a)/ndres: see on 10. 5.
ou)/te o)/nta ou)/te a)\n geno/mena: = a(\ ou)/te e)/stin ou)/te a)\n ge/noito.
logopoiou=sin : cf. Theophr. Char. 8 h( logopoii/a e)sti\ su/nqesis yeudw=n lo/gwn kai\ pra/cewn.
h)=toi...ge...h)/ : see on 34. 10.— lo/gois...e)/rgois : instrumental dats, with kataplh/cantas.
boulome/nous : suppl. pte. with e)pi/stamai and limited by a)/rxein.
kataplh/cantas : cf. 36. 6 th\n po/lin e)s e)/kplhcin kaqista/nai. The ptc. belongs as means to a)/rxein.

me/ntoi : confirmatory, to be sure.— polla\ peirw=ntes kai\ katorqw/swsin: by repeated attempts they may finally succeed. kai/ (etiam) of purposed result.— 8. h(mei=s de\ kakoi/: sc. e)sme/n, i.e. independent, not depending on mh/pote. The orator makes emphatic the reproach that the Syracusans do not know how to take timely precautions. For kako/s with inf. (GMT. 763; Kr. Spr. 55, 3, 3), Kr. cites Hdt. 6. 108. 15 timwre/ein e)ou=si ou) kakoi=si, and Soph. O. R. 445 manqa/nein e)gw\ kako\s sou=. For the like const. a)/ristoi a)pata=sqai, see on 3. 38. 21.—pri\n...w)=men : see on 10. 18, 29. 7.
ai)sqo/menoi: sc. ta\s e)piboula/s.
e)pecelqei=n : sc. toi=s e)pibouleu/ousin, bring to account (the plotters). Cf. 3. 38. 5; 5. 89. 3.

toiga/rtoi di) au)ta/ : toiga/rtoi (only here in Thuc.) referring to h(mei=s de\ . . . e)pecelqei=n, and di) au)ta/ to the persistent plots against the state.—h( po/lis...h(suxa/zei : cf. 36. 9 oi)/per ai)ei\ ta/de kinou=si.

turanni/das de/ : i.e. of Gelon and Hiero (485-467 B.C.).—kai\ dunastei/as a)di/kous: i.e. o)li/gwn a)ndrw=n (cf. 3. 62. 11; 4. 78. 15), referring to the unquiet time following the expulsion of the tyrants. Cf. Diod. 11. 72 f., 76. With both nouns sc. a)nairei=tai in the sense of u(pome/nei, pa/sxei.
w(=n: depends on ti (14).

periidei=n gene/sqai: for inf. after periidei=n, see GMT. 903, 6.—u(ma=s tou\s pollou/s: as Dem. 8. 1 (cf. to\ u(me/teron plh=qos l. 6); opp. to o)li/gous in l. 19.—tou\s de\ ta\ toiau=ta mhxanwme/nous kola/zwn: either, as
Cl. explains, democratic leaders ambitious for the tyranny, or, as Pp., a set of disturbers belonging to the oligarchs. See App.
mh\ mo/non: not ou) because the ptc. belongs to the inf. clause (periidei=n).
w(=n: gen. of the thing for which, with kola/zein, as 2. 74. 16; so with proamu/nesqai l. 18 below, and a)mu/nasqai 1. 96. 5. See on 4. 11. 17.
ei)/per...tis propei/setai : since indeed the man who is not first to guard will be first to suffer.

tou\s d' au)= o)li/gous: opp. to u(ma=s me\n tou\s pollou/s (14). Cf. 2. 44. 16; 5. 14. 12, 68. 6; 8. 78. 10, 104. 7.—ta\ me\n e)le/gxwn...dida/skwn : of these three means to be used against the aristocrats the two first are actual precautions: e)le/gxein, to convict them of guilt in dangerous plots, fula/ssein, to watch them in all their conduct. Only the third, dida/skein, is the orator's task, which is immediately carried out in what follows. Pp. wrongly finds the e)le/gxein in the conclusion of this chapter and in the next, the dida/skein in c. 40. kai/ before dida/skwn represents this teaching as not yet hopeless, and to this alone refers the foll. hope of success—dokw= a)/n moi ou(/tws (i.e. dida/skwn)a)potre/pein th=s kakourgi/as. kai\ dh=ta, and now, ironical, a vivid transition to the dida/skein, while both o(\ polla/kis e)skeya/mhn (a question which I have often considered) and kai/ in ti/ kai\ bou/lesqe make the effort of these people appear entirely unjustified.

w)= new/teroi: from this address it is clear that the majority of the o)li/goi, at least as described here by the orator, were younger men. Hermocrates indeed was no longer young, as he had represented Syracuse at the peace congress at Gela in 424 B.C. (4. 58 ff.); cf. also 72. § 2. In 39. 11 also the orator puts the duna/menoi by the side of the ne/oi.
po/teron : we have in this and the foll. a)lla\ dh/ (25) the same form of refutation by means of questions as in 1. 80. 16, only that there the second question is introduced by simple a)lla/.

h)/dh : already, i.e. before you have reached the required age for office.—o( de\ no/mos...a)tima/zein : Schol. le/gei peri\ tw=n ne/wn o(/ti ei)/rgontai th=s a)rxh=s dia\ no/mon ou)k a)timazo/menoi, a)lla\ kwluo/menoi dia\ th\n h(liki/an.

e)k : with causal force, as not seldomin Thuc., esp. with pass. verb forms. Cf. 40. 16.—ma=llon h)/: the comparison
is only in form, the second member being practically denied. See on 1. 73. 11; 3. 37. 12.

meta\ pollw=n i)sonomei=sqai: cf. Schol. i)so/timoi ei)=nai meta\ tw=n pollw=n. He prob. had therefore in his text tw=n pollw=n, which would answer very well to o)li/goi (19), and is adopted by Hude. i)sonomei=sqai found elsewhere only in late writers.

tou\s au)tou/s: i.e. the citizens of the same state. The democratic principle here expressed (di/kaion . . . a)ciou=sqai) is in direct opposition to the view of Alcibiades in 16. 16 ou)de/ ge a)/dikon e)f' e(autw=| me/ga fronou=nta mh\ i)/son ei)=nai.

The democratie form of government is wrongly reproached with an unjust distribution of power; rather would an oligarchy restrict all the advantages of government to a small number.— 1. fh/sei tis: introducing an objection, as [Xen.] Ath. Pol. 3. 7. For position, see on 10. 1.
cuneto/n, i)/son : for neut. pred. adj. with fem. subj., see G. 925; H. 617. Cf. 3. 37. 1, 16.—i)/son: Schol. di/kaion.
ta\ xrh/mata : wrongly suspected by Kr. and v. H. and supported by its repetition below (5).

a)/rxein a)/rista: depends on belti/stous. See on a)pata=sqai a)/ristoi 3. 38. 21 and kakoi\ profula/casqai 38. 8. Cf. also infs. with kra/tistos 1. 138. 19; 2. 81. 9; 8. 68. 6. a)/rista is unnecessarily rejected by v. H., as belti/stous by Cobet. The reading of Laur. belti/ous seems certainly a copyist's slip, esp. in the light of the following superlatives a)ri/stous, be/ltista, a)/rista.
prw=ta me/n : for the usual prw=ton me/n.
cu/mpan : the whole.
bouleu=sai: give advice (act.), as 3. 42. 25; 4. 68. 30; 8. 76. 33.
kri=nai: give decisions (of the popular assembly), as 1. 87. 2; 2. 40. 8; 3. 43. 17.

tau=ta: to be understood, with the Schol., of the three classes named (tou\s plousi/ous, tou\s cunetou/s, tou\s pollou/s), not, with Grote (“in a demoeracy these functions, one and all, find their proper place”), of the threefold activity (fula/ssein, bouleu/ein, kri/nein); for i)somoirei=n is, as in 16. 18, personal and active, to have an equal part, i.e. in the duties as in the advantages of public life. The sense is then: “and these classes alike both separately (i.e. according to the indicated difference of station) and all together (i.e. in the popular assembly) in a democracy share equally.” For tau=ta (neut.) of classes of citizens, cf. Alcibiades in 18. 33 to/ te fau=lon kai\ to\ me/son kai\ to\ pa/nu a)kribe/s.
o)ligarxi/a de\ kte(.: transition to direct discourse for the sake of vividness and intensity.
tw=n d' w)feli/mwn: part. gen. with pleonektei=, answering to tw=n me\n kindu/nwn metadi/dwsi.

cu/mpant) : (i.e. cu/mpanta ta\ w)fe/lima) so with v. H. for cu/mpan of the Mss.— a)felome/nh e)/xei: takes and holds. For this periphrasis for the perf., cf. 76. 10; 1. 38. 15. Freq. in tragic poets, esp. Soph. See GMT. 47; Gild., Syn. 295.— a(/: the just indicated objects of oligarchic effort. For the acc. with proqumou=ntai, cf. 5. 17. 6; 8.90.9.
oi(duna/menoi: = oi( o)ligarxikoi/, with whom are placed their pupils oi( ne/oi. See on 38. 22. Cf. [Xen:] Ath. Pol. 2. 18 h)\ plou/sios h)\ gennai=os h)\ duna/menos.
a)du/nata : in the sense of kai/per a)du/nata o)/nta.
katasxei=n : hold fast, as in 11. 1, 86. 9, not attain, as in 9. 16; 2. 62. 25. For the act. inf., see GMT. 763; Gild., Syn. 143.

Whoever has the common weal at heart will beware of oligarchic intrigues and not be deceived by false reports of danger. Our city will know how to ward off the Athenians if they come, and to preserve its freedom against machinations from within.— 1. a)ll) e)/ti kai\...au)/cete : if the bracketed words [h)\ a)maqe/statoi/ e)ste], which all the Mss. give, be retained, we may explain, with Jowett, that “the words a)ll' e)/ti kai\ nu=n were intended to be followed more closely by au)/cete, but Thuc. has gone off upon the word a)cunetw/tatoi.” The clause ei) mh\ manqa/nete kaka\ speu/dontes is then prot. to h)\ a)maqe/statoi/ e)ste w(=n . . . *(ellh/nwn, as ei) ei)do/tes tolma=te is to h)\ a)dikw/tatoi. After this practical parenthesis, the admonitory const. is resumed with a)ll' h)/toi. But it seems better, with Dobree and Madvig, to reject h)\ a)maqe/statoi/ e)ste as the gloss of a copyist, meant doubtless to balance h)\ a)dikw/tatoi and supply a government for w(=n . . . *(ellh/nwn. With the words h)\ a)maqe/statoi/ e)ste removed, w(=n . . . *(ellh/nwn becomes a limitation of pa/ntwn all the more emphatic after the intervening clause ei) mh\ . . . speu/dontes. After the extended address, expressed in two corresponding members (w)= a)cunetw/tatoi, ei) mh\ . . . speu/dontes . . . h)\ a)dikw/tatoi, ei) ei)do/tes tolma=te), the repetition of a)lla/ (3), to resume the intended admonition, is natural. —manqa/nete kaka\ speu/dontes: forsuppl. ptc. in indir. disc., see GMT. 904. kaka/ is cogn. acc.

h)/toi...ge h)/ : see on 34. 10.—maqo/ntes: removes the reproach of a)cunetw/tatoi, as metagno/ntes
that of a)dikw/tatoi.

cu/mpasi : pleonastic after koino/n, to emphasize the community of interest; to which further expression is given in the participial clause (h(ghsa/menoi kte(.), where the good results are promised esp. to the a)gaqoi/.

tou=to : sc. to\ koino\n th=s po/lews, i.e. the whole that is shared with others (metasxei=n). The more natural const. would be the gen. (tou/tou), which Steup adopts after v. H. and Badham.—kai\ i)/son kai\ ple/on: in equal or larger measure. For kai/ allowing a choice, see on 1. 82. 12.—ple/on h)/per to\ th=s po/lews: h)/per only here in Thuc., rare in Attic prose, found esp. in Hdt. and Hom. See App. —oi( a)gaqoi\ u(mw=n: with h(ghsa/menoi, in explan. appos. Cf. 32. 7.

ei) d' a)/lla boulh/sesqe: as opp. to to\ th=s po/lews cu/mpasi koino\n au)/cein, pointing to a continuation of oligarchical machinations.— 7. tou= panto\s sterhqh=nai: i.e. by death or banishment, in case of defeat in conflict with the opp. party.—kinduneu=sai: sc. a)/n from the first member, as Kr. explains. St. and Hude write ka)\n . . . kinduneu=sai. Cl. and Steup consider that by the hypothetic ei) a)/lla boulh/sesqe the inf. is sufficiently justified even without a)/n. See on 24. 3.—kai\ tw=n toiw=nde a)ggeliw=n...a)palla/ghte : havedone with such reports, understanding that you are dealing with those who perceive (your objects) and will not permit them. For pro/s, against, in relation to, see on 3. 43. 15. ai)sqanome/nous, which Laur. offers, would suit the context here; but ai)sqome/nous has the support of all the other Mss., and seems justified by 38. 8 h(mei=s de\ kakoi\ . . . ai)sqo/menoi e)pecelqei=n. The aor, was evidently before the Schol., who seems, moreover, to have read w(s pro\s proaisqome/nous (cf. Schütz, Ztschr. f. d. Gymnasialw. XXXIII, 1879, p. 94.
mh\ e)pitre/yontas: abs., as in 17 below. See on 1. 71. 5.

kai\ ei) e)/rxontai *)aqhnai=oi: to this corresponds kai\ ei) mh/ ti . . . e)stin. As only the second clause has to do with the idea contained in w(s pro\s ai)sqome/nous kai\ mh\ e)pitre/yontas, the first clause is in thought subordinate to the second, the sense being, “as this city, if the Athenians really come, will ward them off, so also etc.” For similar cases of parataxis, see on 9. 11.
kai\ strathgoi\...au)ta/ : as a side remark, to be indicated as a parenthesis.

oi(\ ske/yontai au)ta/: cf. to\ e(autou= mo/non skopw=n 12. 9; to\ seautou= skopw=n Plat. Phaedr. 232 D. au)ta/ of the matters in hand or under discussion, as 10. 5. See on 1. 1. 10. So au)tw=n (11), of them, i.e. the reports.—w(/sper ou)k oi)/omai: sc. ti
au)tw=n a)lhqe\s ei)=nai.

pro\s ta\s u(mete/ras a)ggeli/as kataplagei=sa : frightened at your reports. So pro/s with kataplagh=nai, as with xalepai/nein 2. 22. 1, 59. 10; with a)qumei=n 2. 88. 11; with dei=sai 3. 60. 2; with lupei=sqai 2. 64. 32. Cf. also 58. 4 and 7. 74. 1.
au)th\ e)f' au(th=s: itself of itself, i.e. without allowing interference from outside, esp. from you. Cf. e)f) e(autw=n 8. 8. 5; e)pi\ sfw=n au)tw=n 2. 63. 11; 5. 67. 3; 8. 63. 20.
tou/s te lo/gous a)f) u(mw=n : the speeches that come from you. Cf. 1. 37. 5; 7. 77. 17. For art. not repeated, see on 1. 51. 11; 4. 9. 5.
w(s e)/rga duname/nous: as meaning deeds. For force of duname/nous, cf. 36. 8. boulome/nous of Laur. is clearly a slip of the copyist and cannot be supported by boulo/menon ei)=nai 5. 65. 9.
e)k tou= a)kou/ein : sc. ta\s toia/sde a)ggeli/as. For e)k, see on 38. 24.
mh\ e)pitre/pein: as above (8), in reference to the hostile designs of opponents.

After the vehement speech of Athenagoras one of the strategi forbids further speeches, but calls upon all, in view of the reports, to be ready to repel the enemy, and promises for the government watchfulness and energy.
toiau=ta me/n: see on 19. 1.—tw=n strathgw=n: fifteen, acc. to 72. 12, constituting the highest executive authority.
a)nasta/s: rising to speak, as a)nista/menoi 8. 76. 9. Generally Thuc. uses parie/nai, come forward.
pro\s ta\ paro/nta: with reference to present circumstances, as 46. 27. See on 2. 22. 1.
diabola/s: personal imputations, such as Athenagoras had indulged in against the oligarchs.
tina/s: the orators as contrasted with tou\s a)kou/ontas, the assembly as a whole.—e)s a)llh/lous: against one another, as e)s tou\s a)/llous 1. 68. 2. See on 4. 28. 2.

pro\s ta\ e)saggello/mena: in view of the reports that are coming in (pres.).—o(ra=n o(/pws: with fut. indic., as 3. 46. 16; 5. 27. 9. GMT. 339. For o(/tw| tro/pw| with fut., cf. 33. 12, and see on 1. 107. 18.—ei(=s te e(/kastos kai\ h( cu/mpasa po/lis: appos. to implied h(mei=s.
kalw=s tou\s e)pio/ntas...a)mu/nesqai : cf. ka/llista a)munei=sqe au)tou/s 33. 12.
h)\n a)/ra: if indeed, as 3. 56. 15, 67. 4, indicating a doubt, as the speaker, in contrast with Athenagoras, considers the approach of the Athenians probable.—deh/sh|: sc. a)mu/nesqai.

ou)demi/a bla/bh tou= te to\ koino
 kosmhqh=nai kte(.: Cl. marks off th
 d' e)pime/leian kai\ e)ce/tasin au)tw=n h(mei=s e(/comen as a parenthetical explanation introduced by epexegetical de/, thus making kai\ tw=n . . . diapompw=n correl. to tou= te to\ koino
 kosmhqh=nai and dependent on ou)demi/a bla/bh. In agreement with Hermocrates (34. 1 ta/ te au)tou= paraskeuazw/meqa kai\ e)s tou\s *sikelou\s pe/mpontes kte(.) the strategus here refers to the most important means of defense, equipment at home and securing of assistance from outside, and rightly declares that neither will do harm if there shall be no need to defend themselves. e)ce/tasis, the regular expression for military reviews (cf. 45. 7, 96. 16, 97. 11; 4. 74. 11), suits tw=n diapompw=n ill; whereas the appendix a(/ma e)/s te kataskoph
 . . . e)pith/deion has its proper effect only as based on the assumption h)
 mhde
 deh/sh|. Cl.'s view and arrangement have met with general adoption. But see App.— 8. kai\ i(/ppois kai\ o(/plois: connected as in 1. 80. 12; 2. 100. 7.
oi(=s o( po/lemos a)ga/lletai: oi(=s xai/rei o( po/lemos, w(=n xrh/|zei, Schol. War is personified here, as in 34. 13; 1. 122. 4; 2. 36. 13; 3. 82. 18; 4. 18. 13.
h(mei=s: of the strategi, u(ma=s (13) of the popular assembly.—tw=n...diapompw=n : as Hermocrates had recommended 34. § 1. The word is found elsewhere only in App. Bell. Civ. 5. 71.

e)/s te kataskoph/n: with a view to finding out, i.e. “their readiness for war” (Cl.), or “their state of mind in the present condition of things” (St.), or “about the coming and the designs of the enemy” (Valla, etc.).—kai\ h)/n ti a)/llo fai/nhtai e)pith/deion: i.e. about the prospect of help or the seeking of future alliances.
ta\ de\ kai\ e)pimemelh/meqa: and this care we have in part already taken. ta\ de/ cogn. acc. with e)pimemelh/meqa, which refers to e)pime/leian.
kai\ o(/ ti a)\n ai)sqw/meqa : and whatever we find out, referring to kataskoph/n.

e)s u(ma=s oi)/somen : we will bring before you, i.e. for action by decree or otherwise. Schol. mhnu/somen u(mi=n. So fe/rein, nuntiare, referre, Dem. 6. 28 tou\s e)negko/ntas ta\s u(posxe/seis, and freq. in the tragic poets (Aesch. Sept. 40, Eur. Phoen. 1072). Hence neither a)noi/somen (the usual word), which Kr. conjectures, nor e)soi/somen (v. H.) is necessary here.

tosau=ta: used esp. of
short speeches. See on 35. 1; 2. 12. 1.
dielu/qhsan e)k tou= cullo/gou: as Hdt. 3. 73. 11, and dielu/qhsan e)k tou= sunedri/ou Hdt. 8. 56. 8. Cf. dielu/qhsan e)k tw=n lo/gwn 5. 113. 2.
The Athenian generals make for the fleet assembled at Corcyra the necessary preparation to cross over to Italy and Sicily.
oi( d) *)aqhnai=oi h)/dh...h)=san : continuation of 32. § 2.

e)pece/tasin: after-muster, found only here. It means the final review of the united fleet following that made of the separate divisions on setting out.— 4. stratopedeu/sesqai: Kr.'s conjecture, adopted by v. H. and Hude, for stratopedeu/esqai of the Mss. The two infs. are closely connected and express actions that are naturally closely related, and no good reason can be assigned for a change in tense. L. Herbst, Gegen Cobet, p. 17, explains stratopedeu/esqai, be encamped, as expressing esp. duration; but it was quite uncertain how long the individual dispositions would continue. St. cites in defense of the pres. 99. 9, 10, and Dem. 21, 55; but in both these passages the infs. do not stand so close together.
tri/a me/rh nei/mantes: sc. to\ stra/teuma or tou= strateu/matos. See Kühner-Gerth II, 1, 323. Cf. du/o me/rh poih/santes 62. 2.
a(/ma ple/ontes: Valckenaer's necessary correction of a)naple/ontes of the Mss.— lime/nwn: very few, of course, could accommodate the combined fleet.
e)n tai=s katagwgai=s: means putting in at various seaports. The corresponding verb is katai/rein, for Thuc. does not, like Hom., Hdt., and others, use kata/gesqai, corresponding to a)na/gesqai.

r(a/|ous a)/rxein : for limiting inf., see Gild., Syn. 143; GMT. 763. Cf. r(a/|dia katasxei=n 6. 9. 17; a)du/nata katasxei=n 6. 39. 12; r(a=|stoi a)mu/nesqai 4. 10. 15; xalepai\ a)/rcai 7. 14. 5; a)/cios qauma/sai 1. 138. 11; a)/cion fobhqh=nai 1. 142. 6; di/kaia kai\ pre/ponta a)pokri/nasqai 1. 144. 16; polu\ peraiou=sqai 6. 34. 27. Pass. infs. are rare in this const. in Thuc.: 3. 40. 8 di/kaios a)ntidi/dosqai; 3.94.22 xalepo\s katastrafh=nai.
te/lh : of divisions of ships, as 1. 48. 7.—prostetagme/noi: as 5. 8. 14.

ei)some/nas: fut. ptc. of the object in view as 6. 28; 1. 29. 3; 7. 83. 4.—
ei)/rhto: as 30. 4.
proapanta=n: i.e. before the fleet had reached the coast (kataplei=n). The word is found also 1. 69. 22; 4. 92. 28; and in late writers.

, 44. Enumeration of all divisions of the fleet. Voyage from Coreyra to the coast of Italy. The attitude of the cities of Italy is little friendly. The Athenians eneamp in the territory of Rhegium to await news from Sicily.— 2. tosh=|de: pred. put forward; cf. 44. 1 tosau/th after the enumeration. The whole = tosh/de h)=n h( paraskeuh/, h(=| meta\ tau=ta . . . e)peraiou=nto.
th=| paraskeuh=| : dat. of the whole followed by the parts in appos.

e)peraiou=nto: impf. of the events in progress; so also die/plei 44. 1 and cundie/balle 44. 7. Cf. 1. 114. 9; 3. 111. 11; 4. 25. 43.—tai=s pa/sais: in all. Cf. 1. 13, and see on 1. 60. 6.— 4. *(podi/oin: mase. ending in the most and best Mss. Elsewhere Thuc. in ethnic terms has also the fem.: 104. 11; 5. 84. 7. The relation of the Rhodians at that time to Athens was not just that of the Methymnaeans and Chians, (new=n parokwxh=| au)to/nomoi 85. 8); the Rhodians paid rather tribute, as appears from the tribute lists.
ai( me\n e(ch/konta: art. with numerals as parts of a whole. So 14 and freq.
stratiw/tides: = o(plitagwgoi/ 25. 8, 31. 20. See on 1. 116. 8.
kai\ tw=n a)/llwn cumma/xwn: the Methymnaeans and Corcyraeans seem to be esp. meant.— toi=s cu/mpasin: cf. 2. 2.
e)k katalo/gou: from the list of citizens of the three upper property-classes liable to military service.
qh=tes: citizens of the lowest property-class, whoserved usually as oarsmen, but in extraordinary cases, as here, served as mariners (e)piba/tai) with hoplite-armor.

tw=n u(phko/wn: see on 69. 21. They were, as the enumeration shows, 2150, i.e. 5100—2950 (1500 + 700 + 500 + 250). Kr.'s suggestion to insert the number in the text is unnecessary, since any observant reader could easily figure it out, just as the sum total (2900) of nonAthenian hoplites, which is not given. The mention, too, of the contingents of the different places (cf. 2. 9. § 4)
would have little value.

*mantine/wn kai\ misqofo/rwn: of Mantineans and other mercenaries (for kai/, see on 4. 5. 6), if the text is sound. But since the source of the non-Athenian hoplites, so far as these are not from the u(ph/kooi, is given in the context, and we have in 7. 57, 48 *mantinh=s kai\ a)/lloi *)arka/dwn misqofo/roi, Cl.'s conjecture that a)/llwn *)arka/dwn before misqofo/rwn has dropped out meets with favor from recent editors. The fact that acc. to 29. 11 tw=n *mantine/wn tine/s shared for the sake of Alcibiades the expedition to Sicily (cf. 61. § 5 and 1. 60. § 2) can as little be urged against the Mantineans being mercenaries, as the fact that acc. to 5. 81. § 1 the state of Mantinea could hardly have participated in that expedition. Cf. further Nicias' remark 22.3 kai\ h)/n tina e)k *peloponnh/sou dunw/meqa h)\ pei=sai h)\ misqw=| prosagage/sqai.
*krh=tes : cf. 25. 13.

*megareu=si yiloi=s fuga/sin ei)/kosi kai\ e(kato/n: see App. on 19. 2. These Megarians were doubtless of those who, acc. to 4. 74. § 2, in 424 B. C. after the departure of the Athenians, secretly withdrew (u(pech=lqon) in fear of the opposing faction.

i(ppagwgw=|: cf. 2. 56. 6; 4. 42. 4.—tria/konta i(ppe/as: these 30 cavalrymen are not mentioned again. At the beginning of the winter of 415-414 the Athenians are said to have no horsemen (sfi/sin ou) paro/ntwn i(ppe/wn 64. 8), and in 98. § 1 650 horsemen are mentioned as got together from various sources, but with no allusion to these 30. Hence G. Osberger (Festgrub für Heerwagen, Erlangen, 1882, p. 74 ff.) plausibly conjectures that i(ppe/as was miscopied for i(ppotoco/tas (94. 18; cf. 2. 13. 54; 5. 84. 9).

1. h( prw/th paraskeuh\ pro\s to\n po/lemon: as opp. to the a)/llh stratia/ voted in 7. 16. 6 and referred to 7. 42. 10 strato\n i)/son kai\ paraplh/sion tw=| prote/rw| e)pelhluqo/ta. Cf. also 94. § 4; 7. 16. § 2.
tou/tois: referring per synesin to paraskeuh/, which consequently means here only the troops.

tou\s sitopoiou/s: acc. to Nicias' advice 22. 8.—liqolo/gous: here and 7. 43. 15 about equal to the general term liqourgoi/ (4. 69. 6; 5. 82. 28). It indicates the importance of choice of stones for forts and other structures indicated by loga/dhn in 66. 10; 4. 4. 6, 31. 13.

e)s teixismo\n e)rgalei=a: cf. 7. 18. 28. It was the tools that were wanting at Pylos 4. 4. § 2.—ploi=a de\ e(kato/n: with sitagwgoi\ o(lka/des, as 30. 3.—a(\...cune/plei : most recent editors, including
Cl., follow Duker in bracketing a(/ and putting a full stop after die/plei, construing o(lka/des with cune/plei. But with this const. meta\ tw=n o(lka/dwn is disturbing, whereas placing a comma, with Kr., after die/plei removes all difficulty.

e)c a)na/gkhs: = h)nagkasme/na (cf. 22. 8).—meta\ tw=n o(lka/dwn: as well as the merchantmen. These 30 merchantmen also went e)c a)na/gkhs, as is clear from the following sentence.—cune/plei: sc. th=| pro\s to\n po/lemon paraskeuh=|.
e(kou/sioi : with o(lka/des, as 7. 57. 44 e(kou/sios with stratia/. Cf. kaq' e(kousi/an 8. 27. 16.
a(\ pa/nta: includes both o(lka/des and ploi=a.
cundie/balle : sc. th=| stratia=|. Schol. cundieperaiw/qh. In this sense prob. only here. Cf. diaba/llein 30. 6.
h( pa=sa paraskeuh/: i.e. the stratia/ with o(lka/des and ploi=a.
pro\s a)/kran *)iapugi/an : see on 30. 5.
kai\ w(s e(/kastoi hu)po/rhsan: sc. prosbalei=n, as (where and how) they severally found opportunity to land. Finite verb with w(s e(/kastoi as 4. 96. 29.

th\n *)itali/an: for the restricted use of the term in Thuc., see on 1. 12. 14.—ou) dexome/nwn...a)/stei : explained by 50. § 1. de/xesqai a)gora=| = a)gora\n pare/xein. The same explanation also for i(/datikai\o(/rmw|, the latter meaning only an open anchorplace, not a secure harbor (limh/n).— 12. *lokrw=n: i.e. the Epizephyrian Locrians or those near the promontory Zephyrium.—*(ph/gion...a)krwth/rion : cf. 4. 24. 13. On the earlier Sicilian expedition of the Athenians Rhegium had been their chief base (3. 86. 20, 88. 13, 115. 6; 4. 25. 53).
ou)k e)de/xonto: sc. oi( *(phgi=noi.
e)n tw=|...i(erw=| : i.e. in sacred ground belonging to the temple.

kai\ pro/s te tou\s *(phgi/nous: and to the Rhegians also. te, which adds a third clause after kateskeua/santo and h(su/xasan, is bracketed by Kr., St., and others. For kai\ . . . te, as here, cf. 1. 9. 20; 2. 68. 19; 8. 68. 12, 76. 19. See on 103. 21.
*xalkide/as o)/ntas: as 79. 6. Cf. Strabo 6. p. 257 c kti/sma e)sti\ to\ *(rh/gion *xalkide/wn.
*xalkideu=sin ou)=si *leonti/nois : see 3. § 3.

ou)de\ meq' e(te/rwn: see on 2. 67. 34.—o(/ti a)\n...cundokh=| : for the form, cf. 8. 84. 14 cunedo/kei de\ kai\ toi=s a)/llois cumma/xois tau=ta. As a fact all the Italiote cities held aloof for the moment from the war.
pro\s ta\...pra/gmata : with prosoi/sontai. Cf. 5. 105. 17.—o(/tw| pro/pw|: for the more usual o(/pws, with fut. indic., as 11. 23, 33. 12; 1. 107. 18; and freq.
ta\s pro/plous nau=s: cf. 42. § 2. It is to be inferred that these ships after completing their first task were sent to Egesta (cf. 46. 1). The rare word pro/plous also 46. 1; Isocr. 59 D, and later.
ei) e)/stin: pregnant, whether it really exists.
a(\ e)/legon...oi( a)/ggeloi : cf. 8. § 2. For impf. with the force of plpf., see on 4. 24. 3. Gild., Syn. 224; Kr. Spr. 53, 2, 8.
Meanwhile news comes to Syracuse of the arrival of the Athenians at Rhegium; and now measures for defense are pushed with zeal.
a)po\ tw=n katasko/pwn...h)gge/lleto : cf. 41. § 4. pollaxo/qen h)gge/lleto as 32. 14. For a)po/, see on 28. 1.

w(s e)pi\ tou/tois: with a view to this. For e)pi/ here and 8 below, cf. 1. 65. 7; 7. 62. 14.— 4. ou)ke/ti h)pi/stoun: as before, 32. § 3, 35. § 1.—e)/nqa me/n: = pro\s me\n tou/s, i.e. tou\s u(phko/ous. Cf. o(/qen 21. 11.

pro\s de\ tou/s: i.e. tou\s au)tono/mous. For the order, cf. 66. 6. On the matter, cf. 34. § 1.—ta\ peripo/lia: Schol. ta\ e)n th=| xw/ra| frou/ria. Cf. 3. 99. 4; 7. 48. 32.— 6. ta\ e)n th=| po/lei: proleptic obj. of e)sko/poun.
o(/plwn e)ceta/sei kai\ i(/ppwn : see on 41. 10.

o(/son ou) paro/nti: (sc.
pole/mw|) also 1. 36. 8. For o(/son ou), all but, tantum non, see on 2. 94. 6.

Those who had been sent to investigate the matter announee to the Athenians that the reports of the Egestaeans as to their resources are untrue. Story of the deception practiced upon the former Athenian envoys in Egesta.
e)k th=s *)ege/sths: attached proleptically to the subj. See on 1. 8. 9. For the matter, cf. 44. § 4.
a(\ u(pe/sxonto: cf. 6. § 2, 3; 8. § 2.
fai/netai: are to be found.

a)ntekekrou/kei: Schol. para\ gnw/mhn a)phnth/kei, a)pebebh/kei. Cf. Dem. 18. 198 a)nte/krouse/ ti kai\ ge/gonen oi(=on ou)k e)/dei. The verb agrees in number with the nearest subj. (tou=to), in spite of the directly following pl. oi( *(rhgi=noi ou)k e)qelh/santes. To both subjects belongs prw=ton: because to them at the start not only this (the disappointment at Egesta) had come in the way, but the refusal of the Rhegians. This const. of prw=ton is unavoidable because the second cireumstance antedated the other. prw=ton here, as l. 103. 16 and freq., strengthens a)/rxesqai. Van H.'s conjecture prw/tous would introduce an unusual sort of pleonasm.—oi( *(rhgi=noi ou)k e)qelh/santes: for the subst. force of the pte., see App. on 4. 63. 2.
pei/qein kai\ ei)ko\s h)=n: sc. custrateu/ein.
prosdexome/nw| h)=n : for this periphrasis see GMT. 900; Kr. Spr. 48, 6, 4. See on 2. 3. 10; 7. 35. 8. On the matter, cf. 12. 5, 22. 14.

toi=n e(te/roin: Alcibiades and Lamachus.—kai\ a)logw/tera: rather incomprehensible (or unexpected). “Somewhat disconcerting.” W. E. Heitland (Jour. of Philol. XXIV, 8). For the force of the comp., cf. biaio/teron a)nagago/menoi 2. 33. 14; a)naxw/rhsis biaiote/ra 4. 31. 15; au)qade/stero/n ti a)pekri/nato 8. 84. 5.

oi( de\ *)egestai=oi: the epexegetical de/ introduces an added explanation of the whole occurrence, the aorists from e)cetexnh/santo to dieqro/hsan (23) with the force of plpfs. Cf. 2. 2. 11; 4. 1. 4.— 10. oi( prw=toi pre/sbeis tw=n *)aqhnai/wn: cf. 6. § 3, 8. § 2.

h)=lqon au)toi=s: for the dat., see on 1. 13. 12. Kühn. 423, 5. See C. F. Smith, Trans. Amer. Phil.
Assoc. XXV, 69 f.

e)/s te to\ e)n *)/eruki i(ero/n: te correl. with kai\ i)di/a| (16). The sent. itself, as part of toio/nde ti, follows, as generally, without ga/r or other copula. See on 1. 89. 2.— 14. a(\ o)/nta a)rgura=...parei/xeto : which being silver made, with a small money value, a much greater show. It seems that the envoys, dazed by the number of silver consecrated vessels, without estimating their value imagined the treasures to be much more than what they saw. One must remember that it was a question of monthly subsidies of 60 talents (about $ 75,000). See 8. § 1. As to the form of expression, cf. 1. 10. 15 diplasi/an a)\n th\n du/namin ei)ka/zesqai a)po\ th=s fanera=s o)/yews th=s po/lews.
ceni/seis poiou/menoi : periphrasis for ceni/zontes. ce/nisis, which is found only here, Pollux (6. 7) calls traxu/. See Lobeck ad. Phryn. p. 351.
kai\ xrusa= kai\ a)rgura=: cf. 32. 6.
e)se/feron: impf. of repeated occurrences.
e(/kastoi: v. H. writes e(/kastos here as in 15. 17.
w(s e)pi\ to\ polu/: for the most part; so with most of the best Mss. for w(s e)pi\ polu/ (see on l^{4}. 12. 4).
parei=xe: sc. tau=ta general subj. to be supplied from the context. See on 31. 30; 2. 3. 14.
dieqro/hsan: had spread the report. Cf. 8. 91. 1 (where blame is implied) and Xen. Hell. 1. 6. § 4.
kai\ oi( me\n kte(.: return to main narrative, oi( me/n referring to the first envoys of the Athenians.
ai)ti/an ei)=xon: as 14. 5; 3. 13. 34; here pass. with u(po/. Cf. Plato, Apol. 38 c; Hdt. 5. 73. 17.
pro\s ta\ paro/nta: cf. 41. 3, and see on 2. 22. 1.

In the council of generals Nicias declared for bringing Selinus to terms
with Egesta either peaceably or forcibly, but before the other cities to make a display of Athens' power, then without further operations return home.— 2. h)=n gnw/mh: with inf., as 1. 62. 8.— 3. e)f' o(/per: for which very purpose, as 1. 59. 6. On the matter, cf. 8. § 2.— 5. o(/sasper h)|th/santo: referring to 8. 4. 7. dialla/cai au)toi=s: Schol. toi=s *)egestai/ois. Codex Laur. gives au)toi=s, most Mss. au)tou/s owing to misconception. For const., cf. 2. 95. 7.—kai\ ou(/tw: and so, i.e. when that is done, as 5. 38. 5, 55. 8. Cf. 48. 10, 49. 15.— parapleu/santas: generally used abs., with acc. also 62. 7, 104. 14; 7. 56. 2; 8. 56. 21, 94. 4, 101. 9. par' au)th\n th\n gh=n 8. 104. 2.
e)pidei/cantas...po/lews : cf. 11. 14.
e)s tou\s fi/lous kai\ cumma/xous: even Nicias can no longer avoid recognizing the Egestaeans as real allies of the Athenians. See App. on 6. 11.
di' o)li/gou: dia\ taxe/wn, Schol. See on 11. 14.— 11. a)po\ tou= a)dokh/tou: periphrasis for adv., as a)po\ tou= profanou=s 1. 35. 17, 66. 7; a)po\ tou= eu)qe/os 3. 43. 5. See on 34. 50.
th=| po/lei: with mh\ kinduneu/ein, not to imperil the safety of the state (cf. 9. 15, 10. 17), which is made still worse by dapanw=ntas ta\ oi)kei=a, expending their own resources.
ta\ oi)kei=a: as opp. to the resources of the Egestaeans.

Alcibiades, on the contrary, advises to win over to the Athenian alliance not only the other Hellenic cities, except Selinus and Syracuse, but also the Sicels and then to attack Syracuse and Selinus, unless these cities should yield to the Athenian demands.— 2. a)pra/ktous: Pp.'s and Kr.'s conjecture for a)pra/ktws of the Mss. Cl. retained the adv.; but as Thuc. uses the adj. often, while the adv. occurs elsewhere only in late writers (e.g. Plut. Arist. 18, Cato M. 1), it seems best to adopt the adj., as most recent editors
do. For correlation of adv. and adj., see on 3. 4. 4.
e)s ta\s po/leis e)pikhrukeu/esqai: this verb with e)s only here in Thuc., with pro/s and pers. subj. 4. 108. 16; 7. 49. 5; 8. 70. 12; with w(s 7. 48. 14; freq. with dat. (Kr.).
ta\s a)/llas: referring clearly to the other Siceliote cities, which Nicias also refers to as a)/llai in 20. 10. Cf. 41. 10.— tou\s *sikelou\s tou\s me\n kte(.: see on 34. 2.

e)/xwsi: sc. oi( *)aqhnai=oi, i.e. may have always at disposal (a)po\ tou/twn tw=n po/lewn Schol., perhaps also, as Pp. suggests, kai\ tw=n *sikelw=n). St. writes in his text edition sxw=si (so Bm.), and several recent editors adopt Dobree's conjecture pare/xwsi (de Siculis). Even if the Athenians had brought along not only troops but provisions (cf. 44. § 1), additions in both directions would be welcome. For the provisioning, cf. e.g. 88. § 4, 103. § 2, and for troops 62. § 5, 103. § 2.

*messhni/ous: already previously allies of the Athenians for a short time (3. 90. § 4; 4. 1. § 1).—e)n po/rw|...kai\ prosbolh=| ei)=nai au)tou\s th=s *sikeli/as : for they are most conveniently situated for the passage to and landing in Sicily. The expressions e)n po/rw| katw|kh=sqai (1. 120. 8) and prosbolh\n e)/xein (4. 1. 5) are here united with strengthened meaning. For the obj. gen. with prosbolh/, cf. 4. 1. 5; 7. 4. 38.

e)fo/rmhsin: i.e. means of watching and opposing every hostile movement. This meaning is clear from 8. 15. § 1, where of the e)formou=sai nh=es first eight a)polei/pousi th\n fulakh/n, then the remaining twelve likewise th\n e)fo/rmhsin. See on 49. 18.— 10. tis: one, with tacit but unmistakable reference. Cf. 4. 68. 24, 28; 5. 14. 22.—ou(/tws h)/dh: so now, after ptc. as 1. 37. 4.
oi( me/n, oi( de/: the former oi( *selinou/ntioi, the latter oi( *surako/sioi, in chiastic order as 1. 120. 20; 2. 64. 28; 3. 63. 15; 5. 16. 3.
*leonti/nous e)w=si katoiki/zein: subj. of inf. is tou\s *)aqhnai/ous. Cf. 8. 12.

Lamachus, however, was for immediate attack on Syracuse, which would insure to the Athenians all the advantages of a surprise and would win over the rest of the Siceliotes. Megara he claimed would be the most suitable ship-station.
a)/ntikrus plei=n: to sail direct. Cf. 2. 4. 26. a)/ntikrus elsewhere in Thuc. in fig. sense. See on l. 122. 15.
pro\s th=| po/lei: near the city (i.e. under the walls). Cf. Plut. Nic. 14 ma/xhn e)/ggista th=s po/lews tiqe/nai.
th\n ma/xhn poiei=sqai : cf. 5. 65. 17.
xroni/sh|: delay, lose time. Also 8. 16. 12.

kai\ th=| o)/yei katafronei=n: also on sight despise. The simple dat. is induced by antithesis to th=| gnw/mh| a)naqarsou=ntas, hence v. H.'s conjecture ka)n th=| o)/yei is unnecessary. Cf. 2. 11. 21 th=| me\n gnw/mh| qarsale/ous strateu/ein, tw=| de\ e)/rgw| dedio/tas pareskena/sqai.

katafronei=n : opp. to e)kpeplhgme/noi (4). Cf. 11. 20, 33. 13, 35. 5. The inf. pres. (not fut.) to express generality. See St., Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 6.—ai)fni/dioi: preferable to ai)fni/dion of the Mss., acc. to Thucydidean usage (4. 75. 18; 8. 14. 6, 28. 9). For the emphatic position, cf. 13. 10 and see on 1^{4}. 10. 5. From e(/ws . . . prosde/xontai, it is clear that ai)fni/dioi refers only to the immediate advance without further preparations (cf. a)/ntikrus plei=n l. 1 and tw=| au)ti/ka kindu/nw| th=s ma/xhs l. 10), not to an unexpected attack. That the Syracusans expected an immediate attack is confirmed by 63. § 2.

sfa=s perigene/sqai: this is the reading of all Mss., but Bk.'s conjecture sfei=s, on account of plei=stoi (9), has been adopted by St., Hude, and Bm. (not in text edition). But the accus. is sufficiently protected by 96. 5; 3. 111. 13; 7. 21. 17; 8. 32. 15.—kata\ pa/nta: explained by the following datives.

a)polhfqh=nai: without a)/n after ei)ko\s ei)=nai. GMT. 416, 421. See on 1. 81. 13. The Mss. vary between a)polhfqh=nai and a)poleifqh=nai, but only the former suits the context (dia\ to\ . . . h(/cein).—dia\ to\ a)pistei=n...h(/cein : on account of disbelief in our coming, not referring to present conditions and the advance proposed by Lamachus (now the Syracusans expect an immediate attack), but to the past and the coming of the Athenians to Sicily, which the Syracusans had so long not credited. Of the sentiments dominant in Syracuse till quite recently (cf. 45. 4 ou)ke/ti h)pi/stoun) Lamachus might very well have got knowledge. On a)pistei=n mh/ with dependent inf., cf. 4. 40. 5 and
see on 3. 32. 13. GMT. 807.

kai\ e)skomizome/nwn au)tw=n...kaqe/zhtai : and while they were allempting to carry in (their property) the army would not lack supplies, if it encamped under the walls victorious. Against this explanation of Cl.'s Steup objects that the a)polhfqh=nai must have put a stop to the e)skomi/zesqai, and he conjectures something like e)sbalou=san e)/ti to have fallen out before e)skomizome/nwn.
e)skomizome/nwn : used abs., cf. 2. 18. 15.—xrhma/twn: supplies, not merely money. Cf. 97. 27; 1. 49. 21; 3. 74. 10; 7. 24. 7, 25. 7.
kratou=sa: victorious, i.e. in the ma/xh mentioned in 3 and 11.
ou(/tws: see on 47. 7.—h)/dh ma=llon: cf. 59. 5, 105. 14.
periskopou=ntas o(po/teroi krath/sousi: cf. 4. 73. 5 periorwme/nous o(pote/rwn h( ni/kh e)/stai.
e)panaxwrh/santas : returning thither (from their first attack on Syracuse), i.e. with the fleet, for the land army would be encamped before the city (pro\s th=| po/lei e)kaqe/zeto).

e)fo/rmhsinta\ *me/gara: on the reading, see App. Against Alcibiades, who had praised the advantages of Messene as lime/na kai\ e)fo/rmhsin i(kanwta/thn (48. 8), Lamachus recommends the nearer Megara i.e. Hyblaca (4. 8), which the Syracusans under Gelon had destroyed (4. § 2, 94. § 1), as nau/staqmon (ship and supply station, see on 3. 6. 10) and e)fo/rmhsin (watch station against the enemy, see on 48. 8). For the art., cf. 75. 4, 97. 25; 7. 25. 15.

a)pe/xonta...ou)/te plou=n polu
 ou)/te o(do/n : cf. 97. 8 ou)/te plou=n ou)/te o(do
 pollh
 a)pe/xei.

Still Lamachus accepts the view of Alcibiades. The latter thereupon negotiates in vain with the Messenians; then all three generals undertake with 60 ships a voyage of reconnoissance to Naxos, where they are received, to Catana, where they are rejected, and to Syracuse, where through 10 ships sent into the Great Harbor they announce their intentions with reference to Leontini and get information about preparations at Syracuse; whereupon they return to Catana.

prose/qeto au)to/s: so all the better Mss. except M, not kai\ au)to/s, which would indicate adhesion from others. It is only emphasized that Lamachus, although of a different opinion, for himself adopts the view of Alcibiades, to avoid a split. There with the divergent view of Nicias is implied, which however did not
prevent, as shown in what follows, a start being made on the plan of Alcibiades. 2. th=| au(tou= nhi/: i.e. with the trireme which as trierarch he had fitted out and commanded; so 61. 25 e)/xwn th\n e(autou= nau=n.
e)s *messh/nhn : the winning of Messene had been designated by Alcibiades (48. 7) as the next task of the Athenians.
e)/peiqen: impf. of continued effort. See on 4. 4. 1.—po/lei: in the city, dat. as 4. 103. 15.

a)\n ou) de/casqai...pare/cein : transition from aor. inf. with a)/n to fut. inf.; see on 1. 127. 6. The refusal is not so definite as the concession: “in the city they could not receive them, they would however provide them with provisions outside.” For the unusual order a)\n ou) —for which v. H. writes ou)k a)/n—Kr. compares from Attic prose Xen. Anab. 2. 3. 18 and Dem. 9. 9. See Kr. Spr. 59, 7, 5.
cumplhrw/santes: i.e. manning the squadron of 60 ships from the three divisions in common (42. 5).
e(/na: most prob. Nicias, who had opposed the whole plan of Alcibiades. Certainly it could not have been Alcibiades (51. 4).
a)/ndres: see on 10. 5.—ta\ *surakosi/wn boulo/menoi: more freq. fronou=ntes (51. 8; 3. 68. 18; 5. 84. 5; 8. 31. 7). See on 2. 79. 8.
*thri/an: now Fiume di S. Leonardo, near which Leontini was situated. Holm, Gesch. Siz. I, 28.

e)pi\ ke/rws e)/xontes ta\s a)/llas nau=s: i.e. the 50, after 10 of the 60 had been sent off, remained in the line in which they had sailed out. For e)pi\ ke/rws, see on 32. 10. It is necessary to punctuate with comma before de/ka, since also the 10 ships e)pi\ *surakou/sas e)/pleon. For transition from ptc. to fin. verb, see on 1. 57. 10; 4. 69. 11, 106. 4.

e)s to\n me/gan lime/na pleu=sai: this and the foll. infs. to execute the task indicated in prou/pemyan. Cf. similar infs., after prota/ssein 100. 13; after pe/mpein 4. 132. 15; 6. 8. 13, 15; after peripe/mpein 5. 2. 11; after u(pekpe/mpein 4. 8. 12; after komi/zein 5. 56. 12. For the position of te, see on 34. 17.—
15. e)sti kaqeilkusme/non: for the periphrasis, see App. on 1. 1. 5.
e(autw=n: emphasizing the esp. important obj. *leonti/nous. Cf. 1. 17. 5 e)pra/xqh a)p' au)tw=n ou)de\n e)/rgon ei) mh/ ti pro\s perioi(kous tou\s au(tw=n e(ka/stois. Kr. Spr. 51, 2, 6.

tou\s o)/ntas e)n *surakou/sais *leonti/nwn...a)pie/nai : cf. 5. 4. 10. The inf. after khru/ssein (as 4. 37. 8; 5. 115. 7; and after a)nei=pen o( kh=ruc 2. 2. 27) because it is here not, as before (o(/ti . . . cugge/neian), an announcement, but a demand.
*)aqhnai/ous: in most Mss. miswritten *)aqhnai/wn. The prep. is not repeated, as 1. 84. 19; 4. 41. 6.
polemhte/a: see on 1. 7. 2.

While the Catanaeans are holding a popular assembly a part of the Athenian army break into the city; thereupon the adherents of the Syracusans withdraw and the remaining citizens declare for the Athenians, who then betake themselves with their whole fleet from Rhegium to Catana.
e)kklhsi/as: tw=n *katanai/wn Schol.

th
 me
 stratia
...ei)pei=n : Pp. compares the bearing of the Acanthians toward Brasidas 4. 84. § 2.
ei)/ ti bou/lontai: sc. ei)pei=n. See App. on 1^{4}. 91. 18.— 4. pro\s th\n e)kklhsi/an tetramme/nwn: their attention wholly occupied with the assembly. See on 2. 40. 6.
e)nw|kodomhme/nhn kakw=s: sc. tw=| tei/xei. kakw=s = a)te/xnws, saqrw=s (Schol.).

dielo/ntes: breaking through. Cf. 4. 48. 11, 110. 18, 111. 8.—h)go/razon: Schol. a)nti\ tou= e)n a)gora=| diatri/bein. Freq. in Hdt. (2. 35. 9; 3. 137. 3, 139. 10; 4. 78. 21, 164. 21), rare in Attic (Ar. Eq. 1373; Lysist. 633; Xen. Hell. 2. 4. 14; Resp. Lac. 9. 4). Cf. 2. 2. 21 qe/sqai e)s th\n a)gora\n ta\ o(/pla (under similar circumstances).

e)s th\n po/lin: rightly bracketed by v. H. and most recent editors. e)selqo/ntes alone is quite as intelligible here as e)selqo/ntas in 3; besides, if expressed,
e)s th\n po/lin must surely have come before or right after e)selqo/ntes.
ta\ tw=n *surakosi/wn fronou=ntes: see on 50. 11.
e)/ndon: it is not necessary to add o)/n, with v. H. and others. Cf. 5. 56. 5, where Cl., it is true, thought of adding o)/ntas before pa/ntas.
u(pech=lqon : of the same thing also 4. 74. 7.—ou) polloi/ tines: see on 1. 5.

diapleu/santes: this reading of Vat. is, with Bk., Kr., and Cl., to be preferred to pleu/santes of the rest of the Mss. diaplei=n is the proper term for crossing a sea, as 44. 1, 50. 3. Cf. also dia/plous 31. 43.
pa/sh| h)/dh th=| stratia=|: no more with only a part as 50. § 2.
kateskeua/zonto: were arranging, i.e. set about arranging; meanwhile came the following announcements (e)shgge/lleto). On the camp, cf. 61. § 3, 75. § 2, 88. § 5.
Vain attempt of the Athenian flect to win over the Camarinaeans. First, hostilities after landing in the territory of the Syracusans. Return to Catana.
e)/k te *kamari/nhs: correlated with kai\ o(/ti *surako/sioi kte(. (2); the announcements came simultaneously from different quarters.

au)=qis: further, after prw=ton (3) implying advance not retrogression. Cf. 90. 4; 5. 36. 11, 76. 9; 8. 22. 13, and see on 1. 70. 9.—sxo/ntes e)s: see on 3. 29. 5 and 7. 1. 14.—e)s to\n ai)gialo/n: on the open coast, as opp. to limh/n, in which they were not received.

sfi/si ta\ o(/rkia ei)=nai kte(.: accordingly the Athenians must have based their call to the Camarinaeans to join them on a sworn agreement between Camarina and Athens. But this compact was hardly, as Cl. supposed, the peace of Gela (4. 65. § 1, 2). For we have no warrant for assuming that this peace had regulated also the relations of the Athenians to the Sicilian cities to which they had lent assistance against Syracuse, i.e. Leontini, Camarina, etc. On the other hand, the passage in 75. § 3 punqano/menoi tou\s *)aqhnai/ous e)s th\n *kama/rinan kata\ th\n e)pi\ *la/xhtos genome/nhn cummaxi/an presbeu/esqai, ei)/ pws prosaga/gointo
au)tou/s (cf. 82. § 1 a)fiko/meqa e)pi\ th=s pro/teron ou)/shs cummaxi/as a)nanew/sei) makes strongly for an alliance concluded between Athens and Camarina at the time of the command of Laches (3. 86. § 1 ff.).
mia=| nhi/: i.e. coming with only one ship and asking admittance. Cf. 2. 7. 13; 3. 71. 4.
metape/mpwsin: used by Thuc. in both act. and mid. with same force. See on 1. 112. 6.
a)poba/ntes: on the return to Catana.—kata/ ti th=s *surakosi/as: at some point of Syracusan territory on the coast.
poihsa/menoi kai\...bohqhsa/ntwn : for combination of ptes. concordant and absolute, cf. 4. 54. 16, 133. 3. GMT. 876.
tinas e)skedasme/nous: of the Athenians who had scattered a(rpagh\n poiou/menoi.

They find the Salaminia just arrived from Athens to summon to trial Alcibiades, on charges preferred against him by the state, as well as some others, accused partly with him of profanation of the mysteries, partly of mutilation of the Hermae. For at Athens prevailed now the greatest fear and mistrust in recollection of the tyranny of the Peisistratids.
th\n *salamini/an nau=n: one of the two Athenian state triremes. See on 3. 33. 2. nau=n, which might have been omitted, is found also 61. 19. Cf. 8. 74. 1 th\n *pa/ralon nau=n.
w(s keleu/sontas : after th\n *salamini/an nau=n, for the synesis, see on 1. 52. 4. Cobet suspects w(s keleu/sontas a)poplei=n, St. w(s keleu/sontas, both unnecessarily.

a)poplei=n: sail back, as often: 1. 89. 12; 2. 94. 19; 3. 79. 7, 85. 3, 88. 13; 4. 56. 9, 65. 9.—w(=n h( po/lis e)neka/lei: acc. to 61. § 1 reference is here made not only to the profanation of the mysteries, but also to a plot against the democracy (cf. 28. § 2). The expression implies that in the interim a formal charge against Alcibiades had been brought before the people.

tw=n stratiwtw=n tw=n met' au)tou=: Cl. explains, dependent on e)p' a)/llous tina/s (cf. 2. 51. 4 a)/llo ou)de
 tw=n ei)wqo/twn). Steup objects that thus met' au)tou= is strange, since Alcibiades as one of the three generals commanded only the third of the army that fell to him by lot (42. § 1), and that the gens. memhnume/nwn w(s a)sebou/ntwn cannot be explained. He suggests e)p' a)/llous tina/s, tw=n stratiwtw=n tinwn met) au)tou= kte(. Hude writes tw=n stratiwtw=n, tw=n <me
> met' au)tou= kte(., which is doubtless just what Thuc. intended,
as Kr. also understands.—met' au)tou=: cf. 28. 5 w(=n kai\ to
 *)alkibia/dhn e)ph|tiw=nto and 61. 4 ta\ mustika\, w(=n e)pai/tios h)=n.
tw=n de\ kai\ peri\ tw=n *(ermw=n : of the mutilation of the Hermae Alcibiades had not been accused, acc. to 28. § 1 and 61. § 1.
ou)de\n h(=ssonzh/thsin e)poiou=nto kte(.: cf. 27. § 2. 9. ou) dokima/zontes tou\s mhnuta/s: i.e. without satisfying themselves of their credibility.

pa/nta u(po/ptws a)podexo/menoi: in their state of suspicion accepting everything. Cf. diabola\s a)pode/xesqai 41. 4. Lindau's conjecture a)nupo/ptws does not agree with the context.—ponhrw=n a)nqrw/pwn: obj. gen. with pi/stin.
basani/sai : sift to the bottom, examine closely; elsewhere of persons (7. 86. 18; 8. 92. 10).
kai\ xrhsto\n dokou=nta ei)=nai: even though reputed worthy.
ai)tiaqe/nta: once accused.—a)ne/legkton: Schol. a)neceta/stws, i.e. without close investigation.
a)koh=|: (= e)c a)koh=s) with e)pi/stasqai also 60. 2; 4. 126. 15; with ei)de/nai 1. 4. 1; 6. 55. 2; 7. 87. 21; with ai)sqa/nesqai 6. 17. 22, 20. 3; with nomi/zein 4. 81. 12.
xaleph/n : harsh, severe; cf. 59. 4.—teleutw=san: adv. Schol. e)n toi=s teleutai/ois xro/nois.

ou)d) u(f) e(autw=n : not even by themselves (i.e. the Athenians), ou)de/ emphasizing the second and strongest ground, fear of return of a tyranny.—a)ll' u(po\ *lakedaimoni/wn: under Cleomenes, 510 B.C. Thuc. adds in 59. 17 kai\ *)alkmewnidw=n tw=n feugo/ntwn. Cf. Hdt. 6. 123. 8 oi( me\n ga\r e)chgri/wsan tou\s u(poloi/pous *peisistratide/wn *(/ipparxon a)poktei/nontes, ou)de/ ti ma=llon e)/pausan tou\s loipou\s turanneu/ontas: *)alkmewni/dai de\ e)mfane/ws h)leuqe/rwsan, ei) dh\ ou(=toi/ ge a)lhqe/ws h)=san oi( th\n *puqi/hn a)napei/santes proshmai/nein *lakedaimoni/oisi e)leuqerou=n ta\s *)aqh/nas.
u(po/ptws e)la/mbane : see on l. 10; 3. 59. 6; 4. 17. 8.

div2.head: Episode on the end of the Tyranny of the Peisistratidae (54-59)
div2.p: The bold deed of Aristogeiton and Harmodius was committed under the Tyranny of Hippias, eldest son of Peisistratus, and occasioned by an amour of Hipparchus, a younger son. Character of the rule of the Peisistratidae until the murder of Hipparchus.— 1. to\ ga\r *)aristogei/tonos kai\ *(armodi/ou to/lmhma: a digression introduced by ga/r, as 1. 89. 1. The episode is due to the mention made 53. § 3 that recollection of the issue of the Tyranny of the Peisistratidae had been the cause of the feeling then prevailing among the Athenian Demos. Acc. to the words h(\n e)gw\ e)pi\ ple/on dihghsa/menos kte(. (2 ff.), Thuc.'s motive, in our view, was to oppose prevalent popular errors with regard to the sons of Peisistratus and the deed of Harmodius and Aristogeiton. He had already done this more briefly in 1. 20. § 2, where he gives an example of the widespread ignorance among the Hellenes concerning important events of their own history. As to the relation of the two episodes, see on 1^{4}. 20. 5. The conjecture of MüllerStrübing, Aristophanes 543 ff., that Thuc.'s special interest in the fates of the house of the Peisistratidae was due to kinship is prob. correct (see Einleit.^{4} p. xiii, N. 6). But M.-S. is doubtless wrong (Thuk. Forsch. 53 ff.) in finding in Thuc.'s˙ double treatment of the Peisistratid question a proof of the separate publication of the history of the Ten Years' War. (See Einleit.^{4} p. xxxvii). As indicated at 1^{4}. 20. 5, nothing is in the way of believing that we should have had only one treatment of the matter if Thuc.'s work had received a final revision. Wrong, too, is the view of G. Friedrich (N. Jhbb. CLV, p. 177) that at 1. 20 the Athenian Demos is “represented as in entire ignorance of the state of affairs,” while in 6. 53 it has a suspicion of what was really going on. From 1. 20. § 2 it cannot be rightly inferred that Thuc. there ascribed to the Demos the belief that the deed of Harmodius and Aristogeiton had restored freedom to Athens. The accountin Aristotle's *)aqhnai/wn politei/a of the issue of the Tyranny of the Peisistratidae (c. 17 ff.) differs in many points from Thuc., but apparently offers nothing more correct.

cuntuxi/an: affair, matter. Cf. 1. 33. 1; 3. 112. 26.—h(\n...dihghsa/menos a)pofanw= : by a full discussion of which I will prove. L. Herbst (Philol. XL, 306 ff.), assuming e)pi\ ple/on always expresses or implies a definite comparison, connects e)pi\ ple/on a)pofanw= and argues a more definite reference to 1. 20. § 2. But even in Thuc. are found comparatives not essentially differing in force from positives. See on 6. 6; 1. 122. 8; and further dia\ plei/onos 1. 124. 12; biaio/teron 2. 33. 14; makro/tera 3. 52. 22; tou\s lo/gous makrote/rous mhku/nein 4. 17. 5; e)pi\ ple/on 2. 53. 1. Besides, if Thuc. had really meant to refer here to something said earlier, he must have expressed himself more clearly; to say nothing of the improbability that he would have left in a final revision 1. 20. § 2 and 6. 54 ff. as we have them.—
3. ou)/te tou\s a)/llous: to emphasize the second member: neither the other Hellenes, nor even the Athenians themselves, corresponding to the positive oi(/ te a)/lloi kte(.
a)kribe\s ou)de\n le/gontas : of historical questions, as a)kribe/s ti ei)de/nai 5. 26. 24. See on 55. 1.
*peisistra/tou ga\r kte(.: for ga/r, see on 33. 7. ghraiou= teleuth/santos: prob. 528-527 B. C.
w(/sper oi( polloi\ oi)/ontai: so also Pseudo-Plato, Hipparch. 228 B.
e)/sxe th\n a)rxh/n: acquired the sovereignty, = h)=rce 55. 1.

w(/ra| h(liki/as lamprou= : Schol. e)n th=| a)kmh=| e)pifanesta/tou, i.e. in the flower of youth and beauty.—a)nh\r tw=n a)stw=n: cf. a)nh\r *)aqhnai=os tw=n pa/lai 1. 126. 6. a)sto/s referring to his home, poli/ths to his political station.

me/sos poli/ths: Schol. ou)/te e)pifanh\s ou)/te a)/docos. Cf. me/sou a)ndro\s *mh/dou Hdt. 1. 107. 13.—ei)=xen au)to/n: same term that is used of the marital relation. Cf. 2. 29. 2 ou)= ei)=xe th\n a)delfh\n *sita/lkhs.
peiraqei/s: Schol. e)rwtikh\n pei=ran deca/menos.

katagoreu/ei : informs, as 4. 68. 24.—perialgh/sas: greatly pained, peri- intensive, see on 4. 14. 10.— 13. e)pibouleu/ei...kata/lusin th=| turanni/di : for similar turns of expression, see on 3. 109. 21.—w(s a)po\ th=s u(parxou/shs a)ciw/sews: quantum pro sua auctoritate poterat; restrictive, an open attack was out of the question for a me/sos poli/ths.
kai\ e)n tou/tw| o( *(/ipparxos kte(.: see App.

e)n tro/pw| de/ tini a)fanei=: so recent editors, with Levesque, for to/pw| of the Mss. It prob. does not mean that the act was done secretly, but that the manner of the insult did not betray the real motive. Cf. the same idiom in Dio C. 43. 13. The Schol. also read tro/pw|: e)mhxana=to kru/fa prophlaki/sai to\n *(armo/dion w(s di) a)/llhn ai)ti/an
tina/.
dh/ : scilicet. See on 10. 21.—prophlakiw=n: for fut. ptc. after paraskeua/zomai, see on 2. 18. 4.
th\n a)/llhn a)rxh/n: see App. on 14.
a)nepifqo/nws katesth/sato: had established it so as not to give offense (aor. in subord. clause); Schol. a)nepifqo/nws, ou) memptw=s.

kai\ e)peth/deusan kte(.: this aor., as also dieko/smhsan (21), complexive (see on 2. 29; 1. 7. 6) with comprehensive subj. ou(=toi (i.e. the Peisistratidae). The pred. tu/rannoi is put before the subst., acc. to the usage explained at 1. 1. 8 (cf. 31. 6); only here the plural—representing the Peisistratidae—and the preceding sup. (e)pi\ plei=ston dh/) give a somewhat different turn to the sentence: as tyrants (= of all tyrants) these for the longest time (at last even they too fell into other ways) laid stress upon noble sentiment and mental culture. On a)reth/ see Introd. to 1^{4}. li, and on cu/nesis (usually clear insight), see xlviii. a)reth\ kai\ cu/nesis are emphasized also in 4. 81. 11 by Brasidas as comprehending the highest moral and intellectual qualities.
ei)kosth\n mo/non: acc. to Arist. Ath. Pol. 16 Peisistratus levied a deka/th. But cf. Busolt, Griech. Gesch.^{2} II, 328 N. 1.
tw=n gignome/nwn: i.e. all the fruits of the earth.— dieko/smhsan: the best-known of these ornaments was the Enneakrunos (2. 15. § 5).

tou\s pole/mous die/feron: impf. of persistent prosecution. Cf. 1. 11. 12; 8. 75. 13.—e)s ta\ i(era\ e)/quon: short for e)s . . . ta\s qusi/as e)/feron. Cf. e)qew/roun e)s ta\ *)/isqmia 8. 10. 2; qu/ein ei)s tau/thn th\n panh/gurin (Lys.) 6. 5.
au)th\ h( po/lis: the state or citizens apart from the tyrants.

e)peme/lonto: with inf. also Xen. Mem. 4. 7. 1. Only the pres. stem of this verb seems to have been used by Thuc. See St., Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 66.—e)n tai=s a)rxai=s: i.e. the offices of state, esp. the archonship.
*)aqhnai/ois: dat. with h)=rcan (of the e)niausi/a or kat' e)niauto\n a)rxh/), as 1. 93. 11; 2. 2. 6.
tou= turanneu/santos: who had been tyrant. Cf. 55. 11.

o(/s: wrongly suspected by Bk., for the younger Peisistratus is mentioned on account of his archonship, not for the altars dedicated by him, which are referred to only incidentally in a rel. clause. The year of his
archonship is not definitely known.— tw=n dw/deka qew=n bwmo/n: like the miliarium aureum in Rome, starting-point for the roads leading out of Athens and with the distances inscribed on it (cf. Hdt. 2. 7. 5; C. I. G. H, 1078); serving also as a place of refuge. See Curtius, Zur Gesch. des Wegebaues bei den Gr. (Abhandl. d. Berl. Akad., 1854, p. 247 f.; also collected works I, 59 f.); Wachsmuth, die Stadt Athen H, 434 ff.; Milchhöfer in Curtius, Stadtgesch. von Athen, p. ix.
e)n *puqi/ou: sc. i(erw=| or teme/nei (cf. 34). So e)n *dionu/sou 8. 94. 1. See 2. 15. 23 (where the sanctuary is called to\ *pu/qion) and Milchhöfer in Curtius, Stadtgesch. p. xiv.
[tou= bwmou=]: due, as Kr. saw, to some stupid reader seeking a modifier for mei=zon.
dh=lo/n e)stin : sc. to\ e)pi/gramma.

a)mudroi=s gra/mmasi : the stone with this inscription was found in the spring of 1877, on the banks of the Hissus near the fountain Callirrhoe (C. I. G. IV, 373 e). It is in two pieces and some lettersare gone entirely (-tratos *(ippi/ou), others are much abraded. Otherwise the inscription is distinct, so that a)mudroi=s cannot refer to the tracing of the letters. Steup thinks the meaning is here, as in (Dem.) 59. 76, that the red color of the letters had faded. See H. Heydemann, Hermes XIV, 317. Cl. suggested that the injury to the inscription may go back to the earliest period, and that a)mudroi=s possibly referred to this injury. For still another view, see Szanto, Wiener Studien III, 155 ff.
Proofs that Hippias as eldest son sueceeded his father Peisistratus in the tyranny.
h)=rcen: attained the sovereignty, = e)/sxe th\n a)rxh/n 54. 7.

ei)dw\s a)kribe/steron a)/llwn : knowing more accurately than others. Cf. 54. 4; 5. 26. 24. See on 91. 2. The expression a)kribe/steron a)/llwn clearly points to a near relationship of the historian with the family of the Peisistratidae, so that more exact knowledge had come to him by word of mouth (kai\ a)koh=|). See on 54. 1.
i)sxuri/zomai: affirm, as 3. 44. 9; 5. 26. 19.
au)tw=| tou/tw|: Schol. tw=| r(hqhsome/nw|.

mo/nw| : preferable to
mo/non of the Mss. on account of the dependent gen. See on 3. 1.

o( bwmo/s: without doubt the altar e)n *puqi/ou (54. 31, 34), whose inscription proved the existence of a son of Hippias.—h(sth/lh peri\ th=s kte(.: without repeated art. (see on 1. 51. 11), which is here the more negligible since another art. follows soon. The reference in tw=n tura/nnwn is to the Peisistratidae in general (cf. 54. 4, 19; 8. 68. 27).

e)n i(=| *qessalou= me\n kte(.: see App.—*qessalou= me\n ou)d' *(ippa/rxou: the neg. is to be understood also with qessalou=. Cf. ai( foi/nissai nh=es ou)de\ o( *tissafe/rnhs h(=kon 8. 99. 4; and 5. 47. 9.
*(uperoxi/dou: so with Laur. and Meineke (Hermes III, 372), for *(uperexi/dou, because only the name *(upe/roxos, not *(uperexh/s, is known.
prw=ton gh=mai: and consequently by implication gennh=sai. But as the matter of childlessness is left out of consideration the proof is not quite clear. More positive is the second proof, in § 2.
e)n th=| au)th| sth/lh|: so all editors, following the correction (manu sec.) of one Ms., for e)n th=| prw/th| of all the Mss.
a)peiko/tws: always with neg. Cf. 1. 73. 9; 2. 8. 2; 8. 68. 25.
presbeu/ein: Schol. presbu/tatos ei)=nai.
a)p) au)tou= : = met' au)to/n.
ou) mh\n ou)de/: nor yet again. See on 1. 3. 17.

kaqi/stato: sc. e)s th
 a)rxh/n (conative impf.).—a)lla\ kai/: but (even) actually. kai/ is wanting in Laur.—dia\ to\ pro/teron...fobero/n : on account of the hitherto usual fear on the part of the citizens. Cf. to\ fobero
 toi=s u(phko/ois 7. 68. 16. This fear inspired in the citizens (cf. also 54. 12 fobhqei\s th
 *(ippa/rxou du/namin kte(.) is not incompatible with the comparative mildness of the rule of the Peisistratidae emphasized in 54. § 5 f. For pro/teron adv., see Steup, Thuk. Stud. H, 22. For substantivized neut. adj. (fobero/n, a)kribe/s) with attrib. modifier cu/nhqes, see on 34. 16.

e)s tou\s e)pikou/rous a)kribe/s: strict discipline enforced upon the bodyguard. The dorufo/roi are called here and 58. 6 e)pi/kouroi because they were usually hired foreigners. See on
1. 115. 18.

pollw=| tw=| perio/nti...katekra/thse : with a great surplus of security (i.e. very easily) got the upper hand (of the conspirators). Cf. w(s tw=| a)sfalei= perisxh/swn 5. 7. 13, and katakratei=n pollo/n Hdt. 7. 168. 16. to\ perio/n = periousi/a from periei=nai, abundare (diff. from 2. 79. 30 periei=nai, reliquum esse).

e)n w(=|...th=| a)rxh=| : in which case he would not have been continuously used to the sovereignty. e)n w(=| (of hypothetical case, as in 8. 86. 22) refers only to w(s a)delfo\s new/teros w)/n. For o(milei=n in this sense with dat., cf. 70. 4. Cf. prosomilei=n 1. 122. 6. For rare plpf. without a)/n, cf. Isae. 3. 10 dh=lon ga\r o(/ni o( a)delfo\s au)th\n . . . e)kdedw/kei.

tou= pa/qous th=| dustuxi/a|: pleonastic; for dustuxi/a| one would have expected cuntuxi/a| (see on 54. 2).— 19. o)nomasqe/nta: Schol. o)nomasto
 geno/menon. The accus. as in 1. 53. 1; 7. 74. 6.—kai\ th
 do/can th=s turanni/dos: i.e. as he was often mentioned, as it were by consequence he obtained also the credit of being ruler.—e)s ta\ e)/peita: in after times, for which is found elsewhere e)s to\ e)/peita 4. 64. 21; e)s e)/peita 1. 130. 10; e)s to
 e)/peita xro/non 3. 114. 13; ta\ e)/peita 5. 26. 29; to\ e)/peita 4. 107. 2; 5. 115. 4; to
 e)/peita xro/non 4. 45. 9.

After Hipparchus had shamefully insulted the sister of Harmodius, Aristogeiton and Harmodius determine to carry out, with their fellow conspirators, at the great Panathenaea, their purpose to overthrow the tyranny.— 1. d' ou)=n: after the digression resumes the narrative interrupted at 54. § 4. See on 1. 3. 19.—a)parnhqe/nta: cf. 54. § 4.— w(/sper dienoei=to: i.e. e)n tro/pw| tini\ a)fanei= (54. 16).

a)delfh\n ko/rhn: maiden sister. Cf. quga/thrparqe/nos Xen. Mem. 1. 5. 2; Cyrop. 4. 6. 9.—e)paggei/lantes...a)ph/lasan : transition from Hipparchus alone to himself and Hippias as arrangers of the procession. pomph/ tis cannot refer to the Panathenaea since some time elapsed before that: perie/menon *panaqh/naia ta\ mega/la (8). Aristotle (18. § 2 f.) places both the insult to the maiden and the murder of Hipparchus at the Panathenaea.— 3. kanou=n oi)/sousan: this service at a festival was a great distinction, so that the rejection of the maiden was regarded as a bitter insult to the family. See E. Curtius, Arch. Zeitg., 1880, p. 27, = Gesam. Abhandlungen H, 286.— 4. ou)de\ th\n a)rxh/n: not at all. See on 2. 74. 10. Schol. wrongly tou\s a)/rxontas.

dia\ to\ mh\ a)ci/an ei)=nai : ai( ga\r
kanhfo/roi tw=n a)stw=n kai\ tw=n eu)genw=n h)=san, Phot. s.v. kanhfo/roi.
pollw=| dh\ ma=llon: as 8. 89. 8. Cf. 61. 3.

au)toi=s...e)pe/prakto : the other arrangements had been made by them with their fellow conspirators. For pro\s tou\s cunepiqhsome/nous pra/ssein, see on 1. 131. 7. For dat. with pass., see on 1. 125. 6; 3. 64. 15.
pro\s tou\s cunepiqhsome/nous tw=| e)/rgw|: cf. e)piqe/sqai th=| pei/ra| 7. 42. 33; toi=s toiou/tois tw=n e)/rgwn e)piti/qesqai Xen. Mem. 2. 8. 3.

*panaqh/naia ta\ mega/la: celebrated in the last third of the montli Hekatombaion (July-August) of the third year of the Olympiad. See A. Mommsen, Feste der Stadt Athen, pp. 47 ff., 148 ff.; A. Willauer, Étude sur les Panathénées (Lausanne diss., 1899), pp. 20 ff.; Busolt, Gr. Gesch.^{2} H, 344 ff. The festival in question was that of Ol. 66, 3 = 514 B. C.—e)n h(=|...h(me/ra| : manifestly the chief day of the several days' festival, i.e. Hekatombaion 28, when the great procession occurred. This day is called h( e(orth/ in 57. 1.
e)n o(/plois: i.e. met' a)spi/dos kai\ do/ratos (58. 8). For the expression, cf. 61. 13, 74. 7; 8. 69. 13.
pe/myontas: though of slight Mss. authority, required by the context for pe/myantos.
a)/rcai me\n au)tou/s : that they (i.e. Aristogeiton and Harmodius) begin the attack upon Hippias and the lifeguard. e)kei/nous = tou\s cunepiqhsome/nous tw=| e)/rgw|.
cunepamu/nein : elsewhere only in late writers. —ta\ pro\s tou\s dorufo/rous: as to matters against the bodyguard. Schol. e)s ta\ pro\s tou\s dorufo/rous. Cf. 4. 85. 23.

ou) polloi/: cf. Arist. 18. § 2 sune/bh . . . to
 *(armo/dion kai\ to
 *)aristogei/tona pra/ttein th
 pra=cin metexo/ntwn pollw=n, but Thuc.'s testimony is preferable.—e(/neka: the Mss. have ou(/neka, found nowhere else in Thuc.
ei) kai\ o(posoiou=n tolmh/seian: if even ever so few dared the attack. Cf. o(posonou=n 4. 37. 2.
e)k tou= paraxrh=ma: at once, without long reflection or preparation.—e)qelh/sein: will resolve.

During the preparations for the procession, the two leaders, suspecting that their plot had been betrayed to the tyrant and without waiting for their
