accomplices, attack Hipparchus, who was some distance from his brother, and kill him. Harmodius is cut down immediately by Hipparchus' attendants; Aristogeiton escapes for the time, but later is captured and put to death.— 1. kai\ w(s: and when, vividly introducing the execution of the plan.

e)/cw e)n tw=| *kerameikw=| kaloume/nw|: see App. —e)/cw: outside the city, as 49. 12; 2. 15. 21, 18. 17; 3. 81. 7; 4. 84. 6, 106. 4.— dieko/smei, (5) proh=|san: the two impfs. in paratactic relation to each other: while the one was occupied, the others proceeded to the execution of the plot. proh=|san perhaps intentionally repeated after proie/nai: there e(/kasta th=s pomph=s, here e)s to\ e)/rgon.

tw=n cunwmotw=n sfi/si: = tw=n sfi/si cunomosa/ntwn. The const. of personal verbal substs. with the dat. is rarer than that of neuters (see Kr. Spr. 48, 12, 5; Kühner-Gerth H, 1, 426 f.), but not on that account to be rejected in Thuc. Cl. conjectures tw=n cunomwmoko/twn sfi/si, comparing 56. 12.
oi)kei/ws: Schol. filikw=s.
eu)pro/sodos : as personal characteristic also Xen. Ages. 9. 2. Cf. duspro/sodos 1. 130. 10.—o( *(ippi/as: repeated perhaps to make clear that tis (5) is not subject. Van H. brackets.
e)/deisan: became frightened (aor.).—memhnu=sqai: with pers. subj. as 53. 5 memhnume/nwn.
o(/son ou)k : all but. See on 2. 94. 6. With h)/dh also 8. 96. 13.
to\n luph/santa sfa=s: i.e. Hipparchus.

pro/teron protimwrh/sasqai: for similar pleonasms, see on 1. 23. 21. pri\n cullhfqh=nai is to be supplied in thought (cf. 1. 20. 12). For the aor., adopted by St., Hude, Bm., see on 6. 3. All the Mss. except M read protimwrh/s esqai, which Cl. (followed by Steup) would justify on the ground that through the intervening pro/teron, ei) du/nainto (if in any way they could, before Hippias should seize them), e)bou/lonto gets the force of h)/lpizon. protimwrei=n occurs also 1. 74. 16; elsewhere only in late writers.

w(/sper ei)=xon: just as they were. See on 1. 134. 14.—tw=n pulw=n: see App. on 2.—perie/tuxon tw=| *(ippa/rxw| para\ to\ *lewko/rion kalou/menon kte(.: for the Leocorium, see on 1. 20. 13. The statement there, tw=| *(ippa/rxw| perituxo/ntes peri\ to\ *lewko/rion kalou/menon th
 *panaqhnai+kh
 pomph
 diakosmou=nti a)pe/kteinan (cf. Arist. Ath. Pol. 18. § 3 to
 me
 *(/ipparxon diakosmou=nta th
 pomph
 para\ to\ *lewko/rion
a)pe/kteinan), is prob. best brought into agreement with the opening of the present chapter (kai\ w(s e)ph=lqen h( e(orth/, *(ippi/as me
 . . . dieko/smei kte(.) by assuming that both brothers were arranging the procession, the one outside in the Ceramicus, the other in the region of the Agora. Aristotle (18. § 3) makes Hippias await the procession on the Acropolis.

<kai\> eu)qu\s kte(.: kai/, adopted by nearly all editors without Mss. authority, is necessary unless one accepts Badham's bold conjecture perituxo/ntes. A third kai/ introducing the account of the actual assault accords well with the haste of Harmodius and Aristogeiton (w(/sper ei)=xon w(/rmhsan, eu)qu\s a)periske/ptws prospeso/ntes), whereas by an adversative (eu)qu\s d)), as Hude and Marchant write, after F. Portus, the separate occurrences, which are all the consequence of e)bou/lonto pro/teron protimwrh/sasqai, are too much torn apart. Since kai/ occurs several times in quick succession and kalou/menon immediately precedes, it might easily have dropped out.

a)periske/ptws: cf. h( a)lo/gistos to/lma 59. 2. The word occurs also 65. 4; 4. 10. 4, 108. 23; elsewhere only in late writers.—w(s a)\n ma/lista di) o)rgh=s: (sc. prospe/soien, cf. 1. 33. 5) in extreme wrath, the cause of which in Aristogeiton is expressed by the adj. e)rwtikh=s, in Harmodius by the ptc. u(brisme/nos. See on 59. 1.
e)/tupton: the impf. indicating repeated blows, the pres. (a)poktei/nousin) expressing the result.
to\ au)ti/ka: for the moment. See on 4. 107. 2.—o( *)aristogei/twn: added by way of explanation, as 2. 29. 12; 7. 57. 28.
cundramo/ntos tou= o)/xlou: not to assist him; but he availed himself of the confusion to escape.—lhfqei/s: i.e. by the pursuing dorufo/roi.

ou) r(a|di/ws diete/qh : was handled not softly, i.e. cruelly killed (ou) r(a|di/ws, kakw=s Hesych. and Phot.). He was tortured for the names of his accomplices, acc. to Arist. 18. § 4 ff., Polyaen. l. 22, Justin. 2. 9, etc.
Hippias, informed of what had occurred, promptly takes precautions for his own safety and for the punishment of the guilty.

a)ggelqe/ntos: one of the rare instances of the abs. impers. ptc. in gen. for acc. See on 1. 74. 1. GMT. 849.—e)s to\n *kerameiko/n: see App. on 57. 2.—ou)k e)pi\ to\ geno/menon: indicating his great self-control, as does also a)dh/lws th=| o)/yei plasa/menos pro\s th\n cumfora/n (4).

tou\s pompe/as: only here in the sense of tou\s th\n pomph\n pe/myontas (56. 9). The words
tou\s o(pli/tas (which v. H. brackets), added in explanation, give the essential motive for his subsequent action.— pro/teron h)/: with aor. inf., as 1. 69. 21; 2. 40. 11; 8. 45. 29; u(/steron h)/ 4. 11.

a)/pwqen : with ei)=nai as 4. 67. 8.— a)dh/lws...pro\s th\n cumfora/n : dissembling in look in the presence of the calamity so that no one observed (a)dh/lws). For pro\s th\n cumfora/n, see on 40. 12.— 5. dei/cas ti xwri/on: as 1. 87. 8.
a)pexw/rhsan: Pp.'s correction of a)nexw/rhsan, in accordance with e)ke/leusen au)tou\s . . . a)pelqei=n.

oi)o/menoi/ ti e)rei=n au)to/n : they suspected nothing, for it was customary for soldiers to hear unarmed the address of the leader. Cf. Polyaen. l. 21. 2. 7. fra/sas: = keleu/sas, as 3. 15. 5.—u(polabei=n: to carry away sceretly. See on 1. 68. 18.
e)cele/geto: picked out, i.e. for execution. Cf. 4. 74. 12.—ou(\s e)ph|tia=to: whom he held guilty, knowing their disaffection.

kai\ ei)/ tis...e)/xwn : and besides any one who was found with a dagger; for shield and spear belonged to the procession. Hence the words meta\ ga\r a)spi/dos . . . pompa\s poiei=n, omitted by v. H., St., and others, are well motived. poiei=n (for poiei=sqai) is not ground for suspicion, since Thuc. uses the act. esp. of festal arrangements (see on 2. 15. 17). Here, too, poiei=n is used of ordering and preparing, not of the execution of the procession. Doubtless in view of Thuc.'s representation of Hippias' bearing immediately after the murder of Hipparchus, Aristotle says (18. § 4) ou) ga\r e)du/nanto paraxrh=ma labei=n ou)de\n i)/xnos th=s pra/cews, a)ll' o( lego/menos lo/gos, w(s o( *(ippi/as a)posth/sas a)po\ tw=n o(/plwn tou\s pompeu/ontas e)fw/rase tou\s ta\ e)gxeiri/dia e)/xontas, ou)k a)lhqh/s e)stin: ou) ga\r e)/pempon to/te meq) o(/plwn, a)ll) u(/steron tou=to kateskeu/aseno( dh=mos. But in spite of the definiteness of this statement, it is prob. that Thuc. and not Aristotle is right. See Busolt, Gr. Gesch.^{2} H, 53 and 382 ff., and E. Meyer, Gesch. d. Alt. H, 775, 795.

Hippias ruled three years longer, more harshly than before, until he was driven from Athens. He then betook himself to Sigeum and Lampsacus, and from there to King Darius. Later he accompanied the expedition of the Persians to Marathon.

di) e)rwtikh\n lu/phn: i.e. on account of pain occasioned by a love affair. The phrase forms, as St. rightly explains against Cl. and some others, together with *(armodi/w| . . . e)ge/neto the pred. to both following subjects (h te a)rxh\ . . . to/lma
e)k tou= . . . perideou=s). With this view of the sentence we have here a conclusion in accordance with the introductory words (54. 1 to\ ga\r *)aristogei/tonos . . . e)pexeirh/qh) of the discussion of the undertaking of Harmodius and Aristogeiton. St. points out further that in the account of the to/lmhma of Harmodius and Aristogeiton it is expressly stated (57. § 3) to\n luph/santa ou)=n sfa=s kai\ di) o(/nper pa/nta e)kindu/neuon e)bou/lonto pro/teron, ei) du/nainto, protimwrh/sasqai. If one keeps these words in mind along with what is said about the concocting of the conspiracy (54. § 3 o( de\ e)rwtikw=s perialgh/sas . . . e)pibouleu/ei eu)qu\s . . . kata/lusin th=| turanni/di), there can be no doubt that Thuc., in this concluding and summarizing sentence, traces not only the concoction of the plot but the murder of Hipparchus to the pangs of love. e)rwtiko/s is here used in a somewhat more general sense than in 54. 11, where in contrast with the anger of Harmodius on account of insult mention is made of the e)rwtikh\ o)rgh/ (i.e. rage inflamed by jealousy) of Aristogeiton.

h( a)lo/gistos to/lma: as 3. 82. 24.—e)k tou= paraxrh=ma perideou=s: to be closely connected with to/lma though the art. is not repeated (see on 55. 4; 1. 51. 11). The phrase to\ paraxrh=ma peridee/s occurs also 8. 1. 29. As to Thuc.'s use of neut. ptcs. and adjs. for abstract nouns, see on 1. 36. 3, and C. F. Smith, Trans. Amer. Phil. Assoc. XXV, 75 ff.
xalepwte/ra...kate/sth : became harsher, comparative as in 7. 28. 21. For pred. adj. in this const., see on 3. 37. 13. On the matter, cf. 53. § 3; Hdt. 5. 55, 62; 6. 123; Arist. Ath. Pol. 19. § 1.
dia\ fo/bou...w)/n : see on 34. 8.

dieskopei=to: rare mid. form, with more intensive meaning, as Plato, Phaed. 70 c. Cf. the simple form skopei=sqai 8. 48. 23, and see on 86. 6.— a)sfa/leian: means of security or protection. Cf. 87. 20; 1. 40. 7; 3. 13. 4.
metabolh=s genome/nhs: hypothetical, in case of a revolution (Schol. e)a/santi th\n turanni/da).

gou=n: at any rate, introducing an instance (e)/dwken) in confirmation of the general dieskopei=to, i.e. “among other things” he concluded this alliance, although not esp. brilliant for a ruler of Athens (*)aqhnai=os w)\n *lamyakhnw=|).

ai)sqano/menos: with unusual dependent inf. for ptc. Cf. 5. 4. 24.— au)tou/s: i.e. Hippocles and Acantides.
—me/ga para\ basilei= du/nasqai: cf. 2. 29. 3.
e)pi/gramma: from Simonides, acc. to Arist. Rhet. 1. 9 (p. 32, 24 Bk.), who cites the third verse. Cf. Bergk, Poct. Lyr. Gr. (Simon. frg. 111).
tw=n e)f' e(autou=: of the men of his own time (with a)risteu/santos).— 13. *(ippi/ou: sc. qugate/ra.

a)delfw=n : of these only the Peisistratus mentioned 54. 26 is known. MüllerStrübing, Aristoph. p. 541 f., conjectures that the historian Thueydides was descended, on the father's side, from this Archedice, daughter of Hippias.

e)n tw=| teta/rtw|: Ol. 67, 3; 510 B.C. —u(po\ *lakedaimoni/wn kai\ *)alkmewnidw=n tw=n feugo/ntwn: the former led by Cleomenes; the latter had been in banishment since the secure establishment of the tyranny of Peisistratus (Ol. 60, 1; 540 B.C.). On the matter, see 53. § 3; Hdt. 5. 62 ff.; Arist. 19.
u(po/spondos: under safe conduct, as 88. 50. Cf. Hdt. 5. 65.—e)s *si/geion: which the Athenians had conquered under the rule of Peisistratus (Hdt. 5. 94) or earlier.
o(/qen: i.e. from the court of Darius. See on 21. 11.

Recalling what happened after the murder of Hipparchus and the manner of the expulsion of Hippias, the Demos of Athens was greatly exeited and many arrests were made. One of the suspects made a confession about the mutilation of the Hermae. He was set free, but his alleged accomplices were executed after a short trial.
w(=n e)nqumou/menos kte(.: the rel. referring to the details given 59. § 2 ff.; the narrative is resumed where it was broken off at 53. § 3. Cf. similar transition at 1. 42. 1.

a)koh=| h)pi/stato: repeated from 53. 15.—xalepo\s h)=n: as 8. 1. 4.—kai\ u(po/pths e)s tou\s...labo/ntas : cf. 53. 10. u(po/pths is rare; cf. Soph. Phil. 136. The Schol. remarks tou\s i(/ppous fasi\ tou\s tarassome/nous u(po/ptas le/gesqai, and so Xen. De
Re Equestri 3. 9 tou\s u(po/ptas fu/sei(i(/ppous)fulakte/on. Steup thinks that Thuc. must have alluded here also to the processes for the mutilation of the Hermae (cf. 53. § 1 f. and c. 60), hence that some words must have dropped out after mustikw=n, prob. kai\ tou\s peri\ tw=n: *(ermw=n (cf. 53. 9), or only kai\ tw=n *(ermw=n (Stein).
pa/nta au)toi=s...pepra=xqai : cf. 53. 18 pa/nta u(po/ptws e)la/mbane, and 27. 10 e)pi\cunwmosi/a| newte/rwn pragma/twn kai\ dh/mou katalu/sews gegenh=sqai.
e)pi\ cunwmosi/a| : in consequence of a conspiracy, as 27. 10.—kai\ turannikh=|: for such fears on the part of the demos, and esp. with regard to Alcibiades, see 15. § 4.

ou)k e)n pau/lh| e)fai/neto: there seemed to be no end of it (the subj. to\ pra=gma to be supplied from the context; see on 46. 22). Cf. 4. 73. 12 ou)k a)\n e)n tu/xh| gi/gnesqai sfi/sin, and (of a person) 3. 33. 13 ou)ke/ti e)n katalh/yei e)fai/neto.
kaq) h(me/ran e)pedi/dosan : as 7. 8. 2 (of things and without ma=llon).
e)s to\ a)griw/teron: i.e. to even greater rage and embitterment. Cf. e)pi\ to\ mei=zon 8. 24. 22.
kai\ plei/ous e)/ti cullamba/nein : and so that even more persons were arrested. For e)s to/ with inf. after e)pidido/nai, cf. 8. 83. 7.
e)ntau=qa: introducing the decisive result. Cf. 5. 65. 23, 69. 2; e)ntau=qa dh/ 8. 53. 20; e)ntau=qa h)/dh 4. 35. 4.

ei)=s tw=n dedeme/nwn : namely, the orator Andocides, who gives his account of the whole matter in his speech De Mysteriis, esp. § 48 ff. The one who persuaded him was, acc. to Andocides, his cousin Charmides; acc. to Plut. Alcib. 21, it was Timaeus.

ei)/te a)/ra kai\ ta\ o)/nta ei)/te kai\ ou)/: whether after all true or not, the words of the author not of the persuader, anticipating the confession; and to these words refers the following remark e)p' a)mfo/tera ga\r ei)ka/zetai kte(., for conjectures are divided. For the form of the expression, cf. 5. 65. 9. a)/ra emphasizes the doubt or uncertainty. Cf. Plato, Phaed. 70 c skeyw/meqa ei)/te a)/ra e)n *(/aidou ei)si\n ai( yuxai\ ei)/te kai\ ou)/ (Kr.). For the force of kai/, see Kr. Spr. 69, 32, 13. ta\ o)/nta = ta\ a)lhqh=. ou)/, sc. ta\ o)/nta.
ou)/te to/te ou)/te u(/steron e)/xei ei)pei=n: for the zeugma, cf. 1. 86. 7; 3. 40. 5. Kr. Spr. 62, 4, 2.

le/gwn de\ e)/peisen au)to\n w(s xrh/ , kte(.: epexegetical of a)napei/qetai kte(. (9), for he persuaded him, representing that, etc.—ei) mh\ kai\ de/draken: if he had not actually done it. The order puts stronger emphasis on the word following kai/, as in 2. 11. 27, ei) mh\ kai\ nu=n w(/rmhntai.

a)/deian poihsa/menon : here of obtaining immunity, as a)/deian poiei=n tini (3. 58. 11; 8. 76. 34) of granting immunity. Informers were assured of immunity by the state. Cf. Andoc. § 20; Plut. Aleib. 21.

dia\ di/khs e)lqei=n: really opposed to o(mologh/santi met' a)dei/as, so that e)lqo/nti was to be expected. The irregularity is due to striving after parallelism of clauses. See Einleitung^{4}, p. lxviii. For the idiom dia\ di/khs e)lqei=n, to undergo trial, cf. Soph. Ant. 742 w)= pagka/kiste dia\ di/khs i)w\n patri/. Cf. also dia\ ma/xhs i)e/nai (2. 11. 13; Hdt. 6. 9. 22), dia\ fili/as i)e/nai (Xen. Anab. 3. 2. 8).
kai\ o( me\n...o( de\ dh=mos : continuance of the foregoing (kai/, and the consequence was), with the usual transition to the separate facts. Cf. 1. 19. 1.
o( tw=n *)aqhnai/wn: not necessary after l. 1, but hardly to be bracketed, with Kr.
w(s w)/|eto: referring to to\ safe/s.
deino\n poiou/menoi : (ptc. impf.) transition topl.; cf. 53. 17. The expression in Thuc. only here and l. 102. 17. See note there.
sfw=n tw=| plh/qei: the pron. gen. thus placed with almost the effect of dat. of interest. See on 1. 30. 14.
kri/seis poih/santes: after holding some trials therefor.

e)panei=pon a)rgu/rion tw=| a)poktei/nanti: i.e. besides sentence of death they offered a reward to the slayer. Cf. a)neipei=n 2.2.26; 4. 105. 11. The compound is rare. For the force of e)pi-, cf. 1. 70. 8; 2. 65. 48; 3. 57. 6.
oi( me\n paqo/ntes: placed for emphasis before the conj. (ei)); see on 1^{4} 10.5.—h(me/ntoi a)/llh po/lis...w)fe/lhto : Schol. ou) ga\r u(pw/pteuon e)/ti a)llh/lous.

Against Alcibiades, however, there was the more suspicion about the profanation of the mysteries, as a Lacedaemonian army had drawn near the Attic frontier, and in Argos too there were suspicions of hostility to the Demos. Obeying the summons of the Salaminia he set off for Athens; but at Thurii he slipped away and betook himself to Peloponnesus, and in consequence was at Athens condemned to death in absentia.

e)nago/ntwn: urging them on, obj. to be supplied, as in 7. 18. 3; 8. 26. 4; obj. expressed 4. 21. 8.—tw=n e)xqrw=n: among whom Plut. Alcib. 19, 22, mentions esp. Androcles and Thessalus, son of Cimon.

e)pe/qento: cf. *me/lhto/s moi e)pe/qeto Plato, Apol. 23 E. For the matter, cf. 28. § 2. The aor. here with force of plpf. as in 67. 11.—xalepw=s...e)la/mbanon : (sc. to\ pra=gma, as 27. 9), took the matter hard about Alcibiades, i.e. were full of anger and fear. For the idiom, cf. 27. 9, 53. 18.
e)peidh\ to\...safe\s e)/xein : cf. 60. 19. For the free const. of the gen. to\ tw=n *(ermw=n safe/s, the actual facts about the Hermae, cf. 4. 84. 5 tou= ka/rpou to\ de/os.

polu\ dh\ ma=llon : vividly emphasizing, as pollw=| dh\ ma=llon 56. 5; 8. 89. 8. ma=llon, i.e. than before, when in reference to the mutilation of the Hermae also they had only conjectures to go on. Cf. 60. 4 f.

w(=n e)pai/tios h)=n: cf. 28. 5 w(=n kai\ to\n *)alkibia/dhn e)ph|tiw=nto. Alcibiades was not accused of mutilat-ing the Hermae.—meta\ tou= au)tou= lo/gou kai\ th=s cunwmosi/as e)pi\ tw=| dh/mw|: with the same intent, that is, of conspiracy against the Demos. If kai/ is retained, it must be explanatory = tou=t' e)/sti or dhlono/ti (Kistemacher, Dobree); so Bl. and Heilmann render. Poppo says, “kai/ potest et quidem valere.” Steup renders, “for the same reason and in consequence of the conspiracy against the Demos,” explaining that the reason consisted in the conspiracy, which is added with kai/. This gets at the right sense, though it is doubtful if the Greek will bear that translation. Dobree, Kr., and Cl. are inclined to strike out kai/. Stahl brackets kai\ th=s cunwmosi/as, which Bm. approves. Van H. brackets kai\ th=s cunwmosi/as e)pi\ tw=| dh/mw|.

th=s cunwmosi/as : the art. because of the mention in 60. 4.—e)pi\ tw=| dh/mw|: for e)pi/ with dat. in hostile sense, cf. 79. 3, and see on 3. 63. 8.—a)p' e)kei/nou praxqh=nai: so a)po/ freq. with pra/ssesqai and le/gesqai. See on 1. 17. 4.
kai\ ga\r kai/: for also, in further support of polu\ dh\ ma=llon (3). Cf. 103. 18; 4. 108. 18; 8. 64. 13.
e)qorubou=nto: were in great excitement. Cf. 3. 22. 30; 4. 113. 2.

parelqou=sa: Hude
unnecessarily changes, with Badham, to proelqou=sa.

pro\s *boiwtou/s ti pra/ssontes : in agreement with the Boeotians. Cf. 1. 131. 7; 3. 28. 11. For pl. ptc. after stratia/, cf. 60. 19. Nothing further is known about the matter. Andocides (§ 45) states that Boeotian troops had approached the Attic border, but puts this advance before his confession, whereas acc. to Thuc. it was after that (cf. 10 ei) mh\ . . . tou\s a)/ndras).
e)kei/nou pra/cantos: at his instigation.—a)po\ cunqh/matos: on agreement. Cf. 4. 67. 20; 7. 22. 4.
dh/: in emphatic assurance, not without an ironical touch, as Thuc. does not conceal the exaggeration in the whole matter.
tou\s a)/ndras: i.e. tou\s kataitiaqe/ntas (60. 22).

kai/ tina mi/an nu/kta kte(.: doubtless also in the sense remarked at dh/; extraordinary precautions were taken. For tina mi/an, cf. 34. 11, 77.9.—kate/darqon: of an unusual way of passing the night, see on 4. 113. 4.—e)n *qhsei/w| tw=| e)n po/lei: e)n po/lei (without art.) as e)/cw po/lews 8. 67. 8. Andocides (§ 45) gives a different assignment of watch-posts: for e)n a)/stei oi)kou=ntes the Agora, and for those e)n makrw=| tei/xei the Theseum; but he refers to events of a somewhat earlier time. The site of the Theseum in the city is not exactly known. It was long wrongly supposed to be the so-called Theseum, still well preserved, north of the Areopagus, but see C. Wachsmuth, Athenai, in Pauly-Wissowa's Realencyklopädie, Suppl. 1, 181.
e)n o(/plois: see on 56. 9.
u(pwpteu/qhsan: came under suspicion (aor.).—tou\s o(mh/rous tw=n *)argei/wn: the 300 men mentioned 5. 84. 4.
keime/nous: pf. ptc. of kate/qento (5. 84. 4). Cf. 5. 61. 19.
dia\ tau=ta: Schol. w(s oi)kei/ous o)/ntas tw=n tou= *)alkibia/dou ce/nwn.
diaxrh/sasqai : to destroy, as 1. 126. 37; 3. 36. 15. For inf. of purpose after pare/dosan, cf. 1. 58. 15; 3. 36. 23; 4. 36. 4.
pantaxo/qente: for te in résumé. Thuc.'s constant usage, see on 3. 40. 16.

ou(/tw: referring to boulo/menoi kte(. See on 1. 37. 4; 3. 96. 8.—e)p' e)kei=non
kte(.: cf. 53. § 1. For e)kei=non after au)to/n, cf. 35, 36. 16; and see on 1. 132. 31.— 20. kai\ w(=n pe/ri a)/llwn: i.e. kai\ e)pi\ tou\s a)/llous peri\ w(=n.
proeipei=n: announce publicly. See on 1. 29. 3.
qerapeu/ontes: as if ei)rh/kesan, not ei)/rhto, had preceded. For similar anacolutha, see on 2. 53. 13.

to/ te pro\s tou\s e)n th=| *sikeli/a|...mh\ qorubei=n kte(.: St.'s explanation seems best: curantes ne apud milites in Sicilia suos et hostiles turbas excitarent, i.e. curantes ne vehementer commoverent suorum animos irritantes, hostium erigentes. On qerapeu/ontes depends to\ mh\ qorubei=n, to which belongs pro\s tou\s . . . polemi/ous. te is placed as if not boulo/menoi, but a second clause dependenton qerapeu/ontes, were to follow. For the irregular order, cf. 15. 6. With qerapeu/ontes Kr. construes to\ pro\s tou\s e)n th=| *sikeli/a|, to which stratiw/tas te . . . polemi/ous is appos., and mh\ qorubei=n epexegetical. Steup cites 29. 10 (which all the above explanations overlook) o(/ te dh=mos mh\ malaki/zhtai, qerapeu/wn o(/ti di) e)kei=non oi(/ t' *)argei=oi cunestra/teuon kai\ tw=n *mantine/wn tine/s, acc. to which qerapeu/ontes would be taken abs., meaning here conciliating him, and boulo/menoi govern the first inf. clause as well as its own, with te in its proper place.—tou\s e)n th=| *sikeli/a|...polemi/ous : for the single art. with the two very different substs., cf. 1. 6. 1; 2. 35. 19; 3. 56. 7.
tou\s *mantine/as kai\ *)argei/ous: cf. 29. § 3 and 43.

sfi/si: Lindan's conjecture, adopted by Bk., St., Hude, Bm., and others, for the impossible sfa=s of the Mss. Cl. explains sfa=s = au)tou/s “with strong emphasis of the pron.,” as also 5. 49. 6. Steup suspects sfa=s in both passages as an awkward gloss.
th\n e(autou= nau=n: cf. 50. 2.— 27. w(s e)s ta\s *)aqh/nas: as if for Athens.

e)n *qouri/ois: in the territory of the Thurians; for Thuc. uses *qou/rioi only of the inhabitants (104. 21; 7. 33. 27, 35. 2, 57. 58; 8. 84. 3). On the other hand the city is h( *qouri/a (34, 88. 48, 104. 12; 7. 33. 24, 30); and the district h( *qouria\s gh= (7. 35. 6).
e)pi\ diabolh=|: on a false charge. Cf. 3. 67. 33; 5. 90. 6.

oi( e)k th=s *salamini/as: the usual prolepsis. See on 7. 13.—te/ws me/n: of
indefinite duration, as 5. 7. 1.
h)/dh: now, i.e. from this time on. Cf. 1. 18. 28.
e)peraiw/qh e)s *pelopo/nnhson: for the particulars, see 88. § 9, and for the first consequences of his recall, see 74. § 1.

e)rh/mh| di/kh|: in contumaciam. Cf. Bk. Aneed. 1, 245 e)rh/mh di/kh e)sti\n o(/tan mh\ paro/ntwn a)mfote/rwn tw=n proso/ntwn(a)lla\ tou= e(te/rou mo/nou)o( dikasth\s th\n yh=fon e)ne/gkh| kata\ tou= a)po/ntos.
e)kei/nou : see on 19.
The other Athenian generals make a voyage along the north coast of Sicily, taking the Sicanian town Hyecara. Nicias visits Egesta. Fruitless attack of the Athenians upon the Geleatic Hybla.
oi( loipoi/: Nicias and Lamachus.
laxw\n e(ka/teros: sc. e(/n, as expressed at 42. 5.

cu/mpanti: (sc. tw=| strateu/mati) so Kr. after one Ms. and old editions, for cu\npanti/, which seems to be foreign to Thuc.'s usage. Cf. 3. 95. 9, and Nicias' express advice 47. 2 plei=n e)pi\ *selinou=nta pa/sh| th=| stratia=|.

e)pi\ *selinou=ntos kai\ *)ege/sths : manifestly in prosecution of the plan of Nicias (c. 47). Selinus, though further off, is mentioned first as the main goal; cf. 47. 2 plei=n e)pi\ *selinou=nta . . . e)f' o(/per ma/lista e)pe/mfqhsan, and see on 2. 7. 16. Though the Athenians, on this voyage, did not come to Selinus, that was clearly their original intention (cf. 5 kataske/yasqai de\ kai\ tw=n *selinounti/wn ta\ pra/gmata), hence the words e)pi\ *selinou=ntos are not to be bracketed, with St.— 4. ta\ xrh/mata ei) dw/sousin oi( *)egestai=oi: cf. 47. 3.
ta\ dia/fora: the points of contention. See on 1. 56. 2. On the matter, cf. 6. § 2.

paraple/ontes...th
 *sikeli/an : see on 47. 7.—e)n a)ristera=|: without either e)/xontes, which v. H. inserts here (cf. 3. 106. 5; 8. 101. 6), or labo/ntes (cf. 7. 1. 6). The voyage is first northward, then, after passing through the strait between Sicily and Italy, along the north coast of the island, here designated as to\ me/ros to\ pro\s to
 *turshniko
 ko/lpon (see on 13. 11).

e)s *(ime/ran:
cf. 5. § 1.
*(ella/s: as fem. adj. only here in Thuc.; freq. in Hdt. See on 1. 131. 6. On the matter, cf. 7. 58. § 2. —ou)k e)de/xonto: sc. oi( *(imerai=oi.
parekomi/zonto : they proceeded westerly along the coast.
*(/ukkara: for its location, see Holm, Gesch. Siz. I, 60.—po/lisma *sikaniko/n: acc. to 2. § 5 the Sicanians were confined pro\s ta\ meshmbrina\ kai\ e(spe/ria.
paraqalassi/dion : elsewhere only in Dio C. 54. 9.

parege/nonto au)tw=n i(pph=s: (i.e. tw=n *)ege/stai/wn) who had joined the Athenians before the attack on Hyccara.—au)toi/: i.e. all the Athenians (as opp. to the Egestaean cavalry), subdivided presently in tw=| me\n pezw=|, ai( de\ nh=es. Lamachus was prob. the leader of the land troops through the interior.
ai( de\ nh=es perie/pleusan: i.e. sailed on southwards round the island.

*niki/as de\ eu)qu\s...e)s to\ stra/teuma : parenthetical explanation.— 17. ta)=lla xrhmati/sas: attending to the other matters (i.e. other than financial). For xrhmati/zein in this sense, see on 1. 87. 17.—ta/lanta tria/konta: all the money on hand, acc. to 46. 3. Cf. 47. 3 ff.—parh=n e)s to\ stra/teuma: = parege/neto e)s to\ stra/teuma. See on 3. 3. 19. The army had meanwhile united again at Catana. See App.

a)pe/dosan: sold, a meaning which is extremely rare in active, and prob. another of Thuc.'s poetical usages. Cf. Eur. Cyel. 239 (St.); Ar. Ran. 1235 (Kock). The mid. occurs 1. 29. 23, 55. 6; 7. 87. 17. Cl. adopted Bk.'s conjecture a)pe/donto, and Madvig (Adv. 1, 327) suggested a)pedo/qhsan, but without citing parallels for the pass. in this sense.—e)ge/nonto: with neut. pl. subj., as 2. 8. 7; 5. 26. 12, 75. 7; here perhaps because of the definite number.

e)s tou\s tw=n *sikelw=n cumma/xous: to those of the Sicels who were allies of theirs. Except the Sicels the Athenians had as allies only Egesta, Catana, and Naxos. Nicias had just been in Egesta, and Catana was their actual station. So it is quite natural that mention is made here only of the Sicels. It seems unnecessary then, with St., to bracket tw=n *sikelw=n. Nor is Kr.'s objection to the attrib. position of the part. gen. valid for Thuc. He so inserts the part.
gen. not only often between the art. and ptc. (87. 8, 102. 2; 1. 9. 4, 48. 12, 126. 33; 3. 22. 26, 36. 19; 4. 46. 5, 111. 6, 125. 20; 8. 63. 17, 73. 4, 90. 1), as sometimes between art. and adj. (1. 25. 18; 3. 65. 14; 8. 73. 31), but even between art. and subst., oi( tw=n *)epidamni/wn fuga/des 1. 26. 13; oi( *mutilhnai/wn fuga/des 4. 52. 3; oi( *)orxomeni/wn fuga/des 4. 76. 13; tou\s paro/ntas *arka/dwn cumma/xous 5. 64. 20; tou\s *)argei/wn fuga/das 6. 7. 5; oi( tw=n *)aqhnai/wn triako/sioi loga/des 6. 101. 21; oi( e)n th=| *milh/tw| tw=n *peloponnhsi/wn . . . stratiw=tai 8. 78. 1; kata\ to\ nikh=san tw=n *peloponnhsi/wn me/ros 8. 105. 15 (cf. also ta\ au)th=s th=s *pu/lou e)/cw tou= e)/splou pro\s to\ pe/lagos 4. 8. 35; and for the part. gen. in pred. position, 1. 113. 14; 3. 85. 4; 4. 75. 8; 6. 7. 17). Also in Hdt. the part. gen. occurs in attrib. position 1. 98. 21, 143. 3. See H. v. Kleist, Der eingesch. Gen. d. Ganzen b. Thuk. (N. Jhbb. f. Philol. CXLIII, 107 ff.).
perie/pleusan: see App.
*(/ublan th\n *gelea=tin: the modern Paterno at the foot of Aetna; see on 4. 7 and Holm 1, 68, 363.
While the Athenians are preparing for a direct attack upon Syracuse, the Syracusans, in view of their delay, demand to be led against the camp at Catana.
pareskeua/zonto: with varying const., first with acc. (as 1. 54. 3; 4. 30. 11; 5. 10. 1), then verbal with w(s and fut. ptc. (as 2. 7. 3; 3. 107. 10; 4. 13. 18; 5. 62. 7).

pro\s to\n prw=ton fo/bon...e)pe/keinto : i.e. had not attacked immediately as at first they had feared and expected. For pro/s = seeundum. cf. 34. 44, 64. 12, 85. 11; 1. 140. 4; 2. 54. 9; 4. 39. 8, 106. 5. So most editors. Steup objects that the position of the neg. is against this, and renders pro/s by entgegen. On the matter, cf. 45 (end), 49. § 2.

kata/ te th\n h(me/ran e(ka/sthn: e(/kastos occurs both with the art. (cf. 31. 19; 1. 22. 12; 2. 24. 10; 3. 50. 10, 82. 14; 4. 98. 6; 5. 47. 39, 49. 9) and without (cf. 67. 18; 1. 56. 9; 2. 31. 15, 85. 16; 3. 58. 16; 4. 56. 2, 66. 2; 5. 18. 50). Gild., Syn. 661. Here is added the pred. pte. proiou=san, as each day passed on. For the participial const., see App. on 4. 63. 2. te here, correl. to kai/ before e)peidh/, marks the first stage of the gradually reviving self-confidence expressed by impf. a)neqa/rsoun; the decisive result of the weak undertakings (c. 62) of the Athenians (e)peidh\ . . . ou)x ei)lon bi/a|) is expressed by the aor. katefro/nhsan, they came to despise still more. Cf. 49. 5 th=| gnw/mh| a)naqar sou=ntas a)nqrw/pous kai\ th=| o)/yei katafronei=n
ma=llon.

ple/onte/s te ta\ e)p) e)kei=na th=s *sikeli/as : Kr. takes ta\ e)p e)kei=na as construed with ple/ontes, like plei=n th\n qa/lassan; but it seems rather adv., on the opposite coast of Sicily. te ta/, with St., for ta/ te of the Mss., so that both grounds of the recovered courage may stand out clearly. The sense of the passage is: “Since they on their voyage along the opposite coast of Sicily had shown themselves only at a distance from Syracuse and in their attack upon Gela with land troops had not taken it.”
peira/santes: cf. 1. 61. 13 peira/santes tou= xwri/ou.
ei(=lon bi/a| : of violent capture, as 1. 102. 7. Cf. 47. 7; 1. 11. 9.
oi(=on dh\ o)/xlos filei= poiei=n: as 4. 28. 12. Cf. 2. 65. 12; 8. 1. 30.—qarsh/sas: when it has got courage.
i(pph=s te: the indispensable particle is lacking in all Mss.—proselau/nontes...pro\s to\ stra/teuma : cf. 7. 73. 24, and Tac. Annales 2. 13 equo ad vallum acto.
e)fu/brizon: asked scornfully; not found elsewhere in Att. prose.

ei): = po/teron (Schol.), and so Cl. Steup explains ei) as whether not, with St., making h)/ = than after ma=llon, which is more forcible.—cunoikh/sontes sfi/sin au)toi=s...e)n th=| a)llotri/a| : Cl.^{2} and most editors unnecessarily adopt Bk.'s au)toi/. The antithesis is perfect to *leonti/nous e)s th\n oi)kei/an katoikiou=ntes (cf. 76. 6 dokou=sin ou) *leonti/nous bou/lesqai katoiki/sai, a)ll' h(ma=s ma=llon e)coiki/sai). For sfi/sin au)toi=s as indir. reflexive, cf. 1. 19. 3, 128. 5; 2. 21. 19. See Kr. Spr. 51, 2, 7. Plut. Nic. 16 (ei) *katanai/ois sunoikh/sontes h)\ *leonti/nous katoikiou=ntes h(/kousi) seems to have followed Thuc. inaccurately here.

, 65. The Athenian generals, by a false message sent through a Catanaean, induce the Syracusans to advance with their whole army upon Catana. Meanwhile the Athenian force sails by night and lands in the Great Harbor at a suitable point near the Olympieum. The Syracusans, becoming aware of the deception, return in haste.

a)/gein: entice, draw off, in which sense Thuc. elsewhere uses a)pa/gein (73. 8; 1. 109. 6; 3. 36. 4).—o(/ti plei=ston: as far as
possible.

e)n tosou/tw|: for e)n tou/tw|, with a hint of the longer time they hoped to win.—u(po\ nu/kta: Cl. explained at nightfall; but as the journey from Catana to Syracuse took considerable time, u(po\ nu/kta here, as well as in 65. 14, prob. means by night. This is the meaning also at 7. 12; 8. 35. 16; and in the other cases of its occurrence in Thuc. (1. 115. 19; 2. 92. 22; 3. 80. 7, 91. 10; 4. 67. 3; 7. 22. 2; 8. 33. 10) there is nothing against its meaning simply by night.—parapleu/santes: Cl. wrote unnecessarily prospleu/santes. Cf. 50. 7, 9; 52. 3; 94. 3.
e)n e)pithdei/w|: at a suitable place, as 2. 81. 17. Cf. 66. 3 e)s xwri/on e)pith/deion.

ei)do/tes...gnwsqei=en : knowing that they would not in like manner be able, if from the ships against men prepared they disembarked (the army) or should be recognized going by land. For e)kbiba/zein with obj. (to\ stra/teuma) to be supplied, St. compares Xen. Hell. 2. 1. 24 kai\ ou) pro/teron e)cebi/basen e)k tw=n new=n pri\n au(=tai h(=kon. For the text, see App.
tou\s yilou\s...kai\ to\n o)/xlon : note the emphatic position of these obj. accusatives before the subj. tw=n *surakosi/wn tou\s i(ppe/as.
tou\s ga\r a)\n yilou\s [tou\s] sfw=n : Cl. explained the art. here as repeated to avoid misunderstanding, but it is against Thucydidean usage, and prob. rightly rejected by St., Bm., Steup.
to\n o)/xlon: comprising, it seems, camp-followers and baggagetrain.

sfi/si d ou) paro/ntwn i(ppe/wn: de/, which is not strictly necessary, emphasizes the opposition to the preceding, and for the same reason the repetition of i(ppe/wn, which St. brackets, seems justified.—bla/ptein a)\n mega/la: note the repetition of a)/n. See on 1. 36. 15; 4. 18. 17. GMT. 223; Gild., Syn. 467. mega/la is cogn. acc. See on 1. 81. 8. G. 159, N. 2; H. 716 b; Kr. Spr. 69, 7, 3.
ou(/tw de/: but in that case, as 1. 45. 8.—o(/qen: sc. e)pixeirou=ntes.
peri\ tou= pro\s tw=| *)olumpiei/w| xwri/ou : see on 65. 15.
o(/per kai\ kate/labon: which they actually took. Cf. 1. 14. 14.

oi(\ cunei/ponto: i.e. who had joined the Athenians.—toio/nde ti...mhxanw=ntai : the same phrase also 4. 46. 17; 5. 45. 5. —ou)=n: indicating resumption after a parenthesis (see on 3. 95. 9; 7. 6. 7) with repetition of the subj. oi( strathgoi/ from 1. 1.—pro\s a(\ e)bou/lonto: in accordance with what they wished. Cf. 1. 2.
pe/mpousin: after toio/nde without ga/r, see on 1. 89. 2.
sfi/si: = sfi/sin au)toi=s, as 1. 21. See on 4. 28. 27. —th=| dokh/sei: in their opinion. The word is common in Thuc., as in tragedy, but avoided in Attic prose. See on 3. 43. 3.
h)pi/stanto...u(poloi/pous o)/ntas : ou(/s (from w(=n 1. 16) or au)tou/s to be supplied. See on 1. 10. 20; 3. 55. 12.
eu)/nwn: for eu)no/wn after the analogy of eu)/nous 3. 58. 9; eu)/nois 5. 106. 3.
au)li/zesqai: were in the habit of passing the night (pres. inf.); not to be understood, of course, of all the Athenians, for a guard must have remained behind. Cf. 1. 21 tou\s para\ sfi/si.
a)po\ tw=n o(/plwn : away from their arms or camp. For a)po/ in this sense, cf. 1. 7. 6. See Kühn. 86, 1, N. 1. For o(/pla, see on 1. 111. 6; 3. 1. 7.

e)pi\ to\ stra/teuma: i.e. the whole Athenian army, including both tou\s para\ sfi/si (21) and the guard at the camp. To bracket these words, with St., would leave e)lqei=n without goal.—au)toi/: following e)/lege(o( *katanai=os a)nh/r), i.e. the friendly Catanaeans.

tou\s para\ sfi/si: (so correctly Laur., for au)tou\s para\ sfi/si) i.e. the main body of the Athenians who spent the night in the city.—kai\ ta\s nau=s e)mprh/sein: it is to be inferred that, though the camp was outside, the ships were drawn up inside the city.— 22. [to\ stra/teuma]: recognized as a gloss by Bl. The meaning “army” does not suit the context, and there is no objection to indicating by staurw/mati the camp, which is called to\ strato/pedon in 51. 14, 75. 9, 88. 27. The necessity of supplying from staurw/mati an obj. (au)to/) for ai(rh/sein seems to have led to the gloss.
tau=ta tou\s cundra/sontas: note the emphatic position of the dem. pron. for tou\s tau=ta cundra/sontas. See on 77. 18. cundra=n is not found elsewhere in Attic prose. Cf. Liban. Orat. 736.
kai\ h(toima/sqai...h(/kein : Schol. kai\ e(toi/mous ei)=nai tou\s a)/ndras, par' w(=n au)to\s h(/kei. For the inf. in rel. sent., see on 1. 91. 24. GMT. 755; Kühn. 594, 5; Kr. Spr. 55, 4, 9.

2. meta\ tou=...qarsei=n : in accord with their confidence also in other respects. Cl. and Kr. explain meta\ tou= = praeterquam quod, comparing Dem. 5. 5 meta\ tou= prosoflei=n ai)sxu/nhn . . . pa/ntes e)/gnwte. But this does not suit the context.
ei)=nai e)n dianoi/a|: = dianoei=sqai. Cf. e)n e)lpi/di ei)=nai 4. 70. 20.

kai\ a)/neu tou/twn : i.e. without this message. But Cl. prefers to take tou/twn as mase., referring to the Catanaeans.—[pareskeua/sqai]: bracketed by nearly all recent editors. It seems clearly a gloss of ei)=nai e)n dianoi/a|, certainly cannot as pf. inf. depend on that. Possible would be paraskeua/sasqai of four Mss.

a)periskepto/teron: too incautiously. See on 57. 12.— 5. a)pe/steilan au)to/n: sent him back, reckoning on the uprising of the Catanacans. In accordance with this expectation they themselves begin to carry out the plan agreed upon: kai\ au)toi\ . . . *surakosi/ois, and they themselves made proclamation for the whole force of the Syracusans to go out. The parenthesis h)/dh ga\r . . . parh=san, coming before the repetitive and explanatory statement in 67. § 2 e)boh/qhsan de\ . . . w(s penth/konta, was suspected by Cl. But it probably explains why all the Syracusans could march out (Kr.). For allies to remain behind to protect the city (e.g. against the Sicels) would not be strange, since such a service was freq. rendered among the Hellenes for an allied state (5. 23. § 1 f., 47. § 3 f.). Cf. also 5. 33. 9 oi( *mantinh=s th\n po/lin *)argei/ois fu/laci parado/ntes au)toi\ th\n cummaxi/an e)frou/roun.
pandhmei\ pa=sin e)cie/nai *surakosi/ois : for like pleonasm, cf. 1. 90. 22 teixi/zein pa/ntas pandhmei\ tou\s e)n th=| po/lei.
e(toi=ma au)toi=s : belongs only to the first of the foll. clauses and hence was to be expected after kai/. For examples of like irregular order, see on 2. 46. 1.—ta\ th=s paraskeuh=s: cf. 29. 3.

ai( h(me/rai e)n ai)=s...h(/cein : pl. including the day of the march from Syracuse as well as that agreed upon for the attack (cf. 1. 5). Steup puts a comma after e)ggu/s, construing the adv. with h(/cein and taking h)=san as equiv. to e)fh=kon. But this view is not likely to receive support.

e)pi\ tw=| *sumai/qw|: the chief stream of the plain of Catana, and largest of Sicily; now Simeto or Giaretta. It was in Leontine territory, hence in the hands of the Syracusans. See Holm I, 27 f., 340.
to\ stra/teuma a(/pan: including the yiloi/ and o)/xlos of 64. § 1.—o(/soi *sikelw=n: who had been summoned 62. § 5.

h)\ a)/llos tis: included in o(/soi, unless we should read h)\ ei) a)/llos tis. Non-Sicel allies of the Athenians were Egesta, Catana, and Naxos; besides, Leontine fugitives were doubtless with the Athenian army (cf. 8. § 2, 50. § 4).
ta\s nau=s kai\ ta\ ploi=a: cf. 4. 116. 4 toi=s te ploi/ois kai\ tai=s nausi/. With the ploi=a are prob. included the o(lka/des of 30. 3 and 44. 6.—u(po\ nu/kta: see on 64. 3.
a(/ma e(/w|: applying also to kai\ oi( i(pph=s a)gge/llousi. The coincidence in time is emphasized by oi(/ te *)aqhnai=oi . . . kai\ oi( i(pph=s.

e)s to\ kata\ to\ *)olumpiei=on : (nearly all Mss. have e)s to\n, sc. xw=ron or to/pon) in the place opposite the Olympieum (cf. 64. 11): “Whoever sailed [from the east] into the bay called the Great Harbor of Syracuse had directly before him a ridge crowned by the temple of Olympian Zeus, remains of which are still visible in the grainfield” (Holm II, 26).
w(s to\ strato/pedon katalhyo/menoi: as planned 64. § 1, hence the art., which Laur. wrongly omits.

prw=toi: in front. Cf. 66. 12.—prosela/santes e)s th\n *kata/nhn: one Ms. (M) omits e)s, and so Hude writes th=| *kata/nh|. Steup agrees that e)s *kata/nhn, into Catana (whether city or territory), is out of place with prosela/santes, riding up, and suggests proela/santes.
a)nh=ktai : the pf. indicating that the army is gone and they are deceived.—a)postre/yantes: aor. of the sudden turning back of the horsemen.
a)potrepo/menoi e)boh/qoun: of the longer return march of the whole army, Schol. o)pi/sw e)panerxo/menoi.
The Athenians, however, had time to encamp and fortify on all sides. The Syracusans advanced against the camp, but withdrew without accomplishing anything.
e)n tou/tw|: while the Syracusans were hurrying back to the city, which required considerable time, makra=s ou)/shs th=s o(dou= au)toi=s (i.e. toi=s *surakosi/ois).

e)pith/deion kai\ e)n w(=|: attrib. adj. connected by copula with rel. clause (as in French).— 4. h(/kist' [a)\n] . . . luph/sein : one of the five passages in Thuc. where the Mss. have the fut. inf. with a)/n (cf. 2. 80. 40; 5. 82. 21; 8. 25. 28, 71. 4), a const. defended by Herbst (Ueber a)/n b. Fut. im Thuc., Progr. 1867, p. 29 ff.), rejected by St. (Qu. Gr.^{2}p.21 sqq.). Cl. adopted Meineke's conjecture (Hermes III, 372) luph/seian, and is followed by Steup.

e)n tw=| e)/rgw|: in action, as 1. 105. 24; 2. 89. 42; 4. 25. 9; 8. 42. 12; and freq.—th=| me\n ga\r teixi/a kte(.: concerning the locality occupied by the Athenians, see B. Lupus, Die Stadt Syrakus im Altertum (revision of the Cavallari-Holm Topografia), p. 118 f. —teixi/a: prob. to fence in gardens and plots of ground.

li/mnh: not the Lysimeleia (which was too near the city), but either the swanipy ground (now called Pantano) about the Cyane (a tributary of the Anapus), west of the Olympieum, or—if the camp of the Athenians cannot be thought of as extending so far west—a swamp south of the mouth of the Anapus.—para\ de\ to/: on the other side, however. The order as in 45. 5.

e)pi\ tw=| *da/skwni: the ridge extending northward from the present Punta Caderini (about the middle of the west shore of the Great Harbor). Thuc. reckons it up to the bridge over the Anapus. See Lupus, op. cit.—e)/ruma/ te: Kr.'s conjecture e)/ruma/ ti, adopted by several editors, is intended to bring our passage into agreement with Diod. 13. 13, where the Bay of Dascon, south of the Punta Caderini, is mentioned. But it is not prob, that the position of the Athenians extended so far southward, and Diodorus' topographie statements are little trustworthy (see Lupus, pp. 83, 119).—h(=| eu)efodw/taton h)=n toi=s polemi/ois: cf. 101. 14 h)=| phlw=des h)=n. The Mss. read e)fodw/taton, but the Schol. reads as in the text, explaining by prosbh=nai dunato/n, eu)pro/siton. No adj. compound of o(do/s with a prep. occurs, and for e)/fodos Xen. Anab. 3. 4. 41 is wrongly cited. But eu)e/fodos is found in Polybius, Diodorus, and Strabo, as well as Xen. Cyrop. 2. 4. 13. Bk.'s conjecture eu)odw/taton means rather pervius and expeditus, than aditu facilis.

loga/dhn: closely connected with li/qois. See on 1. 122. 15.—w)/rqwsan: erected. Cf. 88. 28.—th\n tou= *)ana/pou ge/furan: over which the road led from
Syracuse southward to the town of Elorus (or Helorus), h( *)elwri/nh o(do/s (16). The Syracusans doubtless restored the bridge after the withdrawal of the Athenians. Cf. 101. § 4.
paraskeuazome/nwn: sc. au)tw=n, while they were making preparations. For gen. abs. with subj. easily supplied from the context, cf. 1. 2. 8; 4. 3. 6. GMT. 848; H. 972 a.
oi( i(pph=s...to\ pezo/n : as they had returned from the expedition against Catana (c. 65, end).

e)/peita u(/steron: connected as in 88. 49. See on 2. 9. 7.— 14. prosh=lqon e)ggu\s tou= strateu/matos tw=n *)aqhnai/wn: cf. 4. 93. 4 prose/meicen e)ggu\s tou= strateu/matos au)tw=n. This must have happened after they had crossed the Anapus higher up.
ou)k a)ntiproh=|san au)toi=s: did not in turn advance against them. The compound occurs elsewhere only in postclassical authors. On the 41 compounds of a)nti- in Thuc. see App. on 4. 80. 3.

diaba/ntes th\n *)elwri/nhn: for the accent, not *)elwrinh/n, see Herodian 2. p. 867. They must have crossed this road before in the opp. direction (from west to east) as they marched out. See Lupus, p. 119.
On the following day both armies take position for battle.
decio\n ke/ras: for freq. omission of the art. with divisions of an army, see on 2. 81. 11; 4. 31. 8.

e)pi\ o)ktw/: eight men deep, the usual depth of front of Athenians and Lacedaemonians at the time of the Peloponnesian War. The const. is usually e)pi/ with gen., but for the acc., cf. Xen. Anab. 4. 8. 11. See on 2. 93. 22.

e)pi\ tai=s eu)nai=s: near their sleepingplaces, i.e. the tents in camp. Cf. e)n tai=s eu)nai=s 3. 112. 10; 4. 32. 2. For e)pi/ with dat. as here, see on 4. 14. 28.—e)n plaisi/w|: as 7. 78. 5. Schol. e)n sxh/mati tetragw/nw|. A hollow square is called tetra/gwnos ta/cis 4. 125. 16.

oi(=s ei)/rhto : cf. 61. 20.—ponh=| ma/lista: as 1. 49. 18. ponei=n of troops hard pressed also 4. 96. 21; 5. 73. 10. Cf. Sall. Jug. 103 ac modo laborantibus suis
succurrere.
e)forw=ntas: looking on, keeping sharp watch, with implication of removal at some distance. Cf. 3. 104. 4.—paragi/gnesqai: as 2. 83. 28.—e)nto\s...e)poih/santo : cf. 2. 83. 26; 4. 125. 17; 7. 78. 7.
tw=n e)pita/ktwn: i.e. those held in reserve, = tw=n e)pitetagme/nwn 5. 72. 17 (cf. e)peta/canto 14).

oi( de\ *surako/sioi e)/tacan kte(.: it must be assumed that the Syracusans had again advanced eastward across the Elorine road (66. 16), for after being put to flight they again take post on this road and get together (70. § 4).— 10. pandhmei\ *surakosi/ous: cf. 65. 7.— 12. *selinou/ntioi me\n ma/lista: with the other (less important) allies definite numbers are given, so that Cl. was inclined to assume before ma/lista the loss of some numeral perhaps a<*>(xi/lioi), and Stein approves. But Steup is doubtless right in rendering me\n ma/lista especially, most of all, on which then follows naturally e)/peita de\ kai/ (cf. 1. 75. 9; 2. 54. 19; 6. 11. 14, 16. 23). With this view it is quite natural that no number should be given with *selinou/ntioi.
kai\ *kamarinai/wn i(pph=s kte(.: on this aid from the Camarinaeans, cf. 75. § 3. 88. § 1.—o(/son ei)/kosi: about twenty. Cf. 7. 38. 14.
e)peta/canto e)pi\ tw=| deciw=|: i.e. they stationed the cavalry on the right to strengthen it. See on 2. 90. 7.
tou\s a)kontista/s: acc. to 1. 14 and 69. § 2 still other light troops were with the Syracusans, but these, as of less importance, seem to be disregarded in the account here of the battle array.

prote/rois e)pixeirh/sein: cf. 69. 11; 4. 73. 7.—kata\ e)/qnh e)pipariw\n e(/kasta: passing along the line of battle, as the contingents of the separate states were drawn up (1. 2 ff.). As Hippocrates had done 4. 94. § 2, Nicias made addresses of similar purport to the separate divisions, and we have here doubtless a summary of the whole.

With the excellent composition and military experience of our army we may have the strongest hope of victory. On the other hand, far from home and encompassed by enemies as we are, we should, in case of <*>ef<*>at, be
in evil plight. Think then in the impending conflict at once of your honor and of the seriousness of the situation.

oi(\ pa/resmen: as if h(ma=s preceded. The rel. has causal force (since we; see on 1. 68. 15). So all recent editors explain except Steup. He would connect oi(/ directly with w a)/ndres, the troops being addressed as comrades in battle (for first person, cf. 3. 30. 1), and to\n au)to\n a)gw=na emphasizing the common danger of the many different e)/qnh (cf. 4. 10. 1 a)/ndres oi( cunara/menoi tou=de tou= kindu/nou). Hude corrects to toiou=ton a)gw=na.

au)th\ h( paraskeuh/ : comprises all preparations and equipments for the expedition—selection, arming, drilling, payment, and maintenance of the army contingents—which now appear in the excellent condition of the whole army: “the composition and condition of our army alone” (see on 37. 3).— 3. kalw=s: ironical, of fine speeches without corresponding content. Cf. 1. 84. 16; 3. 37. 24, 38. 20, 82. 42; 5. 69. 20. It is as if the danger of encroaching rhetoric were hinted at.
o(/pou: not local here, but referring to the matters before them; cf. 8 27. 6, and, as here with foll. pw=s, 8. 96. 4.
*)argei=oi kai\ *mantinh=s : cf. c. 43; 61. § 5.
nhsiwtw=n oi( prw=toi: esp. Rhodians and Chians, c. 43. Under nhsiw=tai are to be understood islanders of the Aegean; cf. Steup, Rh. Mus. XXXV, 328 N.
pa/nta tina/: every one, as comprehensive as possible. See on 2. 41. 21; 3. 13. 33.
mega/lhn th\n e)lpi/da: position and effect of the pred. adj. as 2. 49. 24, 63. 16, 67. 30.—pro/s: as opposed to; cf. 9. 13.

pandhmei\ a)munome/nous: cf. 67. § 2. Meineke (Hermes III, 359) conjectures a)munou me/nous. But it is by no means necessary to conceive of the a)mu/nesqai beginning only with the impending battle.—ou)k a)pole/ktous: the neg. side of the same thing, opposed, by means of te . . . kai/, to pandhmei\ a)munome/nous, not to pandhmei/ alone.—w(/sper kai\ h(ma=s: attraction of case and prolepsis. Cf. 1. 69. 23; 5. 99. 4. Kr. Spr. 62, 4, 3; Kühn. 581, 3. kai/, without reference to the preceding neg., merely for the sake of the comparison; cf. 2. 13. 13.

u(perfronou=si: cf. 16. 20, and, as here with acc., 3. 39. 29. Here for the sake of the assonance (with u(pomenou=si), for the more usual
katafronei=n (34. 54, 35. 5, 49. 6, 63. 8).
e)pisth/mhn: of military knowledge and experience, as 1. 49. 12; 3. 121. 15.
parasth/tw tini\ kai\ to/de: let this also be fixed in the mind of every one. tis in wider sense; cf. 34. 53.
ei)=nai: sc. h(ma=s.
kai\ pro\s gh=| ou)demia=| fili/a| h(/ntina...kth/sesqe : and near to no friendly land, unless you win such by your own arms.
tou)nanti/on h)/: also 7. 80. 6. See on 3. 22. 28.
eu)= oi)=d' o(/ti: see on 34. 43.—oi( me\n ga/r: sc. parakeleu/ontai.

e)gw\ de/ : sc. u(pomimnh/|skw. See on 24. 8.—ou)k e)n patri/di: for e)n ou) patri/di (see on 1. 78. 1) = e)n gh=| ou) patri/di ou)/sh|. In the appended rel. sent. (see on 4. 126. 10) e)c h(=s belongs gram. only with the second clause (h)\ mh\ . . . a)poxwrei=n), the intervening clause (kratei=n dei=), which breaks the const., serving as foil for the following. For similar cases, cf. 2. 11. 9, 88. 7, 92. 5; 3. 68. 9. With the second clause supply perhaps me/llete from dei=, as if we had e)c h(=s, ei) mh\ kratei=te, mh\ r(a|di/ws me/llete a)poxwrei=n.
mh\ r(a|di/ws a)poxwrei=n : cf. 4. 10. 13. The neg. (mh/) still under the influence of parasth/tw.
polloi/ : pred., in large numbers; see on 1. 10. 10.
a)ci/as: subst., as 7. 77. 4. 12.— 18. e)pe/lqete...proqu/mws : placed between the parallel clauses th=s te . . . mnhsqe/ntes and kai\ . . . h(ghsa/menoi kte(. Cf. 15. 16.
The Athenians advance to the attack. The Syracusans, though not expecting this, enter into the battle with spirit. The different motives for the courageous bearing of the combatants.

e)ph=ge: inchoative impf.— 2. a)prosdo/khtoi: active, as in 2. 33. 14, 93. 26; 4. 72. 12; 7. 29. 14, 39. 14 (but in all these it is in the dat. of pers. reference); else where with passive force (2. 5. 13, 61. 13, 91. 15; 3. 39. 23; 4. 103. 21; 7. 46. 1; 8. 23. 12).—
3. w(s h)/dh maxou/menoi: for on the day before the Athenians had not accepted the battle offered (66. § 3). The const. of a verb of expectation with w(s and fut. ptc. is unusual; different is 7. 12. 15 prosdoki/an pare/xein w(s e)pipleu/sontai.
kai/ tines au)toi=s...proudi/dosan : parenthetical explanation, the regular narrative being resumed with o(/mws de/ (1. 10).
kai\ a)pelhlu/qesan: sc. e)s th\n po/lin: had even gone away (to the city). See App.—oi( de\ kai\ dia\ spoudh=s: and these indeed in haste. oi( de/ = tines, without change of subj., as in 1. 87. 2.

w(s de\...prosmei/ceie, kaqi/stanto : but as each everywhere reached the main body, they took their stand, i.e. without regard to the divisions they belonged to. The main body was just advancing against the Athenians (12) and was soon in conflict with these.

a)lla\ th=| me\n a)ndrei/a|...a)nte/xoi : but in bravery they were not inferior (to the Athenians) so far as their experience (in war) extended. h)=san is understood from the preceding clause. th=| a)ndrei/a| repeats and strengthens to/lmh|.

tw=| de\ e)llei/ponti au)th=s...proudi/dosan : but in the lack of it their wish also against their will they abandoned (lit. left in the lurch). tw=| e)llei/ponti = th=| e)llei/yei (see on 1. 36. 3, and Trans. Amer. Phil. Assoc. XXV, 75 ff.). th\n bou/lhsin a)/kontes is a kind of oxymoron.

o(/mws de/: antithetical to a)prosdo/khtoi me\n . . . maxou/menoi (2), but after the parenthesis virtually repeating in (the concessive clauses) ou)k a)\n oi)o/menoi . . . a)mu/nasqai what was said above. See App.
oi( liqobo/loi: throwing stones without slings, = libratores or libritores (Tac.).—sfendonh=tai: cf. 43. 14.

toco/tai: cf. 43. 13, 67. 14. —tropa\s...a)llh/lwn e)poi/oun : made routs of one another, put each other to flight. Cf. Hdt. 1. 30. 25; Xen. Hell. 7. 2. 20. troph/ with poiei=n is verbal noun of the intr. tre/pesqai, whereas in troph\n poiei=sqai (2. 19. 9; 7. 54. 4) it answers to trans. tre/pein or tre/pesqai.

oi(=a ei)ko\s yilou/s : se. poiei=n. Mss. C and G read oi(/as by reverse assimilation to
tropa/s.
sfa/gia prou/feron : Schol. e)/mprosqen th=s stratia=s e)sfagia/zonto.

ta\ nomizo/mena : the eustom is mentioned also 5. 10. § 2.—cu/nodon e)pw/trunon toi=s o(pli/tais: roused the hoplites to conflict; poetic const., lit. stirred up conflict for the hoplites. Cf. Hom. x 152 nw=in e)potru/nei po/lemon kako/n, stirs up evil war against us, and Tac. Hist. 2. 24 irritare proelium.
oi( d' e)xw/roun: they set off, the following clauses as far as e)pidei=n (23) being appos.

th=s i)di/as: modifying both swthri/as and e)leuqeri/as. Cf. 2. 44. 4; 5. 105. 2.—to\ me\n au)ti/ka...to\ de\ me/llon : for the moment . . . for the future; adv. as 7. 38. 8. Cf. 4. 107. 2 kai\ to\ au)ti/ka . . . kai\ to\ e)/peita.
*)aqhnai=oi : sc. maxou/menoi, which is more nearly explained by the epexegetical infs. sxei=n and mh\ bla/yai, just as cugkth/sasqai and e)pidei=n below.

kai\ tw=n cumma/xwn oi( au)to/nomoi: among the independent allies of the Athenians are to be understood here only such cu/mmaxoi as did not come under the a)rxh/ arising from the Delian Alliance, i.e. besides the Argives, esp. the Corcyraeans, Cephallenians, and Zaeynthians. As opp. to these a)po\ cummaxi/as au)to/nomoi (7. 57. 12), all subjects of the a)rxh/ of the Athenians are comprehended under the term to\ u(ph/koon tw=n cumma/xwn (23), even the Chians and Methymnaeans, who under the a)rxh/ enjoyed a certain independence and esp. were not liable to tribute (cf. 85. 7 f.; 7. 57. 17). That Thuc. included the Chians and Methymnaeans among the u(ph/kooi is clear not only from 7. 57. § 4f., but also from 22. 2, where Nicias otherwise would have had to take into consideration besides the u(ph/kooi cu/mmaxoi not merely Peloponnesian allies of the Athenians. See Stahl, De Sociorum Atheniensium Iudieiis, Index lect., Münster, 1881, p. 3f.
cugkth/sasqai e)kei/nois e)f' a(\ h)=lqon: to help those (the Athenians) acquire what they had come for. For e)f' a(\ h)=lqon, cf. 9. 17; 7. 15. 1.

to\ u(ph/koon: neuter collective; see on 35. 6. These belong also to the e)nanti/oi (19), but owing to the distance from the leading clause (oi( d' e)xw/roun) a new finite verb is expressed (to\ pro/qumon ei)=xon).

me/giston me/n: above all. See on 1. 142. 1.—a)nelpi/stou: closely connected with h)\n mh\
kratw=si: above all they were zealous for the safety of their lives, for which there was no hope unless they should conquer.
e)n pare/rgw|: secondarily, by the way. Cf. e)k pare/rgou 1. 142. 25; 7. 27. 20.

kai\ ei)/ ti...u(pakou/sontai : after to\ pro/qumon ei)=xon expressing the hope, whether after having helped (the Athenians) in some other conquest they shall receive milder treatment from them. ei) as in 2. 12. 3. Cf. Xen. Anab. 6. 4. 22 e)deh/qh proqumei=sqai, ei)/ ti kte(. See App.
After long and brave resistance the Syracusan army was routed, first by the Argives, then also by the Athenians; but the superior cavalry of the Syracusans prevented pursuit.

genome/nhs e)n xersi\ th=s ma/xhs: the battle had been begun by the liqobo/loi kai\ sfendonh=tai kai\ toco/tai 69. 13. gi/gnesqai e)n xersi/ is used of the combat (4. 43. 8, 14) as well as of the combatants (3. 108. 1; 5. 72. 10; 7. 5. 6).

a(/ma: at the same time (with the combat). Cf. 7. 79. 9.—gene/sqai: freq. used of natural phenomena. See on 1. 54. 23.— 3. u(/dwr: cf. 2. 5. 5, 77. 18; 7. 79. 9.— 4. pole/mw| w(milhko/si: see on 55. 17. —kai\ tou=to cunepilabe/sqai tou= fo/bou: this too (the storm) contributed to (increased) their fear. Cf. 8. 26. 5, and see on 1. 115. 9.

kai\ w(/ra| e)/tous: even to the season of the year. The sense of the passage is: “while to the more experienced the weather phenomena seemed to be due really to the season of the year” (i.e. the xeimw/n 63. 1). Cf. 7. 79. § 3.

tou\s de\ a)nqestw=tas...pare/xein : the emphasis is on mh\ nikwme/nous: the fact that their antagonists were not conquered (i.e. after so long a conflict) caused far more consternation. For the ptc. in pred. position with force of verbal subst., see App. on 4. 63. 2.
w)same/nwn: pushed back, routed. See on 4. 35. 11.
to\ kata\ sfa=s au)tou/s: i.e. the center (67. 3).—parerrh/gnuto: i.e. the line was broken; cf. 4. 96. 25; 5. 73. 3.
prodiw/kontas: pushing forward in pursuit. Prob. elsewhere only in Xen. Anab. 3. 3. 10.
a)ne/stellon: they drove them back. Cf. 3. 98. 3.
i(/stasan: proceeded to set up. See on 5. 74. 5.
w(s e)k tw=n paro/ntwn: as well as possible under present circumstances; also 4. 17. 4. Cf. w(s w(=d' e)xo/ntwn Soph. Ant. 1179.
to\ *)olumpiei=on: cf. 64. 11, 65. 15.—o(/mws: nevertheless, i.e. although beaten.—sfw=n au)tw=n pare/pemyan: sent from themselves (part. gen.), i.e. from the main body that was retiring to the city.
tw=n xrhma/twn: part. gen., as 1. 143. 2.
kai\ oi( loipoi\ e)panexw/rhsan: correlated with e)/s te to\ *)olumpiei=on . . . pare/pemyan, although in the course of the narrative the subject has been restricted.
The Athenians, after burning their own dead and giving up under truce those of the enemy, decide not to prosecute the attack, on account of the advanced season and other unfavorable circumstances.
to\ i(ero/n: to\ *)olumpiei=on.
e)pi\ pura\n e)piqe/ntes : cf. 2. 52. 16.
au)tou=: i.e. on the battlefield.
ta\ o)sta= cune/lecan: with a view to taking them home to Athens. Cf. 2. 34. 13 ai)ei\ e)n au)tw=|(tw=| dhmosi/w| sh/mati)qa/ptousi tou\s e)k tw=n pole/mwn.
xeimw/n: cf. 63. 1.

au)to/qen: i.e. from where they had bivouacked. But below (11 and 12) au)to/qen = e)k th=s
*sikeli/as.

i(ppe/as te : correlated with kai\ xrh/mata de/ (12), the strengthening of the second clause (with de/) being due to its remoteness. With te in 13 and 15 third and fourth members are added: (1) cavalry, (2) money, (3) allies, (4) provisions and other necessaries.—metape/mywsin: Thuc. uses act. and mid. apparently without distinction; see on 1. 112. 6.
i(ppokratw=ntai: be inferior in cavalry; elsewhere only in later writers. Cf. naukratei=n, to be superior in ships, 7. 60. 7.
xrh/mata...culle/cwntai kai\...e)/lqh| : a rare example of the noun functioning as obj., then as subj. in the same clause. For freq. like const. of rel. pron., see on 4. 17. 2.
a(\s h)/lpizon...u(pakou/sesqai : cf. 49. § 6.

ta\ a)/lla: general obj. of paraskeua/swntai explained by kai\ si=ton kai\ o(/swn de/oi, both food and whatever was needed. Cf. 88. 33.—w(s e)s to\ e)/ar: the Mss. have w(/ste, but Valla translates tanquam sub vernum tempus. i)s of the terminus in view. See on 16. 30.

Hermocrates urges the Syracusans to improve their military organization and equipment in accordance with their experience, and to commit the conduct of the war to a few men, assuring them full confidence and ready obedience.

tau/th| th=| gnw/mh|: in accordance with this determination (referring to the reasons for sailing back to Catana 71. 8). Cf. 1. 45. 1; 2. 20. 1; 4. 32. 23.—a)pe/pleusan e)s th\n *na/con kai\ *kata/nhn: both for temporal and geographical reasons Catana should have come first, but Naxos precedes because there first the fleet, after the attempt upon Messene, passed the greater part of the winter (74. § 2), and from there further undertakings proceeded (88. § 3). The sentence is a sort of caption for the whole following episode (Boehme-Widmann). See App.— 3. e)kklhsi/an e)poi/oun: called an assembly. See on 1. 67. 11.

parelqw\n au)toi=s: see on 15. 19.— 4. *(ermokra/ths: introduced already (4.58 ff.; 6.32 ff.) as conspieuous statesman and orator; here, where he begins to influence decisively the course of the Sicilian war, properly honored with a characterization esp. emphasizing his
already proved military capacity.— kai\ e)s ta)=lla: cf. 15. 5.—cu/nesin: see Bk. 1^{4}. Einl. p. xlviii. The determining acc. with lei/pesqai/ tinos is less freq. than the dat.

kata\ to\n po/lemon...e)pifanh/s : referring prob. not so much to the present war between Syracuse and Athens, but, as in 91. 24 and 2. 100. 7, in a wider sense to wars of the Syracusans before the second appearance of the Athenians in Sicily.
ou)k ei)/a: protested. See on 1. 28. 9.
e)ndido/nai: give in, with dat. also 3. 37. 6 (oi)/ktw|), 8. 86. 33, 89. 4 (toi=s polemi/ois).
gnw/mhn: spirit, courage. See Bk. 1^{4}. Einl. p. xlvii.—ou)x h(ssh=sqai: cf. 8. 66. 13 h(ssw=nto tai=s gnw/mais.

o(/son ei)ko\s ei)=nai : inf. in rel. sent. in indir. disc. See on 24. 13; 1. 91. 24. GMT. 755; Kühn. 594, 5; Kr. Spr. 55, 4, 9; 53, 2, 9. St.'s bracketing of ei)=nai cannot be right, as it would hardly have occurred to any one to add the verb if only o(/son ei)ko/s had been written.—a)/llws te kai/: although wanting in all the better Mss. kai/ is indispensable with the pte. a)ntagwnisame/nous.

i)diw/tas, w(s ei)pei=n, xeirote/xnais : almost as tyros against skilled handicraftsmen. For i)diw/ths as antithesis to one who has become expert by skill and practice, cf. 2. 48. 11 i)atro\s kai\ i)diw/ths. That the Syracusans were lacking in military experience has been indicated already by Thuc. himself in 69. 6 ff. w(s ei)pei=n, in qualification of a strong expression, often placed, as here, in the midst of the expression qualified. Cf. 3. 38. 29, 39. 25, 82. 3; 7. 58. 22; 8. 5. 19. See App.

me/ga bla/yai: see on 64. 8.— kai\ to\ plh=qos...kai\ th\n poluarxi/an : also the multitude of generals and the distribution of command among many. With this interpretation there is no tautology in the text and hence no need, with Stahl, Hude, and others—following Pluygers, Mnem. XI, 92—to bracket to\ plh=qos tw=n strathgw=n kai/. For poluarxi/a, cf. Xen. Anab. 6. 1. 18; Plut. Camill. 18; also Hom. B 204 ou)k a)gaqh\ polukoirani/h.

tw=nte pollw=n th\n a)cu/ntakton a)narxi/an : and the disorderly insubordination of the many. With studied paronomasia (cf. 76. § 2, 4, 79. § 2, 3) Hermocrates contrasts with the large number of nominal commanders the anarehy of the soldiers, i.e. the resultant insubordination of the mass accustomed to no order and discipline. For an example of this, cf. 69. § 1. For the rare use of te to connect two single notions, see on 1. 12. 15.

paraskeua/swsi to\ o(plitiko/n: Schol. paideu/swsin ei)s paraskeuh/n, i.e. prepare the hoplite force for service.— 16. th=| a)/llh| mele/th| prosanagka/zontes: that to which it is to be compelled is to be inferred from the context elsewhere in Thuc. (88. 24, 91. 17; 3. 61. 14; 4. 87. 8; 5. 42. 19; 7. 18. 31; 8. 76. 32); here it is expressed with the dat., forcing them to exercise (drill) besides. For a)/llh| in this sense, cf. 1. 2. 12, 128. 21; 2. 14. 3.

e)/fh: by its position emphasizing the certainty of success, the conditions of which have been stated. Kr. suspected the word on account of its emphatic position.— sfa=s: as freq. referring to those represented by the speaker.

a)ndrei/as me\n...prosgenome/nhs : the former is assumed as actual, the other is hypothetical: having courage, if discipline be added when it comes to action. For e)s ta\ e)/rga, cf. 2. 39. 6, 43. 10, and see on 1. 105. 23.

a)mfo/tera au)ta/: for neut. after two fem. nouns, see on 3. 97. 19. Cl. understood au)ta/ = sponte. But what follows is against this. a)mfo/tera au)ta/ merely reiterates the foregoing ideas; cf. 5. 15. 1; Isoc. 6. 25.—th\n me/n: sc. th\n eu)taci/an.
meta\ kindu/nwn meletwme/nhn : cf. 1. 18. 32 meta\ kindu/nwn ta\s mele/tas poiou/menoi.

th\n d) eu)yuxi/an : = a)ndrei/an. The order is chiastic. For eu)yuxi/an, see Bk. 1^{4}. Einl. p. xlix.—au)th\n e(auth=s...qarsalewte/ran e)/sesqai : the comp. with gen. of the reflex. pron. measures progress in the subj. itself. See on 1. 8. 13; 7. 66. 14. Freq. in Hdt. H. 644; Kühn. 541, 6. The sense of the passage is: “in proportion as (meta/) confidence in their (military) knowledge grows, their courage will be bolder than it was.” qarsalewte/ran e)/sesqai—where e)some/nhn was to be expected—gives e)pidw/sein more definitely. Cf. Veget. 1. 1 scientia rei bellicae dimicandi nutrit audaciam. Nemo facere metuit, quod se bene fecisse confidit.

kai\ o)li/gous kai\ au)tokra/toras: pred., not only few, but also with full powers. The first point has already been fully discussed in § 4, so that the second only is here emphasized. For the force of kai/ . . . kai/, see on 16. 1.— 23. to\ o(/rkion: sing., as freq. in Hdt.
—h)= mh/n: with indirect oath, as 4. 84. 4.
ma=llon a)\n ste/gesqai: poetical form of expression. Cf. ti/ xrh\ ste/gein h)\ ti/ le/gein; Soph. Phil. 136; kako/n ti keu/qeis kai\ ste/geis u(po\ sko/tw| Eur. Phoen. 1214.

a)profasi/stws: without evasions.—paraskeuasqh=nai: a)/n of the first clause is understood here. Steup thinks not, the determining condition being sufficiently expressed by ou(/tw. See App. on 2. 3. 8.
In consequence of this admonition Hermocrates and two others are placed in command and ambassadors are sent to Corinth and Sparta to urge the pushing of the war.
tou/tous trei=s: emphasizing the limitation of the pentekai/deka of 72. 12. For absence of art., cf. e(ni\ e)/rgw| tou/tw| 5. 75. 11; e)pi\ mi/an po/lin tau/thn 7. 56. 23.
cummaxi/a : abstract for concrete, = cu/mmaxoi; cf. w)feli/a below (9).

to\n pro\s *)aqhnai/ous po/lemon bebaio/teron...e)k tou= profanou=s kte(.: the two adverbs strengthen each other: “to make the war more persistently and openly in their behalf.” Cf. 88. 44 to\n au)tou= po/lemon safe/steron poiei=sqai pro\s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous and 91. 20 ta\ e)nqa/de xrh\ a(/ma fanerw/teron e)kpolemei=n.
e)k tou= profanou=s : as 3. 43. 10. Cf. e)k tou= eu)qe/os 1. 34. 10; e)k tou= a)fanou=s 1. 51. 3; e)k tou= fanerou= 4. 79. 10.
u(pe\r sfw=n : in their behalf, carried out in the final clause i(/na . . . e)pipe/mpwsin.

a)paga/gwsin : (sc. oi( *lakedaimo/nioi) draw off, as 1. 109. 6; 3. 36. 4; 5. 55. 10. See on 64. 2.— 9. w)feli/an a)/llhn: other assistance, i.e. reënforcements. For this meaning, cf. 88. 45, 93. 10, 103. 13.
e)pipe/mpwsin: sc. oi( *)aqhnai=oi. The change of subj. is harsh. See on 1. 51. 16.
The Athenians failing in their attempt to bring over Messene betake themselves to Naxos for winter quarters, and send to Athens for money and cavalry.

e)n th=| *kata/nh|: cf. 71. 8, and see on 72. 1.—eu)qu/s: i.e.
immediately after the return to Catana.

w(s prodoqhsome/nhn: in the hope that it would be betrayed, i.e. that the negotiations begun by Alcibiades (50. § 1), and probably continued secretly with the pro-Athenian faction, would now be successful.—a(\ me\n e)pra/sseto: the negotiations, Schol. ta\ th=s prodosi/as. For pra/ssein of secret negotiations, cf. 56. 7 and freq. For me/n the correl. is de/ in 1. 8.

ou)k e)ge/neto: did not come to anything. Cf. 4. 68. 31; 5. 116. 3; and see on 3. 23. 26.—h)/dh: Hude would transpose after e)pista/menos, but it seems to be added to o(/t' a)ph/|ei e)k th=s a)rxh=s to emphasize the fact that the treachery of Alcibiades followed his recall when he had to give up his command.— 4. e)pista/menos o(/ti feu/coito: knowing (i.e. having determined) that he would go into banishment. He had taken at once the resolution which he carried out at Thurii (61. § 6). The opt. of indir. disc., as 1. 38. 4; 4. 108. 13.— mhnu/ei...to\ me/llon : cf. 4. 89. 10 mhnuqe/ntos tou= e)pibouleu/matos.
oi( de/ : sc. oi( tw=n *surakosi/wn fi/loi.

tou\s a)/ndras : as may be understood from the context = tou\s u(po/ptous w(s prodido/ntas Schol.— die/fqeiran: after the hist. pres. mhnu/ei not to be taken, with Cl., as plpf. (see on 46. 9), but as aor. narrandi.— pro/teron: i.e. immediately after the information given by Alcibiades; opp. to to/te, at that time, i.e. on the approach of the Athenian fleet.—stasia/zontes kai\ e)n o(/plois o)/ntes: since oi( de/ (6) can refer only to the party friendly to the Syracusans, as likewise e)pekra/toun mh\ de/xesqai tou\s *)aqhnai/ous, and finally the particles te . . . kai/ seem clearly to indicate that two things are to be said of oi( de/, these participles cannot refer, as Cl. and St. think, to all the Messenians: For stasia/zein of a party in insurrection (not of a whole in dissension), cf. 17. 12; 1. 126. 41; and sta/sis 4. 71. 2; 7. 50. 4.
e)n o(/plois : see on 56. 9. —e)pekra/toun: carried the point, with inf. expressing the result, as 5. 46. 25.
oi( tau=ta boulo/menoi: in epexegetical apposition to oi( de/. Steup follows v. H. in bracketing the words as a marginal explanation.

h(me/ras peri\ trei=s kai\ de/ka: peri/ in a numerical statement placed after the noun, as 1. 54. 13, 117. 5. Cf. 1. 100. 6.—mei/nantes: i.e. before Messene.— 9. e)xeima/zonto: were storm-beaten, as 2. 25. 19; 3. 69. 4, and freq.

o(/ria
kai\ staurw/mata peri\ to\ strato/pedon poihsa/menoi: having constructed dockyards and stockades round the camp. staurw/mata in pl., as 7. 53. 2. See App.

The Syracusans utilize the leisure to build fortifieations for the defense of the city. They make also an expedition against Catana and destroy the abandoned Athenian camp. On information that the Athenians had sent ambassadors to Camarina to win over that city, they too send thither Hermocrates and others for the same purpose.
e)tei/xizon: has double object pro/s te th=| po/lei . . . tei=xos . . . o(rw=n and (4) kai\ ta\ *me/gara frou/rion kai\ . . . a)/llo.

to\n *temeni/thn : the temple of Apollo Temenites and the suburb which had grown up about it, the later Neapolis.—e)nto\s poihsa/menoi: i.e. they brought the hitherto open suburb into the compass of the new wall. If it be true, as is highly probable, that the outer city (Achradina) was walled about, the new wall bent round the earlier one on the eastern declivity of Epipolae (para\ pa=n to\ pro\s ta\s *)epipola\s o(rw=n), and led from there down toward the Great Harbor. For its probable course, see the map Siege of Syracuse. Cf. Holm, Gesch. Siziliens II, 384 f.; Lupus, Die Stadt Syrakus, p. 120 ff.; Freeman, Hist. of Sicily III, 656 ff.; W.E. Heitland, Jour. of Philol. XXIII, 46 ff.; E. Lange, Philologus LVI, 677. —to\ pro\s ta\s *)epipola\s o(rw=n: cf. 97. 25, 101. 2; 2. 55. 4, 93. 22; 7. 37. 6.— 3. o(/pws mh\ di) e)la/ssonos eu)apotei/xistoi w)=sin: a circumvallation on the part of the enemy (a)potei/xisis) should in consequence of the greater circuit of their own wall not be practicable within a slighter distance from the city proper, and so in smaller compass.

ta\ *me/gara frou/rion: sc. e)tei/xizon; for const., cf. 2. 32. 1 e)teixi/sqh *)atala/nth . . . frou/rion. They fortified Megara (a(\ h)=n e)rh=ma 49. 18) for a defense toward the north (see on 94. 6), as the Olympieum toward the south.

th\n qa/lassan proestau/rwsan: they protected the shore by means of pales driven in along it. See on 4. 9. 4. Only the Great Harbor is meant, as 97. § 1 shows, and indeed the pales were driven down pro\ tw=n palaiw=n newsoi/kwn (7. 25. 20).
h(=| a)poba/seis h)=san: where landings were possible. See on 4. 13. 5.
th=s gh=s...e)/temon : part. gen. au)tw=n = tw=n *katanai/wn.
ta\s tw=n *)aqhnai/wn skhna\s kai\ to\ strato/pedon : cf. 51. § 3, 64. § 3, 88. § 5.

e)s th\n *kama/rinan: cf. 52. § 1.— 12. th\n e)pi\ *la/xhtos genome/nhn cummaxi/an: cf. 3. 86. § 2. See on 52. 6.—ei)/ pws: with opt., as 4. 11. 12 and freq.— 13. a)ntepresbeu/onto: elsewhere only in later writers.—kai\ au)toi/: added to give additional force; see on 1. 50. 18.
u(/poptoi: followed (1) by mh/ with inf. (2) by mh/ with subjv.

a(\ e)/pemyan: about 20 horsemen and 50 bowmen (67. § 2).—mh\ ou)ke/ti bou/lwntai: the reference to the future in e)s to\ loipo/n induces (as opposed to mh\ pe/myai of the past) the subjvs. dependent on u(/poptoi in the sense of aroused anxiety; but the two clauses are closely correlated by mh/te . . . te.
kata\ th\n prote/ran fili/an : belongs to peisqe/ntes, not to prosxwrw=si; with the latter it would be superfluous.

prodiaba/llein: i.e. to forestall the influence of the Athenians by a contrary representation; cf. 76. 2 dei/santes . . . tou\s me/llontas a)p' au)tw=n lo/gous. For diaba/llein means here not so much to ‘slander,’ as to ‘put in an unfavorable light,’ as also 83. 12.

div2.head: Speech of Hermocrates of Syracuse at Camarina (76-80)
div2.p:
We are come because we feared you might give heed to what the ambassadors will say. Not the restoration of Leontini, but the subjugation of the whole island is the object of the Athenians. They intend to proceed here just as at home, where the Hellenic cities, which accepted their leadership
in the alliance concluded on the pretext of taking revenge on the Medes, have one after another been enslaved on trumped-up charges.

ou) th\n parou=san du/namin tw=n *)aqhnai/wn...a)lla\ ma=llon tou\s...lo/gous (3): objs. of dei/santes so construed that the former recurs as obj. (au)th/n) of mh\ kataplagh=te, while from the latter (tou\s lo/gous) a subj. is supplied for mh\ u(ma=s pei/swsi. Thuc. freq. uses such proleptic consts. to make vivid important ideas. Cf. 77. 1, 88. 5.
mh\ au)th\n kataplagh=te: for accus., cf. h(ma=s . . . e)kpeplhgme/noi ei)=en 11. 12.

tou\s me/llontas a)p) au)tw=n lo/gous : sc. le/gesqai, the words that are going to be said on their part. See on 28. 1, 32. 16; 3. 36. 24. With tou\s me/llontas lo/gous, cf. ta\ me/llonta e)/rga 3. 38. 17; to\n me/llonta po/lemon 1. 36. 8; 8. 43. 11; o( a)gw\n o( me/llwn 7. 61. 2.
pri/n ti kai\ h(mw=n a)kou=sai : put for emphasis before the mh/ clause. See on 80. 17.
h(/kousi ga\r kte(.: stating what is pointed to in pri/n ti kai\ h(mw=n a)kou=sai. For ga/r, see on 33. 7.

profa/sei me\n...dianoi/a| de/ : cf. Hdt. 2. 100. 11 tw=| lo/gw|, no/w| de/. The dat. profa/sei, as 5. 53. 2; elsewhere accus., 33. 8; 3. 111. 2; 5. 80. 17.—h(=| punqa/nesqe: se. h(/kein. In the second clause the rel. is construed as dir. obj. with u(ponoou=men, as 7. 73. 1 u(ponoh/sas au)tw=n th\n dia/noian. On the matter, see 33. § 2.
*leonti/nous katoiki/sai: cf. 33. 9, 50. 17, 63. 14, 77. 6.—katoiki/sai...e)coiki/sai : paronomasia, freq. in Thuc., esp. in speeches. See on 72. 12; 1. 33. 26.
ou) ga\r dh/: cf. 69. 6.—ta\s e)kei= po/leis: as Aegina, Scione, Melos.
a)nasta/tous poiei=n: as 8. 24. 15.

*leonti/nwn *xalkide/wn: cf. 3. § 3.—kata\ to\ cuggene/s: cf. 6. 4, 77. 6.—kh/desqai: always of especially thoughtful care or sympathy, here ironical. See on 14. 2.— 10. doulwsame/nous e)/xein: see on 39. 10; 1. 38. 15.

th=| au)th=| i)de/a|: in the same way, as 3. 62. 4; 7. 81. 30. Cf. tou=to to\ ei)=dos 77. 13. For Thuc.'s use of the word, see on 1. 109. 2.—e)kei=na: i.e. the Hel
lenic cities in the east brought under their rule.
peirw=ntai: sc. sxei=n.

e(ko/ntwn : for the matter, cf. 1. 75. § 2, 95. § 1, 96. § 1.—tw=n te *)iw/nwn kai\ o(/soi...timwri/a| : both of the Ionians (of Asia Minor) and all who, descended from them, were members of the alliance concluded for revenge upon the Mede. The original members of the Delian Confederation that were not tribally related to the Athenians, as the Lesbians, are disregarded here, because the orator would draw a paralled between the present conduct of the Athenians in Sicily and their attainment to power in the east, and has before spoken of the Athenian pretext of interference on behalf of their kinsmen, the Leontines. For both these reasons, mention of allies not tribally related to the Athenians, which Kr. misses here, would be out of place, and would besides be in open contradiction of 82. § 3, where the Athenian speaker, with manifest reference to the present passage, says: e)s to\ a)kribe\s ei)pei=n ou)de\ a)di/kws katastreya/menoi tou/s te *)/iwnas kai\ nhsiw/tas, ou(\s cuggenei=s fasin o)/ntas h(ma=s *surako/sioi dedoulw=sqai. h)=lqon ga\r e)pi\ th\n mhtro/polin e)f' h(ma=s meta\ tou= *mh/dou. On the other hand, the mention of the Hellespontians in 77. 8 proves nothing for Kr.'s view, since most of the dwellers on the Hellespont and the Propontis were of Ionic descent, and so, in Hdt.'s phrase (1. 147. 7), were a)p' *)aqhne/wn; besides 77. § 1 need not refer merely to the time of the formation of the Delian Confederation. For the whole passage, esp. its importance for the history of the transition of the naval hegemony to Athens, its relation to 1. 89. § 2 and 1. 95. § 1, and its contradiction of Hdt. 9. 106—acc. to which, of the Ionians of Asia Minor only the Chians and Samians at the time of the formation of the Delian alliance had belonged to the great Hellenic confederation, which also is irreconcilable with Arist. Ath. Pol. 23—see Steup, Rh. Mus. XXV, 329 ff., and App. on 1. 89. 8.—tw=n te *)iw/nwn kai\ o(/soi: correlation of whole and part, as 16. 21, 69. 21, 88. 55; 1. 5. 18; 2. 69. 9; 3. 51. 7; 4. 5. 6.

a)po\ sfw=n h)=san: Schol. a)/poikoi h)=san au)tw=n. Cf. 1. 12. 13 *)/iwnas *)aqhnai=oi kai\ nhsiwtw=n tou\s pollou\s w)/|kisan. Cf. also 2. 15. 25; 7. 57. 19.—cu/mmaxoi: here members of an alliance; see on 1^{4}. 48. 11.—w(s e)pi\ tou= *mh/dou timwri/a|: timwri/a tino/s, vengeance on some one, as 7. 68. 4; 8. 82. 4; whereas in 3. 63. 3 e)pi\ th=| h(mete/ra| timwri/a| must mean for your protection against us. The meaning vengeance here is supported by 1. 96. 4 pro/sxhma h)=n a)mu/nasqai w(=n e)/paqon dh|ou=ntas th\n basile/ws xw/ran, and the fact that in § 4 of the present chapter the reference is to events of 480 and 479 B.C. need not keep us from understanding the present passage in agreement with the parallel one in Book I.

tou\s me\n...tou\s de\...toi=s d)...e)penegko/ntes katestre/yanto : for the matter, cf. 1. 98. § 4, 99. In the first two clauses we have the accus. depending on katestre/yanto, but in the third toi=s d) by attraction to w(s e(ka/stois
tina\ ei)=xon ai)ti/an eu)preph= e)penegko/ntes, understanding au)toi=s with e)penegko/ntes in the first two clauses and au)tou/s with the verb in the third clause. See on 77. 15.—lipostrati/an: for the form, see on 1. 99. 3.

e)penegko/ntes: has obj. first in accus. (lipostrati/an), then in inf. clause (e)p' a)llh/lous strateu/ein, referring to Samos and Miletus, 1. 115. § 2), and last in rel. cl. (w(s e)ka/stois tina\ ei)=xon ai)ti/an eu)preph=, sc. e)pife/rein).
kai\ ou) peri\ th=s e)leuqeri/as a)/ra: a)/ra gives a tone of bitter scorn to the conclusion that even in the preceding conflicts the question was never one of Hellenic freedom.

ou)/te tw=n *(ellh/nwn ou)/q)...th=s e(autw=n : for omission of art. (th=s) in the first member, cf. 83. 7, and see on 6. 27.—tw=| *mh/dw| a)nte/sthsan: not to be understood, with Cl., of the continuance of the war till 449 B.C. The Hellenes here mentioned were at the time of the formation of the Delian Confederation no longer under Persian rule, and the liberation of Hellenes was also not the object of thatalliance. In the reply of Euphemus, too (83. § 2), the struggle for freedom is put in the earlier period.
peri\ de\ oi( me\n sfi/sin...kakocunetwte/rou de/ : for analysis of the passage, see App. —sfi/sin: = sfi/sin au)toi=s. See on 4. 28. 27.
e)pi\ despo/tou metabolh=|: i.e. to change one master for another. Cf. 18. 39.
kakocunetwte/rou: (= kakofroneste/rou) coined for the sake of the paronomasia.

It is high time that we, warned by these examples and not deceived by their false pretenses, show them by our united resistance that we are Dorians and of quite other spirit than the Hellenes subject to them. Or shall we let ourselves be subdued severally by them and believe ourselves safe until our turn comes?
