a)ll)...ga/r : a)lla/ breaks off from the preceding, ga/r leads over to something else. Kr. Spr. 69, 14, 4.—th\n tw=n *)aqhnai/wn...po/lin...o(/sa a)dikei= : proleptic const., as 76. 1.

paradei/gmata tw=n t' e)kei= *(ellh/nwn: te—which is slightly misplaced, belonging after paradei/gmata—is correl. to kai\ nu=n. Cf. 76. 11. Most of the better Mss. have e)kei=se, but this for e)kei= is found only in late writers. Elsewhere Thuc. uses para/deigma, in sing. and pl., as predicate of persons or events which serve
as examples (para/deigma au)toi\ o)/ntes 2. 37. 2; paradei/gmasi toi=s progegenhme/nois xrw/menoi 3. 10. 19; paradei/gmasi xrw/menoi toi=s e)s tou\s a)/llous 3. 11. 24; para/deigma e)/xomen tou\s a)ntipe/ras *eu)boe/as 4. 92. 18). Only here is it obj. with the gen. of persons serving as examples. So much the stronger is the emphasis upon the dependent clause w(s e)doulw/qhsan kte(. (cf. 4. 92. 20 w(s au)toi=s dia/keitai): having warning examples in the oversea Hellenes, how these have been enslaved because they did not defend one another.
sfi/sin au)toi=s: = a)llh/lois, as 5. 69. 17; 8. 76. 9. See on e)n e(autoi=s 4. 25. 34.

kai\ nu=n e)f) h(ma=s tau)ta\ paro/nta sofi/smata : tau)ta\ sofi/smata is second obj. of e)/xontes with e)f' h(ma=s paro/nta as pred. For sofi/smata, sophisms, only here in Thuc., cf. sofisth/s also occurring once only (3. 38. 31). For e)f' h(ma=s paro/nta, directed against us, cf. 8. 92. 45. See on 3. 3. 19. The admissibility of this const. can scarcely be doubted, considering Thuc.'s fondness for the periphrastic use of e)/xein with pred. adjs. (see on 1. 120. 9), even if elsewhere only in 1. 144. 19 (h(=sson e)gkeisome/nous tou\s e)nanti/ous e(/comen) he addsaptc. as pred. to e)/xein. On account of the position of te (4), St. understands with this clause e)/xontes paradei/gmata, but the slight misplacement of te, which really belongs after paradei/gmata, need not be taken as a fatal objection to the explanation here adopted. See on 2. 46. 1.

katoiki/seis...e)pikouri/as : explan. appos. to sofi/smata. The pl. by its general character indicates the unreality of the pretexts assigned. On the matter, cf. 6. § 1, 8. § 2, 33. § 2, 50. § 4, 63. § 3, 76. § 2.—*)egestai/wn e)pikouri/as: obj. gen., as 7. 43. 12 th\n e)pixei/rhsin tw=n *)epipolw=n.
custrafe/ntes : uniting together, not merely in a military sense. Cf. 91. 5; 8. 54. 17.—proqumo/teron: see on 6. 6.—dei=cai: cf. dh=lon poih=sai 34. 21.

o(/ti ou)k *)/iwnes ta/de ei)si/n : that this is not Ionians. The neut. ta/de with masc. pred. gives esp. emphasis. Cf. *)apo/llwn ta/d' h)=n Soph. O.R. 1329; ou) ga/r e)sq' *(/ektwr ta/de Eur. Androm. 168. ei)si/n construed with pred., as 3. 112. 2; 4. 102. 13.—ou)k *)/iwnes...ou)d) *(ellhspo/ntioi kai\ nhsiw=tai : a complete enumeration of the subjects of the Athenians is not intended, rather only chief groups are made prominent; e.g. the communities of the Thracian coast and the Aeolians of Asia Minor are not taken into account. See Steup, Rh. Mus. XXXV, 327 N.—nhsiw=tai: inhabitants of the Cyclades. See on 3. 104. 11.
e(/na ge/ tina: any one whoever. Cf. 34. 11, 61. 12.—metaba/llontes: changing to, adopting. Cf. metabolh=| 76. 19.
a)p) au)tono/mou th=s *peloponnh/sou : cf. a)po\ sfw=n 76. 13.
h)\ me/nomen e(/ws: or are we waiting until. The indie. in the ironical question is more effective than the dub. subjv.—e(/kastoi kata\ po/leis: severally city by city.
tau/th|: in this way, i.e. thus isolated.
e)pi\ tou=to to\ ei)=dos trepome/nous w(/ste kte(.: cf. 8. 56. 7 tre/petai e)pi\ toio/nde ei)=dos w(/ste kte(. For tou=to to\ ei)=dos, cf. th=| au)th=| i)de/a| 76. 11.

toi=s de\ w(s e(ka/stois...kakourgei=n : toi=s de/ is assimilated to e(ka/stois, which is construed with le/gontes. Jowett explains, “kakourgei=n stands in a double const., with du/nantai and with w(/ste.” The sense of the passage is as if we had tou\s de\ kakourgei=n w(s e(ka/stois ti proshne\s le/gontes du/nantai (sc. kakourgei=n au)tou/s). Cf. 76. 15. But Steup, who adopts with Hude (after Badham) tou\s de/, objects to the above (Cl.'s) explanation, that, whereas in 76. 15 toi=s de/ is connected naturally with a ptc. in the leading clause (e)penegko/ntes), here it must be dependent on a ptc. (le/gontes) to be supplied from the dependent clause. St. brackets du/nantai, which relieves the difficulty, if we also read, with v. H., le/gontas. Schütz (Ztsch. f. d. Gym. XXXIII, 101) would transpose du/nantai le/gontes.
proshne/s : not found elsewhere in Attic prose.

e)s au)to/n tina: to each one himself. See on 31. 25. e)s with h(/cein as xwrei=n e)/s tina 4. 35. 2; katafeu/gein e)/s tina 4. 113. 10; pe/mpein e)/s tina 4. 93. 8; 8. 47. 9. For the thought, cf. 1. 120. 12 prosde/xesqai de/ pote, ei) ta\ ka/tw prooi=nto, ka)\n me/xri sfw=n to\ deino\n proelqei=n.

pro\ au)tou= : referring to au)to/n tina and put for esp. emphasis before to\n pa/sxonta, to which it belongs. Cf. 64. 23 tau=ta tou\s cundra/sontas, and see on 4. 20. 15. For position of ma=llon, cf. 4. 98. 5. The sense of the passage is that rather whoever before him comes to grief suffers misfortune for himself alone. Madvig (Adv. 1, 327) thinks that the word-order requires h)/ after pa/sxonta.

Let no one doubt that contending for us he is defending himself. Indeed, whoever has heretofore feared or envied us should not for that hold aloof from us; otherwise he will after our defeat wish too late for former conditions. Camarina, however, as our neighbor and next in danger has reason above all to give up her slothfulness and vigorously make common cause
with us.

kai\ ei)/ tw| a)/ra pare/sthke kte(.: this same appeal for solidarity and warning against particularisticnarrowness Hermocrates had used in 424 B.C. at the peace congress in Gela, 4. 58-65, in part employing similar terms, esp. in 4. 60, 61.—pare/sthke: see on 34. 53. —to\n *surako/sion, tw=| *)aqhnai/w|: the collective singular, being more familiar in tone, is more urgent. Cf. o( *xalkideu/s 84. 9.
e(auto/n : rare case of acc. of refl. pers. pron. as subj. of inf., due partly to the antithesis (cf. Hdt. 5. 86. 18; 6. 137. 23, etc.), partly because ei)/ tw| pare/sthke does not admit of a nom.
u(pe/r ge th=s e)mh=s: note the change to peri/ in 3, such change of preps. being not infreq. in Thuc. where there are two clauses, Cf. 1^{4}. 1. 14.
e)n i)/sw|: as 87. 13; 1. 133. 11; 2. 53. 14.—kai\ th=s e(autou=: without repetition of prep. (peri/), as often.
o(/sw|: in so far as. See on 1. 68. 11.—ou) prodiefqarme/nou e)mou=: gen. abs., the speaker as representative of his mother-city. Cf. 1. 137. 24; 4. 64. 1.

ou)k e)rh=mos: the reading of a few inferior Mss. preferred by Steup (with Bk., St., Hude, etc.) to e)rh=mon of the better Mss., which Cl. and others retain. Not to emphasize the fact that cu/mmaxon e)rh=mon, an isolated ally, is a contradiction in terms, the context is against a reference to the already existent allies of Syracuse. As the first three sections of 78 are in form general and apply to all the Siccliotes except the Syracusans, so there is in these nowhere reference to allies of Syracuse already existent; and esp. ou) prodiefqarme/nou e)mou=, opp. to e)/xwn de\ cu/mmaxon e)me\ kte(., is said only of the Syracusans. We have then the same idea expressed first positively and then negatively, as not infreq. in Thuc. Cf. 2. 2. 19; 3. 40. 15; 7. 85. 17. For e)rh=mos, isolated, cf. esp. 1. 32. 14.—to/n te *)aqhnai=on...bou/lesqai : transition from suppl. ptc. (maxou/menos) with e)nqumhqh/tw to accus. and inf. See on 4. 27. 4.— 7. kola/sasqai: the rarer mid., as 3. 40. 22. See on dieskopei=to 59. 6.

th=| e)mh=| profa/sei : with me as a pretext.— 8. th\n e)kei/nou fili/an: referring to tw| (1), which includes all the Siceliotes except the Syracusans, but esp. the Camarinaeans. The fate awaiting them is ironically indicated: “that the Athenians while punishing the hostility of the Syracusans will know how none the less to secure their friendship,” i.e. by complete dependence. Several emendations have been proposed (Reiske doulei/an for fili/an, Pp. bia/sasqai for bebaiw/sasqai, H. Stein dh/ after fili/an),
but these only weaken the effect.— ou)x h(=sson: i.e. still more, as 88. 4.
a)mfo/tera ta/de: referring, as au)ta/, to envy and fear.
ta\mei/zw: greater things, here greater states.
i(/na swfronisqw=men: that we may receive a lesson in moderation. Cf. swfrosu/nh 1. 32. 15; to\ sw=fron 1. 37. 7.
perigene/sqai : maintain ourselves. See on 1. 55. 11.

ou)k a)nqrwpi/nhs duna/mews bou/lhsin e)lpi/zei: i.e. he hopes what he wishes, but his wish does not keep within the bounds of human power (or weakness). With bou/lhsin e)lpi/zei cf. 3. 39. 18 e)lpi/santes makro/tera me\n th=s duna/mews, e)la/ssw de\ th=s boulh/sews.

ou) ga\r oi(=o/n te...tami/an gene/sqai : gives the reason for the preceding: for it is impossible that the same person be in like measure the controller at once of his own desires and of fortune. For the thought, cf. 4. 64. 5. tami/an gene/sqai is slightly different in force from tamieu/esqai 18. 13. For te . . . kai\ o(moi/ws, cf. 2. 53. 7, and see on 2. 44. 6.

gnw/mh| a(ma/rtoi: i.e. that Syracuse will not be completely overthrown. Cf. gnw/mh| sfale/ntes 4. 18. 7; gnw/mhs a(marta/nein 92. 3; 1. 33. 17; gnw/mhs sfalh=nai 4. 28. 27; th=s do/chs sfalh=nai 4. 85. 5.

toi=s au(tou= kakoi=s o)lofurqei/s : brought to grief by his own ills. Thuc. uses elsewhere the aor. mid. of this verb (2. 46. 7; 7. 30. 21; 8. 66. 16. 81. 21); in the pass. the sense is prob. not lamented, which does not suit the context here, but in lamentabilem statum abductus (St.). Cf. memfqh=nai (4. 85. 7) and me/myasqai (1. 143. 14; 2. 60. 3, 64. 21; 3. 37. 25, 61. 5; 8. 109. 9).—ta/x) a)\n i)/sws...au)=qis fqonh=sai : he would perhaps sometime wish again to become envious of our good fortune. The aor. fqonh=sai is ingressive. For ta/x' a)\n i)/sws, see on 10. 13.
proeme/nw|: for one letting go (sc. e)me/, tou\s *surakosi/ous).

kai\ mh\ tou\s au)tou\s kindu/nous...proslabei=n : and not consent to take up the same dangers not about names, but about facts. kindu/nous proslabei=n, used by Hermocrates also in 4. 61. 3, followed here by the const. peri/ tinos, as not seldom ma/xesqai, a)gwni/zesqai, kinduneu/ein.

lo/gw| me\n ga\r...e)/rgw| de\...swthri/an : explanation of the above ou) peri\ tw=n o)noma/twn . . . e)/rgwn, for nominally one might be preserving our power, but actually his own
safety. For sw/|zein swthri/an Bl. compares Cic. ad Fam. 11. 7. 2 conservare salutem populi Romani.
ta\ deu/tera kinduneu/sontas: will incur danger next (cogn. acc.).—au)ta/: i.e. the state of affairs. Cf. 10. 5, 40. 11.

malakw=s w(/sper nu=n: cf. 75. § 3. —au)tou/s: yourselves, sponte. To this belongs not only pro\s h(ma=s i)o/ntas but also parakeleuome/nous fai/nesqai: but should of yourselves come to us, and as you, if the Athenians had first come against Camarina, would be calling us with the prayer not to yield an inch (o(/pws mhde\n e)ndw/somen), so also now show yourselves (fai/nesqai), using in like manner the same exhortation.
a(/per: belongs only to deo/menoi, as tau=ta to parakeleuome/nous, both explained by o(/pws mhde\n e)ndw/somen.
e)k tou= o(moi/ou : = o(moi/ws, as 87. 23; 2. 44. 16; 4. 10. 19. Cf. e)k tou= i)/sou 2. 3. 19.

a)ll) ou)/q)...w(/rmhsqe : but neither you, as yet at least, nor the rest have shown zeal for this. Cf. w(rmh=sqai e)s 2. 65. 5; 7. 21. 25; 8. 40. 19, 47. 17. w(rmh=sqai e)pi/ ti 9. 17 is slightly different. The verb is construed here with the more prominent subj. (u(mei=s).

, 80, § 1, 2. You cannot hold up to us your treaty of alliance with Athens, in cowardice urging the plea of justice. This treaty does not concern the present case, neither pledging you to support the Athenians nor hindering your standing by us against them. Nor out of anxiety for your safety need you decide for neutrality. If we Siceliotes only hold together, the power of the Athenians is not at all to be dreaded; especially as we can reckon upon the assistance of the war-trained Peloponnesians. Besides, neutrality toward us would not be equitable.— 1. to\ di/kaion: the point of right, or legal obligation. Cf. 4. 61. 15 to\ di/kaion th=s cunqh/khs.

pro/s te h(ma=s kai\ pro\s tou\s e)pio/ntas : the emphasis is on the second member, as shown by le/gontes . . . pro\s *)aqhnai/ous. See on 16. 1. The prep. is repeated and te placed as in 6.8 peri/ te gamikw=n tinwn kai\ peri\ gh=s a)mfisbhth/tou. The substitution of tou\s e)pio/ntas (the aggressors) for tou\s *)aqhnai/ous is purposely made, for acc. to what follows the alliance between Camarina and Athens was not for wars of aggression.

qerapeu/sete: will lay stress on. Cf. 3. 56. 9. to\ cumfe/ron ma=llon qerapeu/ontes.
—cummaxi/an...pro\s *)aqhnai/ous : the orator assumes that the Camarinaeans might seek to justify a cowardly neutrality in the present war by a plea that hostility to the Athenians would be a violation of the treaty made with the Athenians at the time of the command of Laches (cf. 75. § 3; see on 52. 6). But this treaty with Athens was directed, the orator argues, not against friends of the Camarinaeans, but against enemies attacking them; and the Camarinaeans were to support the Athenians in case these suffered injustice from others, but not if they themselves were the aggressors. And this latter was really the case, even if the Athenians talked of helping in the restoration of the city of the Leontines, their allies and kinsmen. The emptiness of this pretext even the Rhegians had recognized, who, although being Chalcidians, like the Leontines, had held aloof from that Athenian enterprise, in spite of their alliance with the Athenians. So the Camarinaeans should see that without violating their alliance with Athens they could fulfill their treaty obligations to Syracuse.— 3. h(/n ge: rel. with the force of a strong adversative conj., “this alliance, however.” See on 1. 39. 2. With the following exposition of the treaty, cf. 1. 40. § 2.—e)pi\ toi=s fi/lois: against your friends. See on 61. 5.—tw=n de\ e)xqrw=n: put before the conj. for the sake of the antithesis to toi=s fi/lois.

kai\ toi=s ge *)aqhnai/ois bohqei=n : dependent on cummaxi/an e)poih/sasqe, as 1. 44. 8 e)pimaxi/an e)poih/santo . . . bohqei=n. The ge prepares for the limiting o(/tan clause, to aid the Athenians only when.
u(p' a)/llwn: sc. a)dikw=ntai. For ellipses, similar, though not so strong, cf. 1. 78. 10; 2. 11. 34, 86. 14; 7. 69. 3.—tou\s pe/las: = a)/llous. See on 1. 32. 2.
ou)d' oi( *(phgi=noi o)/ntes *xalkidh=s: cf. 44. 17, 46. 7. Note the chiastie arrangement.
*leonti/nous cugkatoiki/zein: cf. 8. 12.—deino/n ei)...me\n...de/ : parataxis, as 1. 35. 4, 121. 19. Cf. 76. 5.

to\ e)/rgon tou= kalou= dikaiw/matos: the real meaning of the fine plea of right. kalou= (ironical) = eu)prepou=s. The same antithesis again 80. 7. —a)lo/gws swfronou=sin...w)felei=n : against the letter of the agreement display prudence (obey policy), while you on the pretext of the letter wish to aid those who are your natural enemies. For swfronei=n, cf. 78. 11, 87. 19. For the paronomasia, see on 72. 12.
eu)lo/gw| profa/sei: cf. 8. 19 profa/sei braxei/a| kai\ eu)prepei=.

e)/ti ma=llon fu/sei cuggenei=s : i.e. as
Dorians and inhabitants of the same island. For fi/lous, the logical antithesis of polemi/ous, is substituted cuggenei=s. Sameness of blood was the ground of natural friendship between Syracuse and Camarina, difference of blood the cause of natural hostility between Athens and Camarina.
a)mu/nein de/: (di/kaion understood) but (it is right) to lend aid (sc. toi=s fu/sei cuggene/si).

mh\ fobei=sqai th
 paraskeuh
 au)tw=n: cf. 76. 2.—h)
 h(mei=s custw=men: cf. 21. 4, 33. 26, 37. 15.— 13. o(/per ou(=toi speu/dousi: cf. 10. 14.— 14. ta)nanti/a: adv. as 3. 67. 17; 4. 86. 6; 7. 87. 5.—diastw=men: cf. 4. 61. 6. For the paronomasia, see on 72. 12.— pro\s h(ma=s mo/nous: cf. 65 ff. The allied forces mentioned in 65. § 1 and 67. § 2 are ignored by the orator. For such cases of inexactness in speeches, see App. on 12. 4. Note pro/s, for the usual e)pi/ (which Cobet would substitute here), as with e)pie/nai (31. 43; 1. 86. 20; 2. 65. 46; 4. 92. 39).
1. a(qro/ous ge o)/ntas: sc. h(ma=s, about equiv. to h)/n h(mei=s custw=men pa/ntes (79. 12).

i)e/nai de\ e)s th\n cummaxi/an proqumo/teron: (sc. u(ma=s) enter into the alliance more heartily; here, as Jowett says, “in the sense, not of joining a new alliance, but of taking a more energetic part in an old one,” as opposed to mh\ malakw=s w(/sper nu=n cummaxei=n 78. 21. St.'s rendering of e)s th\n cummaxi/an, ad praestandum auxilium sociale, gets the same general sense, though in a different way. The meaning cannot be, of course, the ordinary one of entering into a (new) alliance (as in 5. 30. 29), for an alliance already existed (cf. 75. § 3) and the Athenian ambassadors had come to renew this (82. 1). See App.
oi(/: sc. *peloponnh/sioi implied in the antecedent clause. Cf. 94. 3 *me/gara ou(/s.

ta\ pole/mia : as to matters of war. Cf. 1. 18. 32; 4. 126. 7.—e)kei/nhn th\n promhqi/an: that prudent course, referring to the neutrality which the orator characterizes 79. 1 by deili/a| to\ di/kaion pro/s te h(ma=s kai\ pro\s tou\s e)pio/ntas. As to the form promhqi/an, it seems better to follow that of the tragic poets, when the Mss. vary (between -qi/a and -qeia).
dokei=n tw|: Duker's correction for dokei=n tw=| of the Mss.; dependent on ei)ko/s.

h(mi=n me\n i)/shn ei)=nai, u(mi=n de\ a)sfalh= :
from what follows it is clear that the stress is to be laid upon the first clause —to be equitable to us, as safe for you —so that we have here the same relation of the two clauses as with te . . . kai/ 1. 8. 1; 2. 39. 24; 3. 38. 27; 4. 81. 3; with kai\ . . . kai/ 89. 24; 3. 58. 10; with ou)/te . . . ou)/te 3. 46. 1.

to\ mhdete/rois dh\...bohqei=n : to aid neither forsooth on the ground of being allies of both, explan. appos. to e)kei/nhn th\n promhqi/an. dh/ is ironical as in 13; kai/ placed in the dependent clause though really emphasizing the leading one. Cf. 18. 3.
ou) ga\r e)/rgw| i)/son w(/sper tw=| dikaiw/mati/ e)stin: for it is not in fact equitable as in the article of the law (i.e. in the abstract). Cf. 79. 8.

di) u(ma=s mh\ cummaxh/santas: on account of your not giving aid. For the const., see App. on 4. 63. 1, and Gildersleeve, Amer. J. of Phil. XIII, 258 f.—o( paqw/n: = o( *surako/sios, as o( kratw=n = o( *)aqhnai=os (Schol.). Both collectives are taken up below by plurals (toi=s me/n, tou\s de/).
h)mu/nate, e)kwlu/sate: the impending results being vividly represented as if they had already occurred, the assumed cases are treated as if facts. Cf. pf. kekwlu=sqai 2. 8. 17.

swqh=nai : inf. of purpose. See on 8. 17. —ou)k e)kwlu/sate kakou\s gene/sqai: remark here and below (13) kai\ tou\s *)aqhnai/ous . . . a(martei=n the sarcasm, the sense being that if the Athenians are really their friends, it is the duty of the Camarinaeans to prevent the former from being wicked (i.e. from enslaving all Sicily). For dh/, see on 6 and 10. 21.

th
 koinh
 w)feli/an: th
 e)leuqeri/an tw=n *sikeliwtw=n Schol. Cf. koino\s o( ki/ndunos 34. 4.

, § 3-5. We beg your support and we declare most emphatically that if you do not join us you will be betraying Dorian kinsmen who are threatened by Ionians. And if the Athenians win, you will be the prize of victory which they will take; but if we win, you will none the less be punished for the dangers occasioned to us. Choose then either slavery that is for the moment without risk, or. winning with us, escape from shameful serfdom to the Athenians and enmity from us.

cunelo/ntes te le/gomen: in résumé, as freq. in Thuc. Cf. 37. 17 and see on 3. 40. 16.—oi( *surako/sioi:
for similar cases of appos. to the subj. contained in the verb, with a view to increase of effect, see Kr. Spr. 50, 7, 14.
ou)de\n e)/rgon ei)=nai: ou) xalepo\n ei)=nai Schol. Cf. Hdt. 1. 17. 12; 3. 112. 13; and Caes. B. G. 2. 17 neque esse quicquam negoti.
deo/meqa: sc. u(mw=n, as 3. 59. 9 ai)tou/meqa u(ma=s.

marturo/meqa : we solemnly declare. For const. with o(/ti, cf. 29. § 2 e)pemartu/reto . . . o(/ti swfrone/steron ei)/h kte(. Cl. rightly made all that follows down to u(fe/cete (23) dependent on marturo/meqa o(/ti, punctuating with a colon only after *dwriw=n (18), as well as after lh/yontai (21). For this view speaks the fact that ei) mh\ pei/somen must be supplied in thought also in the clauses of § 4.
ei) mh\ pei/somen: placed for emphasis before o(/ti. Cf. 86. 3, and the position of pri/n ti kai\ h(mw=n a)kou=sai 76. 3.

e)pibouleuo/meqa me\n...prodido/meqa de/ : the former is already occurring, while the latter is still in the future, but the orator vividly expresses the latter also in the present. See on 34. 25. In the thought, the first clause is subord. to the second. See on 9. 11.—u(po\ *)iw/nwn ai)ei\ polemi/wn: cf. 82. 4.

prodido/meqa de/: gets by its relation (anaphora) to e)pibouleuo/meqa me/n (i.e. by those from whom it was to be expected), as well as by the interlocked order of the words u(po\ u(mw=n *dwrih=s *dwriw=n, the chief odium of the complaint.
tai=s me\n u(mete/rais gnw/mais: by your decisions.

timhqh/sontai: the fut. pass. form is found in Dem. 19. 223 and freq. in Attic inscriptions. See Meisterhans, Gr. d. att. Inschriften,^{3} p. 193, and Kühn. 1, 2, 112. In 2. 87. 35 the Mss. have the more usual fut. mid. timh/sontai.
a)=qlon : (neut.) prize of victory, pred. to ou)k a)/llon tina/.
th=s ai)ti/as tw=n kindu/nwn : for causing the dangers which we have been subjected to.—oi( au)toi/: pred., as 2. 40. 12; 3. 47. 18; 4. 17. 3.

h)/dh: now, at the decisive moment.—th
 au)ti/ka a)kindu/nws doulei/an: for the adv. a)kindu/nws in attrib. position modifying the verbal noun, cf. th
 a)/ntikrus e)leuqeri/an 8. 64. 23; dia\ th
 . . . ou)ke/ti e)panagwgh/n 7. 34. 26.

h)\ ka)/n : when two clauses are disjunctively connected, the second is freq. introduced, as here, by h)\ kai/ (cf. 85. 14, 86. 22; 2. 13. 7; Hom. d 80). a)/n gives to
both infs., labei=n and diafugei=n, hypothetical character after perigeno/menoi (= ei) perige/noisqe). a)/n below (26) belongs only to genome/nhn.

tou/sde te mh\ ai)sxrw=s despo/tas labei=n : the neg. modifies both adv. and verb: not shamefully to get these as masters.— th\n pro\s h(ma=s e)/xqran: hostility with us, where a)f' h(mw=n was to be expected. Cf. 1. 42. 8 e)/xqran . . . pro\s *korinqi/ous.
mh\ a)\n braxei=an genome/nhn : =h(\ ou)k a)\n braxei=a ge/noito (i.e. ei) mh\ meq' h(mw=n stai/hte). mh/ is due to the influence of the inf. Kr. Spr. 67, 8, 3.

div2.head: Speech of Euphemus, Athenian ambassador (82-87)
div2.p: After Hermocrates, the Athenian ambassador Euphemus comes forward.

ei)=pen: aor., as always in Thuc. in referring back to a completed speech. See on 2. 71. 6.—o( d' *eu)/fhmos: already mentioned 75. 20, hence the art. Nothing further is known of his personality. In the following speech the idea of the interest of his own state is dominant.

It is a fact that, against the constant menace of the superior strength of the Lacedaemonians, we have built a bulwark by bringing under our rule those Hellenic cities which sided with the Persians against us.

a)fiko/meqa: aor. instead of pf. of an event that has just occurred. Cf. 1. 73. 2; 2. 60. 3.— e)pi\ th=s pro/teron ou)/shs cummaxi/as a)nanew/sei: although the Athenian alliance made with Camarina at the time of the command of Laches (75. § 3) was still formally in effect (79. 2, 88. 12), it could be treated as belonging to the past. The preceding gen. supplies the place of the art. with a)nanew/sei, as 1. 1. 11, 3. 1, 11. 2, etc.
kaqayame/nou: sc. h(mw=n. Cf. 16. 2.—peri\ th=s a)rxh=s: because the attacks of Hermocrates were directed against the establishment of this supremacy (76. § 3).
to\ me\n ou)=n me/giston martu/rion: sc. w(s ei)ko/tws a)/rxomen, i.e. that race hostility forces us to defensive precautions. Cf. 1. 73. 25 tekmh/rion me/giston au)to\s e)poi/hse.
ai)ei/ pote pole/mioi : inveterate enemies. For the expression, see on 2. 102. 10; for the fact, cf. 80. § 3.

e)/xei de\ kai\ ou(/tws: and it is even so, i.e. as Hermocrates has asserted.— h(mei=s ga\r...u(pakouso/meqa : on the
text, see App.

o(/tw| tro/pw| h(/kista au)tw=n u(pakouso/meqa: cf. 33. 12; for the more usual o(/pws with fut. See on 1. 107. 18. Thuc. construes u(pakou/ein, be subject to, generally with gen. (87. 5; 2. 62. 22; 3. 50. 13; 4. 56. 16; 5. 84. 11; 8. 5. 19), sometimes with dat. (69. 26; 2. 61. 3; 4. 63. 12).
kai/: = atque, and so.
meta\ ta\ *mhdika/: belongs not so much with the ptc. as with a)phlla/ghmen.

ou)de\n prosh=kon ma=llo/n ti : not in any way more fitting. The accus. abs., as 84. 1; 3. 40. 21; 4. 95. 4. GMT. 851; Kr. Spr. 56, 9, 5. For ma=llo/n ti, cf. 1. 49. 9.— 10. e)pita/ssein: give orders. See on 1. 140. 18.

au)toi\ de\...h(gemo/nes katasta/ntes oi)kou=men : in sharp contrast with th=s me\n *lakedaimoni/wn a)rxh=s kai\ h(gemoni/as a)phlla/ghmen. Chief stress is on h(gemo/nes katasta/ntes (cf. 1. 75. § 2, 95. § 1 ff.), not on the finite verb, so that katasta/ntes oi)kou=men is practically a fuller expression for kaqe/stamen. In Thuc. oi)kei=n is sometimes so used that the sense inhabit, dwell in, is weakened into find one's self, be so situated, i.e. a more concrete e)sme/n. In this sense oi)kei=n is modified by an adv. in 18. 40, 92. 26; 1. 124. 19; here by a ptc. The pres. is quite in place here, rather than impf. or aor., otherwise we should miss in the orator's exposition a transition to present conditions. So Steup explains, with a number of the best editors. Cl. and others take offense at oi)kou=men and would either add a)sfalw=s or substitute i)sxu/omen or h)rkou=men (Cl.), or a)/rxomen (v. H.), or oi)keiou/meqa sc. au)tou/s (St.).
nomi/santes: as below katastreya/menoi (14), explanatory of au)toi\ tw=n . . . o)/ntwn h(gemo/nes katasta/ntes.

h(=| a)munou/meqa : cf. o(/tw| tro/pw| u(pakouso/meqa (7).—e)s to\ a)kribe\s ei)pei=n: inf. abs., as to\ cu/mpan ei)pei=n 1. 138. 18; 7. 49. 18. GMT. 777. For e)s to\ a)kribe/s = a)kribw=s, cf. e)s to\ fanero/n 1. 6. 17, 23. 26; e)s ta\ prw=ta 3. 39. 9, 56. 22. Kr.'s emendation w(s for e)s (cf. Dio C. 46. 35. 2; 51. 22. 6), approved by St., etc., is unnecessary, and not supported by the Schol. a)nti\ tou= w(s a)lhqw=s ei)pei=n, since w(s a)lhqw=s is adv., rendering e)s to\ a)kribe/s.
dedoulw=sqai : (mid.) on the matter, cf. 76. § 2 f.

e)pi\ th\n mhtro/polin e)f' h(ma=s: the prep. is repeated, as e)pi\ th\n mhtro/polin is appos. put first for emphasis. Cf. 3. 53.
3, and see Herbst, Ueber Cobet, p. 31.— 18. a)posta/ntes: sc. tou= *mh/dou.
w(/sper h(mei=s : sc. ta\ oi(kei=a fqei=rai e)tolmh/samen.
e)klipo/ntes th\n po/lin : as 1. 18. 19, 91. 21. Cf. 1. 74. 13 e)klipo/ntes th\n po/lin kai\ ta\ oi)kei=a diafqei/rantes.

doulei/an de\ au)toi/ te e)bou/lonto kai\ h(mi=n to\ au)to\ e)penegkei=n : and both themselves wished slavery and to bring the same upon us. For subst. as obj. of e)bou/lonto, cf. th
 a)po/basin au)to
 e)s th
 nh=son dianoei=sqai 4. 29. 5, and th
 au)th
 du/natai dou/lwsin 1. 141. 5. See App.—to\ au)to/: referring to doulei/an, as 3. 104. 43 o(/ after i(ppodromi/as. Cf. 72. 19.

We rule both because we are worthy of it and for the sake of security against the Peloponnesians, and we make, in order to justify our supremacy, no fine speeches about our conduct in the Persian wars. In Sicily, too, we appear in the interest of our security, and our sole object is together with our friends so to order things that we shall be freed of all danger.

a)nq) w(=n a)/cioi/ te o)/ntes a(/ma a)/rxomen...o)rego/menoi : Athenian rule (a)/rxomen) is based on the one hand upon worth (a)/cioi/ te o)/ntes a(/ma), on the other, upon the desire for strength against the Peloponnesians (a(/ma de\ kte(.). Again the claim of worth (a)/cioi o)/ntes) is based on two grounds (o(/ti te . . . kai\ dio/ti . . . e)/blapton).—a)/cioi o)/ntes a)/rxomen: cf. 1. 75. § 1.—nautiko\n plei=sto/n te kai\ proqumi/an...e)s tou\s *(/ellhnas : cf. 1. 74. § 1, 2. te is placed after nautiko\n plei=ston as if it were a single word.
a)profa/siston: without pretexts or excuses, answering to the adv. in 72. 25.

kai\ tw=| *mh/dw| e(toi/mws tou=to drw=ntes: even for the Mede doing this willingly. The reproach is sharpened by kai/ as well as by e(toi/mws. For tou=to drw=ntes, standing for nautiko\n parexo/menoi, see on 1. 5. 11. For the dat. with drw=ntes, cf. Plato, Legg. 713 D oi(=on drw=men toi=s poimni/ois. Kr. Spr. 46, 12, 3.

ou) kalliepou/meqa kte(.: we do not say in fine phrases that etc. For a similar frank admission of the policy of expediency, cf. 5. 89.—to\n ba/rbaron mo/noi kaqelo/ntes: such a claim would have been correct at most for Marathon (cf. 1. 73. § 4). kaqelo/ntes, having overthrown, as 1. 77. 20; 3. 13. 32; 4. 85. 7.
ei)ko/tws a)/rxomen: cf. 82. 3.— e)p) e)leuqeri/a|...kinduneu/santes : referring to 76. § 4.

tw=nde: i.e. tw=n te
*)iw/nwn kai\ tw=n nhsiwtw=n.
pa=si de\ a)nepi/fqonon...e)kpori/zesqai : no one however is to be blamed for providing for his own safety, as we have done by the subjugation of the Ionians and islanders. Cf. 1. 75. § 5.

kai\ nu=n: as 86. 4, 14; 89. 10.— 11. o(rw=men kai\ u(mi=n tau)ta\ cumfe/ronta: Cl. rightly follows Haacke in adopting tau)ta/ of E for tau=ta of the other Mss. tau=ta(to\ h(ma=s parei=nai) is hardly satisfactory, because the presence of the Athenians in Sicily could not yet be represented as of itself advantageous to the Camarinaeans; that depended entirely on the motive of their coming. But the assertion of a mutual interest in hindering Syracusan supremacy over all Sicily was from the standpoint of the Athenians quite appropriate.

a)pofai/nomen de/: (sc. tou=to) and this we prove to you.—e)c w(=n oi(/de te diaba/llousi kte(.: referring to the objects of the Athenians in their Sicilian enterprise, which were discredited by the Syracusans and suspected in the highest degree by the Camarinaeans (cf. 88. § 1), but if correctly conceived, acc. to the orator, must lead the Camarinaeans to recognize that their interests were the same as those of the Athenians.

oi(/de diaba/llousi: cf. 76. § 2; 77. § 1, 2.—e)pi\ to\ foberw/teron: with exaggerated fear. Cf. e)pi\ to\ foberw/teron a)gge/llesqai Dion. H. Arch. 1. 57; Dio C. 47. 24. 1. See on e)pi\ to\ plei=on 34. 43.
lo/gou h(donh=| : cf. h(donh=| lo/gwn 3. 40. 7; a)koh=s h(donh=| 3. 38. 31.
to\ parauti/ka terpome/nous : of the seductive effect of speech, as 2. 41. 14 to\ au)ti/ka te/rpein of poetry.—th=| d' e)gxeirh/sei: (temporal) when it comes to action.
ga/r: refers to a)pofai/nomen (11). —ei)rh/kamen: cf. 82. § 2.

kai\ ta\ e)nqa/de...katasthso/menoi : (sc. le/gomen) and (we say) that we are come for the same reason, with our friends to place matters here on a safe footing, i.e. to secure the Siceliotes against the lust for rule on the part of the Syracusans. Cl. put a semicolon after pra/ssontas and explained the ga/r clause as taking up a)pofai/nomen (“now then, as we have often said . . . , so we declare”). But it seems hardly to be doubted that Thuc., if he had come to revise his work, would have inserted le/gomen or fame/n, and therefore it is unnecessary, with St., to change h(/kein to h(/komen.

dia\ to\ au)to/ : i.e. dia\ de/os, not anxious fear,
but well-grounded apprehension.— meta\ tw=n fi/lwn: the real kernel of the argument: “we wish only common action.”
kai\ ou) doulwso/menoi: sc. ta\ e)nqa/de.
mh\ paqei=n tou=to : sc. u(po\ *surakosi/wn. tou=to, i.e. to\ doulwqh=nai.
We have great interest in the maintenance of your independence and power and in setting up again a strong Leontini. At home, on the contrary, it is to our advantage that our allies be weak.
u(pola/bh|mhdei/s: order as in 3. 13. 22; 4. 95. 3.—ou)de\n prosh=kon: see on 82. 9.

sw|zome/nwn u(mw=n kai\ dia\ to\...a)nte/xein : gen. abs. and prep. clause correlated to give the grounds for o(/ti . . . hsson a)\n . . . blaptoi/meqa. mh/ belongs only to a)sqenei=s o)/ntas, not to a)nte/xein.
h(=sson : the less, minus, belongs to both ptc. and finite verb.

kai\ e)n tou/tw| prosh/kete h)/dh h(mi=n ta\ me/gista: opp. to ou)de\n prosh=kon (1), and in this you become at once our chief concern. For ta\ me/gista, cf. ta\ deu/tera 78. 21; ta\ kra/tista 1. 19. 8. There is a play on the double sense of prosh=kon and prosh/kete, the orator assuming by the pers. const. a sort of relationship where there is no blood-kinship.— 5. dio/per: for this very reason, referring to h(=sson a)\n . . . blaptoi/meqa.
eu)/logon : (sc. e)stin) answer to 76. 7 ff.—mh\ u(phko/ous: pred. (= w(/ste mh\ u(phko/ous ei)=nai), as also w(s dunatwta/tous.
tou\s cuggenei=s : acc. by attraction to tou\s *leonti/nous, not connected with katoiki/zein.
toi=sde : i.e. toi=s *surakosi/ois.
luphroi\ w)=si : for expression and thought, cf. 18. 5.
ta\ me\n e)kei=: as to matters there. Cf. ta\ de\ e)nqa/de below (12).
kai\ au)toi/: even ourselves, i.e. alone. Cf. 37. 3.— o( *xalkideu/s: see on 78. 1.
fhsi: direct reference to 76. § 2.

cu/mforos (sc. e)stin) . . . w)\n kai\...fe/rwn : (pers. const.) for the structure of the sent., cf. 4. 44. 3 h)=san . . . oi( i(pph=s w)fe/limoi cummaxo/menoi, and see App. on 4. 63. 2.—a)para/skeuos w)\n kai\
xrh/mata mo/non fe/rwn: cf. 1. 99. 11 xrh/mata e)ta/canto a)nti\ tw=n new=n to\ i(knou/menon a)na/lwma fe/rein. In fact they were, however, in case of need, to furnish troops also (cf. 2. 9. § 5; 7. 57. § 4).— 12. kai\ *leonti=noi kte(.: sc. cu/mforoi h(mi=n ei)si.
o(/ti ma/lista au)tonomou/menoi : opp. to u(phko/ous (6).

Whoever has a supremacy to maintain must look solely to selfinterest, and it is to our advantage to have our Sicilian friends so powerful that our enemies can undertake nothing against us. Mistrust of us is unwarranted; for, as at home relations with our allies have been so shaped as in each case was most advantageous for us, so in Sicily we have been influenced solely by self-interest, that is, by fear of the designs of the Syracusans.— 1. a)ndri\ de\ kte(.: frank admission of the same kind of policy as guided the Athenians against the Melians 5. 85113. Cf. esp. 5. 89.—a)ndri\ tura/nnw|: for generic and specific term united, as often, see on 1. 115. 9.—po/lei a)rxh\n e)xou/sh|: as 2. 65. 45. For the connection with a)ndri\ tura/nnw|, cf. turanni/da e)/xete th\n a)rxh/n 3. 37. 9 (and 2. 63. 8). —a)/logon: inconsistent, i.e. contrary to a well-considered line of action, selfinterest being recognized as the test (lo/gos) in political life.
cumfe/ron: without e)sti/, as in 3. 44. 5. So often a)/cion, deino/n, di/kaion.
oi)kei=on : of family or tribal relationship. In politics even kinship is of value only as it contributes to self-interest.—pro\s e(/kasta: in every case.
meta\ kairou=: as 8. 27. 12, more significant than e)n kairw=|: “in accord with opportunity,” i.e. according to circumstances.—tou=to: looks forward, as in 55. 3. See on 4. 114. 19.

tou\s e)kei= cumma/xous: this reading of C is adopted by Steup (with Bk., Kr., Hude, Oxford text, etc.), on account of the following appositives (*xi/ous me\n kte(.). Pp., St., Cl., Bm., and M. keep the reading of all the other Mss. toi=s cumma/xois. Thuc. has e)chgei=sqai with accus. 1. 71. 27, e)chgei=sqai with dat. 3. 55. 14.—w(s e(/kastoi xrh/simoi: as they were severally useful to us.

e)chgou/meqa: the manner of the leadership is defined more exactly in what follows, (1) by adj. (au)tono/mous), (2) by adv. (biaio/teron), (3) by ptc. (e)leuqe/rws cummaxou=ntas).—*mhqumnai/ous: who alone of the Lesbians retained
their autonomy after 427 B.C. Cf. 3. 50. § 1, 2.—new=n parokwxh=|: as xrhma/twn fora=| (8), dat. of attendant circumstance. See on 12. 6. parokwxh=| for paroxh=| of the Mss., acc. to analogy of a)nokwxh/ and diokwxh/ (3. 87. 3) and the express testimony of Photius (s.v.). See St., Qu. Gr.^{2} p. 44. Cf. 7.57. § 4. *xi/oi fo/rou ou)x u(potelei=s o)/ntes, nau=s de\ pare/xontes au)to/nomoi...*mhqumnai=oi nausi\ kai\ ou) fo/rw| u(ph/kooi.
xrhma/twn biaio/teron fora=| : referring to the fo/rou u(potelei=s cu/mmaxoi of 1. 19. 1, 80. 14; 7. 57. 17.
nhsiw/tas...*pelopo/nnhson : the reference is to the Coreyraeans, Cephallenians, and Zacynthians. Cf. 7. 57. § 7. The Argives are disregarded.
pro/s: secundum. Seeon 63. 3.

o(\ le/gomen: cf. 83. § 4.—e)s *surakosi/ous: with a view to fear of the Syracusans (pro\s to/ belonging to de/os as well as to lusitelou=n). Cf. 3. 14. 1 ta\s tw=n *(ellh/nwn e)s u(ma=s e)lpi/das, and 3. 37. 3 dia\ to\ kaq) h(me/ran a)dee\s kai\ a)nepibou/leuton pro\s a)llh/lous kai\ e)s tou\s cumma/xous to\ au)to\ e)/xete.
kaqi/stasqai : sc. h(ma=s.

a)rxh=s ga\r...pro\s u(ma=s ei)=en : proof that Athenian fear of the Syracusans is well grounded.—u(mw=n: including all the Siceliotes except the Syracusans, as u(ma=s in 14 and 18; so also custh=te in 16.—e)pi\ tw=| h(mete/rw| u(po/ptw|: on the ground of suspicion of us. For poss. pron. as obj. gen., cf. 1. 33. 18, and see G. 999; H. 694; Kühn. 454, N. 11.

custh/santes u(ma=s: having united you. Cf. the intr. custh=nai below (16).—bi/a| h)\ kai\ kat' e)rhmi/an: (sc. tw=n kwluso/ntwn) by force or in absence (of those who will hinder), referring to the Syracusans and to be taken with au)toi\ a)/rcai th=s *sikeli/as. For kat' e)rhmi/an, “because they have a free field,” cf. Dem. 3. 27. The above is Cl.'s explanation, approved by St. Some editors refer the clause to the Camarinaeans, with the Schol. kai\ bou/lontai . . . u(f' au(toi=s poih/sasqai th\n *sikeli/an, h)/toi bi/a| krath/santes u(mw=n, h)\ mo/nous a)polabo/ntes, h(mw=n a)pra/ktwn a)pelqo/ntwn. Steup refers it, with Haacke, to a)pra/ktwn h(mw=n a)pelqo/ntwn (removing the comma after e)rhmi/an), suggesting that in case of a union of all Siceliotes the withdrawal of the Athenians might have been due to defeat or merely to lack of allies (cf. 86. 22 h)\ a)/prakton a)pelqei=n h)\ kai\ sfalei=san).
a)na/gkh de/: to\ a)/rcai *surakosi/ous th=s o(/lhs *sikeli/as Schol.

custh=te pro\s au)tou/s: as 1. 1. 6, 15. 10.—
17. e)s e(\n custa=sa: i.e. by the union of the Syracusans with all of the Siceliotes.—eu)metaxei/ristos: easy to handle. Cf. Xen. Anab. 2. 6. 20, and the apparent imitation of our passage in Xen. Hell. 5. 2. 15 ei) tosau/th du/namis prosgenh/setai th=| te *)aqhnai/wn kai\ *qhbai/wn i)sxu/i, o(ra=te o(/pws mh\ ou)ke/ti eu)metaxei/rista e)/stai e)kei=na u(mi=n. Cf. dusmetaxei/ristos Hdt. 7. 236. 12.—ou)/q) oi(/d) a)sqenei=s a)\n...pro\s u(ma=s ei)=en : litotes. oi(/de refers to the Syracusans.

On your former summons you yourselves held before us the danger from the Syracusans threatening us as well as you; and will you now give no credence to assurances from us that agree with your former declarations? Though we are here with an army superior to the Syracusan forces, we can never win in this contest without your help, and if we wished to make conquests here, we could not maintain them on account of the distance. We Athenians and you Siceliotes depend upon one another; the danger is closer to you, and if you reject our aid, you will repent when it is too late.
au)to\ to\ e)/rgon: the fact itself.—to\ pro/teron: in 427 B.C., when Camarina stood with the Leontines and the rest of the Chalcidian cities against Syracuse (3. 86. § 2 ff.).

e)phga/gesqe: as in 85. § 3, the Camarinaeans appear throughout c. 86 as representatives of all the Siceliotes except the Syracusans. So u(mw=n also 87. 8.—ou)k a)/llon tina\ prosei/ontes fo/bon h)/: shaking before us no other weapon of alarm than. The metaphor seems to be derived from the brandishing of swords or spears before enemies to frighten them (cf. 4. 126. 22 h( e)pana/seisis tw=n o(/plwn), and is here perhaps a reminiscence of Homer's (*d 167) au)to\s e)pissei/h|sin e)remnh\n ai)gi/da pa=sin. Cf. 5. 17. 7 paraskeuh\ proepanesei/sqh a)po\ tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn, and Eur. H. F. 1209 ti/ moi prosei/wn xei=ra shmai/neis fo/non;
o(/ti kai\ au)toi\ kinduneu/somen : placed after the cond., as 80. 17.
kai\ nu=n: see on 83. 10.—kai\ h(ma=s: such prolepsis is freq. in rel. sents. The underlying thought is tw=| lo/gw| w(=|per h(ma=s pei/qein h)ciou=te, kai\ u(ma=s pei/qesqai di/kaion.

h)ciou=te pei/qein : emphatically connected also 87.4.—duna/mei mei/zoni pro\s th\n tw=nde i)sxu/n: with a force disproportioned to the strength of Syracuse. See on 31. 43. Kr. and Jowett explain, “greater than before.”— 6. u(popteu/esqai: (pass.) the context requires h(ma=s to be understood here, though above with a)pistei=n sc. u(ma=s. Steup, contending that all three infs.
must have the same subj. (u(ma=s), takes u(popteu/esqai as middle; but this is without parallel.
h(mei=s me/n ge: we certainly. For the combination, see on 1. 40. 15.— e)mmei=nai: sc. e)n th=| *sikeli/a|, to maintain ourselves in Sicily.

mh\ meq' u(mw=n: = a)/neu u(mw=n. See on mh\ meta\ no/mwn 3. 62. 16. Kr. Spr. 67, 9 and 10, 4. See St., Symb. Phil. Bonn. p. 387.—ei)/ te kai\ geno/menoi kakoi\ katergasai/meqa: sc. th\n *sikeli/an, mocking answer to the insinuations of Hermoerates, 80. 10. katerga/sasqai and katasxei=n in the same connection as in 11. 1.

a)pori/a| fulakh=s...h)peirwti/dwn : Schol. ou) duna/menoi fula/ttein po/leis mega/las kai\ paraskeuh\n h)peirwtikh\n pareskeuas me/nas, tou=t' e)sti i(ppeu=si kai\ pezw=| i)sxuou/sas, au)toi\ nautikoi\ o)/ntes. Cf. 1. 35. 21 nautikh=s kai\ ou)k h)peirw/tidos th=s cummaxi/as didome/nhs.

oi(/de de\...e)poikou=ntes u(mi=n : and these not with a camp, but in hostile proximity to you with a city greater than our present force. For a similar comparison of an attack menaced by a near-by city with one from a camp, cf. 37. § 2.—po/lei: with e)poikou=ntes u(mi=n. For this dat., cf. 3. 93. 7 fobou/menoi mh\ sfi/si mega/lh| i)sxu/i paroikw=sin.

th=s h(mete/ras parousi/as : abstract for concrete (h(mw=n tw=n paro/ntwn). Cf. 7. 24. 14 h( e)pagwgh\ tw=n e)pithdei/wn = ta\ e)pago/mena e)pith/deia. For Steup's view of the passage, which he considers corrupt, see App.
e)poikou=ntes u(mi=n: cf. 7. 27. 10 u(/steron de\ frourai=s a)po\ tw=n po/lewn kata\ diadoxh\n xro/nou e)piou/sais th=| xw/ra| e)pw|kei=to.
e)pibouleu/ousi kai\...ou)k a)nia=sin : cf. 18. 14 toi=s me\n e)pibouleu/ein, tou\s de\ mh\ a)nie/nai.

o(/tan kairo\n la/bwsin e(ka/stou : whenever they have got an opportunity against each of you. Some editors consider e(ka/stou neut., “each attack” (cf. e)/rgou kairw=| 2. 40. 2); but the mase. agrees better with the foll. example from the Leontines. For the sing., cf. o( *xalkideu/s 84. 9.— 13. (e)/deican de\...kai\ ta\ e)s *leonti/nous ): they have given both other examples already and especially that of the Leontines. a)/lla cogn. acc. (= e)/deican dei/gmata a)/lla). For h)/dh, see on 7. 77. 2. With ta\ e)s *leonti/nous, cf. ta\ e)s *boiwtou/s 5. 39. 16. Most editors make this remark parenthetical and punctuate the whole sent. as in this text; for Steup's variant arrangement, see App.

kai\ nu=n tolmw=sin: and now they make bold, characterizing the representations of the Syracusans based, acc. to the Athenians, on a false charge, the falsity of which is emphasized esp. by w(s a)naisqh/tous (“as if you were
foolish enough to believe them”).— e)pi\ tou\s tau=ta kwlu/ontas: against those who prevented these things, i.e. what the Syracusans undertook against the Leontines.

a)ne/xontas...mh\ u(p) au)tou\s ei)=nai : hindered Sicily up to this time from being under them. a)ne/xein (abs.), hinder, hence mh/ with inf. Cf. Bekker, Anecd. Gr. p. 400, where this passage and one from Aristophanes are cited in proof that le/getai a)ne/xein kai\ to\ kwlu/ein. GMT. 815, 1; Kr. Spr. 67, 12, 3.
u(p' au)tou\s ei)=nai: see on 1. 110. 4; and Herbst, Ueber Cobet, p. 27 ff. Van H. writes u(p' au)toi=s.
polu/: modifying a)lhqeste/ran, but by its position before the prep. emphasizing the antithesis. Cf. polu\ de\ e)n ple/oni ai)ti/a| 1. 35. 10.
a)ntiparakalou=men : one of Thuc.'s forty-one a(/pac ei)rhme/na compounds with a)nti-. See App. on 4. 80. 4.
th\n u(pa/rxousan a)p' a)llh/lwn a)mfote/rois: sc. swthri/an.
prodido/nai : strong expression for “give up,” here = “throw away.”
nomi/sai te: Hude writes de/ with Cod. M, on the ground that this clause must be adversative to the preceding, but unnecessarily.
dia\ to\ plh=qos: on account of their numerical superiority. See on 2. 11. 12.— 21. parasxh/sein: impers. of an opportunity presenting itself. See on 1. 120. 18.
tw=| u(po/ptw|: causal dat. Cf. tw=| u(mete/rw| u(po/ptw| 85. 13.
a)/prakton a)pelqei=n : cf. 85. 14 a)pra/ktwn h(mw=n a)pelqo/ntwn.
h)\ kai/ : see on 80. 24.
e)/ti boulh/sesqe: you will yet wish, apod. of monitory cond. GMT. 447.

ou)de\n e)/ti peranei=: will no longer accomplish anything, i.e. help will do no good after the Syracusans have subjugated all Sicily. In the conclusion of this chapter we have the rhetorical answer to Hermocrates' words in 78. § 3 kai\ ei) gnw/mh| a(ma/rtoi, toi=s au(tou= kakoi=s o)lofurqei\s ta/x' a)\n i)/sws kai\ toi=s e)moi=s a)gaqoi=s pote boulhqei/h au)=qis fqonh=sai.

From our policy, which for the maintenance of our supremacy must take precautions on all sides, you have nothing to fear; do not try, therefore, to direct it along other courses. Use rather our offered aid for your security, and oppose resolutely, both you and the rest, the Syracusan lust for
rule.
tai=s tw=nde diabolai=s: cf. 83. 12 e)c w(=n oi(/de diaba/llousi.

mh/te oi( a)/lloi : here is definitely expressed what elsewhere in the admonitions to the Camarinaeans was implied. See below on 8 and on 85. 13 and 86. 2.—pa=san th\n a)lh/qeian: a stock phrase in Greek from Homer down, as in English.— 3. u(popteuo/meqa: cf. 83. 13; 85. 14; 86. 6, 22.—e)n kefalai/ois: in the chief points. Cf. 6. 14; 1. 36. 14; 4. 50. 8.
a)ciw/somen pei/qein: see on 86. 5.
fame\n ga/r: we say, namely. See on 33. 7.—a)/rxein me\n kte(.: cf. 82. § 2, 3; 83. § 4.
u(pakou/wmen a)/llou: see on 82. 7.

o(/pws mh\ u(p' au)tw=n blaptw/meqa: cf. 84. 3.—polla\ pra/ssein: as polupragmosu/nh below (12), in a good sense, characterizing the policy of the Athenians at their acme, as described by Pericles in the funeral oration 2. 40, 41; its antithesis a)pragmosu/nh, to\ a)/pragmon in 2. 63. 7, 12. Cf. 18. 39.— 7. polla\ fulasso/meqa: we are on guard at many points. Strictly cogn. accus.

toi=s e)nqa/de u(mw=n a)dikoume/nois: u(mw=n including all the Siceliotes except the Syracusans. For the part. gen. in attrib. position, see on 62. 19. —ou)k a)/klhtoi, paraklhqe/ntes de/: cf. kai\ parakalou/menos kai\ a)/klhtos 1. 118. 23. For emphasis by both negation and affirmation, cf. 76. 19, and see on 2. 98. 10. On the matter, cf. 19. § 1; 3. 86. § 3.

tw=n h(mi=n poioume/nwn: for dat. of agent with pass., see on 3. 64. 15, and C. F. Smith, Trans. Amer. Phil. Assoc. XXV, p. 71.—w(s swfronistai/: as moderators, i.e. schooling us to moderation, as 3. 65. 16; 8. 48. 43. Cf. swfroni/zein 78. 11; 8. 1. 27.
o(\xalepo\nh)/dh : referring to a)potre/pein.

kaq) o(/son de/ ti...to\ au)to\ cumfe/rei : in proportion as anything of our busy activity and character (way of acting) is profitable alike to you (as to us). Cf. 83. 10 f. The specific word and the general (tro/pou) with asingle article, though of different genders., Cf. 1. 102. 21; 3. 61. 5. polupragmosu/nh only here in Thuc. Cf. Ar. Acharn. 733. to\ au)to/ pred. appos. to ti.
Cf. 3. 47. 18; 4. 25. 3.
tou/tw| a)polabo/ntes xrh/sasqe: take this out and use it. Cf. Plato, Rep. 420 C th\n eu)dai/mona(po/lin)pla/ttomen ou)k a)polabo/ntes, o)li/gous e)n au)th=| toiou/tous tina\s qe/ntes, a)ll) o(/lhn.
au)ta/ : i.e. polupragmosu/nh kai\ tro/pos.

e)n panti\ ga\r pa=s xwri/w|: pa=s inserted for the sake of the paronomasia. Cf. a(\ e)n tw=| panti\ xro/nw| o)li/gois dh\ a(/ma pa/nta cune/bh 1. 33. 13; e)pese/rxetai . . . e)k pa/shs gh=s ta\ pa/nta 2. 38. 4; kata\ pa/nta ga\r pa/ntws nikhqe/ntes 7. 87. 23; pa/nta de\ pantaxo/qen au)tou\s e)lu/pei 8. 1. 9.
kai\ w(=| : prep. not repeated, as freq., in the second clause. Cf. 1. 6. 20 f., and see on 4. 46. 1. Kr.'s conjecture ka)n w(=| is unnecessary.
u(pei=nai e)lpi/da: subesse spem. e)lpi/da, hope in the first case (tw=| me/n), anticipation in the second (tw=| de/).
a)ntituxei=n e)pikouri/as a)f' h(mw=n: i.e. to get redress (a)nti-) through our aid, as Haacke explains.

mh\ a)dee\s ei)=nai kinduneu/ein: that it is not without danger to take up the conflict. a)deei=s is the reading of the Mss., which Jowett retains, explaining, “a)deei=s, though in the plural, refers to tw=| de/ preceding.” But all recent editors emend. a)dee/s is Reiske's conjecture, adopted also by St., who brackets kinduneu/ein. Cf. Dem. 16. 22 ou) ga\r e)/gwg' a)dee\s tou=q) u(polamba/nw th=| po/lei. But Steup contends that kinduneu/ein as subj. inf. makes no difficulty. For a)dee/s in the rare pass. sense, cf. 1. 36. 5; Plato, Sympos. 198 A. For kinduneu/ein meaning take up the conflict without esp. emphasis on the danger involved, cf. 1. 74. 15; 3. 5. 11; 4. 91. 10; 5. 9. 6; 7. 48. 30. Cl adopted Kr.'s conjecture a)deei=, making kinduneu/ein depend on mh\ a)deei= ei)=nai (cf. 1. 136. 3; 4. 110. 13; 5. 105. 12), and rendering: “because there is to the aggressor the anticipation that, if we come, he has to fear coming into dangerous conflict with us.” But Steup, with St., wants proof of this pregnant meaning of kinduneu/ein, and doubts that not only he who does not fear, but also he who does not need to fear, can be called a)deh/s.

a)mfo/teroi a)nagka/zontai...sw/|zesqai : a)nagka/zontai is really applicable only to a)/kwn swfronei=n, but the emphatic position of a)mfo/teroi seems to show that the structure of the sent. was intentional, and we may render with Jowett, must both alike submit, the one to learn moderation against his will, the other to receive at our hands a deliverance which costs him nothing. Some, like Kr., think a)nagka/zontai has a milder sense with sw/|zesqai (“are placed in the way to be saved”); Cl., that oi)=o/s te/ e)sti or the like must be supplied.—o( me/n, o( de/: the former = o( e)pibouleu/wn, the latter = o( oi)o/menos a)dikh/sesqai, in chiastic order.
a)/kwn swfronei=n: cf. 79. 9.—a)pragmo/nws: Schol. xwri\s po/nou. Cf. 4. 61. 27.

tau/thn ou)= th
 koinh
...a)sfa/leian mh\ a)pw/shsqe : reject not, then, this common safety now present for you, as well as for the one that asks you. For tw=| deome/nw| referring, as Cl. explains, to the Athenians, cf. 86. 18 deo/menoi th
 u(pa/rxousan a)p' a)llh/lwn a)mfote/rois swthri/an mh\ prodido/nai. Most editorsunderstand tw=| deome/nw|, “any one that asks.” Steup objects that the context here is quite different from that at 86. 18 and opposed to Cl.'s view of tw=| deome/nw|, while koinh/n is opposed to tw=| deome/nw|, representing, collectively, any or all that ask. Assuming that the passage is corrupt, he substitutes e(toi/mhn for koinh/n, explaining e(toi/mhn tw=| te deome/nw| and kai\ u(mi=n nu=n parou=san as parallel modifiers of tau/thn th
 a)sfa/leian, i.e. “this safety ready for all that ask and now at hand for the Camarinaeans.” For position of te, with this view, see on 2. 46. 1.

a)ll) e)cisw/santes toi=s a)/llois kte(.: but putting yourselves on an equality with the rest, along with us, instead of always being on guard against the Syracusans, take a different course and in your turn at last plot against them in like manner, i.e. as they have plotted against you (51. § 2).—e)cisw/santes toi=s a)/llois: i.e. the Leontines, Egestaeans, and Catanaeans (51. § 2). The verb intr., as 5. 71. 17 and Soph. El. 1194 mhtri\ d' ou)de\n e)cisoi=. So Cl. St. explains, “e)cisw/santes, sc. th\n a)sfa/leian tw=| te deome/nw| kai\ u(mi=n: postquam eam utrisque aequalem (communem) reddidistis, i.e. post quam nobis pariter atque vobis tutum praesidium societate nobiscum renovata paravistis.” Taking toi=s a)/llois = toi=s *surakosi/ois, St. brackets the latter words. So Bm. and M., see App.

a)ntepibouleu=sai: to plot in turn against. The compound is coined by Thuc. See App. on 4. 80. 4.—metala/bete: take a different course. See on 18. 18; 1. 120. 16. For const. with dependent inf., cf. 1. 44. 4 mete/gnwsan . . . mh\ poih/sasqai.

The Camarinaeans answered that as allies to both parties in the war it seemed their duty to help neither. The Athenians now sought as much as possible to win the Sicels for themselves and by ambassadors to get help in Carthage and Tyrrhenia. They transferred their naval station from Naxos to Catana and made preparations for an attack upon Syracuse in the spring. Meanwhile Syracusan ambassadors, who had found great zeal for their cause at Corinth, proceeded in company with Corinthian ambassadors to Lacedaemon, and met there Alcibiades, who had come on the invitation of the Lacedaemonians from Cyllene, whither he had betaken himself from Thurii. Alcibiades joined them in persuading the Lacedaemonians to
renew the war with Athens.

toiau=ta de/: see on 19. 1.—e)pepo/nqesan toio/nde: had been thus affected, i.e. already (plpf.), not merely in consequence of the opposing speeches.— 2. toi=s me\n *)aqhnai/ois kte(.: after toio/nde without conj., as freq. in Thuc. See on 1. 89. 2.—kaq) o(/son [ei) ] kte(.: Steup, following Reiske, brackets ei), with nearly all recent editors. The part. is not more in place here with plh\n kaq' o(/son, except in so far as, than it would be at 54. 24, 82. 10. Cl., who retained ei), thought Thuc. could not have meant to say that the Camarinaeans really ascribed to the Athenians intentions of conquest. But in various passages of the speech of Euphemus are intimations of mistrust on the part of the Camarinaeans and the rest of the Siceliotes as to the intentions of the Athenians (cf. 83. 13; 85. 14; 86. 6, 22).
kata\ to\ o(/moron: cf. Tac. Hist. 5. 1 solito inter accolas odio.
tou\s *surakosi/ous...mh\ perige/nwntai : prolepsis, as in 2. 67. 23.

tou\s o)li/gous i(ppe/as e)/pemyan: acc. to 67. § 2 the Camarinaeans had sent 20 horsemen and 50 bowmen, hence Kr. suspects that kai\ toco/tas has dropped out here.—kai\ to\ loipo/n: answering to to/ te prw=ton.
e)/rgw| : in fact, opp. to lo/gw| (10), in word.— w(s a)\n du/nwntai metriw/tata: as moderately as they can. Abresch would insert d).

i(/na mhde\...e)/lasson dokw=si nei=mai : that they may not seem to be less favorable to the Athenians. nei=mai is Valckenaer's excellent emendation for ei)=nai. Cf. mei=zon me/ros ne/montes 3. 3. 5; ple/on nei/mantes 3. 48. 2.
e)pikrate/steroi : elsewhere only in late writers; the adv. e)pikrate/ws occurs several times in the Hiad.
ou(/tw bouleusa/menoi: after these deliberations.
a)mfote/rois ou)=si cumma/xois sfw=n: cf. 80. 6.
eu)/orkon: in accordance with their oath, as 5. 18. 58.
ta\ kaq' e(autou\s e)chrtu/onto: cf. 1. 82. 5 ta\ h(me/tera au)tw=n e)cartu/esqai.
e)n th=| *na/cw| e)stratopedeume/noi : cf. 74. 10.—ta\ pro\s tou\s *sikelou\s kte(.: cf. 48, 62. § 5, 65. § 2.

u(ph/kooi o)/ntes tw=n *surakosi/wn: cf. 34. § 1, 45, 48; 3. 103. § 1.—ou) polloi/: Canter's correction for oi( polloi/, opp. to plh
 o)li/goi (21).—20 meso/geian: the correct form, not-gaian. Cf. 1. 100. 15, 120. 8; 2. 102. 4; 3. 95. 19; 7. 80. 22.—tw=n...e)xo/ntwn...<ai(> oi)kh/seis : Bk. inserted the art. and has been followed by most editors; but Cl. and Steup consider the art. unnecessary after the preceding gen. (see on 1. 1. 11) notwithstanding the intervening words (au)to/nomoi . . . ai)ei/). Jowett would govern tw=n e)xo/ntwn by plh
 o)li/goi (=most, pa/ntes plh
 o)li/goi), making au)to/nomoi . . . oi)kh/seis appos. to the main subj. (plh
 o)li/goi). For oi)kh/seis, settlements (=kw=mai), cf. 1. 6. 2.
plh\n o)li/goi: plh/n adv., not prep., as 2. 21. 13, 34. 14; 4. 23. 12. For the rather harsh transition to the inhabitants of the oi)kh/seis, cf. 80. 3, 94. 3.
kateko/mizon: brought down, i.e. from the interior to the coast. Cf. 4. 67. 14 and katakomidh/ 1. 120. 10.

ei)si\n oi(/: as 10. 10; 1. 23. 7; 2. 49. 39; 7. 13. 16, 44. 46, 57. 12; 8. 101. 16; but e)/stin w(=n po/lewn below (30) and 7. 11. 7; toi=s barba/rois e)/stin oi(=s 1. 6. 21; e)/sti par' oi(=s (masc.) 1. 23. 15; e)/stin ou(/s 5. 72. 25. See F. Haase, Lucubr. Thuc. p. 72 f.

a)pekwlu/onto: (for a)pekw/luon, with all recent editors, following Doederlein and Bk.) sc. prosanagka/zein. Cf. 102. 8 and 7. 56. 6, where after diekw/lusen and kwlu/swsi infs. are supplied from what preceded.—to/n te xeimw=na...diexei/mazon : Steup finds this statement some what inexact; for in the winter of 415-414 B.C. the Athenians make the first attack upon Syracuse (63-71); then attempt to bring Messene over to their side, spending thereby some thirteen days in the territory of Messene (74. § 1, 2); then proceed to Naxos and spend some time there (74. § 2, 75. § 2). He suggests that teleutw=nta after
xeimw=na may have dropped out (cf. e)n tw=| au)tw=| qe/rei teleutw=nti 7. 9. 1).— 27. o(\katekau/qh: cf. 75. § 2.
a)norqw/santes: referring to w)/rqwsan 66. 10. Cf. e)panorqw/sontes 7. 77. 39.
e)/pemyan me/n, e)/pemyan de/: epanaphora, as 1. 85. 6.

kai\ au)tw=n: even themselves, i.e. of their own accord, with e)paggellome/nwn. On the matter, cf. 103. § 2; 7. 53. § 2, 57. § 11.— perih/ggellon: as e)ke/leuon below, limited by i(/ppous . . . pe/mpein. Cf. 1. 116. 5. There is no reason to suspect (with Kr.) e)ke/leuon, or to bracket (with v. H.) pe/myantes e)ke/leuon.
pe/myantes e)ke/leuon...pe/mpein : cf. 62. 20 perie/pleusan, stratia\n keleu/ontes pe/mpein.
ta)=lla : with plinqi/a kai\ si/dhron, kai\ o(/sa e)/dei in appos., as 71. 15.

plinqi/a: Hude writes plinqei=a with the Schol. of Patmos (plinqei=a, ta\ e)/n tu/pois cu/la, oi(=s ta\s pli/nqous kateskeu/azon).—si/dhron: sc. liqourgo/n, as 4. 69. 6. Cf. sidh/ria liqourga/ 4. 4. 5.
w(s...tou= pole/mou : cf. 8. 3. 17 w(s eu)qu\s pro\s to\ e)/ar e(co/menoi tou= pole/mou.
oi( d)...a)postale/ntes : cf. 73. § 2.
e)pibouleuo/mena: pass. with neut. subj., as 3. 96. 11 (often with pers. subj., as 33. 27, 80. 17). See on 3. 109. 21.
eu)qu\s yhfisa/menoi au)toi\ prw=toi kte(.: cf. 3. 101. 6 au)toi\ prw=toi do/ntes o(mh/rous kai\ tou\s a)/llous e)/peisan dou=nai foboume/nous kte(. Hude's bracketing of prw=toi is quite unnecessary.
w(/ste: after yhfisa/menoi, as 5. 17. 20. See on 3. 25. 10.

au)toi=s: sc. toi=s tw=n *surakosi/wn
pre/sbesi.
to\n au)tou= po/lemon : see on 34. 15.—safe/steron: = bebaio/teron e)k tou= profanou=s 73. 6, or fanerw/teron 91. 20.
w)feli/an tina/ : see on 73. 9.
parh=san e)s: see on 77. 5.— 47. meta\ tw=n cumfuga/dwn: cf. 61. § 6.
to/te: referring to 61. § 7.—e)k th=s *qouri/as: see on 61. 28.
e)/peita u(/steron: as 66. 13.

metapemya/ntwn: used in act. by Thuc. with apparently the same force as the usual middle. See on 1. 112. 6.—u(po/spondos: under free conduct, as 59. 18, explained by the following ga/r clause.— 51. th\n peri\ tw=n *mantinikw=n: cf. 89. § 3 and 5. 43 ff. On the Mantinean matters, see 5. 29-81.

e)n th=| e)kklhsi/a| tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn: which all Spartans of 30 years of age and over were entitled to attend.— 53. ta\ au)ta/: obj. of pei/qein, placed emphatically in the midst of the subjects connected by te . . . kai\ . . . kai/. pei/qein is conative, as the context shows.
tw=n e)n te/lei o)/ntwn: = tw=n a)/llwn tw=n e)n te/lei o)/ntwn, for the ephors also belonged to these.
kwlu/ontas: pres. ptc. with the better Mss., as in 3. 52. 11; 7. 3. 4, 25. 40. A few inferior Mss. read kwlu/sontas.
parw/cune : egged on, by working on the feelings or passions of the Lacedaemonians. Bl. cites Shakespeare, “Oh whet not on those two too furious peers.”— 58. e)cw/rmhse: goaded on to action.

div2.head: Speech of Alcibiades in the Popular Assembly at Sparta (89-92)
div2.p:
I was endeavoring by friendly acts to acquire again the relation of proxenus to you which my forefathers possessed, and only when you had begun to favor my enemies did I seek by the alliance with Argos and Mantinea
to injure you. For that you cannot be angry at me, nor, when you have considered all the circumstances, because I have favored the cause of the Demos.
ta\ koina/: public matters, opp. to personal imputations (th=s e)mh=s diabolh=s).—tw=| u(po/ptw| mou: cf. tw=| h(mete/rw| u(po/ptw| 85. 13.

tw=n d' e)mw=n: Haacke's conjecture, adopted by most editors for tw=n d' h(mw=n of the Mss., which offends both by plural number and by position of the pron. Reiske's tw=n dh\ e)mw=n, adopted by Kr. and Hude, would be most acceptable if any good reason for dh/ could be assigned here. de/ marks transition from general to particular, as 1. 37. 7.—th\n proceni/an u(mw=n kte(.: cf. 5. 43. § 2.

pa/lin a)nalamba/nwn: conative; cf. 5. 43. 13 dienoei=to a)nanew/sasqai. pa/lin pleonastic, as 4. 75. 14.— e)qera/peuon u(ma=s...peri\ th
 e)k *pu/lou cumfora/n : cf. 5. 43. 12 tou\s e)k th=s nh/sou au)tw=n ai)xmalw/tous qerapeu/wn. With th
 e)k *pu/lou cumfora/n, cf. th
 peri\ *pu/lon cumfora/n 7. 18. 17.
diatelou=ntos : without o)/ntos, as 1. 34. 12. Kühn. 483 c; Kr. Spr. 56, 5, 4.
toi=s e)moi=s e)xqroi=s: i.e. Nicias and Laches. Cf. 5. 43. § 2.
perie/qete: here in bad sense, as 8. 43. 21; in 4. 87. 26 in good sense.
kai\ o(/sa a)/lla h)nantiou/mhn u(mi=n: loosely correlated with pro/s te . . . trapome/nou, as well as by all the opposition that I made to you. For the facts, cf. 5. 53 ff.
kai\ nu=n: cf. 83. 10.—ei)...kai/ : cf. 33. 15; 3. 46. 5; 4. 22. 11. —e)n tw=| pa/sxein: = e)n tw=| bla/ptesqai.

ou)k ei)ko/tws : unreasonably, as 1. 37. 3, 76. 21; 2. 60. 25; 3. 56. 6. The expression corresponds to the preceding dikai/ws e)bla/ptesqe and the following mhd' ou(/tws h(gh/shtai o)rqw=s a)/xqesqai. The neg. belongs to ei)ko/tws alone, not to the prot., hence ou). Cl. conjectured ou)k a)peiko/tws, “with good reason,” as demanded by the context; but this has been almost universally rejected. —meta\ tou= a)lhqou=s: in the light of truth, i.e. in connection with the reasons stated.

a)napeiqe/sqw: Schol.
metapeiqe/sqw.

dio/ti kai/ : i.e. not merely because I was against you, but also because etc.—tw=| dh/mw| prosekei/mhn ma=llon: was more inclined to the cause of the Demos, i.e. than to that of the o)li/goi. proskei=sqai as 1. 93. 26; 7. 50. 31; 8. 89. 22.

mhd' ou(/tws: not even for this reason. Alcibiades justifies his political attitude, first by the tradition of his family, the Alemeonids, who had always led in the contest with the turanni/s, and second by the dominant form of government, which it was the duty of the individual citizen to support.

ai)ei/ pote: freq. used to emphasize a friendly or hostile relation. See on 2. 102. 10.—dia/foroi/ e)smen: the Alemeonids had shown their hostility to the turanni/s esp. against Cylon (1. 126) and the Peisistratids (59. § 4). This point would be effective with the tyrant-hating Spartans (1. 18. § 1, 122. § 3).
tw=| dunasteu/onti: neuter.— dh=mos w)no/mastai: cf. 39. 4.—a)p' e)kei/nou: i.e. tou= diafo/rous ei)=nai h(ma=s toi=s tura/nnois.

cumpare/meinen : continued along with it, i.e. with their hatred of tyrants remained to the Alcmeonids the leadership of the people. —h( prostasi/a tou= plh/qous: cf. h( tou= dh/mou prostasi/a 2. 65. 49; tou= dh<*>mou proesta/nai 28. 7; 3. 70. 12; 8. 65. 6. tou= plh/qous, as well as tou= cu/mpantos (21), selected by Alcibiades in order to represent himself not as a mere partyleader. He would be the head of the whole state; democracy, as the traditional form of Attic government he would endure, but seek to check its extravagances; toward the rule of the dh=mos, meaning that of one part of the citizens over the other, he is bitterly hostile. His expressions are cleverly chosen with a view to their effect upon the assembly of aristocratic Sparta.— a(/ma de/: as 83. 4; 1. 44. 15; 3. 115. 14; 4. 6. 4, 108. 24, 130. 19, 132. 9; 7. 5. 3, 68. 5, 84. 8; 8. 1. 13, 47. 3, 100. 11. Hude writes, with Laur., a(/ma de\ kai/, as 1. 25. 13, 92. 3, 97. 13; 2. 20. 10; 3. 22. 8, 112. 15; 4. 1. 11, 83. 13, 103. 20; 5. 33. 4.
ta\ polla/: adv. with toi=s parou=sin e(/pesqai, in most respects to conform to existing conditions.
th=s de\ u(parxou/shs a)kolasi/as: the gen. in the sense of h)\ w(/ste th=| u(parxou/sh| a)kolasi/a| xrh=sqai. Cf. 1. 84. 13 a)maqe/steron tw=n no/mwn th=s u(peroyi/as.
e)pi\ tw=n pa/lai : in the times of our forefathers.
e)ch=gon: = parh=gon. See on 3. 45. 19.—oi(/per...e)ch/lasan : among these, Androcles (8. 65. 6).
sxh/mati: cf. sxh=ma politiko/n 8. 89. 21.
kai\ o(/per e)de/cato/ tis : and which had come down to us. Cf. 2. 36. 7, 62. 24. The rel. is repeated after kai/ because a dem. clause follows. Cf. 4. 18.
dhmokrati/an: rule of the Demos.—oi( fronou=nte/s ti: pregnant force, those who had any sense. Cf. 5. 7. 10.

kai\ au)to\s . . . o(/sw| kai/ †, loidorh/saimi : the lacuna after o(/sw| kai/ is most prob. due to the dropping out of me/gist' h)di/khmai, and I myself could find fault as much as any, inasmuch as I have been most injured. See App.— a)lla\...le/goito : but about an admitted folly nothing new could be said. o(mologoume/nhs as 2. 37. 18; 4. 62. 3; Xen. Mem. 4. 6. 15.

kai\ to\ meqista/nai au)th
...proskaqhme/nwn : kai/ goes back to tou=to cundiasw/|zein, hence all the intervening words (e)pei\ . . . le/goito) must be considered parenthetical, or out of their place owing to a copyist's slip (see on 11. 15).—to\ meqista/nai au)th/n: the pron. refers to po/lis (22). The verb is freq. used of political changes; cf. metasth=sai to
 ko/smon 4. 76. 6; th
 po/lin metasth=sai 8. 48. 24, 66. 2; ta\ e)n tw=| *sa/mw| metasth=sai 8. 75. 7.

But the Athenians are planning to subdue not only the Siceliotes, but also the Italiotes and Carthage, and then with their resources thus inereased to make themselves masters of the whole Hellenic world.
h)/dh: followed by explanation without ga/r, while 91. 5 has ga/r. So explanations indicated by toio/sde and o(/de sometimes have and sometimes omit ga/r. See on 1. 89. 2.
*sikeliw/tas katastreyo/menoi kte(.: cf. 15. § 2.—au)=qis: further. See on 52. 5.
th=s *karxhdoni/wn a)rxh=s: prob. referring esp. to Sardinia and Corsica.
a)popeira/sontes: to make an attempt on. See on 4. 24. 7.
h)\ kai\ ta\ plei/w: or at least the greater part. kai/ as in 1. 1. 7.
tw=n *(ellh/nwn: i.e. tw=n te *sikeliwtw=n kai\ tw=n *)italiwtw=n.
kai\ *)/ibhras kai\ a)/llous : epexegetical appos. to pollou\s barba/rous.

barba/rwn : bracketed unnecessarily by Bk., St., and v. H. It modifies maximwta/tous to which o(mologoume/nws nu=n belongs, and the repetition after barba/rous (9) is not stranger than that in 3. 116. 4 or 4. 122. 2.
trih/reis te: third particular after *(/ellhnes and ba/rbaroi.
ai(=s : Duker's conjecture for oi<*>=s, generally accepted. With pe/ric poliorkou=ntes the reference can only be to the triremes; besides transition to the land forces is emphasized by kai\ a(/ma.
th\n *pelopo/nnhson pe/ricpoliorkou=ntes : cf. 2. 7. 18 pe/ric th\n *pelopo/nnhson katapolemh/sontes.

e)k gh=s e)formai=s : by attacks from the land side. e)formh/ except here and Hom. x 130 is found only in late poets; see Steph. Thes. s.v. The verb e)forma=n is found in the classical period only in the poets; see App. on 49. 18.

e)nteixisa/menoi: (mid. elsewhere prob. only in late authors; see App. on 1^{4}. 142. 8) having walled in. The Schol. explains: periteixi/santes h)\ frou/ria e)n th=| xw/ra| au)tw=n e)piteixi/santes. Cl. approved the latter explanation; but Steup argues that the proper antithesis to bi/a| lamba/nein po/leis (cf. 4. 5. 3, 69. 3) was not capture by an e)piteixismo\s th=| xw/ra| (see on 1. 122. 3), but by a regular siege, to which belonged above all a circumvallation (cf. 2. 77. § 1 f.). For e)nteixi/zesqai, surround with walls or fortifications, cf. Dio C. 42. 38 e)kra/tei th=s me\n h)pei/rou o( *)axilla=s, xwri\s w(=n o( *kai=sar e)netetei/xisto (where, however, not siege works but works of defense are meant). Cf. Plut. Pomp. 28 pare/dwkan e(autou\s kai\ po/leis kai\ nh/sous, w(=n e)pekra/toun e)nteixisa/menoi (—having built fortifications).
katapolemh/sein: sc. th\n *pelopo/nnhson. The compound = debellare, as 16. 7.— 16. tou= cu/mpantos *(ellhnikou=: the whole Hellenic world. Cf. to\ *(ellhniko/n 1. 1. 6; 3. 82. 3.
eu)porw/teron: more practicable. Cf. ou)k eu)/poron h)=n 4. 78. 10; eu)po/rws 8. 36. 2.
ti au)tw=n : i.e. something of these plans, as 92. 1; not, with Cl., referring to xrh/mata kai\ si=ton.

au)ta\
ta\ prosgeno/mena e)kei=qen...pare/cein : the places added from that quarter were going to furnish enough (money and food) of themselves without our home revenue. e)kei=qen as in 8 above. Cf. prosgegenhme/nas nau=s e)k tw=n *)aqhnw=n 1. 52. 7; prosege/nonto e)k tou= *(ellhspo/ntou tine\s du/o nh=es 8. 100. 26.

, 92, § 1. Against this impending danger you must give vigorous support to the Syracusans, who cannot alone withstand the Athenians, and especially must you send them an experienced general. At the same time you must openly renew the war with the Athenians, and, what they themselves fear most, you must occupy Decelea in Attica, whence you can cut off their chief sources of supply.
peri\ tou= nu=n oi)xome/nou sto/lou: concerning the expedition that is gone. Of the same expedition we read 2. 65. 47 oi( e)kpe/myantes ou) ta\ pro/sfora toi=s oi)xome/nois e)pigignw/skontes.

ta\ a)kribe/stata ei)do/tos : has the most accurate knowledge. Cf. a)kribe/s ti ei)/somai 5. 26. 24; to\ safe\s ei)de/nai 3. 29. 7. The accus. is cognate, but does not differ practically from the adv. a)kribe/stata in 27 below.
o(/soi: referring to two only, Nicias and Lamachus. Pal. reads w(s oi(, but Alcibiades has said nothing as yet of what the other generals will do.
u(po/loipoi: as 4. 2. 7. oi( loipoi/ of the same in 62. 1.
ou) perie/stai: Schol. ou) swqh/setai. Cf. perige/nointo below (6).—h)/dh: now, as 90. 3.
custrafe/ntes a(qro/oi: as 4. 68. 25. Cf. 77. 7.
pandhmei/: cf. 67. 10, 68. 8.—h(sshme/noi kai\...kateirgo/menoi : ptes. pf. and pres. expressing the present situation.
e)/xetai: pres. vividly anticipating the result, then all Sicily is theirs. Cf. 34. 25. The cond. is monitory, as in 4 above. GMT. 447.
a)/rti...proei=pon : 90. § 3.
ou) dia\ makrou=: see on 15. 18.

w(/ste: with imv., as 7. 63. 17.—mh\ peri\ th=s *sikeli/as...bouleu/ein : for the thought, cf. 1. 36. 6, 120. 14. bouleu/ein,
as freq., = bouleu/esqai.

ei) mh\ poih/sete ta/de e)n ta/xei : this prot. depends, as Kr. and St. explain, on something implied but not expressed in the preceding, i.e. also about the Pcloponnesus (which is in danger) unless you will do the following things quickly. Steup suggests the loss of some words before ei) mh\ poih/sete, perhaps ei)/per kai\ au(/th ta\ me/gista bla/yetai.

stratia/n te...kai\...a)/ndra *spartia/thn : te and kai/ correlate the double obj. of pe/myete, which still depends upon ei) and explains ta/de. Cf. 2. 77. 22 to/de cumbh=nai followed by epexegetical inf. without connective. See on 1. 89. 2.
oi(/tines: pl. rel. referring to the collective stratia/n, as 3. 67. 12; 7. 1. 9.—au)tere/tai: fighting men serving at the oar. Cf. 1. 10. 26; 3. 18. 16.
w(s a)\n tou/s te paro/ntas...prosanagka/sh| : cf. the advice of Hermocrates 72. § 4. For w(s a)/n with subjv., found only here in Thuc., but not infreq. in tragedy, see Stahl, Qu. Gr.^{2} 25.
qe/lontas: for the form, see on 34. 18.
e)ndoia/zontes: also 1. 36. 9, 122. 15. Not elsewhere in Attic.

kai\ ta\ e)nqa/de xrh\...e)kpolemei=n : and here you must at the same time prosecute the war more openly. Cf. 73. 6 f. and 88. 44 f. ta\ e)nqa/de is adv. here, as in 84. 12. fanerw/teron is enforced by e)k in e)kpolemei=n. Though the intr. form seems appropriate here, St. and others adopt against all Mss. the trans. e)kpolemou=n. See App.
e)pime/lesqai: see on 54. 24.

toi=s e(autw=n h(=sson a)/llhn e)pikouri/an pe/mpwsi: may be less likely to send to their allies further assistance. Cf. 73. 9 f. For toi=s e(autw=n, their allies, cf. 4. 126. 4 th\n a)po/leiyin tw=n h(mete/rwn, the withdrawal of our allies.
teixi/zein de\ xrh\ *deke/leian: this advice, fateful for Athens, was later carried out, 7. 19.

au)tou=: pers. for rel., acc. to Greek usage in a second clause of a rel. sent. See on 1. 42. 2. G. 1040; H. 1005; Kr. Spr. 60, 6, 2. —tw=n e)n tw=| pole/mw|: i.e. war in general,
not this particular war. Cf. 72. 5; 2. 100. 7.
diapepeira=sqai: only here in Thuc.
safw=s punqano/menos: the vague ai)sqa/noito becomes here clearly learning.—au)tou/s: ipsos, pred. to e(ka/stous.
a(/: cogn. accus. with w)felou/menoi.
th=| e)piteixi/sei : a hostile stronghold on the border or in the territory of an enemy. See on 1. 122. 3.
kwlu/sete: sc. w)felei=sqai.
kefalaiw/sw : found also 3. 67. 32; 8. 53. 3.

kateskeu/astai: applied to every kind of structure and domestic equipment. Cf. 8. 24. 18 th\n xw/ran kalw=s kateskeuasme/nhn. To this kind of property belong also slaves, and to these applies ta\ d' au)to/mata h(/cei (32). Cf. 7. 27. 22 a)ndrapo/dwn ple/on h)\ du/o muria/des hu)tomolh/kesan.
*laurei/ou : so (for *lauri/ou) some of the best Mss. here and 2. 55. 2, in agreement with Steph. Thes. s.v. *se/rreion.

dikasthri/wn : “from the courts, since in case of a war at home a cessation of the courts occurs” (Boeckh, Staatshaushaltung I^{3}, 415). Cf. also Schol. tau/ths ou)=n th=s pa/shs proso/dou sterh/sesqai e)/mellon oi( *)aqhnai=oi, polemi/wn au)toi=s i(drume/nwn e)n th=| xw/ra| kai\ sxolh\n ou) parexo/ntwn dika/zesqai. The expression a)po\ dikasthri/wn w)felou=ntai prob. includes also the misqo\s dikastiko/s received by individuals. See App.— 35. th=s...proso/dou : added, with change of const., to a)posterh/sontai, with h(=sson diaforoume/nhs in explan. addition, as the tribute is less regularly brought in. diaforei=n, as 100. 24, but not elsewhere found in this sense. Bl. cites, as nearest parallel, Dio C. 34. 6, where it means remit. The pres. ptc. used of wont or custom. See App.— 36. oi(/: referring to cumma/xwn, in the sense of e)pei\ e)kei=noi.
kata\ kra/tos polemei=sqai : neut. pass. with ta\ par' u(mw=n in adv. force.
o)ligwrh/sousi: they will take their tribute obligations lightly.
, § 1. 1. ti au)tw=n: see on 90. 17. The reference is to the proposals developed in 91. § 4 ff.

proqumo/teron:
used with reference to perai/nesqai implied in gi/gnesqai.

e)n u(mi=n e)stin : depends upon you.—w(/s ge dunata/...pa/nu qarsw= : Alcibiades intimates that the Athenians would not be able to prevent the Spartans from bringing aid to the Syracusans and fortifying Decelea.— 3. a(marth/sesqai gnw/mhs: cf. 1. 33. 23.

, §§ 2-5. Do not mistrust me because I am an Athenian exile and urge you to war against my fatherland. Use me rather without fear for every danger and difficulty; shrink not from proceeding against Sicily and Attica, in order to rescue the Siceliotes, to break the power of the Athenians, and to have security for yourselves and the hegemony over all Hellas with its free consent.

kai\ xei/rwn...ei)=nai : cf. 3. 9. 11 mhde/ tw| xei/rous do/cwmen ei)=nai. The orator is led by the consideration that his proposals might be distrusted in Sparta, as coming from an Athenian exile, again to go into his personal relations, as in c. 89 he had sought to show that his former political conduct should not prevent the Spartans from giving him an unprejudiced hearing.—th=| e)mautou=: sc. gh=|.

e)gkratw=s : (Schol. karterw=s) as 1. 76. 6.—mou: dependent on to
 lo/gon, but gets by its position the force of dat. incommodi.—e)s th
 fugadikh
 proqumi/an: on the score of (with reference to) the exile's zeal, i.e. as if only the zeal that characterizes exiles were beneath my proposal. For e)s, cf. 8. 88. 8 boulo/menos au)to
 e)s th
 . . . fili/an . . . diaba/llein. fugadiko/s also in Isocr. 9. 28; elsewhere only in late writers.

fuga/s te ga/r ei)mi kte(.: “The following definitions are doubtless so arranged by Thuc. that by ingenious paradox and forced sophistry may be revealed the insincerity and unsteadinessof Alcibiades” (Bm.). The answers to the possible reproaches are given in chiastic order: for I am a fugitive from the villaing of those that expelled me, and yet not banished from benefiting you, if you hearken to me. With the word-play on fuga/s, cf. cu/mmaxoi 3. 10. 10, and a)posth/sesqai a)po/stasin 3. 13. 8.

kai\ polemiw/teroi kte(.: this kai/, not the preceding, correl. to te. The predicate applied above (5) to enemies in war, the Lacedaemonians, is here transferred to his enemies in Athens, and the word is put forward for emphasis where we should naturally have
ou) polemiw/teroi: and more hostile are not those who, like you, have injured foes, but those who have forced friends to become foes.

to/ te filo/poli kte(.: te introducing third rejoinder. The Schol. remarks: filo/polis, fhsi/n, ou) nu=n ei)mi/, h(ni/ka a)dikou=mai, a)lla\ to/te o(/te a)sfalw=s e)politeuo/mhn. But e)n w(=| is not merely temporal, but circumstantial: and patriotism I cherish not where I am wronged, but where my political rights were secure. Sc. ei)=xon; see on 1. 86. 7.

e)politeu/qhn: lived as a citizen. This (aor. pass.) form occurs also in Lys. 26. 5; Isocr. 7. 15; Aeschin. 2. 176; but e)politeusa/mhn Dem. 18. 207. Veitch remarks that of classical authors only Thuc. and Xen. use the active politeu/ein.
ou)d) e)pi\ patri/da...nu=n i)e/nai : and it is not against a land that is still my country that I consider I am now going, referring to (4) ei) th=| e)mautou= . . . e)pe/rxomai.

th
 ou)k ou)=san a)nakta=sqai : sc. patri/da. From the whole context only Athens can be thought of. di) e(te/rwn zhtei=n th
 ka/qodon, as Isocr. 9. 28 expresses it, was something common enough in Hellenic antiquity. Van H. wishes to write th
 ou)ke/t' ou)=san or th
 ou)k ou)=san e)/ti, but after e)/ti in 12 this is unnecessary.—kai\ filo/polis kte(.: transition from the personal to the general, with a reference also to the assumed reproach (5) filo/poli/s pote dokw=n ei)=nai: and the true patriot is not that one who, having unjustly lost his fatherland, refrains from going against it, but who on account of longing for it tries in every way to get it back. Such a definition would not seem as strange to the Hellenes of the fifth and fourth centuries as to us. Cf. Isocr. 16. 12 ff. and A. Fokke, Rettungen des Alkibiades H, 76 ff.— 16. peiraqh=|: in act. sense, as in 2. 5. 20, 33. 9 (elsewhere peira=sai or peira/sasqai); in pass. sense 54. 9.

ou(/tws: drawing the conclusion from the preceding, as 1. 76. 6; 4. 86. 23.— e)moi/ te a)ciw=...w)feloi/hn : clearly imitated in the conclusion of the speech of Coriolanus in Dion. H. Antiq. 8. 8. —e)moi/ te: (Bk.'s correction for e)/moige) opp. to kai\ au)tou/s (21).
pa=san: though agreeing in gender with the nearer noun, affecting also ki/ndunon.

tou=ton : looks forward. See on 85. 3.—proballo/menon: advanced.— 19. ei)...e)/blapton : actual case more vividly presented in hypothetical form.
See on 1. 33. 8.
o(/sw|: in so far as, without comp. or sup. See on 1. 68. 11. —ta\ d' u(me/tera h)/|kazon: while I could only conjecture yours. Note the modest impf. as contrasted with the self-conscious pres.
au)tou\s...mh\ a)poknei=n : dependent on a)ciw= (16).

tw=n diafero/ntwn: the interests at stake, as 1. 70. 3, and ta\ dia/fora 1. 68. 8; 2. 37. 5; 4. 86. 23; 5. 115. 8. Cf. i)di/a| ti au)tw=| diafe/rei. The pred. megi/stwn dh/ is emphatically put forward, as all important.
te kai/: connecting the two divergent goals of the stratei/a, as inseparable if the object is to be reached.

braxei= mori/w|: of a division of troops, as 2. 39. 17.—mega/la sw/shte: keep great, preserve in their greatness. The adj. is pred., containing the effect of the verb. Cf. 1. 90. 20. Steup connects, with Portus and Haase, ta\ e)kei= mega/la, notwithstanding the intervening words, urging that we have thus (i.e. in the great Sicilian cities) a better antithesis to braxei= mori/w|.
