th/n te ou)=san kai\ th\n me/llousan du/namin : the power which they now possess and that for which they hope. th\n me/llousan the increased power on which they might reckon after the subjugation of Sicily and with which Alcibiades threatens them in 90. § 3.—kaqe/lhte: pull down, overthrow, as 11. 12; 5. 14. 14. See on 1. 77. 20.

kai\ meta\ tau=ta...h(gh=sqe : parody, with intentional optimistic coloring, of Alcibiades' own description, in 90. § 3 (end), of the hopes of the Athenians. Against a)/rcein there appears here the mild e(kou/shs kai\ ou) bi/a|, kat) eu)/noian de\ h(gh=sqe.
h(gh=sqe : so with Vat., in preference to h(gh/shsqe or h(gh/sesqe of other Mss., to express continuance, as in oi)kh=te (26).

In consequence of this speech the Lacedaemonians determine to fortify Decelea, and send Gylippus to Syracuse, with orders to see that aid is brought as soon as possible to Sicily. In Athens it is voted to comply with the request of the generals and send money and cavalry to Sicily.
tosau=ta: Vat. reads, perhaps more correctly, toiau=ta. See on 35. 1.
au)toi/: sua sponte, as 3. 65. 4.

periorw/menoi:
circumspectantes. Cf. 103. 9; 7. 33. 9. So Cic. Tusc. 1. 30. 73 dubitans, circumspectans, haesitans.
4. dida/cantos...au)tou= kai\ nomi/santes : for similar coupling of gen. abs. and nom., see on 1.65.2.
para\ tou= safe/stata ei)do/tos a)khkoe/nai: cf. 91. § 1.

prosei=xon to
 nou=n: more freq. th
 gnw/mhn (1. 95. 7; 2. 11. 10; 5. 26. 23; 7. 15. 15, 23. 3). With dat. here, as in 7. 23. 3.—kai\ to\ parauti/ka kai\...timwri/an : and in particular to sending immediately to the Sicilians some assistance. Compare herewith the feeling of the Spartan authorities before the speech of Alcibiades, 88. 54 ff. The inf. follows prosei=xon to
 nou=n as if e)n nw=| ei)=xon had preceded. Stahl compares the inf. after nou=ne)/xein Soph. El. 1014. to\ parauti/ka as 1. 27. 4, 134. 10; 3. 4. 8; 4. 121. 7.

prosta/cantes a)/rxonta: see App. on 3. 26. 3. Gylippus, whose generalship in Sicily was so fateful for Athens, first appears here. His father Cleandridas was implicated in the charge of bribery on which King Pleistoanax was banished in 446 B.C. (1. 114. § 2; 2. 21. § 1; 5. 16. § 3), and he had to go into exile himself. Cf. 104. § 2; Plut. Pericl. 22; Nic. 28.
met' e)kei/nwn kai\ tw=n *korinqi/wn: i.e. with the ambassadors of the Syracusans and Corinthians.— poiei=n o(/ph|: operam dare quomodo. Cf. pra/ssein h(=| 26. 3.
ma/lista : best, most certainly. Steup alone of the editors adopts from Vat. ka/llista. But that attractive reading looks like a marginal explanation of ma/lista.

h)/dh: without delay, as 25. 3.— 12. e)s *)asi/nhn: prob. the harbor in Messenia (4. 13. 3). See on 4. 54. 20. —paraskeua/zesqai: prob. pass.; or ta\s loipa/s must be at once its obj. and the subj. of e(toi/mas ei)=nai.

tau=ta de\ cunqe/menoi a)nexw/roun : i.e. the ambassadors of Syracuse and Corinth, as all recent editors, except Steup, explain. The latter thinks the words oi( *kori/nqioi must have fallen out here, because only the Corinthian ambassadors would have part in an agreement to send Corinthian ships in aid.—a)nexw/roun: set off on the return.
h( e)k th=s *sikeli/as trih/rhs: cf. 74. 12.

th\n trofh/n: not provisions, but pay or money for maintenance, as is shown by 94. 19. This is the usual meaning of trofh/ in military matters; cf. 4. 83. 24; 8. 57. 33. sithre/sion first occurs Xen. Anab. 5. 10. 4 (Kr.).— 19. tw=| pole/mw| e)teleu/ta tw=|de: Vat. offers here and in 7. 18. 33, against the other Mss., the rarer word-order e)teleu/ta tw=| pole/mw| tw=|de (cf. 7. 22; 2. 70. 5), whereas it alone has in 8. 60. 17 tw=| pole/mw| e)teleu/ta tw=|de. See on 2. 17. 2.

div2.head: The Eighteenth Year of the War
The Eighteenth Year of the War
div2.p: The Athenians make from Catana forays into the territory of Megara Hyblaea and to the river Terias, also against the Sicel town of Centoripa, which they induce to join them. From Athens 250 cavalrymen—but without horses—and 30 mounted bowmen, along with 300 talents of money, arrive at Catana.
a)/rantes e)k th=s *kata/nhs: cf. 88. § 5.

*mega/rwn: Megara Hyblaea; see on 4. 7.—tw=n e)n th=| *sikeli/a|: bracketed by Stahl and others, following Kr. It might easily be spared, but without it e)pi\ tw=n *mega/rwn must be expected, acc. to 49. 18, 75. 4, 97. 25; 7. 25. 15. The reading of Vat. e)pi\ *megare/wn tw=n kte(. is not acceptable, as e)pi/ takes gen. only of names of places, and the Megarians at that time had been driven from town and territory (4. § 2).—ou(/s: per synesin referring to *mega/rwn. Cf. 80. 3, 91. 14.
pro/teron: 4. § 2.

e)dh/|wsan tou\s a)grou\s kte(.: so with Vat., for tou/s te a)grou/s of the Mss., which most editors accept. The position of te is not ground for rejection (see on 2. 46. 1); but not only is the coupling of aor. and impf. of the same verb by te . . . kai/ objectionable, but it is hardly to be supposed that Thuc. would thus correlate the devastation of the fields and the plain, with the unsuccessful attack on the fort and the advance along the shore to the Terias river thrown in between. L. Herbst (Zu Thuk. H, 109 f.) would bracket not only te, but also tou\s a)grou/s, because in 3. 79. 12 Thuc. writes porqei=n a)grou/s.
But cf. dh|ou=n a)grou/s 2. 13. 7, 12.

e)pi\ e)/ruma/ ti tw=n *surakosi/wn : acc. to 75. § 1 the Syracusans had turned the depopulated Megara into a fort, which prob. is here designated by e)/ruma/ ti, as it is not likely that they would have fortified two points in the district of Megara. The historian prob. did not recall that he had already spoken more definitely at 75. § 1 about the e)/ruma.

au)=qis...parakomisqe/ntes : Stahl rightly explains that au)=qis refers to para- in pare/pleusa<*> (2). The Athenians advanced again along the coast, the movement being made this time not only by sea, but kai\ pezh=| kai\ nausi/n. As Hdt. (5. 98. 26), so also Thuc. sometimes uses komi/zesqai of land-marches (cf. 3. 114. 24; 8. 80. 15, 100. 20). Not observing this, Cl. understood pezh=| to refer to the return-march from the e)/ruma to the coast and corrected (8) a)naba/ntes (going up, i.e. inland) into a)poba/ntes (disembarking).
*thri/an: about this river, see on 50. 12.
tisi\n ou) polloi=s: see on 1. 5.
e)pisitisa/menoi: having supplied themselves with provisions. Cf. 8. 95. 17, 101. 2.

*kento/ripa: now Centorbi. See Holm I, 68. Cf. Strabo 272 C kei=tai u(pe\r *kata/nhs ta\ *kento/ripa suna/ptonta toi=s *ai)tnai/ois o(/resi kai\ tw| *sumai/qw| potamw=| r(e/onti ei)s th\n *katanai/an.

*sikeliko\n po/lisma : the reading of Vat., the other better Mss. having *sikelo/n. Most editors write *sikelw=n with the inferior Codex G. Cf. *(/ukkara, po/lisma *sikaniko/n 62. 10; *)/inhssan, to\ *sikeliko\n po/lisma 3. 103. 5.
prosagago/menoi : having brought over; see on 2. 30. 7; 3. 91. 7.

e)mpipra/ntes: Vat. has e)mpiprw=ntes, the other Mss. pimpra/ntes or pipra/ntes. The compound is necessary (with v. H.), as the simple verb seems to be quite foreign to Attic prose. The compound occursabove (9) and elsewhere in Thuc. fourteen times.—tw=n te *)inhssai/wn kai\ tw=n *(ublai/wn: Inessa and Hybla Geleatis were Sicel towns, the former mentioned 3. 103. 5, the latter 62. 21.

tou/s te i(ppe/as kte(.: cf. 93. 18.— 17. a)/neu tw=n i(/ppwn: without the necessary horses, hence the article.—meta\ skeuh=s: as elsewhere of equipment of men (see on 1. 2. 12), so here of horses. —w(s...porisqhsome/nwn : for the
matter, cf. 37. § 1, 98. § 1.
i(ppotoco/tas: cf. 2. 13. 54; 5. 84. 9.
ta/lanta a)rguri/ou triako/sia: the payment of this sum to the ships, which carried it to Sicily, is mentioned in Inscr. Gr. I, 183. 11 ff. = Sylloge Inscr. Gr. ed. Dittenberger I^{2}, 37, p. 64.
Hostilities between the Lacedaemonians and Argives. A democratic uprising in Thessaly miscarries.
e)p' *)/argos: the last hostilities between Lacedaemonians and Argives had occurred in the sixteenth year of the war (7. §§ 1, 2).

me/xri *klewnw=n: see on 5. 67. 16. Apparently the Lacedaemonians had taken the way through Arcadia and the territory of Phlius.— seismou= genome/nou: the same reason for the turning back of the Lacedaemonians as in 3. 89. § 1.

a)nexw/rhsan: so with Vat.; with the usual reading a)pexw/rhsan one would expect e)p' oi)/kou (cf. 7. 9; 2. 68. 31; 4. 44. 5) or pa/lin (cf. 1. 107. 11; 2. 94. 18).—e)s th\n *qurea=tin: cf. 2. 27. 11 h( *qurea=tis, gh= meqori/a th=s *argei/as kai\ *lakwnikh=s. It was in the possession of the Lacedaemonians.
ou)k e)/lasson: for h)/ omitted, cf. 4. 44. 28, and see O. Schwab, Hist. Syntax d. gr. Komparation (Schanz, Beitr. IV), p. 212 ff.

*qespiw=n: which, belonging unwillingly to the Theban alliance under the supremacy of Thebes, was deprived of its walls in 423 B.C. (4. 133. § 1), because the Thebans feared its leaning toward Athens; hence the attempt of the Demos to throw off at once their own oligarchic rule and the supremacy of Thebes.

ta\s a)rxa\s e)/xousin: (cf. 5. 34. 11) = e)n a)rxh=| or a)rxai=s ei)=nai (54. 24; 2. 37. 16; 4. 74. 11).—ou) kate/sxen: did not get the upper hand. For this abs. use of katasxei=n, corresponding to the trans. in 9. 16, Stahl compares Lys. 3. 42.—bohqhsa/ntwn *qhbai/wn: so only Vat. correctly. The reading of the other Mss., bohqhsa/ntwn *)aqhnai/wn, even if the gen. abs. be taken, with Heilmann, as concessive (although the Athenians lent aid), gives no satisfactory sense; for in case of a real interference on the part of the Athenians, which would have meant an infraction of existing peace relations with the Boeotians (cf. 5. 32. § 5), more exact information was to be expected.

cunelh/fqhsan: and doubtless executed later.—e)ce/peson:
not passive here, were driven out (as e.g. 1. 2. 23; 2. 27. 7; 3. 68. 17), but fled for refuge; cf. 7. 71. 31.
The Syracusans, expecting a renewal of the attack of the Athenians, held a review of their forces in a meadow on the Anapus, and designated 600 picked hoplites to guard the approaches to Epipolae.

te: omitted by three Mss. (Vat., Pal., Paris.), and bracketed by Stahl and Classen; but it is indispensable, for me/llontas refers unquestionably not to i(ppe/as, but *)aqhnai/ous to be supplied from toi=s *)aqhnai/ois.

toi=s *)aqhnai/ois : dat. with h(/kein, (also 1. 91. 11; 5. 10. 12, 34. 1), as with e)lqei=n (see on 1. 13. 12) and a)fiknei=sqai (3. 5. 12). See C. F. Smith, Trans. Amer. Philol. Assoc. XXXV, 69 f.— 3. tw=n *)epipolw=n: the triangular plateau extending westward from the base of Achradina for about five kilometers to the point of Euryelus, for the most part with steep declivities north and south; from this an enemy could make the most dangerous attack upon the city.
eu)qu/s: directly (see on 4. 43. 6) above, i.e. to the west of the city. See Holm H, 31, 32.
sfa=s: on account of the distance of nomi/santes, for sfei=s that was to be expected (see on 49. 8).
ta\s prosba/seis au)tw=n: the approaches to it (Epipolae), which were kata\ to\n *eu)ru/hlon (97. 11; 7. 2. 14, 43. 21).

kata\ tau/tas: so rightly read Bk., Cl., and others, with Vat., for kata\ tau=ta of the rest of the Mss. Since the following a)/llh| is opp. to the approaches of Epipolae, it was necessary that there should be in the purpose clause a definite reference to the prosba/seis au)tw=n, hence kata\ tau=ta, in these places, for which 2. 69. 7 has been cited, is not so good.
dunhqh=nai: sc. a)nabh=nai. Supply e)no/mizon from dienoou=nto (cf. 4. 8. 34, 108. 8).

e)ch/rthtai to\ a)/llo xwri/on: Schol. to\ a)/llo xwri/on, plh\n tw=n prosba/sewn. The meaning here of e)chrth=sqai is suspensum esse, which though not found in other early authors, is sufficiently confirmed by the imitation of Strabo 290 C e)ch/rthtai h( xw/ra pro\s no/ton. Virgil's saxis suspensa rupes (Aen. 8. 190) depends upon the same point of view. On the contrary Plut. Anton. 46 ta\ mega/la pedi/a tw=n lo/fwn tou/twn e)ch/rthtai is not parallel. Stahl adopts Casaubon's conjecture e)ch=rtai, which Kr. too prefers in spite of the caution
of the Schol. mh\ e)pi\ tou= e)ch=rqai kai\ metewri/sqai a)koue/sqw. See App.

e)pifane\s pa=n e)/sw: in full view within the city. The Schol. explains katafane\s e)/swqen, which is the same thing from the reverse (our) point of view. Epipolae clear to the top is still visible from the lower town.
e)pipolh=s: above (really elliptical gen. of e)pipolh/), adv. = e)pa/nw. Cf. Hdt. 1. 187. 4; Ar. Plut. 1207 (Schol. e)pi/rrhma topiko/n). See Lobeck ad Phryn. p. 126.

para\ to\n *)/anapon potamo/n: i.e. along the left bank of the river, not far from its mouth. Most recent editors think, with Kr., that to/n must be inserted before para/. But cf. 40. 14 tou\s lo/gous a)f' u(mw=n, and see on 1. 51. 11; 3. 91. 10; 4. 9. 5.
au)toi=s: ethical dat. Cf. 1. 89. 14; 5. 3. 21.— oi( peri\ to\n *(ermokra/thn strathgoi/: who, chosen in the winter (73. § 1), had prob. in the spring entered upon their office.
e)ce/tasin o(/plwn: see on 41. 10.

pro/teron: the choice of the 600 (the Mss. have wrongly e(ptakosi/ous, cf. 97. 15; 7. 43. 29) was the first measure taken before the general review, with which the arrangement of the separate divisions was connected. On these 600, see Holm H, 418.
ei)=en ...kai\...paragi/gnwntai : the same change of mood, in reverse order, as in 3. 22. 37; 7. 17. 15; 8. 87. 14, 17. GMT. 321; Kr. Spr. 54, 8, 2; Kühn. 553, 6.

The Athenians, however, had already landed the night before with their whole army at Leon at the foot of Epipolae and ascended this height by way of Euryelus before the Syracusans could lend aid from the Anapus meadow. The 600 picked men and the rest of the Syracusans rush in disorder against the Athenians, but are repulsed with great loss. Next day the Athenians advance against the city; but as the Syracusans do not come out, they turn back and build at Labdalum, the northernmost point of Epipolae, a fort to serve as a base and a depository of military supplies.

oi( de\ *)aqhnai=oi tau/ths th=s nukto/s, <h(=|> th=| e)pigignome/nh| h(me/ra| e)chta/zonto e)kei=noi, e)/laqon au)tou\s...kata\ to\n *le/onta kalou/menon: the Athenians during that night, on the day after which the Syracusans held their review, came from Catana with their whole force and landed
unobserved at the place called Leon. The general situation was this: the Athenians use the same ruse as in their first attack upon Syracuse (64-66), that is, they avail themselves of a time to ascend Epipolae when the main force of the Syracusans is engaged outside of the city in the opposite direction. This time they had doubtless information of the intended great review and hence sail during the night preceding the day set therefor from Catana to the point Leon, distant six or seven stades from Epipolae (as 65. 14 u(po\ nu/kta e)/pleon e)pi\ ta\s *surakou/sas), land the troops, and ascend Euryelus, while the Syracusans are still on the meadow by the Anapus. On the text, see App.

sxo/ntes: condensed expression for parapleu/santes kai\ sxo/ntes. For const. sxei=n kata/, see on 1. 110. 11.—to\n *le/onta: Leon was near the modern Casa della Finanza south of Thapsus. See Holm H, 385 f.; Freeman, Hist. of Sic. III, 211.
e)s th\n *qa/yon: the peninsula north west of Leon with a roomy harbor for ships. See on 4. 5.
e)n stenw=| i)sqmw=|...pe/lagos : with a narrow isthmus, extending into the sea.
plou=n: understand polu/n from pollh/n. Cf. 92. 17. Measure of distance, as in 2. 38, 49. 19.
diastaurwsa/menos: =stauroi)=s a)polabw/n (cf. 4. 102. 18). The middle diastaurou=sqai is found nowhere else, the act. only in Dio C. 41. 50.
kata\ to\n *eu)ru/hlon: not far from the westernmost point of Epipolae, near the present Belvedere. See Holm H, 32, 386; Freeman III, 211 f.
w(s e(/kastos ta/xous ei)=xe: as in 2. 90. 19. See on 1. 22. 13; 7. 2. 2.—oi( peri\ to\n *dio/milon: cf. 96. 16.

prosmei=cai: of approach (1. 46. 8), prospeso/ntes (16) of attack.—e)gi/gnonto: (to which belongs e)k tou= xeimw=nos) with
numerals, as in 1. 87. 10, 107. 24; 2. 13. 27, 20. 11, 98. 14; 3. 75. 22; 4. 9. 10.
au)toi=s: toi=s *)aqhnai/ois.

toiou/tw| tro/pw| : with a)takto/teron. Against the reading of Vat. a)takto/teroi might be cited a)ta/ktws kai\ ou)deni\ ko/smw| prospi/ptontes 3. 108. 15; a)ta/ktws prosferome/nous 7. 53. 8. Cf. however a)prosdo/khtos prospesw/n 4. 103. 21, and prospi/ptein a)prosdokh/tws 4. 29. 17.
tropai=o/n te sth/santes: te is wanting in Vat.
w(s ou)k e)pech=|san au)toi=s: Cl. would read, unnecessarily, w(s d) ou)k e)pech=|san.

tw=| *labda/lw| : (cf. 98. § 2; 7. 3. § 4) on the extreme north ridge (as e)p' a)/krois toi=s krhmnoi=s means; not on the highest ridge, against which would be 7. 3. § 4), a point at once splendid and dominant (Holm H, 33. 387). Cf. Freeman III, 213.— 25. o(rw=n pro/s: see on 2. 55. 4. It belongs to frou/rion, but might have been as well o(rw=si with krhmnoi=s.
ta\ *me/gara : see on 4. 7.
proi/oien: for the inappropriate prosi/oien of the Mss., conjecture of F. Portus universally accepted.
toi=s xrh/masin: see on 49. 13.—a)poqh/kh: apparently not found elsewhere in Attic writers.

After increasing their cavalry to 650 men they establish at a point called Sykê a circular fort. The Syracusans seek to prevent this, but avoid a general engagement and meet with defeat with a part of their cavalry.— 1. au)toi=s h)=lqon: see on 96. 2.
i(pph=s triako/sioi kte(.: the somewhat variant numbers given by Diod. 13. 7 have no authority against Thuc.
*)aqhnai/wn u(ph=rxon: cf. 94. § 4.
e)/labon: i.e. with consent (not by force).
cunele/ghsan: i.e. from the different divisions.

e)n tw=| *labda/lw|: Vat. reads e)pi\ tw=| *labda/lw| (cf. 97. 24).—pro\s th
 *sukh=n: the view maintained by some, esp. Letronne, that *sukh= is another name for *tu/xh, the suburb to the westward adjoining Achradina (a suburb unknown to Thuc.), is generally rejected by recent authorities, esp. Holm (H, 387). Sykê (i.e. a place set with fig-trees; see Steph. s.v. *sukai/) is “prob. to be located in the middle of the plateau of Epipolae.” Here the Athenians built first a circular fort, which later was the starting-point for the wall of circumvallation extending northward toward Trogilus, southward to the Great Harbor. The words i(/naper (cf. 4. 48. 27, 74. 3) kaqezo/menoi e)tei/xisan to
 ku/klon dia\ ta/xous prove the reference cannot be to the circumvallation, for the aor. e)tei/xisan indicates completion, whereas this was never finished. The art. to
 ku/klon seems to refer, from the point of view of the historian, to the wall as if known to the reader, though just then constructed. Cl. compares a)/neu tw=n i(/ppwn 94. 17, and Holm (H, 387) para\ th
 puli/da 100. 17; e)pi\ th
 xhlh/n 7. 53. 5. Stahl and BoehmeWidmann, following Arnold, explain it as “the usual circle,” o( ku/klos being a part of the circumvallation, but itself the kind of fortified enclosure and central point of the whole line from which the walls to right and left usually commenced. But Steup urges that the passages cited by Cl. and Bm.-W. do not refer, as here, to something before nonexistent, and he would prefer the conjecture first suggested by Stahl, later by Gertz, e)teixi/santo ku/klon (cf. for middle 1. 11. 5; 3. 105. 6; 4. 3. 8). This circular fort is mentioned also 99. 2, 14; 101. 1; 102. 5, 8, 14, and possibly 7. 2. 20. See Freeman III, 662 ff.— 10. e)pecelqo/ntes: sc. oi( *surako/sioi.
mh\ periora=n : sc. to\n ku/klon oi)kodomou/menon. Cf. 7. 6. 3.

h)/dh a)ntiparatassome/nwn a)llh/lois: when they were already being drawn up against each other. The alignment of the Syracusans was not completed, because their troops on marching out had not kept ranks and hence could not readily be brought into line (hence pres. ptc. cuntasso/menon).
e)kw/luon: conative. This attempt to hinder the Athenians was interrupted by (16) kai\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn . . . e)tre/yanto.

liqoforei=n te kai\ a)poski/dnasqai : i.e. for work
on the not yet finished ku/klos. liqoforei=n is found only here.
makrote/ran: comp. of makra/n (3. 13. 23, 55. 5). Cf. Xen. Anab. 7. 8. 20; Plato, Rep. 263 A. Kr. Spr. 43, 3, 9.
fulh\ mi/a: (borrowed by the military from the civil classification) = ta/cis. See on 3. 90. 10.
th=s i(ppomaxi/as: for const. with tropai=on, cf. 2. 82. 8; 4. 12. 8; 7. 41. 12, 54. 1. Kr. Spr. 47, 7, 3.

Hereupon the Athenians commence work on the wall of circumvallation on the north side; but the Syracusans, giving up the combat in open field, begin on the south side a cross-wall starting from the city.— 1. e)tei/xizon...to\ pro\s bore/an tou= ku/klou tei=xos : began to build on the wall north of the circular fort. So generally explained; but Steup, objecting that this wall has not been mentioned before and could not have been assumed by Thuc. to be known to his readers, takes to\ pro\s bore/an tou= ku/klou adv. (see 2. 12).

pare/ballon...ai)ei/ : (impf. with Vat. for pare/balon of the other better Mss.) wood and stones were being laid along the course by the second division of Athenians.—e)pi\ to\n *trwgi/lon kalou/menon: for more exact designation of the direction taken by the wall they were building. Trogilus was a small harbor on the north side of Epipolae. —h(=|per: in which direction.

braxu/taton kte(.: the shortest line for the proposed wall of circumvallation went, to northward, by Trogilus. For like const., cf. 101. 3, on the southern portion of the circumvallation.—e)gi/gneto: Schol. e)/mellen e)/sesqai.
th\n e(te/ran qa/lassan : the sea by Trogilus. —to\ a)potei/xisma: cf. 101. 5 to\ peritei/xisma for the same wall.
tw=n strathgw=n: construed by Cl. and Kr. with *(ermokra/tous (cf. 3. 5); but better taken with ou)x h(/kista. Cf. ma/lista pa/ntwn 1. 139. 5; 4. 27. 10, 86. 12.
e)shghsame/nou : see on 90. 2.— 7. pandhmei/: used almost as adj. with ma/xais, in battle with their whole force. Cf. custado\n ma/xais 7. 81. 25.

u(poteixi/zein de\...to\ tei=xos : it seemed
better to build across the line where the Athenians were likely to build their wall. u(poteixi/zein (lit. to build an underwall, cf. ka/twqen tou= ku/klou tw=n *)aqhnai/wn in 14) found elsewhere only in late authors.

kai/, ei) fqa/seian, a)poklh/|seis gi/gnesqai: and, in case they (i.e. the Syracusans) anticipated them, a shutting out would be effected. The inf. depends upon a)/meinon e)do/kei ei)=nai. a)po/klh|sis also 4. 85. 9; elsewhere only in late authors. See App.

kai\ a(/ma kai/, e)n tou/tw| ei) e)pibohqoi=en : and at the same time also, if they (the Athenians) should attack them thereby (i.e. while at this work). Only e)n tou/tw|, not (with Cl.) kai\ e)n tou/tw|, belongs with ei) e)pibohqoi=en. For emphatic position of e)n tou/tw|, see on 1^{4}. 10. 5. Kr. Spr. 54, 17, 7; Kühn. 606, 6.—me/ros th=s stratia=s: opp. to ma/xais pandhmei/ (6) and pa/ntas a)\n . . . tre/pesqai (13).—a)ntipe/mpein au)tou/s: dependent on a)/meinon e)do/kei ei)=nai.

kai\ fqa/nein a)/n...tre/pesqai : the const. changes and continues as if h(gou=nto or h)/lpizon had gone before: and they expected that they would be beforehand in fencing off the approaches with palisades, and that those ceasing from the work would all turn against themselves. For text, see App.—fqa/nein...prokatalamba/nontes : for the pleonasm and for pres. ptc. see 2. 91. 5; 3. 83. 11.

ta\s e)fo/dous: Schol. ta\ ba/sima le/gei. Grote renders e)fo/dous attacks and is followed by Bl. and Stahl. But stauroi=s prokatalamba/nein e)fo/dous, vallis impetus praevertere is too strange an expression, for which prokatalamba/nein tw=n po/lewn ta\s a)posta/seis 1. 57. 14 is not a parallel.
pa/ntas a)/n: for repetition of a)/n, cf. 10. 14; 11. 6; 18. 10, 33; 37. 13; 64. 9, and see on 4. 18. 17.

a)po\ th=s sfete/ras po/lews a)rca/menoi: i.e. from the wall by which the Syracusans the preceding winter had included the Temenites (the later Neapolis). Cf. 75. § 1. See Holm H, 385. —ka/twqen tou= ku/klou tw=n *)aqhnai/wn: lit. from below the circular fort of the Athenians, i.e. from the point of the city wall nearest to the circular fort (98. 8).
e)gka/rsion tei=xos a)/gontes: (cf. 7. 4. 3, 7. 5) i.e. a cross-wall intended to cut off the proposed circumvallation of the Athenians and prevent its completion. See App.
tou= teme/nous: the sanctuary of Apollo Temenites (see on 75.2). Cf. Steph. Byz. *te/menos to/pos *sikeli/as u(po\ ta\s *)epipola\s pro\s tai=s *surakou/sais. Some editors write tou= *teme/nous.
pu/rgous culi/nous : on top of the wall, to facilitate its defense.
ai( de\ nh=es...e)ph/gonto : explaining why the Syracusans in building their counter-wall had nothing to fear from the Athenian fleet. On the matter, cf. 97. § 1, 2; 101. § 3; 102. § 3.
e)kra/toun tw=n peri\ th\n qa/lassan: (cf. 2. 33. 8; 4. 54. 21) i.e. the Syracusans were still masters of their harbors and of the entrances to them.

The Syracusan counter-wall is completed, but a little later is stormed by the Athenians, who destroy also the pipes which brought water into the city. The Athenians, pushing forward after the fleeing Syracusans into the outer city-wall enclosing Temenites, are driven back; but they destroy the counter-wall of the Syracusans.
a)rkou/ntws e)do/kei e)/xein kte(.: clearly indicating that the Syracusan counter-wall got across the line of the proposed Athenian circumvallation.

o(/sa te e)staurw/qh kai\ w)|kodomh/qh tou= u(poteixi/smatos: te should come after e)staurw/qh. There was probably on both sides of the counter-wall a row of palisades for greater security: the protected space behind these palisades is called stau/rwma, and of the whole extension a definite part might be designated by the words to\ para\ th\n puli/da (16). u(potei/xisma (cf. u(poteixi/zein 99. 8) designates the whole Syracusan counter-wall. This word, as well as u(potei/xisis (23), is found only here.
[au)tou/s]: wanting in Vat. and Par. (B, H), and kwlu/sontes is even more forcible without it.
di/xa gignome/nois: cf. 1. 64. 6.
th\n kaq' au(tou\s peritei/xisin: i.e. the part of the circumvallation now building northward. Cf. 99. § 1.—e)peigo/menoi: trans., as 3. 2. 14; 4. 5. 9; 8. 9. 2.

fulh/n: of a military division, as with the Athenians 98. 16. Holm (H, 418) makes prob. for Syracuse the Doric division into three fulai/. From what follows the division left behind must have been pretty large.—fu/laka: pred. after fem. noun, as 8. 61. 10, 73. 29 fu/lakes with nh=es.
tou= oi)kodomh/matos : as u(potei/xisma (2) of the whole counter-wall.

tou\s o)xetou/s: with modifier potou= u(/datos in the rel. clause. See on 4. 12. 8. Of the course of these water-pipes nothing certain is known, except that they ran from
Epipolae into the city. See Lupus, Die Stadt Syrakus, pp. 259 ff.
u(ponomhdo/n: Schol. dia\ u(pono/mwn kai\ swlh/nwn (pipes; cf. Hdt. 3. 60. 8).

thrh/santes...fula/ssontas : there are three objects with participial modifiers, but the guard consisted really of only two divisions (tou/s te a)/llous and tou\s e)n tw=| staurw/mati), the tinas . . . a)pokexwrhko/tas being only a subdivision of tou\s a)/llous. Of the one division the greater part had betaken themselves at midday to the tents for rest; some had even, manifestly because of lack of discipline, gone off to the city (cf. 69. 4).

sfw=n au)tw=n: i.e. of the Athenian hoplites, whereas the yiloi\ e)klektoi/ for this attack were equipped with hoplite armor (w(plisme/nous). e)klekto/s only here in Thuc.; a)po/lektos only 68. 8; e)pi/lektos not at all.
qei=n dro/mw|: see on 3. 111. 8. For the inf. after prou/tacan, see on 50. 14.
ei) e)pibohqoi=en: i.e. to oppose any troops that might come to the rescue from the city.

pro\s to\ stau/rwma to\ para\ th
 puli/da: to that part of the palisade by the postern gate, i.e. a part thus designated of the Syracusan counter-wall (u(potei/xisma in 14), doubtless a part nearer to the city, as Cl. suggested. Just where this postern gate was is not indicated. Cl. suggests that its purpose might have been to connect the stau/rwma with the protei/xisma peri\ to
 *temeni/thn (19). This seems clearly right. The 300 picked men with those selected from the yiloi/ make in advance a sudden attack on the Syracusan counter-wall; of the main body half advance toward the city to ward off any rescuing force, half go against the part of the stockade or counter-wall near the postern gate in the protei/xisma to\ peri\ to
 *temeni/thn—the object of these last being to cut off the fugitives in case the attack of the 300 was successful. See App.
oi( triako/sioi ai(rou=si to\ stau/rwma: here to\ stau/rwma = to\ u(potei/xisma (14).

oi( fu/lakes: prob. to be understood of tou\s e)n tw=| staurw/mati a)melw=s fula/ssontas (11), for of those that were in the tents at the time of the attack (10) many could hardly have
taken part in the defense of the stau/rwma.
to\ protei/xisma to\ peri\ to\n *temeni/thn : i.e. the lately erected citywall that took in the Temenites (75. § 1). The word occurs elsewhere only in later writers.
oi( diw/kontes: not only the 300, but also the part of the Athenian army that had proceeded pro\s to\ stau/rwma to\ para\ th\n puli/da, for among the fallen some Argives are mentioned (21).

th\n u(potei/xisin...kai\ to\ stau/rwma : the two parts of the Syracusan fortification comprehended in o(/sa te e)staurw/qh kai\ w)|kodomh/qh tou= u(poteixi/smatos (2), hence to\ stau/rwma (the palisade) is used here in a narrower sense than in 11 and 18. On the different parts of the Syracusan fortifications, see Holm II, 389 ff.
diefo/rhsan: see on 91. 35.
par' e(autou/s: i.e. to be used for their own circumvallation.

Hereupon the Athenians build the southern part of their wall of circumvallation from the circular fort to the bluff of Epipolae which is nearest to the Great Harbor. A second counter-wall entirely in the low grounds, which the Syracusans meanwhile had begun to construct, is attacked by the Athenians and taken; in the stubborn conflicts that occur thereby Lamachus is killed.

oi( *)aqhnai=oi kte(.: the Athenians stop work for the present on the north section of the circumvallation (99. § 1, 100. 5), and turning to the south side fortify next the steep bluff above the marsh looking toward the Great Harbor, at the point nearest to this harbor. It seems clear from the context (9) that the wall now built extended southward from the ku/klos to the edge of the bluff, but the statement is general, and it seems hardly necessary to insert a prep. (e)s or pro/s or e)pi/) before to\n krhmno/n. See App.
tou= e(/lous: see on 99. 15.
o(ra=|: see on 75. 2.—kai\ h(=|per...to\ peritei/xisma : cf. 99. 4.— h(=|per: where. For rel. continuation of sent., cf. 4. 18, 89. 23.

kataba=si: i.e. when they had come with their wall down from Epipolae.—to\ peritei/xisma: the same wall, regarded from
a different point of view, is called in 99. 5 to\ a)potei/xisma.
e)n tou/tw|: i.e. while the Athenians were thus occupied.—e)celqo/ntes kai\ au)toi/: coming out themselves also. Cf. 99. 13 (of the Syracusans).

a)rca/menoi a)po\ th=s po/lews: as 99. 14, though here from a point of the citywall nearer to the Great Harbor.— 7. kai\ ta/fron parw/russon: and dug a ditch alongside, as was easy to do in the low ground.
to\ pro\s to\n krhmno/n: the stretch of wall to the edge of the bluff above; see on 1.
au)=qis: i.e. as they had attacked the u(potei/xisma in 100. 9 ff.— 11. e)k th=s *qa/you: cf. 99. § 4; the execution of the order 102. § 3.
peri\ o)/rqron: see on 3. 112. 9.
dia\ tou= e(/lous: to be connected with e)piqe/ntes.
h(=| phlw=des h)=n : see on 66. 9; 1. 63. 10.
diabadi/santes: elsewhere only in later writers.
kai\ u(/steron: these indispensable words found only in Vat.

[e)n au)th=|]: not in Pal.; in Vat. misplaced before kai/. The idiom is contrary to Thuc.'s usage (1. 29. 19, 105. 2, 8, 116. 7; 3. 74. 1). nika=n e)n ma/xh| does not occur in Thuc., who has regularly ou)k e)/lasson e)/xein e)n ma/xh| (cf. 1. 105. 23; 2. 22. 12; 3. 5. 7; 4. 25. 20; 8. 61. 17), and once e)n ma/xh| eu)= pra=cai (75. 16).
e)/feugon: so better with Vat. (for e)/fugon), indicating the beginning of the flight, whose further course is stated below.

para\ to\n potamo/n: i.e. along the left bank of the Anapus, “in order to escape across the bridge to the Olympieum” (Holm H, 36). The
bridge (cf. 66. 11) had been repaired by the Syracusans. They were prevented from crossing by the 300 loga/des, who reached the bridge before them (22 h)pei/gonto pro\s th\n ge/furan).
oi( tw=n *)aqhnai/wn triako/sioi loga/des: for position of the part. gen., see on 62. 19. These 300 loga/des are clearly identical with those mentioned 100. 12.

(h)=san ga\r...e)ntau=qa ): giving the reason for the following o(mo/se xwrou=si (cf. 1. 31. 7, 72. 2; 4. 116. 6); the presence of the cavalry gave them courage to halt and attack the Athenians, e)sba/llousin referring esp. to the coöperation of the cavalry.
to\ decio\n ke/ras: which the 300 loga/des, in pursuing the enemy's left wing, had got ahead of.

cunefobh/qh: (pass.) the first division (fulh/ for fulakh/ correctly restored by Duker, cf. 98. 16) of the Athenian right wing was swept into the flight along with the 300 (tre/pousin au)tou/s). Cf. 3. 108. 5. The compound found elsewhere only in late writers.

tou= e(autw=n: the pl. in view of the Athenians commanded by Lamachus; cf. 7. 3. 12, 53. 7.—kai\...paralabw/n : note the correlation with prepositional phrase, meta\ . . . te; cf. 1. 26. 19. Kr. Spr. 59, 2, 3.

e)pidiaba\s ta/fron tina/: advancing across a ditch (not that of the Syracusan fortification, but prob. one for draining the marsh).—monwqei\s met' o)li/gwn tw=n cundiaba/ntwn: cf. Hdt. 6. 15. 9 met) o)li/gwn cumma/xwn memounwme/noi.
a)poqnh/|skei : acc. to an unlikely statement of Plutarch's (Nic. 18) in single combat with a certain Callicrates, who had challenged him to single combat and who likewise fell.

fqa/nousin a)narpa/santes kai\ diabiba/santes: this reading of two Mss. (B, H), for fqa/nousin a(rpa/santes of the rest of the Mss., Cl. adopts (also Bochme-Widmann), on account of the great authority of Vat. in the later books of Thuc. The only objection that could be made to this form of expression is diabiba/santes applied to corpses, for which diakomi/santes
was to be expected. Stahl defends the vulgate as breviloquentia; and Steup considers the reading of Vat. a not altogether successful explanation of a(rpa/santes, which Thuc. might have used to express at once a hasty taking up (a)nairei=sqai, 1. 54. 5 and freq.) and carrying off.

au)toi\ de/: though referring to the subj. oi( *surako/sioi, expressed because in the first clause attention has been centered on the bodies of the fallen.—tou= a)/llou strateu/matos: from 102. 4 it is clear that a part of the Athenians had been arrayed against the Syracusan right wing that fled to the city.

Meanwhile the Syracusans with part of their army attack the Athenian circular fort on Epipolae, in which Nicias had been left sick on this day; they take the outworks, but are obliged to withdraw before the fire which Nicias has kindled from the wood heaped up before the main fort. As the Athenian fleet at this very time runs into the Great Harbor, the Syracusans find themselves put upon the defensive.— 2. oi( pro\s th\n po/lin...katafugo/ntes : i.e. the right wing of the Syracusans, who (to\ prw=ton) after the capture of their stockade had retreated within the city-walls (101. 19).—au)tw=n: part. gen. with oi( katafugo/ntes. See on 62. 19.
tau=ta gigno/mena: i.e. the successes of the Syracusans described in 101. 26 ff.
a)nteta/canto pro\s tou\s ...*)aqhnai/ous : i.e. against a part of the left wing of the Athenians. See on 101. 33.
e)pi\ to\n ku/klon: see on 98.7.
to\...protei/xisma : an outwork of the ku/klos (10 plethra, 1000 feet in extent).
diekw/lusen: sc. e(lei=n.
di) a)sqe/neian : Nicias was suffering from nephritis 7. 15. 9.

ta\s ga\r mhxana\s kte(.: stating, after the parenthesis, how it was prevented (diekw/lusen). At this middle point of the Athenian siege was collected all the apparatus intended therefor (e.g. ladders, scaffolding), as well as the stakes and other wood for the circumvallation (e.g. the stauroi/ taken from the Syracusan u(potei/xisma, 100. 24).

h)=n katabeblhme/na: periphrasis of ptc. with ei)=nai. See App. on 1. 1. 5.—tou\s u(phre/tas: i.e. the attendants of the hoplites (see on 3. 17. 10).
The guard of soldiers was evidently slight.

a)duna/tous e)some/nous: Steup adopted Cobet's conjecture a)du/natos e)so/menos, approved by v. H.—e)rhmi/a| a)ndrw=n: through lack of (armed) men. Cf. to\n *peiraia= e)rh=mon o)/nta new=n 8. 96. 12; e)n e)rhmi/a| fi/lwn Xen. Mem. 2. 2. 14.
kai\ cune/bh ou(/tws: sc. perigene/sqai. Cf. 3. 3. 15 h)\n cumbh=| h( pei=ra.
kai\ ga/r : giving the two grounds besides the fire for the retreat of the Syracusans.

tw=n *)aqhnai/wn a)podiwca/ntwn tou\s e)kei=: of the main body of the Athenians, before which the Syracusan left wing had given way (101. 34), a part had, after the pursuit ended (a)podiwca/ntwn), returned from below to bring aid to the threatened fortification. Cl. and others understood the reference here to be to the Athenians mentioned in l. 4. But it is clear from 101. § 6 that the Athenians mentioned above (4) were only a small part of the army; besides, the omission of further mention of the main body would be strange.
tou\s e)kei=: sc. tou\s ka/tw, i.e. the Syracusan left wing.— 16. w(/sper ei)/rhto: i.e. as orders had been given 101. 11. See on 30. 4.
oi( a)/nwqen: i.e. the Syracusans who had attacked the ku/klos.
kata\ ta/xos a)ph=|san : resumes, after the details given in kai\ ga\r . . . lime/na, the a)pexw/roun pa/lin above (13).

nomi/santes mh\ a)\n e)/ti...i(kanoi\ gene/sqai : the idea of fear implied in nomi/zein induces the particle of subjective negation (mh/ for the more usual ou)). For similar const. of mh/ after nomi/zein, cf. 4. 18. 13. GMT. 685; Kr. Spr. 67, 7, 4.
a)po\ th=s parou/shs sfi/si duna/mews: with the force at their disposal. For force of a)po/, see on 19. 5; 1. 91. 28.

The Athenians now push forward unopposed their circumvallation, in the form of a double wall, from Epipolae to the Great Harbor. They receive also supplies from Italy, as well as new Sicel allies, and even ships sent to their aid from Etruria. The Syracusans on the other hand, as no help comes to them from Peloponnesus, begin negotiations with Nicias, and choose three new generals in place of
the former ones, to whose fault they ascribe their ill success.

tou\s meta\ *lama/xou kai\ au)to/n: cf. 101. 32. The order is unusual for *la/maxon kai\ tou\s met' au)tou=. Kr. would bracket kai\ au)to/n and Hude adopts the corrected reading of one Ms. (F) kai\ au)toi/.

kai\ tou= krhmnw/dous: and indeed from the cliff, defining more exactly tw=n *)epipolw=n. This work continued south or southeast the wall mentioned 101. § 1.— 6. a)petei/xizon: still the impf., because, with all their energy in building, the goal—the water's edge of the Great Harbor—was not reached; cf. 7. 2. § 4.

ta\ d) e)pith/deia...penthko/ntoroi trei=s : the three points most important for the Athenians: abundant opportunity for provisioning, increase of their allies in Sicily, and reënforcements from a distance; after that follows more naturally kai\ pa/nta (as Vat. reads) than the vulgate kai\ ta)=lla prouxw/rei, since with the favorable position taken up for the land army as well as for the fleet not much more was to be desired: and so (kai/) all went forward according to their hopes. Thereto is added in confirmation (kai\ ga/r) the report of the mood prevailing in Syracuse.—e)k th=s *)itali/as pantaxo/qen: cf. Plato, Phaedo 67 C pantaxo/qen e)k tou= sw/matos.
oi(\ pro/teron periewrw=nto : for the expression, cf. 93. 3; on the matter, cf. 88. § 3 ff.—e)k th=s *turshni/as: cf. 88. § 6.

nh=es penthko/ntoroi: cf. penthko/ntoroi, without nh=es, 43. 5; 1. 14. 4, 12. Cf. i(ppagwgoi\ nh=es 2. 56. 5; 4. 42. 4, and i(ppagwgw=| alone 43. 16.— 11. e)s e)lpi/das: according to their hopes. Cf. the imitation of Dexippus, w(s ou)de\n prouxw/rei e)s e)lpi/das (in L. Dindorf's Hist. Gr. Min. I, p. 190; cf. v. H. Mnem. N.S. VIII, 166). e)s as in e)s du/namin 4. 118. 6; 8. 27. 6. Cl. adopted from Vat. and Lond. e)s e)lpi/da, and, comparing e)s kairo/n, e)s kalo/n, e)s ke/rdos (Soph. Phil. 111), rendered: all went so well as to justify the best hope.

w)feli/a ou)demi/a: see on 73. 9.
—tou\s de\ lo/gous...kai\ pro\s to\n *niki/an : and discussions looking to an agreement were begun among themselves and with Nicias.—e)nsfi/sin au)toi=s: = e)n a)llh/lois, as 5. 69. 17; 8. 76. 8.
cumbatikou/s: which occurs also 8. 71. 7, 91. 3 (= cumbathri/ous 5. 76. 4, 17), is pred.—ou(=tos ga\r dh/: Steup would adopt, with v. H., from Vat. h)/dh.
ku/rwsis me\n ou)demi/a e)gi/gneto: no conclusion was reached. ku/rwsis, a rare word, is found only here in Thuc.; the verb kurou=n, 4. 125. 5; 8. 69. 1.

oi(=a de\ ei)ko/s : sc. h(=n gi/gnesqai. Cf. 2. 54. 3.— 17. ma=llon h)\ pri\n poliorkoume/nwn: more than before pressed by the sicge. Hude follows Laur. in omitting pri/n. But nothing further happened to the Syracusans than to be besieged; they were, however, besieged now in quite other style than before, when the circumvallation of the Athenians was only just begun.
kai\ ga/r: referring esp. to plei/w e)/ti kata\ th\n po/lin: increasing suspicion led to much talk. For kai\ ga\r kai/, see on 61. 6.

u(po\ tw=n paro/ntwn kakw=n: for u(po/, by reason of, cf. 1. 49. 8; 4. 34. 17, 80. 14.—kai\ tou\s strathgou/s te: Cl. understood te and, kai/ also (see on 44. 17), holding that only thus is tou\s strathgou/s properly emphasized, and that kai\ a)/llous a)nqei/lonto is an independent addition; but Stahl and Steup are clearly right in explaining te as correlated with kai/ before a)/llous (21). As to these generals, cf. 73. § 1, 96. 14.
e)f' w(=n: under whose lead.
th=| e)kei/nwn: belonging to dustuxi/a|, as well as to prodosi/a|. For the order, see 1. 1. 6.

*(hraklei/dhn: not the son of Lysimachus (73. 3), but apparently the son of Aristogenes (Xen. Hell. 1. 2. 8). Thuc.'s failure to distinguish this Heraclides from the one mentioned in 73. 3, who was deposed, is prob. due to lack of final revision on the part of the author. —*eu)kle/a: Vat. reads *eu)rukle/a. Xen. (Hell. 1. 2. 8) mentions Eucles, along with Heraclides, as Syracusan general.

Meanwhile Gylippus, with two Laconian and two Corinthian ships, had reached Tarentum. His attempt to sail further failed in consequence of stormy weather. Nicias paid no attention to the approach of so small a fleet.

*gu/lippos: cf. 93. § 2 f.—ai( a)po\
th=s *kori/nqou nh=es : 93. § 3.
peri\ *leuka/da : near the city Leucas, which also at 2. 80. § 2 appears as a collecting point for a fleet.

e)foi/twn: mostly personal; here of a)ggeli/ai, as 8. 18. 5 of xrh/mata. —deinai\ kai\...e)yeusme/nai : aspred. more forcible.—h)/dh pantelw=s: as was not the case, acc. to 7. 2. § 4.— 6. th\n de\ *)itali/an...peripoih=sai : since at Sparta information was given through Alcibiades of the plans of the Athenians; cf. 90. §§ 2, 3.
*puqh/n: cf. 7. 1. 1, 70. 8; Diodorus (13. 7. 2) writes incorrectly *pu/qhs.
duoi=n de\ *korinqi/ain : apparently the two Corinthian ships which Gylippus, acc. to 93. § 3, had first ordered to Asine.
to\n *)io/nion: see on 30. 5.—e)s *ta/ranta: apparently directly across the open sea.
prosplhrw/santes: for the pleonasm (pros-) after pro\s tai=s sfete/rais, cf. prosplhrw/santes e)/ti 7. 34. 5; a)/llas prosplhrw/santes 8. 10. 13.

e)s th\n *qouri/an: see on 61. 28.— presbeusa/menos: sending ambassadors, hardly “going as ambassador,” assome explain. If Gylippus had gone as ambassador to Thurii, there could hardly have been, after speaking of the embassy, a mere mention of the departure from Tarentum (with a)/ras must certainly be supplied e)k tou= *ta/rantos).

kai\ th
 tou= patro\s a)nanewsa/menos politei/an: this reading of Vat. and Par. (followed also by Valla) gives welcome light on this matter known in general only from Plut. Pericl. 22. Cleandridas, father of Gylippus (93. § 2), had after his banishment from Sparta, 444 B.C., joined the colony sent at this time from Athens to Thurii; the right of citizenship obtained by him Gylippus now claims, and bases thereon his unsuccessful demands upon his ostensible mother-city. So Cl. reads with Bk., Kr., Bm., Stahl, Müller, and the Oxford text; but Steup, with Hude, Marchant, and Spratt, follows the rest of the Mss., kata\ th
 tou= patro/s pote politei/an, justifying the form of expression as Thucydidean by comparing 75. 11 punqano/menoi tou\s *)aqhnai/ous e)s th

*kama/rinan kata\ th
 e)pi\ *la/xhtos genome/nhn cummaxi/an presbeu/esqai, ei)/ pws prosaga/gointo au)tou/s. Headds that th
 politei/an a)nanewsa/menos means not claiming, but actually renewing, citizenship, and with the reading of Vat. the sent. must continue not copulative (kai\ ou) duna/menos), but adversative; further that this is not in accord with § 3 o( de\ *niki/as . . . o(/per kai\ oi( *qou/rioi e)/paqon.
prosagage/sqai : to bring over, as 2. 30. 7; 3. 91. 7; 4. 86. 3; 7. 7. 8.—pare/plei th\n *)itali/an: see on 47. 7. For *)itali/a as used in Thuc., see on 2. 19.

[kata\ to\n *terinai=on ko/lpon]: the gulf of Terina is on the west coast of Bruttium (*)itali/a in Thuc.), which Gylippus could reach only by sailing round through the strait. As that is out of the question, most editors, following Goeller, rightly regard the words as a gloss to tau/th|. But Steup objects that such a gloss is improbable, since this gulf is rarely mentioned by the ancients (elsewhere only in Pliny, N.H. 3. 5. 10, 10. 15); further that bracketing the words makes unintelligible the following e)kpnei= (cf. 2. 84. 8 ei) e)kpneu/seien e)k tou= ko/lpou to\ pneu=ma), unless, with Badham and v. H., that be changed to pnei=. So Steup adopts Pp.'s conjecture *taranti=non, as quite in accord with the fact that Gylippus, after the storm, returned to Tarentum, whence he had started.

tau/th|: in that quarter, for one sailing from Tarentum along the west coast of the gulf.—me/gas: violently, pred., as 1. 23. 4.—kata\ bore/an e(sthkw/s: standing in the north, i.e. blowing steadily from the north. Cf. h)\n ai)ei\ kata\ pru/mnan i(sth=tai to\ pneu=ma 2. 97. 4; oi( e)th/sioi a)/nemoi th=| w(/ra| e)kei/nh| kata\ no/ton ma/lista a)/nemon i(/stantai Arr. Anab. 6. 21. 1.

pa/lin xeimasqei\s e)s ta\ ma/lista: and driven by a most violent storm back, i.e. in the opposite direction. So Cl. and Stahl explain; but Steup says, before all the return to Tarentum is to be expressed, and to connect pa/lin with tw=| *ta/ranti prosmi/sgei has the further advantage that with a)pofe/resqai e)s to\ pe/lagos, which was the effect of a steadily blowing wind acc. to Thuc., we do not have to think also of a sudden storm. For e)s ta\ ma/lista, cf. patriko\s e)s ta\ ma/lista ce/nos w)/n 8. 6. 17, and e)s ta\ makro/tata 31. 24.
e)po/nhsan : of ships, as 7. 38. 11. Vat. has o(/sai ma/lista e)po/nhsan.
e)peskeu/azen : set to repairing (impf.); the completion (aor.) is mentioned 7. 1. 1.
prosple/onta: so Vat.; the rest of the Mss. wrongly ple/onta.

to\ plh=qos : of the small number, as 4. 10. 22. and likewise with u(perora=n 5. 6. 15.—
21. lh|stikw/teron: rather in a piratical fashion. See on 1. 10. 32. Kühn. 540, N. 7.—e)/doce: arbitratus est; see on 4. 62. 4.—pareskeuasme/nous: referring to the whole expedition of the four ships and their crews. Cf. 1. 110. 11, 12. Hude's pareskeuasme/nos would be worthy of consideration if Nicias were not again subject in the last clause.— 22. ou)demi/an fulakh/n pw e)poiei=to: has reference to the later dispatch of four Attic ships (7. 1. § 2). Vat. has ou)demi/an pws fulakh\n e)poiou=nto. But pws is out of place here, and that Nicias alone can be meant is clear from the foregoing and from 7. 1. § 2.

About the same time the Lacedaemonians again invade Argos; the Athenians, who come with 30 ships to the aid of the Argives, for the first time since the conclusion of the peace make an unmistakable attack upon Laconian territory.
*lakedaimo/nioi e)s to\ *)/argos e)se/balon kte(.: repetition of the unsuccessful campaign of 95. § 1.
e)s to\ *)/argos: into the territory of Argos. Cf. e)k tou= *)/argous 16; e)c *)/argous 5. 63. 1, 65. 7; e)n *)/argei 4. 133. 5; e)s *)epi/dauron 12. See on 2. 18. 2; 3. 91. 11; 4. 118. 25.
th=s gh=s th\n pollh/n: for assimilation of the articular adj. to the gender of the part. gen., see on 1. 3. 12; 7. 3. 15. G. 1090; H. 730 e; Kr. Spr. 47, 28, 9; Kühn. 405, 5 c.

ai(/per ...e)/lusan : on this breach of the peace on the part of the Athenians, cf. 7. 18. § 2 f., and see App. on 5. 25. 11. Besides, the Athenians, acc. to 5. 56. § 3, in the winter of 419-418 had already had inscribed at the bottom of the Laconian pillar of peace: o(/ti ou)k e)ne/meinan oi( *lakedaimo/nioi toi=s o(/rkois.

ta\s pro\s tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous : so Vat.; all the rest of the Mss. omit ta/s, most tou/s. But ta/s is necessary, and tou/s doubtless correct, as on the third and fourth (13, 16) mention of the Lacedaemonians the art. is added.—au)toi=s: dat. in free relation, as 1. 6.8.—e)/lusan: broke. See on 1^{4}. 35. 1.

lh|stei/ais e)k *pu/lou: as related 5. 115. § 2. Cf. also 5. 56. § 3.—kai\...a)pobai/nontes : second modifier after the dat. lh|stei/ais e)k *pu/lou. Cf. 1. 80. 4; 4. 36. 18. Such landings, not mentioned by Thuc., had prob. occurred in the Epidaurian war (5. 53 ff.).

meta/ te *)argei/wn kai\ *mantine/wn cunepole/moun:
(only Vat. has cun-) indicating doubtless both the alliance and the participation in the hostilities; see on 2. 67. 33.

o(/son sxo/ntas mo/non...a)pelqei=n : (dependent on keleuo/ntwn) only so much as to land with arms in Laconian territory, devastate with them ever so small a part, and then go away. For the restrictive force of o(/son mo/non with ptc., cf. o(/sa mh/ with ptc., 1. 111. 5; 4. 16. 12. Cf. Ar. Vesp. 1288; Lys. 732. The chief stress is on the ptc.; see on 82. 11; 1. 82. 10.—sxo/ntas e)s: see on 7. 1. 14. cu\n o(/plois: see on 5. 50. 9. This was an unmistakable breach of the stipulation of the treaty: o(/pla de\ mh\ e)ce/stw e)pife/rein e)pi\ phmonh=| kte(. (5. 18. § 4).

*puqodw/rou...a)rxo/ntwn : of the generals Pythodorus, Cl. thinks, was prob. the one mentioned 3. 115. 6; 4. 2. 7, 65. 11; but see Busolt, Gr. Gesch. III, p. 1351. Laespodias is mentioned again 8. 86. 44. For him, see J. Kirchner, Prosopographia Attica II, 1, and Busolt, ibid. 1350 f. Of Demaratus nothing further is known.— 12. e)s *)epi/dauron th\n *limhra/n: see on 4. 56. 10.

*prasia/s: on the same east coast of Laconia; cf. 2. 56. 16.—a)/lla a)/tta: with Vat. (cf. a)/lla a)/tta xwri/a 1. 113. 3; 2. 100. 12) for o(/sa a)/lla of the rest of the Mss., which most recent editors prefer. Cf. 7. 18. 20.—th=s gh=s: part. gen. with dh|ou=n, as with te/mnein below (17) and freq. See on 1. 30. 8. G. 1097, 1; H. 736; Kühn. 416, N. 2. —kai\ toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois...e)poi/hsan : and they brought it about that the Lacedaemonians with so much better pretext now had cause to defend themselves against the Athenians. Decelea is hinted at. eu)profa/siston found elsewhere only in late writers. tou= a)mu/nesqai depends on th\n ai)ti/an. e)s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous for e)s sfa=s, as if expressing a complaint of the Lacedaemonians. Stahl brackets the words, but comparison with 1. 55. 13; 66. 2, 5 makes likely the designation of the state against which there is ai)ti/a tou= a)mu/nesqai.
e)k tou= *)/argous: (Vat. e)c *)/argous) would have been expected after *lakedaimoni/wn, for the Athenian fleet was last mentioned on the Laconian coast (12).
e)s th\n *fleiasi/an: as 5. 83. 11, 115. 2.
